author: PRNEWS
title: Ella Bleu Travolta: A look at her diet and why she is vegan
text:
Ella Bleu Travolta: A look at her diet and why she is vegan

Ella Bleu. Credit / Getty Images


Ella Bleu Travolta, the daughter of legendary actors John Travolta and the late Kelly Preston, has been making waves not only in Hollywood but also in the wellness world, particularly for her commitment to a vegan lifestyle. 


Her decision wasn‚Äôt just about health, but something much bigger. 

Ella Bleu was born on April 3, 2000,
Ella Bleu Travolta is the daughter of iconic actors¬†John Travolta¬†and the late Kelly Preston. She was born on April 3, 2000, in the Travolta home in California. 
Ella‚Äôs birth was no ordinary moment ‚Äì it was something truly special. Her mother, Kelly Preston, shared the unforgettable moment when she first laid eyes on her daughter. 

‚ÄúJohn put his hands under her arms while she was still halfway out, and I put my hand on his, and we pulled her out together and laid her on my chest,‚Äù¬†Kelly¬†told¬†Redbook¬†just months after giving birth. 
She is a big sister
Ella is a proud big sister. She was John Travolta and Kelly Preston‚Äôs second child, following the birth of their son¬†Jett¬†in April 1992. Tragically, Jett passed away at the age of 16 after hitting his head on a bathtub following a seizure at the family‚Äôs vacation home. 
Getty Images
Two years after Jett‚Äôs heartbreaking death, Ella became a sister again when her brother Benjamin was born on November 23, 2011. 
According to her mother Kelly, Ella was absolutely overjoyed when she heard the news. The actress shared Ella‚Äôs reaction to becoming a big sister for the first time: 


‚ÄùYou would have thought Ella was having Benjamin herself because of her enthusiasm about his arrival ‚Äî she was elated, to say the least. When she first saw him, she fell in love,‚Äù Kelly said. 
Following in her parents‚Äô footsteps
Today, Ella shares a close bond with her younger brother and every year, she posts heartfelt messages on social media to celebrate Benjamin‚Äôs birthday. 

Ella Bleu loved the stage already as a child. In the family house in Maine, they set up a small stage area with a red curtain, and there, Ella and her friends performed. They did everything from performing The Incredible Hulk to different Christmas shows. One year, they even performed as different ‚ÄòHousewives of Maine.‚Äô 
‚ÄúSince I was very little, I‚Äôve loved performing, singing, dancing and putting on shows at home for my family and friends,‚Äù Ella Bleu told¬†People. 
When she was just 9 years old, she made her film debut in¬†Old Dogs, starring alongside her parents, as well as the late legendary actor and comedian¬†Robin Williams. 
‚ÄùIt was awesome to act with my parents in my first movie, it made it a lot easier,‚Äù Ella Bleu told¬†Celebrity Pulse. 
Starring in¬†Old Dogs¬†wasn‚Äôt the last time she‚Äôd be working alongside her father John Travolta. 10 years later, she stared in the drama¬†The Poison Rose. Ten years after her first role, Ella once again acted beside her dad in the drama¬†The Poison Rose.¬†In the picture above, Ella and dad John can be seen on the set in the past. 
As of 2024, Ella has built an impressive resume, with notable experience in modeling, acting, and music. 


Ella‚Äôs journey to veganism
In 2022, Ella BleuTravolta made the decision to adopt a vegan lifestyle and plant-based diet. Her motivation to become vegan was rooted in both ethical reasons and a desire for a healthier lifestyle. 
Inspired by one of her closest friends, Ella decided to try a vegan diet for two weeks. The results were so positive that she continued with it. During this time, she watched several documentaries, gaining a deeper understanding of the environmental benefits of a plant-based lifestyle. It was eye-opening for her to realize how her choices were directly contributing to the well-being of the Earth. 
‚ÄùIt has really been a game-changer in how I feel ‚Äî overall I have more energy, and I feel great,‚Äù she told¬†Greenmatters.com. 
When Ella first went plant-based, she did extensive research on how it could boost her health. But what truly stood out was the environmental impact. Watching documentaries, she learned that reducing animal products can lower our carbon footprint, save water, and help clean the air‚Äîmaking a real difference for the planet. 
Ella Bleu‚Äôs diet
Ella‚Äôs favorite¬†breakfast¬†often includes something simple yet satisfying, like toast with crunchy peanut butter, a drizzle of agave, and a sprinkle of pumpkin spice seasoning. It‚Äôs a quick, protein-packed option that keeps her energized throughout the morning, offering a delicious balance of sweetness and spice. 
Is John Travolta vegan?
Although Ella has embraced a plant-based diet, it seems her father, John, hasn‚Äôt jumped on board‚Äîyet. 
‚ÄúFor me, I never try to force or convince someone to go plant-based. I believe (as for any lifestyle choice) it should always be your decision. But I‚Äôm definitely always sharing with others the benefits I‚Äôve experienced while being plant-based and also encourage friends and family to try the food, so they can see for themselves ‚Äî oftentimes they like the vegan versions just as much or more than the regular versions,‚Äù Ella says. 
Ella loves baking
In her spare time, Ella loves spending time in the kitchen experimenting with new recipes. In July 2023, she even launched her own food-inspired Instagram account,¬†ellableubakes. 


On this account, she shares her favorite recipes and explores cafes and restaurants around the world that specialize in plant-based dishes and baked goods. 
Ella has put her baking skills to the test by recreating the coconut bundt cake Tom Cruise is famous for gifting his celebrity friends during the holidays. The result? She wowed both her dad and brother, Benjamin. 



‚ÄúIt‚Äôs delicious, oh my goodness,‚Äù John Travolta said in an Instagram video. Her brother, Benjamin, couldn‚Äôt agree more, showing off his nearly empty plate as he scraped up the last bits. 
Ella‚Äôs go-to recipe is a ‚Äùdelicious‚Äù¬†vegan banana bread. 
‚ÄúThat‚Äôs sort of my specialty,‚Äù she told People during a photoshoot and added that also loves drinking a morning matcha with dairy-free milk. 
When Ella goes out to eat, one of her favorite spots is PLANTA, an innovative plant-based restaurant that draws inspiration from cuisines around the world. 
Ella Bleu weight loss
Those who have followed Ella over the years may have noticed how much she has changed in appearance. Unfortunately, some websites and tabloids were unkind to her when she was younger, often commenting on her looks and even describing her as ‚Äúchubby.‚Äù 
The world certainly doesn‚Äôt need more focus on young women‚Äôs appearances, but when you grow up in Hollywood and are the daughter of one of the world‚Äôs biggest actors, it‚Äôs almost inevitable ‚Äî no matter how tragic that reality may be. 


Photos of a young Ella, around 12 or 13 years old, unfortunately sparked cruel comments online. Some speculated she was pregnant, while others described her as ‚Äùa little big‚Äù, according to¬†Amomama. 
Despite this scrutiny, Ella has undergone a remarkable transformation and now seems to be thriving. Thanks to her new plant-based diet and lifestyle, she radiates confidence and good health, proving that true beauty shines from the inside out. 
Ray Tamarra/WireImage
Being the child of an incredible famous and successful actor can surely be very tough. But Ella has always felt that she had the support of her parents. Sadly, Ella was just 20 years old when she faced the heartbreaking loss of her mother, who passed away in July 2020 after a two-year battle with breast cancer. 
Ella and John shares a strong bond
Fortunately, Ella has found strong support in her father, who also serves as her mentor in many ways. 
The two share a close bond, often traveling and spending time together. In 2024, they visited Europe and attended the Olympic Games in Paris, including the tennis final between Novak Djokovic and rising star Carlos Alcaraz. 
Earlier this year, the father-daughter duo was spotted together celebrating 30 years of¬†Pulp Fiction¬†at the TCM Classic Film Festival in Los Angeles. 



Ella Bleu Travolta is proving that a plant-based lifestyle is more than just a diet‚Äîit‚Äôs a way of living with purpose. 
From her kitchen experiments to sharing the benefits of going vegan, she‚Äôs inspiring others to make choices that are kinder to their health, the planet, and even their taste buds. 


As Ella continues to thrive and share her journey, she‚Äôs a shining example of how small changes can create a big impact. Would you try a plant-based dish inspired by Ella? Share your thoughts!

author: Editorial Team
title: 10 Vegan Food Hacks That Will ‚ÄòChange Your Life‚Äô
text:
Derek Simnett, a certified nutritional practitioner from Canada, has been a key figure in the plant-based community since launching his YouTube channel, Simnett Nutrition, in 2015. With over 750,000 subscribers, he shares insights on plant-based nutrition, fitness, and holistic health.  



Transitioning to a plant-based diet can feel overwhelming for some, especially when it comes to meal prep, nutrition, and finding the right ingredients. But following a healthy and nutritious vegan diet is far easier than many people think. If you‚Äôd like some help along the way, Simnett regularly shares simple, effective food hacks to make plant-based eating easier. One of his videos, titled ‚Äú10 Vegan Food Hacks That Will Change Your Life!‚Äù, showcases a number of hacks that will upgrade your cooking and reduce food waste. Whether you‚Äôre new to veganism or looking for ways to simplify your routine, these ten tips can help improve your cooking, reduce waste, and boost nutrition. 



Read more: ‚ÄòThe One Dish I‚Äôd Cook to Impress a Vegan Skeptic‚Äô 



1. Keep greens fresh longer



Simnett Nutrition/YouTube Simnett recommends keeping herbs and green onions in water


Fresh herbs like cilantro and parsley tend to wilt quickly in the fridge. Simnett recommends washing them, trimming the ends, and placing them in a glass or jar of water‚Äîjust like fresh flowers. This method helps them stay vibrant and fresh for longer. He also applies the same technique to green onions, noting that they will continue to grow when stored in water. Changing the water regularly further extends their shelf life. 



2. Select the best avocados









Picking a ripe avocado can be hit or miss. Simnett advises looking for avocados that still have the small stem (or ‚Äúbutton‚Äù) attached, as they are less likely to be bruised or brown inside. He also suggests buying avocados when they‚Äôre firm and letting them ripen at home to avoid damage from excessive handling at the store. If too many ripen at once, placing them in the fridge will slow the process. 



3. Manage banana ripeness



To prevent bananas from over-ripening, Simnett recommends storing them in the fridge. While the peel may darken, the fruit inside remains fresh. For long-term storage, peeling and freezing ripe bananas is a great option, especially for smoothies or baking. 



4. Simplify mixing nut and seed butters



Natural nut butters often separate, with oil rising to the top, making them hard to stir. Simnett‚Äôs solution is simple: store the jar upside down for a few days before opening. This allows the oil to distribute evenly. When ready to use, shaking the jar helps create a smooth consistency without messy spills. 



5. Add kala namak for an ‚Äòeggy‚Äô flavor



Kala Namak, or black salt, adds an egg-like flavor to vegan dishes due to its sulfur content. Simnett uses it in tofu scrambles and vegan ‚Äúegg‚Äù salads to enhance their taste. A small amount can make a significant difference in replicating the flavor of eggs. 



6. Create a cheesy nut and seed crumble



Simnett Nutrition/YouTube If you have a blender, this cheesy nutty topping is a great staple to keep in the fridge


For a nutritious, flavorful topping, Simnett blends nuts and seeds ‚Äì such as Brazil nuts, almonds, sunflower seeds, and cashews ‚Äì with nutritional yeast, garlic powder, onion powder, smoked paprika, salt, and pepper. A touch of apple cider vinegar helps the mixture clump together, creating a crumble perfect for sprinkling over salads, pastas, and stir-fries. 



Read more: ‚ÄòWhat I Eat In A Week: Realistic Vegan Meals‚Äô 



7. Embrace frozen fruits and vegetables



Many people assume frozen produce is inferior to fresh, but Simnett explains that fruits and vegetables are picked at peak ripeness before being flash-frozen, preserving their nutrients. He encourages using frozen produce, as it‚Äôs convenient, budget-friendly, and reduces food waste. Frozen fruits work well in smoothies, while frozen vegetables can be quickly added to soups or stir-fries. 



8. Grind flax and chia seeds for better absorption



Flax seeds are rich in omega-3s, but the body absorbs them better when they‚Äôre ground. Simnett recommends using a coffee grinder or high-speed blender to break them down before consuming them. This ensures the full nutritional benefits of these seeds are available. 



9. Cook mixed grains and legumes together



Simnett suggests mixing grains like white rice, quinoa, and red lentils when cooking to improve texture, boost nutrition, and diversify the amino acid profile of meals. He advises rinsing them thoroughly before cooking to remove bitterness and enhance digestion. Choosing grains with similar cooking times ensures they cook evenly. 



10. Quickly identify non-vegan ingredients



Instead of scanning entire ingredient lists, Simnett recommends looking for the ‚Äúcontains‚Äù statement at the bottom of food labels. This section highlights common allergens like milk and eggs, making it easier to identify non-vegan products at a glance. He also clarifies that ‚Äúmay contain‚Äù warnings are related to cross-contamination risks and do not necessarily mean the product contains animal-derived ingredients. 



Follow Derek Simnett on YouTube and Instagram. 



Read more: ‚ÄòWhy Vegans Have Smaller Brains‚Äô: Debunked 
This article was written by Editorial Team on the PBN Website.

author: noreply@blogger.com (A Bountiful Love)
title: Ultimate Guide to Egg Substitutes
text:
I am not a stranger when it comes to substituting eggs in baking. A few years ago, my family dived into veganism. We did it for about a year and switched back to a different lifestyle or diet that fit the season of life we were currently in. Honestly, knowing a substitute for any ingredient is also important. Whether you are on a tight budget or just do not have the time to do a grocery run, ingredient substitution is a good skill to learn. NEXT READ: 8 Clean Eating Seasonings (FREE PRINTABLE) Eggs are a staple ingredient in many recipes, but whether you‚Äôre vegan, allergic, or simply out of eggs, there are plenty of great alternatives. The right egg substitute depends on the recipe and the role eggs play‚Äîbinding, leavening, or adding moisture. Here‚Äôs a breakdown of the best egg replacements for different cooking and baking needs.     ¬†Best Egg Substitutes for Baking¬† ¬†For Binding (Holding Ingredients Together)¬† ¬†If eggs help bind ingredients, try: ¬†‚Ä¢ Flaxseed or Chia Seed Egg ‚Äì Mix 1 tbsp ground flaxseed or chia seeds with 3 tbsp water and let sit for 5 minutes. Works well in cookies, muffins, and pancakes.¬† ¬†‚Ä¢ Mashed Banana ‚Äì Use ¬º cup mashed banana per egg. Adds natural sweetness but may alter the flavor. Great for cakes and quick breads. ¬†‚Ä¢ Applesauce ‚Äì Substitute ¬º cup unsweetened applesauce per egg. Helps bind and adds moisture, ideal for brownies and muffins ¬†‚Ä¢ Silken Tofu ‚Äì Blend ¬º cup silken tofu for each egg. Perfect for dense baked goods like cheesecakes and brownies.¬† ¬†For Leavening (Helping Dough Rise)¬† ¬†If eggs make baked goods fluffy, try:¬† ¬†‚Ä¢ Baking Soda & Vinegar ‚Äì Combine 1 tbsp vinegar (apple cider or white) with 1 tsp baking soda per egg. Best for cakes, cupcakes, and muffins.¬† ¬†‚Ä¢ Carbonated Water ‚Äì Replace each egg with ¬º cup sparkling water. Adds lightness to pancakes, muffins, and cakes. ¬†‚Ä¢ Yogurt or Buttermilk ‚Äì Use ¬º cup per egg for extra moisture and a slight tang in baked goods.¬†  Best Egg Substitutes for Cooking



For Scrambles & Omelets ¬†‚Ä¢ Tofu Scramble ‚Äì Crumble firm tofu and saut√© with seasonings for an egg-like texture. Adding turmeric gives a yellow hue.¬† ¬†‚Ä¢ Chickpea Flour Batter ‚Äì Mix ¬Ω cup chickpea flour with ¬Ω cup water and seasonings to make an omelet-like batter.



For Breading & Coating ¬†‚Ä¢ Flour + Water Slurry ‚Äì Mix ¬º cup flour with ¬º cup water for a sticky egg substitute. ¬†‚Ä¢ Milk or Plant-Based Milk ‚Äì Helps breadcrumbs stick for fried foods. ¬†‚Ä¢ Mustard or Vegan Mayo ‚Äì A little goes a long way in holding coatings together.¬† ¬†Best Store-Bought Egg Replacements ¬†If you need convenience, these commercial options work well:¬† ¬†‚Ä¢ JUST Egg ‚Äì A liquid, plant-based egg substitute for scrambling and baking.¬†¬†‚Ä¢ Bob‚Äôs Red Mill Egg Replacer ‚Äì Powdered mix that mimics eggs in baking.¬†¬†‚Ä¢ Ener-G Egg Replacer ‚Äì Great for cookies, muffins, and pancakes. ¬†Final Tips: ¬†‚Ä¢ Choose substitutes based on the role of the egg in your recipe.¬†¬†‚Ä¢ Experiment! Some substitutes work better in specific recipes¬†‚Ä¢ When in doubt, try a flax egg‚Äîit‚Äôs one of the most versatile replacements.¬† ¬†Whether you‚Äôre baking, frying, or scrambling, there‚Äôs an egg substitute for every dish. Happy cooking!

   OTHER RECIPES TO TRY:

author: itstimholman
title: Even One Person's Food Choices Affect the Whole Planet | Opinion
text: From¬†newsweek.com Most environmental scientists agree that producing food from animals has a much greater environmental and climate impact than producing food from plants with equivalent nutritional value. And, yet, all too often, when veganism is presented as an environmental action, it's accompanied by a caveat: we need systemic change, not individual effort.¬† As an interdisciplinary UCLA teaching team whose research focuses on the health, climate, and environmental impacts of food systems; the environmental impact of animal agriculture; the structure of activism; and life cycle assessments, we disagree with the claim that "going vegan" is unimportant to the fight against environmental devastation. An abundance of scientific research supports our position that both systemic and individual behaviour change are needed to support large increases in plant-based diets in order¬†to save our planet,¬†including from climate change. Frequently, veganism is¬†compared to recycling,¬†as both are seen as individual actions that have limited effects. Building a plant-forward food economy is not, however, structurally comparable to recycling. Recycling is a¬†downstream¬†effort to mitigate the damage of a throwaway society. Veganism is an¬†upstream¬†effort to shrink the size of the animal agriculture industry by reducing demand for its products. Compared with omnivore diets, plant-based diets cause less biodiversity loss, freshwater use, air and water pollution, antibiotic resistance, and human disease. Climate change is, however, the most often discussed, and studies suggest that switching to a vegan diet in the¬†United States could reduce food system greenhouse gas emissions by 47 percent. Switching to plant-based food systems internationally could reduce global food system emissions by¬†49 percent. Since the food system accounts for¬†10-30 percent of US greenhouse gas emissions¬†and¬†34 percent of global emissions, this could reduce total U.S. emissions by 5-14 percent and global emissions by 16 percent. If we pursued, for example, a limited substitution of¬†beef with beans,¬†we would achieve up to 74 percent of the reductions needed to meet climate targets, while also reducing land use. Similarly,¬†our work at UCLA¬†showed that after learning about the connections between food and the environment, students made voluntary, modest shifts in diet; extrapolated across the population, these small shifts would add up to 33 percent of the needed reductions to meet the Paris Climate Accord. More importantly, we¬†cannot meet climate targets¬†without¬†moving toward a plant- rather than animal-based food system. A recent¬†study¬†showed that by 2100 a business-as-usual food system would result in more emissions than the¬†total allowable budget from all sectors¬†if we are to meet the 1.5 C climate targets. Of five mitigation strategies studied, a shift to plant-rich diets was the most effective at reducing food system emissions. Similarly, the¬†Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change¬†has compared the mitigation potential of various dietary patterns, with the vegan diet having the highest potential reduction of 8 gigatons of greenhouse gas emissions per year. The argument that veganism lacks impact assumes that it is merely an individual lifestyle choice. In fact, while individuals may adopt a plant-based diet for their health or for ethical, religious, or spiritual reasons, veganism is also a social movement. For at least the last four centuries,¬†veganism in the Global North has involved a stance against the exploitation of animals and in favour of improving human health and protecting the environment. Asia's dharma traditions have for centuries signalled the importance of an ethics of compassion in relationships of humans to each other, to¬†non-human animals, and to the¬†surrounding world. Indeed, it is the mass movement nature of veganism that causes discomfort: veganism reminds us that food is political. Veganism's influence is limited by a¬†subsidy system¬†that skews market signals. Here's where the emphasis on systems change is correct: market signals are muted by policies in need of alteration. However, activists concerned with animal rights, the environment, the rights of farmers, and human health are already working to¬†ease the distortions¬†of the subsidy system and align government subsidies with recommendations as to what constitutes a healthy, sustainable diet. However, moving to a more plant-based food system does not depend only on "getting the price right" in the marketplace, because this is based on the discredited economic assumptions of neoliberalism. The motivation, for many vegans and plant-forward policies, requires values that go beyond the market‚Äîconserving natural resources and biodiversity for future generations, promoting social justice, reducing and stopping economic growth in high consuming populations, sufficient versus superfluous consumption, and extending compassion to all living beings. The mainstream environmental movement spent decades encouraging individual change. When it became obvious this wasn't working, they changed tack, arguing that only systemic change could make a difference. However, social scientists and activists alike acknowledge that¬†individual efforts and systemic change¬†support each other. Theory and research suggests that this is true of veganism, with some studies showing that the¬†majority of vegans are politically motivated, and with a growing number of¬†organizations¬†promoting more plant-based diets for animal welfare, health, environmental and equity reasons Climate scientists agree that the only thing that can avert environmental catastrophe is massive societal change at social, political, and economic levels, including adopting plant-based diets,¬†especially in the Global North. Our food system harms consumers, workers, frontline communities, animals, and the environment. As more people connect the dots between animal exploitation, the exploitation of human workers, the spread of diseases from animals, the epidemic of degenerative disease in wealthy countries, the climate crisis, food insecurity, and other forms of environmental degradation, veganism is becoming part of an organized, coalitional effort to build a more just food system. There is little that would be more of a systemic change than that. David A. Cleveland is a professor at UCSB and UCLA whose focus is understanding and improving the environmental, health, and equity impacts of food systems. Jennifer Jay is a professor of Environmental Engineering at UCLA, focusing on transport of contaminants in the environment. Shanna Shaked is an adjunct professor in UCLA's Institute of the Environment and Sustainability and has co-authored a textbook on quantifying environmental impacts of products. Janet O'Shea, professor and chair of World Arts and Cultures/Dance at UCLA, researches the role of physicality and emotion in justice efforts. https://www.newsweek.com/even-one-persons-food-choices-effect-whole-planet-opinion-2030211¬†

author: Farjad Taheer
title: 130+ Blog Ideas: The Ultimate List of Blog Post Ideas for Every Niche
text:
Generating consistent and engaging blog ideas can be challenging. 



If you‚Äôve ever found yourself searching for fresh blog post ideas or pondering over the most trending blog topics, you‚Äôre not alone. Beginners and experienced writers alike often struggle to churn out a steady stream of engaging content. 



Sure, you can do search engine keyword research and browse other popular blogs. But sometimes, writer‚Äôs block still hits. 



The quest to discover¬†what to blog about¬†is a universal challenge, but fear not!¬†This comprehensive guide is here to fuel your creativity with a plethora of¬†blogging ideas. 



From exploring diverse blog topic ideas to diving deep into niche-specific blogging topics, I‚Äôve got you covered. 



Whether you‚Äôre brainstorming¬†ideas for a blog¬†revamp or seeking¬†blog content ideas¬†to kickstart your blogging journey, this guide promises a treasure trove of inspiration.

title: Life and Times: Veganuaries ‚Äì do they work? (2025)
text: The Life and Times column from the February 2025 issue of the Socialist Standard Is veganism weird? That‚Äôs the question the organisation behind Veganuary asked recently on their website as they urged people to go vegan for January and then, if possible, to carry on with it forever. Of course, their answer was no, it isn‚Äôt weird. In fact, they said, it‚Äôs ‚Äòpart of something huge‚Äô. And they had various celebrities on their site backing them, eg Joaquin Phoenix, Billy Eilish, Chris Packham, Sarah Pascoe. Their statement of intent was: ‚ÄòOur vision is simple; we want a vegan world. A world without animal farms and slaughterhouses. A world where food production does not decimate forest, pollute rivers and oceans, exacerbate climate change, and drive wild animal populations to extinctions‚Äô. Animal welfareThis took me back many years to when I was a student and anything but a vegan or even vegetarian. I remembered being openly (and immaturely) contemptuous of a fellow student who was vegetarian. Little did I know that many years later I myself would decide to go vegetarian and then a long time after that ‚Äì fairly recently in fact ‚Äì vegan. How did that happen? Well, I became a vegetarian when I found the idea of eating the flesh of another sentient being too difficult. Later ‚Äì much later ‚Äì when a vegan friend suggested I attend an online talk by a leading advocate of plant-based eating, the suffering dairy farming brought to animals was also brought home to me and I saw no alternative but to go the whole hog and move to veganism. The speaker, Dr Klaper, described as ‚Äòan internationally recognized clinician, teacher and speaker on diet and health‚Äô, told us he had himself grown up on a dairy farm in the USA and that seemed to make his talk on ‚ÄòThe Most Powerful Strategy for Healing People and the Planet‚Äô all the more authentic. I also found it impressive in that he avoided being openly proselytising, simply sticking to simple facts in three key areas: animal cruelty, human health, and the environment. While the animal cruelty area was the one of most immediate interest to me, I also appreciated the case he put forward in the other two, even if I could think of some counter-arguments from opponents. Veganism effective?But what about Veganuary? It‚Äôs certainly possible that, if it does result in more people going vegan or vegetarian on a permanent basis or at least eating less meat or fish, it might lead to a reduction in the cruelty suffered by animals. But would it do much to lessen the hold of animal agriculture over the world‚Äôs food supply and reduce the raising and slaughtering of vast number of animals almost everywhere An argument often heard that says it wouldn‚Äôt, because the relative monopoly over food production held by a small number of big producers means that, even if they respond to a ‚Äòmarket‚Äô need to produce vegan ‚Äòalternatives‚Äô (as some of them are in fact doing), the effect of this will just be to increase their profits and investment power, so allowing them to produce meat and milk products more cheaply and more enticingly than before and thereby potentially increase animal suffering and exploitation. And would an increase in veganism do much to solve the climate and environmental problems that the current system‚Äôs unbridled quest for ‚Äògrowth‚Äô and profit has brought about? Some of the effects of what is happening were outlined in a recent article for the Earth/Food/Life project by Vicky Bond, animal welfare scientist and president of the US-based Humane League. She wrote:‚ÄòFactory farming touches every aspect of our planet, from emitting massive amounts of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere to contaminating the groundwater, rivers, lakes, and streams we rely on for fresh water. Factory farms house animals in crowded and often filthy conditions, subjecting millions of cows, chickens, and pigs to the worst forms of abuse for the entirety of their short lives. Driven by the demand for cheap eggs, meat, and dairy, the animal agriculture industry has disastrous consequences for the planet‚Äô.She went on to reveal that in 2024 animal agriculture accounted for almost a third of fresh water used globally and that, every day in the US, it withdrew 2 billion gallons of water from freshwater resources. One of the reasons she gave for this was the large quantities of water used by slaughterhouses both in electrified stun baths and in scalding tanks for feathering chickens. She went on: ‚ÄòBecause this method of slaughter is so terrifying for chickens, they also use vast amounts of water to clean feces and vomit from the chickens‚Äô bodies afterwards‚Äô (tinyurl.com/5yz7crxf). Feeding the beastYet it is clear that, even if there were a significant reduction in meat-eating and so in animal agriculture, as Bond would like, the environment would continue to be polluted and the climate would keep on warming owing to the demands of the economic system we live under, that untameable ‚Äòbeast‚Äô of production for profit. Faced with the system‚Äôs need to feed the beast, our food choices would do little to contribute to stopping or reversing ecological deterioration or global warming. It is decades too late now for me to apologise to that fellow student for ridiculing his choice of vegetarianism. Of course, I would if I could, since I feel that in a sense that we are ‚Äòon the same side‚Äô. But, having said that, nothing in the Socialist Party‚Äôs case for a moneyless, marketless society of free access and voluntary cooperation demands adherence to any particular kind of diet. That is, and will always be, a matter of personal choice. But the fact is that, choice of diet apart, the Earth has sufficient resources to feed (and house and clothe) all its inhabitants to a highly comfortable level a number of times over, once we, the human species, decide to put our natural capacity for cooperation and collaboration to full use and apply those resources to make sure that all ‚Äì whether they choose to be vegan, vegetarian or anything else ‚Äì have enough healthy food to eat and the certainty of a decent, secure life. Failing this, under the existing worldwide system of production for profit and buying and selling, those who do not have money to buy will go hungry, very many more will lead insecure and highly stressed existences, human health will not be well safeguarded, and the ecosystem will continue to be in imminent danger of collapse.Howard Moss
tags: ["Animal Rights","Factory Farming","February 2025","Green Reformism","Howard Moss","Life and Times Column","Politics of Water","R2025","The Food Industry","Veganism"]

author: Irshad Ahmad
title: What do people eat in your country? A Look at American Cuisine
text:
¬†The
 United States of America, often called a melting pot of cultures, 
boasts a diverse culinary landscape that reflects its history of 
immigration and regional influences. From coast to coast, the foods 
Americans eat vary widely, but certain dishes and eating habits have 
become synonymous with American cuisine. This article explores the 
typical foods, meals, and dining customs that shape the American dietary
 experience ¬† ¬†   Breakfast: The Most Important Meal of the Day Americans often start their day with a hearty breakfast. Common breakfast foods include:  1. Eggs: Scrambled, fried, or in omelets, often served with bacon or sausage 2. Pancakes or waffles: Topped with butter and maple syrup 3. Cereal: A wide variety of cold cereals served with milk 4. Toast or bagels: Often spread with butter, cream cheese, or peanut butter 5. Oatmeal: A warm, hearty option, especially in colder months 6. Fresh fruits: Alone or as a side to other breakfast items  For those on the go, breakfast might consist of a quick coffee and a pastry from a local caf√© or a fast-food breakfast sandwich.   Lunch: Midday Fuel Lunch in America is typically a lighter meal compared to dinner. Common lunch options include:  1. Sandwiches: From classic peanut butter and jelly to deli meat and cheese 2. Salads: Often featuring mixed greens, vegetables, and protein like chicken or tuna 3. Soups: Especially popular in colder weather 4. Leftovers from previous dinners: Reheated and enjoyed the next day 5. Fast food: Burgers, fries, and other quick options for busy days  Many
 Americans eat lunch at work or school, often bringing packed lunches 
from home or purchasing food from nearby restaurants or cafeterias. Dinner: The Main Event Dinner
 is typically the largest and most significant meal of the day for 
Americans. It's often a time for families to gather and share their day.
 Popular dinner options include:  1. Meat dishes: Such as grilled chicken, steak, or pork chops 2. Pasta: Spaghetti with meatballs, lasagna, or mac and cheese 3. Casseroles: One-dish meals combining proteins, vegetables, and starches 4. Pizza: Both homemade and delivery are common dinner choices 5. Tacos or burritos: Reflecting the influence of Mexican cuisine 6. Stir-fries: Quick, vegetable-rich meals often served over rice 7. Seafood: Fish or shellfish dishes, especially in coastal areas  Dinners are usually accompanied by side dishes such as steamed or roasted vegetables, salads, or starches like potatoes or rice.   Regional Specialties The vast expanse of the United States has led to the development of distinct regional cuisines:  1. Southern cuisine: Known for fried chicken, biscuits and gravy, grits, and barbecue 2. New England: Famous for clam chowder, lobster rolls, and baked beans 3. Midwest: Home to hearty dishes like casseroles and pot roasts 4. Southwest: Influenced by Mexican flavors, with dishes like chili con carne and fajitas 5. Pacific Northwest: Known for fresh seafood and farm-to-table cuisine 6. Hawaii: A unique blend of Polynesian, Asian, and American flavors   Fast Food and Convenience The
 fast-paced American lifestyle has contributed to the popularity of fast
 food and convenient meal options. Fast food chains like McDonald's, 
Burger King, and Wendy's are ubiquitous across the country. These 
restaurants typically serve burgers, fries, chicken sandwiches, and 
other quick, portable meals.  In recent years, there's been a 
growing trend towards healthier fast food options, with chains offering 
salads, wraps, and plant-based alternatives to traditional fast food 
fare.  Snacks and Beverages Snacking is a common practice in American culture. Popular snacks include:  1. Potato chips and other salty snacks 2. Popcorn 3. Nuts and trail mix 4. Fresh fruits and vegetables 5. Cookies and crackers 6. Granola bars  As for beverages, Americans consume a wide variety of drinks: 1. Water: Both tap and bottled 2. Soft drinks: Carbonated beverages like cola are very popular 3. Coffee: A staple for many Americans, consumed throughout the day 4. Tea: Both hot and iced varieties 5. Fruit juices 6. Beer, wine, and spirits: For adults, often consumed with meals or socially   Eating Out and Restaurant Culture Dining
 out is a common practice in America, with a wide range of restaurants 
catering to every taste and budget. From casual diners and family 
restaurants to upscale fine dining establishments, Americans have 
countless options when eating out.  Ethnic restaurants are also 
prevalent, offering cuisines from around the world. Chinese, Italian, 
Mexican, and Indian restaurants are particularly common, reflecting the 
diverse cultural influences on American eating habits.   Health and Dietary Trends In recent years, there has been a growing awareness of health and nutrition in America, leading to several dietary trends:  1. Organic and locally sourced foods 2. Plant-based diets, including vegetarianism and veganism 3. Gluten-free and dairy-free options 4. Low-carb and ketogenic diets 5. Intermittent fasting 6. Superfoods and functional foods  Many
 Americans are now more conscious of their food choices, reading 
nutrition labels and seeking out healthier alternatives to traditional 
favorites.   Holiday and Celebratory Foods Certain foods are closely associated with American holidays and celebrations:  1. Thanksgiving: Turkey, stuffing, cranberry sauce, and pumpkin pie 2. Fourth of July: Barbecued meats, corn on the cob, and watermelon 3. Christmas: Ham or roast beef, mashed potatoes, and cookies 4. Super Bowl Sunday: Wings, chips and dip, and pizza  These foods play a significant role in American culture, bringing people together and creating shared experiences around meals.   Conclusion The
 American diet is as diverse as its population, reflecting a rich 
tapestry of cultural influences, regional specialties, and evolving 
health trends. From hearty breakfasts to family dinners, fast food to 
fine dining, the foods Americans eat tell a story of innovation, 
convenience, and tradition. While certain dishes and eating habits may 
be considered typically "American," the country's cuisine continues to 
evolve, embracing new flavors and adapting to changing lifestyles and 
health consciousness. Understanding what people eat in America provides 
insight not just into their diets, but into the cultural, social, and 
economic factors that shape American society as a whole.

title: For anyone wanting to live a healthy, more ethical and sustainable life in 2025, I would recommend‚Ä¶
text: acti-veg: For anyone wanting to live a healthy, more ethical and sustainable life in 2025, I would recommend that you consider veganism. I made the switch in January 13 years ago, and can honestly say it is one of the most unequivocally positive decisions I have ever made. It could be for you, too. Going vegan and advocating for the rights of animals is an act of protest against a corporate system that treats sentient beings as mere objects, commodities to be bought and sold as property. Animal agriculture industries breed animals into unhealthy bodies, exploit them for profit then slaughter them at a tiny fraction of their life expectancy. Most animals are killed when they‚Äôre little more than infants. Adopting a plant-based diet is the single biggest dietary change you can make to reduce your carbon footprint by up to 73%. Eating plant-based requires less land, less water, fewer crops and can be up to 1/3 cheaper. There is a broad scientific consensus that plant-based diets can be perfectly healthy, with organisations like the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics and the NHS in agreement. Those who still think that vegans cannot be healthy in 2025 are denying decades of nutritional research, and must find it hard to explain how committed vegan athletes are competing at the highest levels of sport. There are significant barriers that prevent some people from adopting a 100% plant-based diet, whether that is because of health issues, a difficult living situation or limited food availability. But veganism is about avoiding animal exploitation as far as is possible and practicable. It‚Äôs about doing your best, whatever that looks like. Just honestly ask yourself; if you can be healthy while living a more humane, more sustainable lifestyle, why not give it a try?

author: healthcare556
title: Who Can Benefit from Nutritionist & Dietitian Advice?
text:
In today‚Äôs fast-paced world, making healthy choices can sometimes be a challenge. That‚Äôs where professional advice from a Nutritionist & Dietitian in Dubai can help. Whether you are struggling with a specific health condition, aiming to improve your overall well-being, or simply want guidance on maintaining a balanced diet, a nutritionist or dietitian can provide personalized support and actionable insights. But who exactly can benefit from their expertise? Let‚Äôs explore the diverse groups of people who can significantly improve their health with professional nutritional guidance. 
1. Individuals with Chronic Health Conditions
People who are living with chronic health conditions, such as diabetes, hypertension, or heart disease, can greatly benefit from tailored dietary plans. Nutritionists and dietitians have the knowledge to recommend specific foods that can manage or even improve these conditions. For instance, someone with diabetes can receive guidance on how to balance carbohydrates and control blood sugar levels through food choices, while someone with high blood pressure can learn which foods help reduce sodium intake and support cardiovascular health. 
2. Athletes and Fitness Enthusiasts
For athletes, fitness enthusiasts, and anyone pursuing an active lifestyle, the right diet is just as important as training. Nutritionists and dietitians can provide customized meal plans that help optimize performance, enhance recovery, and prevent injury. They can guide athletes in fueling their bodies with the proper nutrients before and after workouts, ensuring maximum energy levels, muscle growth, and overall stamina. 
3. Those Looking to Lose or Gain Weight
Weight management is a common concern for many people, whether it‚Äôs shedding a few pounds or gaining muscle. A nutritionist or dietitian can create a plan tailored to your individual goals, ensuring you receive the right balance of nutrients while avoiding fad diets that may not be sustainable. With their professional advice, you can safely navigate your weight loss or weight gain journey without compromising your health. 
4. Pregnant Women and New Mothers
Pregnancy and breastfeeding require special attention to nutrition, as both the mother and baby need adequate nutrients for health and development. A nutritionist or dietitian can help ensure that pregnant women are meeting their increased nutritional needs and provide advice on which foods can support a healthy pregnancy. After childbirth, new mothers can also benefit from advice on maintaining energy levels and balancing nutrients while managing the demands of caring for a newborn. 
5. Children and Teenagers
Proper nutrition is vital during the growing years. For children and teenagers, balanced meals support growth, development, and academic performance. A nutritionist or dietitian can help parents navigate the sometimes picky eating habits of children and provide practical tips for ensuring their kids get the right nutrition. Whether it‚Äôs guiding through childhood obesity or helping teenagers build healthy habits that last a lifetime, professional advice can make a huge difference. 
 
6. Individuals with Digestive Issues
Those suffering from digestive problems like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), gluten sensitivity, or food intolerances can greatly benefit from a nutritionist‚Äôs or dietitian‚Äôs expertise. These professionals can help identify problematic foods and recommend alternatives to ensure that individuals are still getting a balanced and nutritious diet. They can also help with meal planning to reduce symptoms and improve overall gut health. 
7. Elderly Adults
As we age, our nutritional needs change, and maintaining proper nutrition becomes even more critical. For seniors, a dietitian can assist in addressing concerns like weight loss, bone health, and managing age-related conditions like osteoporosis or arthritis. They can also provide advice on maintaining a balanced diet that supports cognitive function and enhances energy levels for a higher quality of life. 
8. Individuals Seeking Preventative Health
Even if you don‚Äôt currently have a specific health condition, seeking nutritionist and dietitian advice can be a proactive approach to better health. Many people turn to nutritionists and dietitians to learn how to reduce their risk of developing chronic diseases in the future. By adopting healthier eating habits early on, you can improve your immune system, reduce inflammation, and prevent conditions such as obesity, heart disease, and even some cancers. 
9. People Interested in Sustainable Eating Habits
In today‚Äôs world, many people are becoming more conscious of the environmental impact of their food choices. A nutritionist or dietitian can help individuals who are transitioning to plant-based diets, veganism, or other sustainable eating habits. They can ensure that individuals are still receiving the necessary nutrients, like protein, iron, and calcium, while following eco-friendly or ethical dietary practices. 
10. Individuals with Eating Disorders
For those struggling with eating disorders like anorexia, bulimia, or binge eating disorder, a nutritionist or dietitian can offer crucial support. These professionals can work alongside therapists and medical practitioners to create a nutritional rehabilitation plan that supports mental and physical health. They provide the tools to build a healthier relationship with food and develop balanced eating habits. 
Conclusion
Nutritionists and Dietitian Dubai offer invaluable support for anyone looking to improve their health, regardless of their stage in life or lifestyle choices. Whether you‚Äôre dealing with a health issue, embarking on a fitness journey, or simply aiming for a more balanced life, seeking advice from a Nutritionist & Dietitian in Dubai could be a transformative step. Their tailored plans and expert guidance can help you make informed, sustainable food choices that benefit your long-term well-being. So, why not take charge of your health today and explore how a nutritionist or dietitian can help you live your best life?

author: Aidan Alexander
title: Sponsor a Meat-Eater with FarmKind (..because sometimes, a little pettiness is exactly what the world needs)
text:
What if you could turn someone else‚Äôs meat habit into your own little act of rebellion?  That‚Äôs where we come in. Using FarmKind‚Äôs Compassion Calculator, you can offset the true consumption of a meat-eater in your life. Think of it as ‚Äúsponsoring a meat-eater.‚Äù Your contribution transforms their everyday indulgence into your cheeky act of protest against factory farming.¬† And here‚Äôs the fun part: it only costs $23 a month. The Price of Factory FarmingThe true cost of factory farming goes beyond a menu price or grocery receipt. In fact it‚Äôs immeasurable: This system is built on animal cruelty, is destroying our environment and putting our health at risk through increased pandemic risks and antibiotic resistance.¬† And while many of us choose to go vegan as an act of personal protest, we can‚Äôt control the choices ‚Äì or impact ‚Äì of those around us who don‚Äôt share the same lifestyle. But we can offset their consumption: We can prevent the same amount of harm that their lifestyle creates ‚Äî like carbon offsets, but for one‚Äôs diet. The extra ‚Äúprice tag‚Äù for an average omnivorous adult comes out to roughly $281 a year. Break that down, and it‚Äôs just about $23 each month. (Feel free to check out the math here). For the cost of just one weekly oat-milk latte, you can provide high-impact donations to charities working to shift the corporate farming machine from all angles. Our Compassion Calculator





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Our calculator, powered by data from trusted sources like Our World In Data estimates the number of animals impacted by the user‚Äôs diet, and how much it costs our recommended charities to do an equivalent amount of good. They account for hidden factors, like the extra animals raised‚Äîand lost‚Äîto the harms of factory farming.  Check out our blog post on How Our Calculators Work for all the details. Why Petty Protest?Because sometimes a dash of mischief is the spark for real change. Your monthly donation turns someone‚Äôs meat feast into a win for animal welfare. It‚Äôs your playful way of saying, ‚ÄúNot on my watch!‚Äù Even if you don‚Äôt know the meat-eater personally (or maybe you do‚Äîno judgment), your support reclaims a tiny bit of justice from a system built on hidden cruelty. Make Your MarkJoin the movement of playful defiance. By sponsoring a meat-eater, you transform their everyday habits into your bold stance against factory farming. Your $23 a month will offset their lifestyle, while funding the charities that are moving the needle on factory farming. Ready for a bit of playful defiance? Head over to our Compassion Calculator and start sponsoring a meat-eater today‚Ä¶ you can even put their name on your donation üòâ  Give someone the gift of veganism ‚Äî whether they like it or not!

author: Anna Starostinetskaya
title: These Top 3 Vegan Food Cities Are Poised to Become Blue Zones
text:
In the quest for longevity and health, Blue Zones‚Äîareas where people live significantly longer lives‚Äîhave captured global attention. Exercise, social interaction, and a focus on plant-forward eating are common traits of the five global Blue Zones, namely Sardinia, Italy; Okinawa, Japan; the Nicoya Peninsula in Costa Rica; Ikaria, Greece; and Loma Linda, CA in the US. 
Could new Blue Zones emerge in the US? Insights from¬†Forbes Health and HappyCow are pointing to three US cities where the Blue Zones habits echo those of locales where people tend to live the longest. The cities with emerging Blue Zones, and where plant-based fare is king, are Los Angeles, CA; Portland, OR; and New York City, according to the insights. 
Common traits of Blue Zones
The methodologies of Forbes Health and HappyCow, while distinct in their focus, share a common theme in evaluating factors that contribute to healthier and more sustainable living environments. 
Forbes Health‚Äôs approach is centered on identifying potential Blue Zones within the US by examining a range of lifestyle factors, including the availability of plant-based foods, levels of physical activity, community engagement, sleep patterns, life expectancy, and the presence of centenarians.¬† 
Bruna Bronco/Pexels 
HappyCow, on the other hand, specifically targets the vegan-friendly nature of cities by assessing the density and variety of vegan businesses, including restaurants, shops, and bakeries, within a 10-kilometer (6.2-mile) radius of city centers.¬† 
The growth of vegan businesses and qualitative factors such as the ease of finding vegan options and the city‚Äôs overall engagement with veganism are also crucial components of HappyCow‚Äôs evaluation. 
The overlap in these methodologies suggests a significant link between the rise of vegan-friendly cities and the characteristics of Blue Zones. Both approaches recognize the importance of plant-based diets in promoting health and longevity.¬† 
‚ÄúWhether you‚Äôre already embracing a vegan lifestyle or just beginning to explore it, we strongly advocate for supporting local vegan enterprises,‚Äù HappyCow founder Eric Brent said in a statement. ‚ÄúThese top cities boast a remarkable array of delicious, compassionate, and healthy cuisine.‚Äù
Los Angeles: a vegan haven in California
In Los Angeles, the vegan scene, despite a 22-percent decline in the number of vegan businesses since HappyCow‚Äôs last report in 2024, continues to be vibrant and diverse. The city boasts 50 fully vegan restaurants alongside a total of 128 vegan businesses. 
Ubuntu 

Upscale dining options such as Shojin and Crossroads Kitchen offer luxurious plant-based cuisine, while affordable options like Cena Vegan and Baba‚Äôs Vegan Cafe cater to budget-conscious consumers. 
Unique spots such as Justine‚Äôs Wine Bar, Besties Vegan Paradise, and vegan ghost kitchens such as Lucky Catsu exemplify the city‚Äôs rich and varied vegan offerings. Despite the geographic spread of these options, Los Angeles maintains its reputation as a vegan haven. 
Moreover, celebrity-backed concepts such as TikTok-favorite Mr. Charlie‚Äôs continue to bring a celebrity flare to LA‚Äôs plant-based food scene.¬† 
‚ÄúLos Angeles has a vibrant vegan community, hosting regular events like Vegan Exchange [and more], all friendly places for vegans to connect,‚Äù HappyCow‚Äôs Emma Cebuliak tells VegNews.¬†
Despite California‚Äôs ranking as the tenth place in Forbes Health‚Äôs list, largely due to its lower walkability score and higher percentage of inactive adults, Los Angeles shines in its number of vegan and vegetarian restaurants.¬† 
The state‚Äôs commitment to plant-based eating, Forbes Health found, is evident in its robust number of vegan and/or vegetarian establishments, signaling a shift towards the dietary patterns celebrated in Blue Zones. 
Portland, OR: a pioneer in the sustainable vegan lifestyle
Portland showcases a high density of vegan establishments relative to its population. The city features 46 all-vegan restaurants, 103 vegan businesses, and a total of 631 listings on HappyCow. 
Chubby Bunny PDX 
Chubby Bunny, cocktail resto-bar June, and Mirisata (which serves Sri Lankan cuisine) are just a few of the city‚Äôs more casual vegan spots.¬†Feral offers an upscale dining experience with a focus on foraged and wild food.¬† 
Unique destinations such as El Salto PDX (serving Venezuelan comfort foods); Baby Ketten Klub (a vegan karaoke bar); and Ice Queen (a frozen dessert bar) highlight Portland‚Äôs diverse and thriving vegan culture. 
‚ÄúPortland stands out globally for its high density of vegan businesses, including bakeries, shops, and other vegan venues, having one for every 6,000 people,‚Äù Cebuliak says.¬†
In line with the Blue Zone criteria, the state of Oregon‚Äîwhere Portland is the largest city‚Äîranked seventh in Forbes Health‚Äôs analysis, primarily due to its high number of vegetarian/vegan restaurants, which comes to approximately 23 per million residents.¬† 
Additionally, the state‚Äôs emphasis on adequate sleep, with 68 percent of adults getting seven hours of sleep per night, plays a crucial role in overall health and longevity. 
New York City: a melting pot of vegan diversity
In 2024, New York City didn‚Äôt make HappyCow‚Äôs top 10, but 2025 is different. This year, the Big Apple comes in at number nine.¬† 
Ras Plant Based 
Often hailed as the international food capital, NYC still offers an astonishing variety of plant-based options. Eateries such as Chloe, Ras Plant Based, Aunt Et Uncles, and May Kaidee highlight the diversity, serving everything from artisanal plates to the finest Thai cuisine. The city‚Äôs commitment to veganism doesn‚Äôt stop at restaurants. Vegan bakeries, including Rawsome Treats, are becoming staple destinations for those seeking plant-based indulgence.¬† 
NYC is where to get your vegan fast-food fix, too, with options such as Jerrell‚Äôs Betr Brgr, Slutty Vegan, and PLNT Burger all available to residents throughout the city.¬† 
Forbes Health‚Äôs analysis found that approximately 15 percent of New Yorkers meet their daily fruit intake, and 14 percent meet their vegetable requirements, surpassing national averages. The city‚Äôs high walk score, indicative of pedestrian-friendly environments, aligns with the Blue Zone characteristic of natural movement, promoting daily physical activity in urban life. 
One added health bonus here is that the city has implemented several initiatives in schools and hospitals to make plant-based eating more accessible and appealing to New Yorkers. 
Future Blue Zones
In New York, Los Angeles, and Portland, the growth of the vegan lifestyle mirrors the traits‚Äîfirst identified in 2004 by National Geographic fellow Dan Buettner‚Äîthat Blue Zones have in common such as diets heavy in plant-based foods, natural physical activity, strong community ties, and stress reduction techniques. 
KBO Bike/Unsplash 
As such, the availability and accessibility of plant-based foods in these cities reflect a deeper understanding of health and the environment. The emphasis on natural movement aligns with the Blue Zone principle of incorporating physical activity into daily life.¬† 
Moreover, the sense of community, particularly evident in the strong vegan scenes of these cities, echoes the social connectedness observed in Blue Zones. 
‚ÄúBlue Zones exhibit a holistic approach to living at the intersection of diet and lifestyle,‚Äù Cebuliak says. ‚ÄúIn this regard, Portland and Los Angeles could be considered leaders in North America for their plant-based food accessibility and supportive vegan communities.‚Äù¬†
In addition to New York, California, and Oregon, Forbes Health also points to Vermont, Massachusetts, Connecticut, Rhode Island, New Hampshire, Hawaii, and Maine as states with the highest Blue Zone traits. 
Palm Springs wasn‚Äôt named in the research but the Californian city also recently launched its own Blue Zones Project in a bid to improve the health and wellbeing of its residents. More than 45,000 people live in Palm Springs, and the new $6 million community-focused initiative, which is backed by local healthcare organizations, aims to help identify key areas where their quality of life can be improved. This will include making the city more walkable, for example, increasing the accessibility of healthy food. 

‚ÄúThe ultimate goal is to see a much healthier and happier community,‚Äù said Geoff Kors, a former Palm Springs City Council member and mayor, in a statement. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people who are isolated [‚Ä¶] If we can see ourselves increase the positives while decreasing the negative health impacts, that is the goal.‚Äù 
New international Blue Zones
Outside of the US, HappyCow has named Mexico City, Lisbon, Amsterdam, Ho Chi Minh City, Barcelona, Berlin, and (its top city) London as leaders in plant-based food options.¬† 
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs encouraging to observe a growing mainstream trend towards vegan options in urban areas, building momentum as more people relate their health, the environment, and animal welfare to their plate,‚Äù Cebuliak says. 
‚ÄúWe believe this has the potential to catalyze significant lifestyle shifts, with plant-based eating becoming a default choice for many,‚Äù Cebuliak says. ‚ÄúThis could lead to a collective improvement in health outcomes and a greater public consciousness regarding sustainable living.‚Äù

author: foodtechpathshala
title: Adopting Flexitarianism in 2025: Why This Diet Continues to Rise and How to Transition Effectively
text: What is the Flexitarian Diet?The flexitarian diet is a semi-vegetarian approach that primarily emphasizes plant-based foods while allowing occasional consumption of meat and animal products. Unlike strict veganism or vegetarianism, this flexible plant-based lifestyle makes it easier for individuals to embrace healthier eating habits without feeling restricted. Why is Flexitarianism Growing in 2025? Health BenefitsStudies show that reducing meat intake can lower the risk of heart disease, diabetes, and obesity while improving digestion and longevity.  Sustainability MattersWith climate change concerns escalating, many are choosing plant-based diets to reduce their carbon footprint and minimize environmental impact.  Budget-Friendly EatingMeat and dairy can be expensive. A flexitarian diet encourages the consumption of affordable, nutrient-dense plant-based proteins like lentils, beans, and tofu.  No Strict RulesThe biggest advantage of flexitarianism is that it‚Äôs realistic and adaptable. You don‚Äôt have to give up meat entirely‚Äîjust eat less of it! How to Transition to a Flexitarian Diet1. Start with Small ChangesTry Meatless Mondays or substitute one meal a day with a plant-based alternative. 2. Experiment with Plant-Based ProteinsIncorporate chickpeas, tempeh, mushrooms, quinoa, and nuts to ensure you‚Äôre getting enough protein. 3. Reimagine Your PlateFill half of your plate with vegetables, a quarter with whole grains, and a quarter with lean protein (plant-based whenever possible). 4. Try Meat SubstitutesOpt for jackfruit ‚Äúpulled pork,‚Äù lentil-based burgers, or cauliflower steaks instead of traditional meat dishes. 5. Plan Your MealsHaving a meal plan makes it easier to stick to your flexitarian goals while ensuring balanced nutrition. 6. Listen to Your BodyIf you feel like having meat occasionally, that‚Äôs okay! The goal is progress, not perfection. The Future of FlexitarianismIn 2025, the flexitarian lifestyle is more than just a trend‚Äîit‚Äôs a sustainable way of eating that supports both personal health and planetary well-being. Whether you‚Äôre transitioning for health, environmental, or ethical reasons, this balanced approach to plant-based eating makes it easier to stick with long-term. Ready to Go Flexitarian?Are you considering the flexitarian diet this year? Share your thoughts or favorite plant-based recipes in the comments!

author: Graeme M
title: Farmers Defending Animal Welfare Miss the Point
text: Something I often see on social media is farmers objecting to vegan advocacy on the grounds that vegans know nothing about animal husbandry. Because vegans aren‚Äôt engaged in the business, the story goes, they don‚Äôt understand just how well farmers really do look after their livestock. Unfortunately, this criticism rather misses the point. I think ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Farmers Defending Animal Welfare Miss the¬†Point
