author: Amy Yee
title: Black-owned vegan restaurants join Chicago Black Restaurant Week
text:
Now in its 10th year, Chicago Black Restaurant Week kicked off Sunday and runs until Feb. 23 with more than 40 Black-owned eateries offering special meals during Black History Month. This year, three vegan restaurants are participating: The Black Vegan in Little Village, Your Organic Inner G in Ashburn and Native Foods in the Loop. But there are many more Black-owned vegan and vegan-friendly eateries in the Chicago area. Last year, Chicago food blogger Tamika Price listed 15 restaurants on her blog, Plant-based Tamika; that‚Äôs about double the number since she started tracking in 2019, she said. Appetite for vegan and vegetarian food is expanding among Black communities as health awareness grows and food options become more diverse and appealing.  When Lauran Smith founded Chicago Black Restaurant Week in 2015 there were no vegan restaurants on the list. Now, ‚Äúmore and more people look to change their diets completely, and would still like to experience amazing flavor while they make their transition to vegan and vegetarian options,‚Äù Smith said. There are also holistic and ethical reasons for the shift toward plant-based eating in Chicago and across the U.S. For example, RZA, a founder of hip-hop group Wu-Tang Clan, has been vegan since 2000 and is a prominent advocate of veganism and animal welfare ‚Äî and is vocal about the philosophical reasons for not  consuming animal products. Sparkle Le‚ÄôStar, founder of the Black Vegan, became a bigger fan of RZA after learning that he was vegan. ‚ÄúIt was confirmation that I wasn‚Äôt crazy or alone in this beautiful journey,‚Äù she said. The Black VeganLe‚ÄôStar opened the Black Vegan in 2020 at 2300 S. Kedzie Ave. She was born and raised on the West Side and ‚Äúnever naturally gravitated toward vegetables.‚Äù But in 2018, she decided to try plant-based eating for 30 days. She was surprised when she felt a dramatic physical, mental and emotional shift within a month. 
        
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        Sparkle Le‚ÄôStar, founder of The Black Vegan. Pat Nabong/Sun-Times 
    


                        
                    
                
            
        
    ‚ÄúMy stress, anxiety and depression eased. My body felt lighter, stronger. But the biggest change? My heart,‚Äù Le‚ÄôStar said. ‚ÄúI began to care more ‚Äî not just for my own well-being but for others, for animals, for the world around me. I went from living in my own bubble to volunteering at animal shelters, gently escorting bugs out of my home instead of killing them.‚Äù Le‚ÄôStar said the vegan ‚Äúmovement is only growing ‚Äî especially among youth. It‚Äôs like each new generation is getting wiser and more in tune with what their bodies need.‚Äù She added, ‚ÄúOne minute, people are totally against it, and the next, they‚Äôre diving headfirst into the plant-based life.‚Äù When designing the Black Vegan‚Äôs menu, ‚Äúthe key was fun and familiarity,‚Äù she said, with offerings such as wings, ribs, Italian beef, burgers and shrimp made from ingredients like oyster and lion‚Äôs mane mushrooms, tofu and banana blossom. She sought to veganize ‚Äúculturally Black‚Äù dishes, ‚Äúthe real, nostalgic, straight-from-childhood favorites that every Black omnivore grew up on, such as mac and cheese and greens.‚Äù The restaurant also has holiday specials like plant-based chitterlings. ‚ÄúAs much as I hated them growing up, I can‚Äôt deny their place in Black food history,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúAnd guess what? People were thrilled to get that nostalgic taste without the smell or the pork.‚Äù Customer favorites include portobello wings made of crispy, ‚Äúsauced-up‚Äù mushrooms; banana blossom ‚Äúcatfish;‚Äù and the "290 Burger" made with plant-based Italian beef, priced at $16. It's named for Interstate 290 that runs through the West Side. 
        
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        The Black Vegan‚Äôs 290 Burger. Pat Nabong/Sun-Times 
    


                        
                    
                
            
        
    Le‚ÄôStar‚Äôs goal isn‚Äôt just to sell food but to ‚Äúhelp people, to guide them toward health and healing in a way that felt exciting, not restrictive.‚Äù Her customers are diverse, ranging from someone ‚Äúwith baggy clothes, looking like the type society has unfairly been taught to fear. And next thing you know, they‚Äôre breaking down the benefits of holistic healing, herbal remedies and plant-based living,‚Äù Le‚ÄôStar said. ‚ÄúOn the flip side, we‚Äôve got elders in walkers making the switch and embracing a whole new way of eating.‚Äù Your Organic Inner GRena Parks opened Your Organic Inner G, a plant-based salad and juice bar, in February 2024. Parks was previously an executive chef with food services company Sodexo. She struggled with inexplicable reactions to foods like cheese, butter and soy. Doctors prescribed inhalers for symptoms such as her throat closing up, but her health problems persisted. Then she began eliminating certain foods from her diet and her health improved. Parks realized her body had been reacting badly to specific ingredients. That fueled the launch of Your Organic Inner G, ‚Äúwhere people with dietary restrictions or those simply seeking healthier options can enjoy flavorful, nourishing meals without worry,‚Äù Parks said. 
        
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        Organic Inner G chef and owner Rena Parks Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times 
    


                        
                    
                
            
        
    She said many African Americans face high rates of diabetes, heart disease, high blood pressure and other health conditions, often related to diet. Parks wanted to change that through ‚Äúplant-based meals that heal the body and uplift the spirit.‚Äù Interest in veganism grew during the pandemic. ‚ÄúWe realized that much of our food was heavily processed, tainted with bio-engineered ingredients and lacking real nourishment. That awakening led more people to start paying closer attention to their health and the quality of their food,‚Äù Parks said. Your Organic Inner G at 8259 S. Kedzie Ave., doesn‚Äôt use processed foods. Everything is made from scratch except for the bread, for now, Parks said. One customer favorite is jerk grilled cheese for $12.50 made with lion‚Äôs mane mushrooms and house-made cheese. For Black History Month, the ‚ÄúSoul Bowl‚Äù features cornbread, saut√©ed greens, sweet potatoes, black-eyed peas and bourbon barbecue trumpet mushrooms, topped with a wedge of fried green tomato. 
        
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        Your Organic Inner G‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Philly,‚Äù made with lion‚Äôs mane mushrooms, bell peppers, onions, lettuce, tomatoes and spicy ranch cashew dressing. Anthony Vazquez/Sun-Times 
    


                        
                    
                
            
        
     Native FoodsNative Foods launched in 1994 in Palm Springs, California, and grew to a nationwide chain. But due to the pandemic, Native Foods closed all of its locations except in Chicago, Palm Springs and Glendale, Colorado, where employees were offered ownership. In 2023, Dame Dia became an owner of Native Foods' last Midwest restaurant. Dia, originally from Dakar, Senegal, had started working at Native Foods in 2018. 
        
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        Native Foods owner Dame Dia. Pat Nabong/Sun-Times 
    


                        
                    
                
            
        
    Native Foods, 218 S. Clark St., offers items such as bean chili and shrimp rolls made of konjac, a root vegetable. But its ‚ÄúTaste of Senegal‚Äù sampler for $21.95 has been especially popular. It features vegan mafe (peanut butter tomato stew with plant-based beef, as well as carrots, Brussels sprouts and sweet potatoes); Yassa Chick‚Äôn (plant-based chick‚Äôn with caramelized onions, lime, and bell peppers); and jollof rice (West African-seasoned jasmine rice with saut√©ed cabbage, sweet bell peppers, carrots and sweet potatoes). ‚ÄúThe demand for plant-based options in the Black community has grown significantly in recent years,‚Äù said OnJaLee LaShay, director of marketing. ‚ÄúMore people are learning about the health benefits of a plant-based diet, especially in combating conditions like hypertension and diabetes that disproportionately affect us.‚Äù LaShay, who is married to Dia, said many Black customers are excited about plant-based meals that reflect their tastes and culture. ‚ÄúWe can help break the stigma around plant-based eating and inspire more people to explore healthier food choices,‚Äù LaShay said. ‚ÄúWe want to show that eating well doesn‚Äôt mean giving up the flavors and traditions we love ‚Äî it means reimagining them in a way that nourishes our bodies and honors our culture.‚Äù 
        
            
            
                
                    
                        
                            
        
    
            
                

            
        

        
        
            
    
            

    

    
        

    


        
        
    



    

    
        A sampling of Native Foods dishes, including shrimp rolls, Yassa Chick‚Äôn, Senegalese jollof rice and beef mafe Pat Nabong/Sun-Times

author: broShaul
title: 30 Years on a Raw Vegan Diet: Key Tips for Success and Longevity
text: In today‚Äôs video, I‚Äôm sharing my personal journey of living on a raw vegan diet for 30 years! Over the decades, I‚Äôve learned a lot about what it takes to stay healthy, successful, and thriving on this lifestyle long-term. I‚Äôll be discussing the keys to maintaining balance, staying energized, and making this diet work for you over the years. Whether you're new to raw veganism or have been on the journey for a while, I hope these insights will help you create a sustainable and healthy path that works for you, just as it has for me.

author: broShaul
title: Can a 54-Year-Old Raw Food Vegan Complete 50 Pull-Ups & 100 Push-Ups in Under 5 Minutes?
text: In today‚Äôs video, we‚Äôre putting raw food vegan nutrition to the test with a challenge that combines strength, endurance, and determination. Can a 54-year-old who follows a raw food vegan lifestyle complete 50 pull-ups and 100 push-ups in under 5 minutes? Watch as we explore the connection between raw food veganism and fitness, while pushing the limits of what‚Äôs possible at any age. Let‚Äôs see if age, diet, and dedication can make this impressive feat a reality!

author: Conscious Vegan
text: ¬†From Picky Eaters to Plant-Powered Pros: How I Raised 4 Happy Vegan Kids (Tips & Tools That Worked!)         üå± Our Vegan Parenting Journey: Chaos, Compassion, and Raising Healthy Little Humans   When I first decided to raise my four kids vegan, I braced for meltdowns‚Äîboth theirs and mine. Fast-forward to today, and my teens happily meal-prep tofu scrambles, my youngest begs for ‚Äúcheezy‚Äù kale chips, and all of them proudly share their vegan values with friends. But let‚Äôs be real: this journey wasn‚Äôt Instagram-perfect. From navigating birthday party pizza temptations to soothing skeptical grandparents, we‚Äôve learned (and laughed) through it all. In this post, I‚Äôm sharing our family‚Äôs wins, mistakes, and Amazon affiliate-linked lifesavers that made raising vegan kids not just possible, but joyful.   Why We Chose Vegan Parenting: A Family‚Äôs Story As parents, we wanted to nurture kindness‚Äîfor animals, the planet, and their own bodies. But transitioning four kids (ages 2 to 12 at the time!) to a plant-based diet felt daunting. The turning point? My oldest daughter, then 8, tearfully asked, ‚ÄúWhy do we eat animals if we love them?‚Äù That‚Äôs when we committed to veganism‚Äînot just as a diet, but as a values-driven lifestyle.      Key Lesson: Involve kids in the why. We watched documentaries like Paying to kill: Safari Hunting Tourism together and visited animal sanctuaries. When they understood the impact, their choices became proud, not forced.   Nutrition Wins (and Fails!): Keeping 4 Kids Thriving Balancing nutrients for growing bodies was my biggest worry. Here‚Äôs what worked:¬†Protein Hacks: Blending silken tofu into smoothies (they never noticed!) and using this foolproof tofu press for crispy nuggets. Iron Fixes: Lentil ‚Äúmeatballs‚Äù became a weekly staple. Pro tip: Serve with lemonade (vitamin C boosts iron absorption!). B12 Solutions: We use this berry-flavored B12 spray‚Äîmy kids call it their ‚Äúsuperpower sprinkle.‚Äù Snack Attacks: Homemade energy balls with oats, nut butter, and chia seeds saved countless after-school meltdowns. Fail Moment: My ‚Äúhidden beet brownies‚Äù turned everyone‚Äôs teeth pink. Lesson learned: Let kids see the veggies they‚Äôre eating!    Meal Prep for Busy Families: Survival Mode Activated With four kids, efficiency is key. Our MVP tools: Instant Pot : From 20-minute lentil soups to quinoa bowls, this kept us sane during soccer-practice nights.   Freezer-Friendly Containers : Batch-cooking veggie chili and muffin-tin oatmeal bites meant always having ‚Äúfast food‚Äù on hand. Kid-Tested Recipe: ‚ÄúCan‚Äôt-Believe-It‚Äôs-Vegan‚Äù Mac & Cheese   Blended cashews, nutritional yeast, and butternut squash became our go-to comfort food. Even the pickiest eater (yes, you, Jake!) licked the bowl.        Social Hurdles: Birthday Parties, Holidays & Judgy Relatives Grandma‚Äôs turkey dinners and school pizza days tested our resolve. Here‚Äôs how we coped:   Birthday Party Rule: Always bring a vegan cupcake and a extra to share. These allergy-friendly cupcakes¬† won over even the skeptics.   Grandparent Diplomacy: We hosted a ‚Äúvegan Thanksgiving‚Äù with stuffed squash and mushroom gravy‚Äînow it‚Äôs a yearly tradition!   School Solutions: Partnered with teachers to add plant-based options to hot lunch programs.   Proud Mama Moment: My 14-year-old recently gave a class presentation on factory farming‚Äîarmed with facts and vegan cookies!        Affordable, Eco-Conscious Swaps That Grew With Us Baby Days: Used BPA-free silicone feeders for frozen peach purees‚Äîmess-free teething relief!   Toddler Phase: Splat Mat + Easy-Clean Bibs saved my floors from avocado explosions.   Big Kids: Stainless steel bento boxes for zero-waste lunches and DIY ‚Äúsnackle‚Äù boxes.   You‚Äôve Got This: Tips for Staying Motivated Celebrate Small Wins: When my son chose hummus over chicken nuggets at a friend‚Äôs house, we threw a living room dance party.   Find Your Tribe: Local vegan playgroups and Facebook communities kept us inspired.   Flexibility > Perfection: Accidentally non-vegan cookies at a bake sale? We shrugged it off and kept going.      Join Us! Resources That Made All the Difference Book: Vegan Cook Book For Kids ‚Äîpractical advice for handling school, travel, and more.   Documentary: Kid-Friendly Vegan Film‚Äîsparked heartfelt dinnertime convos. Final Thought: It‚Äôs Worth Every Veggie-Packed Bite Raising vegan kids isn‚Äôt always easy, but watching them grow into compassionate, healthy humans makes every challenge worth it. Trust your instincts, lean on community, and remember: even small steps create lasting change.

author: Jill Filipovic
title: "I think people are afraid to learn about what is happening to animals because they are afraid of the grief they will feel."
text: Subscribe now I first read The Sexual Politics of Meat as a college student, newbie feminist, and not-so-new animal advocate. Like many girls, sympathy and love for animals were animating emotions of my young life. My first attempt at organizing was getting my fellow fourth graders to write letters to Johnson & Johnson demanding they cease testing their products on animals. I stopped eating meat when I was ten and didn‚Äôt start again until I was in my 20s, and only then because I felt rude refusing food while traveling and staying with host families (the first meat I ate as an adult was horse, and I felt awful about it).  At the time I read The Sexual Politics of Meat, I was 20 and had been a pescatarian for roughly a decade, but still wasn‚Äôt convinced that the struggle for women‚Äôs rights tied in with advocacy for animals. The Sexual Politics of Meat didn‚Äôt turn me into a vegan, but it did change how I think about the way I eat, and how I think about animals and our relationship to them. And it did present a fascinating and challenging framework for understanding how power, dominance, and patriarchy aren‚Äôt confined only to relationships between men and women, but infiltrate many other aspects of our lives as well ‚Äî and especially how we relate to the non-human animals that humans dominate and mistreat on industrial scales.  When I got an email from Carol Adams, the author of The Sexual Politics of Meat, about her book turning 35, I jumped at the chance to ask her some of the questions that I‚Äôve been thinking about for (no joke) the last 20 years. Below is a Q&A we conducted over email. I hope you find it as enlightening and fascinating as I did. And if you haven‚Äôt read The Sexual Politics of Meat, its 35th birthday is a great time to pick it up.  Subscribe now Jill: First, congrats on The Sexual Politics of Meat turning 35! What a milestone. What was the original genesis of the book? What inspired it?Carol: Thanks! Phew. 35 years! It‚Äôs one of many examples‚Äîthough who needed any more of them?‚Äîthat we feminists are in this for the long run. We have to be. The idea for the book came fifty years ago this past October. I moved to Cambridge, Mass and become a vegetarian in the midst of a vibrant Boston feminist community, even finding my roommates by searching the bulletin board of the Cambridge Women‚Äôs Center for feminist households looking for vegetarians. I was taking courses on feminist ethics and women‚Äôs history, and one, at Harvard Divinity School on feminist metahistory. I was reading manuscripts at The Arthur and Elizabeth Schlesinger Library on the History of Women in America at Radcliffe. That was the setting, one month into my vegetarianism, as, one day, I walked toward Harvard Square. My mind constantly turns over ideas I encounter, holding diverse content in tension. Fifty years ago, because of all I was reading, I began to hold the ideas of feminism and vegetarianism in tension (suffragists who were vegetarian, literary works that tied together these two issues, etc.) and so as I walked, I asked myself, ‚Äúwhat‚Äôs going on?‚Äù If dialectical thinking involves asking dialectical questions, the result sometimes is an epiphany, which happened to me between the Erewhon Store on Massachusetts Avenue and the Harvard Coop. The answer to my question, I realized, was that there was a connection between meat eating and male dominance, between feminism and vegetarianism, and with that insight, I felt myself levitating off the sidewalk. Then came the years of figuring out how to say this. Early attempts were published in 1970s feminist publications, and a small press invited me to write a book on the subject. That forthcoming book was mentioned in the mid 19780s edition of Our Bodies, Ourselves, but I withdrew it. I figured I would have only one chance to make my point, and that version wasn‚Äôt it. I remember friends saying, ‚Äúbut what if someone else beats you to it?‚Äù And I shrugged, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs okay. If someone else can figure this out, great!‚Äù During ten years of being a rural activist in Western New York against poverty, racism in housing, and domestic violence, I kept reading, feeling the idea pulsing within, k noting new connections. I thought my mid-1980s manuscript was better and obtained an agent, but it was soundly rejected by major New York publishers. In 1987, we‚ÄîBruce, my spouse, I, and our 2 1/2 year old son‚Äîdrove from Western New York to Dallas, Texas. Bruce was going to pursue a ministry with the homeless and I would devote myself to completing my manuscript. On our second night on the road, we stayed in Arkansas. Reading Margaret Homans‚Äôs Bearing the Word before going to bed, I encountered the literary concept of the absent referent. I thought, ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt this what animals are when they are killed and eaten?‚Äù I must have continued to engage with this idea in my sleep, because I woke up thinking, ‚ÄúAnd that‚Äôs what women are too, absent referents in a culture structured to deny and thwart our subject status.‚Äù And then, ‚ÄúIsn‚Äôt that what links the oppression of women and animals in a patriarchal culture, that they are overlapping and interconnected absent referents?‚Äù That‚Äôs when I felt everything I had been working on for fifteen years come together. I remember reading The Sexual Politics of Meat as a college-age vegetarian, and finding it both fascinating and quite provocative. What was the response when it came out? How did feminists respond to it? How did non-feminists?Well, you probably won‚Äôt be surprised that the word ‚Äúprovocative‚Äù attached to it immediately! Publishers Weekly called it an ‚Äúoriginal, provocative book‚Äù and Library Journal said it was ‚Äúan important and provocative work.‚Äù The usual suspects (conservative media) found the idea laughable. The tabloid London Sunday Express called it ‚ÄúDotty title of the year.‚Äù Rush Limbaugh had just entered the talk radio world, and he used my book as part of his shtick to arouse the anger of his rightwing followers against ‚Äúpolitical correctness.‚Äù The book debuted at the 1990 Modern Language Association meeting. In the Exhibits Hall, publishers hung posters announcing new books above their booths. My publisher and the behemoth publisher Harper Collins were next to each other at the main entrance. Dominating the space above the booth was a large reproduction of the cover of The Sexual Politics of Meat. Several years later, I met a HarperCollins editor who had been there. She told me that in her years exhibiting books at the MLA she had never seen anything like the excitement she witnessed that year as conference attendees entered the hall, beheld the book cover, and swamped the booth. A few feminist booksellers told me animal rights activists bought the book in hardcover but heard feminists saying they were going to wait for the paperback. (I think I can understand that‚Äî animal rights theory in 1990s was like feminist theory in the early 1970s‚Äîeach new book introduced wildly exciting ideas, and you didn‚Äôt want to wait to read them.) When I applied the concept of the absent referent to the status of animals and women and explained its function in creating overlapping or interwoven connections, I offered a new theoretical vocabulary. Throughout the 1980s, the majority of books addressing the status of animals were philosophical in approach and focused solely on non-human animals. But, The Sexual Politics of Meat offered a different framework, arguing we could not understand the status of animals, especially those who are consumed by humans, without looking at the patriarchal culture in which this exploitation occurred. Graduate students wrote to say it liberated them to claim the topics they wanted to write about for their doctoral theses. I found one comment, laughingly ironic. A feminist English professor told another she didn‚Äôt want to read the book because she might have to become a vegetarian. When I heard this, I thought, ‚ÄúBut isn‚Äôt that why we read feminist theory?‚Äù Ms. Magazine seemed to agree in their mention of it. ‚ÄúRead this powerful new book and you may well become a vegetarian.‚Äù It was briefly stopped at the Canadian border for having a supposed pornographic cover. Completely unexpected was the amount of mail I received. Readers began to send me examples they found of the sexual politics of meat, like photographs of billboards and menus. Animal rights activists who monitored animal agriculture publications sent me advertisements found there, saying ‚ÄúIt is so good to have someone to send this to who gets it.‚Äù It‚Äôs one reason I say that my readers showed me my work wasn‚Äôt done. I‚Äôd look at these images and think ‚Äúyuck‚Äù and then ‚Äúoh‚Äù‚Äîfrom repulsion to insight; look what they are saying about animals and women here! A rock band reached out wanting to create a track of the sexual politics of meat for their next CD. (You can listen to it here.) And my mail, though it is now email, not snail mail, continues to arrive. You write about patriarchal attitudes toward women, and how those play out in the attitudes toward and treatment of animals. Can you expand a bit on that? (I realize this is the thesis of the whole book, but for people who haven't read it, give us the highlights!).The Sexual Politics of Meat identifies the patriarchal context for the Western world‚Äôs commitment to meat eating, and dairy and egg consumption. It proposes that women‚Äôs oppression and animals‚Äô exploitation are overlapping and interconnected. Some of its main themes include: * The association of meat eating and masculinity: entire cultures were deemed ‚Äúvirile‚Äù because of the large amount of animal flesh consumed. This is tied to racist colonial attitudes, too. I argue that ‚ÄúRacism is perpetuated each time meat is thought to be the best protein source.‚Äù I suggest that meat eating functions as a marker that legitimates the gender binary system and the gender binary system uses the sexual politics of meat to define who men should be: ‚Äúreal men,‚Äù not ‚Äúsissies,‚Äù not ‚Äúeffeminate.‚Äù Men are expected to keep participating in the construction of manhood by eating animals. Otherwise, they face being abjected and feminized. * Behind every meal of meat is an absence: the death of the animal whose place the meat takes. This is the absent referent; it separates the meat eater from the animal and the animal from the end product. Once the existence of flesh is disconnected from the existence of a nonhuman animal who was killed to become that product, ‚Äúmeat‚Äù becomes unanchored by its original referent (the nonhuman animal), becoming instead a free-floating image, a metaphor, unbloodied by suffering. In this way, feeling like a piece of meat functions as a metaphor for women‚Äôs experience. * Women, too, become absent referents in a misogynistic world, visually fragmented and consumed. The consumed object is experienced without a past, without a history, without a biography, without individuality. And so we see how the women are animalized and animals feminized and sexualized. (Find examples here.) The result is interrelated yet not equivalent oppressions in the treatment of women and the treatment of animals. * It offers a feminist analysis of the politics of language and shows how a dominant culture mutes the radical analysis that challenges it, whether feminist or vegetarian/vegan. * It proposes the term feminized protein to name precisely the exploitation of the reproductive processes of female animals in the production of mammalian milk and eggs. I wanted a term that, I hoped, would unsettle the sexual commodification of female animals. * It explores examples of historical, contemporary, and fictional resistance to meat eating and argues that food decisions are coded forms of feminist resistance, and that feminist theory logically contains a vegan critique. In the 35 ensuing years, what has changed in terms of the cultural conversation around feminism, vegetarianism/veganism, and the intersection of the two? What about the book still feels resonant? Are there parts that you feel we've made progress on?Lord! It is exhausting being the author of a book I wish were no longer relevant! Yes, there is some progress: the word ‚Äúvegan‚Äù is more widely known. Progress, too, in the embrace of the flavors of vegetables, found in restaurants like Dirt Candy, Vedge, and Plant, and interest in vegan meals by mainstream chefs. Major newspapers feature vegan recipes. Certainly, there are more articles about the link between masculinity and meat eating, but often the discussion contains an air of mystification, a mainstream media that says, ‚Äúgosh, what could be going on here?‚Äù I‚Äôm excited by the reclamation of the food heritage of pre-Conquest peoples, led by vegans of color, like the AfroVegan Society and Food Empowerment Project. Diverse, vibrant, incisive voices advance our understanding: Breeze Harper, the Ko sisters (Aph and Syl), Claire Jean Kim, Maneesha Deckkha, B√©n√©dicte Boisseron, and Margaret Robinson are among the authors addressing white supremacy, colonialism, and animal oppression. There‚Äôs progress in the fact that the gender binary has been exposed to be a cultural construction. But as we know there is a huge reactionary pushback. In the binary world of the sexual politics of meat, there is no gender fluidity, no exception to what ‚Äúreal‚Äù men eat. Even if they don‚Äôt mean to, vegetarian and vegan men illustrate how unsettled ideas of ‚Äúmanhood‚Äù are. Add to that, white supremacists began to claim meat and dairy as part of white power. I see this as a reaction to the election of Barack Obama. (There‚Äôs an extra coding about whiteness here because it is mainly white people who are able to drink cow‚Äôs milk because they have the enzyme that digests milk.) Certainly, for feminist issues, the loss of Roe in 2022 continues to be devastating; it let loose a pernicious misogyny costing women‚Äôs lives, our ability to make decisions about our bodies, curtailing free speech, emptying some red states of gynecologists and obstetricians. In the abortion debate, women are the absent referents. And, surprise! livestock imagery appeared immediately after the terribly dishonest Dobbs decision in 2022 was announced. That day, protesters headed to the Supreme Court. As they gathered, a postcard was distributed with a photo of a pregnant cow, with the words ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs a term for creatures not permitted to control their reproduction. That term is LIVESTOCK.‚Äù And that is the absent referent. Are animals only metaphors for our oppression? In fact, the belief that others can make decisions about someone else‚Äôs pregnancy is at the heart of animal agriculture, hidden in plain sight. Controlling female reproduction is the key to profits. And the images that accompany these discussions often qre of sexualized female animals who ‚Äúwant‚Äù to be pregnant, who ‚Äúwant‚Äù to give the man one extra piglet a year. Here, women were the absent referents. Like many representations promoting the consumption of dead animals, where we encounter sexy pigs, sexy cows, sexy chickens begging to be consumed, another being appears in place of ‚Äúwoman,‚Äù yet the fact of sexualized dominance is still present. In our culture, today, the patriarchal cultural commitment to consuming animals and feminized protein remains dominant. Not only our loss of the protection of the right to abortion but the alignment of Christian nationalism with Trump strengthens patriarchal attempts to control women. It seems women have become more of an absent referent now then when the book was published. And so, I keep updating the book and my publisher remains committed to bringing out new editions. You've changed the subtitle from "A Feminist-Vegetarian Critical Theory" to "A Feminist-Vegan Critical Theory." Why?The title clarifies its theoretical commitments. The word vegetarian had become more opaque in this regard. Dairy: yes or no? Eggs: yes or no? In the 1980s, the term ‚Äúcomplete vegetarian‚Äù meant vegan in terms of food choice and it reflected a radical commitment. As the word ‚Äúvegan‚Äù became more widely known, vegetarianism became associated with consumption of dairy and eggs, and the earlier subtitle was now retrograde, unreflective of the theory inside the book. It‚Äôs an example of how I try to keep the book updated. With any new development, the question I try to answer is: Does this new development illustrate something I have already discussed, extend, or complicate a part of my theory? It‚Äôs not about examples accumulating (and wow have they!), but does the conceptual framework I offered 35 years ago continue to help understand the cultural dynamics in the 2020s? And sadly, yes. Do you think the response to the book would be different today?Yes and no. Yes, terms that were unfamiliar as I finished the book in 1989 like ‚Äúintersectional‚Äù or ‚Äúvegan‚Äù are now more familiar. In addition, ecofeminism is more widely accepted now as an activist and academic approach. Back in the early 1990s it was viewed suspiciously by some feminists as being ‚Äúessentialist,‚Äù that is, that we reinforced gender stereotypes. It was a case of the analysis being mistaken for what we were analyzing‚Äîa culture teeming with gender stereotypes that spilled over and informed attitudes toward the Earth and animals. The book itself influences how we receive it now by having helped to create the intellectual climate for discussing the connections between oppression of humans and the other animals. Still, many feminists and progressives respond to my approach saying, ‚ÄúWe have to solve human problems first before we consider animals.‚Äù What if how we view and treat animals influences how we treat humans? I am uneasy with the popular feminist slogan ‚ÄúFeminism is the radical notion that women are human‚Äù because it accepts the belief that concept of ‚Äúhuman‚Äù is settled and inclusive. But the concept of ‚Äúhuman‚Äù is neither of those things; racist, patriarchal, and rationalist attitudes are embedded in our concepts of ‚Äúhuman.‚Äù Similarly, disempowered groups of people are made more vulnerable by being animalized. This happens not just with women, but people of color. Think of the Republican view of undocumented immigrants (J.D. Vance and Trump claiming ‚Äúthey‚Äù were eating the cats). In addition, animal agriculture causes human crises. A third of global greenhouse gas emissions associated with climate change are emitted by cattle and sheep. Why else were all the big meat companies at the recent Cop29 Climate Summit? And don‚Äôt get me started on pandemics and their relationship to use of animals! Right now, human cases of bird flu (H5N1) (which replicates in the udders of cows) have been identified. Whatever progress has occurred, there‚Äôs a sense that factory farms are here to stay. Indeed, an intense reaction against my ideas persists that, ironically, often proves my argument. Now it‚Äôs not Rush Limbaugh inciting his followers to write universities where I am scheduled to speak, but right-wing blowhards like the Canadian academic, Jordan Peterson. (In October, Canada‚Äôs prime minister, Justin Trudeau that Peterson, along with Tucker Carlson was funded by Russia.) Peterson discovered he had an opinion about my ideas after hearing me participate in a debate at the Oxford Union in November 2021, defending the motion ‚ÄúThis House Holds It Should Move Beyond Meat.‚Äù I was one of three people, but my feminist-vegan argument disturbed Peterson, especially because I inserted a disparaging comment about his belief that men represent order and women chaos. Or it might have been that his daughter, who advocates a diet only of red muscle, argued against the motion. First Peterson appeared on Joe Rogan and described my ‚Äútwisted‚Äù ideas. When the Oxford Union uploaded the videos from the debate to YouTube, Peterson linked to it on his twitter account, saying ‚ÄúWhen the left goes too far.‚Äù As he knew they would, his followers rushed to the YouTube site. Most of the 5,000 plus comments are not quite as polite as the take downs of the book by the likes of novelist Auberon Waugh in 1990, when he suggested my book had been written by an Eastern European male √©migr√©, but they offer a researcher much proof on the persistence of the belief in the sexual politics of meat! It‚Äôs a worldview of misogyny and entitlement, unhappily challenged. There are so many parts of this book that resonated with me, but the one I have often recalled in the decades since I first read the book was your criticisms of the actions of people who work in the meat industry -- the way the men who work in it treat animals, sometimes abusing them for sport, and how that desensitizes people to the abuse of human animals (and particularly women), too. There has been so much criticism of factory farming and the meat industry, but I have rarely seen that criticism take the approach you did. For people who haven't read the book, can you tell us a little bit about what you found / detailed in the book, and if you've seen any shifts in the past almost four decades? Or are things as cruel and misogynist as ever?Are things as cruel and misogynist as ever? I‚Äôd say even more so. The sexual manipulation of all farmed animals is inherent to animal agriculture. There is a fascinating paper on how laws against bestiality need to make exceptions for contemporary farming practices in the statutes because, in other contexts they would be seen as sex with animals. (The author points out that the distinction is made not in relation to what animals experience but because this is what capital needs.) We know that farmed animals are sexually abused, described in Ted Genoways‚Äô The Chain: Farm, Factory, and the Fate of Our Food and summarized here. In terms of slaughterhouse workers, when you think about it, who chooses to slaughter animals on a fast moving dis-assembly line if they have other choices? It‚Äôs a job with a high turnover rate, and one of the highest injury rates. This is why so many undocumented workers are employed there. (If Trump succeeds in his cruel vision of expelling undocumented immigrants, the price of meat could sky rocket.) Children are working in slaughterhouses now, often as part of the clean up crew; clean up is equally dangerous, blood-covered floors are slippery; butchering implements are sharp. The workers themselves become absent referents in the great cog of meat production. What I say in the book is: ‚Äúthe worker on the assembly line becomes treated as an inert, unthinking object, whose creative, bodily, emotional needs are ignored‚Ä¶.They, more than anyone, must accept on a grand scale the double annihilation of self‚Ä¶.They must view the living animal as the meat that everyone outside the slaughterhouse accepts it as, while the animal is still alive.‚Äù (See a discussion of slaughterhouse workers here.) Researchers have found that, of all employees at a slaughterhouse, employees on the kill floor or handling the animals‚Äô dead bodies evidenced the highest prevalence rates of aggression, anxiety, and depression. And some researchers have found a link between areas where there are slaughterhouses and interpersonal violence. These are the workers who were sacrificed to die during the pandemic because of the collusion of meat companies with the Trump administration. But because of the structure of the absent referent, consumers are desensitized to the costs to workers and their families of working at slaughterhouses. Did meat consumption drop when national newspapers reported about the collusion of the Trump administration and meat companies that led to the death of slaughterhouse workers? Did meat consumption drop with the reports of children working in slaughterhouses? Or of prisoners carted across state lines to work in slaughterhouses? Or of the sexual abuse of animals in factory farms? Consumers‚Äô ongoing demand for cheap meat sustains the industry and every cruel, misogynistic act at its center. One new wellness trend is colostrum in beauty products. I'm not a vegan, but the first time I saw this it stopped me in my tracks / broke my heart a little bit. Have you seen similar trends / products / dynamics since the book first published that have surprised or shocked you as well? If you were re-writing this book today, what would you add to it?The marketing of colostrum truly is a heartrending example of how human exceptionalism‚Äîthe belief that we are better, smarter, significantly different from other animal in ways that matter ethically‚Äîand capitalism together permit the monetizing of anything from animals, no matter the consequences for the animals themselves. In this case, it‚Äôs the discovery that the first milk from a cow after giving birth can be marketed for ‚Äúgut health‚Äù or ‚Äúskin care.‚Äù Colostrum is the name for that nutrient-rich first milk which calves need to thrive. But any milk the calves suck from their mothers takes profit away from the farmer. In a world where the calf is but a byproduct of the dairy industry, the calf‚Äôs health is not the primary priority; nor that cows mourn for weeks after having their calf taken from them. (Which is why the industry is trying to genetically engineer cows to be less attached to their offspring to increase efficiency.) The cow‚Äôs forced pregnancy is necessary to bring her milk back in. Calves may be auctioned off‚Äîsometimes just hours old, or carried by wheelbarrow to a hutch, to become a veal calf, destined for someone‚Äôs plate. Kathryn Gillespie‚Äôs The Cow with Ear Tag #1349 describers calves at an auction so young, the umbilical cords were still attached to them. It makes me think of Mary Oliver‚Äôs poem, ‚ÄúLead,‚Äù which begins ‚ÄúHere is a story to break your heart‚Äù and she describes a loon dying, of how the loon ‚Äúlifted its head and opened/ the elegant beak and cried out/ in the long, sweet savoring of its life/ which, if you have heard it,/ you know is a sacred thing.‚Äù You ask about other trends that shock me. Well, the short list would include: * The emergence of the locavore movement and its relationship to white supremacy, Christian nationalism, and misogyny identified by Vasile Stanescu here, and explained more fully in John Sanbonmatsu‚Äôs forthcoming book, The Omnivore‚Äôs Deception. Locavore farmers claim cows have ‚Äúonly one bad day‚Äù‚Äîthe day they are shot in the head. Why, then, are there so many reports of ‚Äúproblematic‚Äù ‚Äústubborn‚Äù cows, like the ones who resist having their calves removed? * The increasing popularity of gas chambers to kill poultry. (First used in the UK in 1996.) The use of carbon dioxide is painful to the birds. Or that some high schools sponsored chicken slaughter projects. * The passing by many states of ‚ÄúAg Gag Laws‚Äù outlawing the gathering of information about abuses of animals by undercover investigation, described by Will Potter in Green is the New Red. * The rocketing to celebrity fame of Temple Grandin, who asserted that she could know that animals are not afraid when slaughtered and meat eaters happily accepted her essentializing of her autism in making that claim. * Meanwhile, butchering has been claimed to be a ‚Äúreal‚Äù ‚Äúhonest‚Äù relationship with animals and taken up by women as a form of liberation, through which ‚Äúmeaning and purpose‚Äù are discovered. (And the way the New York Times, especially its style section, is fascinated by this trend.) I write new introductions for new editions, to incorporate trends that relate to my thesis. All in all, it continues to do the work of raising consciousness I envisioned for it. The sanctimonious vegan / vegetarian is a cultural trope. So is the sanctimonious feminist. In your many decades doing this work, what have you found to be most persuasive to people who may initially balk at vegan feminism?I wish I had a perfect answer. I think philosopher Mary Midgley got it right when she described the gestalt shift that separates meat eaters and vegetarians, non vegans and vegans: they see life; we see death. Feminists and non-feminists? We see equality as a good; they see us as disruptive, threatening, disempowering. The beneficiaries of oppression experience it as pleasurable. Who wants to have their pleasure taken away? The question becomes: how does consciousness change? The next line in Mary Oliver‚Äôs poem, ‚ÄúLead,‚Äù after ‚ÄúHere is a story/to break your heart‚Äù Is ‚ÄúAre you willing?‚Äù Language is at the heart of how the absent referent functions so that the victims disappear. We are not supposed to use language that is accurate because it‚Äôs treated as emotional. How do we explain what‚Äôs going on without falling into the normalized and naturalized language of meat and dairy and egg consumption? Phrases like ‚Äúcow separated from calf,‚Äù ‚Äúforced pregnancy,‚Äù ‚Äúactively disabling animals,‚Äù come with heightened emotional registers even if they accurately describe what is happening. The patriarchal exaltation of reason‚Äîso central in Western philosophy and the sciences‚Äîwas, and continues to be, a profound obstacle to making the world more just and compassionate. Refuse to be an accomplice, the great 20th century French mystic Simone Weil said. But that requires recognizing where we have become accomplices! What seemed a menu choice, is actually a pledge to the oppressors‚Äîwe will continue to support you. After helping my sisters and my father care for my mother after she developed Alzheimer‚Äôs disease, I find that the most important thing I can do is help people think about grief. I think people are afraid to learn about what is happening to animals because they are afraid of the grief they will feel. The hostile patriarchal rejection of emotion provides little modeling of living with grief; three days off for a funeral, etc. But for vegans, grief is a part of our lives. We cannot not know these things. Grief is a gift that we are given, and we learn to welcome it, ‚Äúoh there you are grief, you are a reminder of why I care, but you, grief, won‚Äôt kill me.‚Äù This is not grief that goes nowhere and has nothing it can do about the problem. Grief is part of being an aware citizen in the world right now, and that grief can be mobilized for the good. It is fighting always against this patriarchal human-centered culture that says it gets to decide who matters. Mary Oliver‚Äôs poem concludes: ‚ÄúI tell you this/ to break your heart,/ by which I mean only/ that it break open and never close again/ to the rest of the world.‚Äù What if we said: ‚Äúhere you are grief, I welcome your return. You are a reminder of my connection to the world and to others. You exist within me because I have chosen to care.‚Äù Other than picking up a copy of The Sexual Politics of Meat, what books would you recommend to readers?There are so many brilliant younger feminist scholars working on these issues and important activist groups making clear the connections between social justice and attention to animals. I have referred to some already, but Chlo√´ Taylor‚Äôs magisterial Gender and Animals, a 744-page long collection that came out in June brings together many of the writers. You can find the table of contents here. Meanwhile, The Unbound Project highlights the work of more than 150 women around the world at the forefront of animal advocacy. There is Sunaura Taylor‚Äôs Beasts of Burden: Animal and Disability Liberation. She and her sister Astra also did a thorough analysis of ‚ÄúThe Socialist Feminist Case for Animal Liberation‚Äù for Lux. Incredible feminist scholarship on dairy exists now: from Kathryn Gillespie‚Äôs beautifully-moving The Cow with Ear Tag #1389 who describes the complete sexual commodification of the dairy cow to Jessica Eisen‚Äôs powerful ‚ÄúMilked: Nature, Necessity, and American Law‚Äù on the dairy industry for the Berkeley Journal of Gender, Law & Justice. Among the numerous insights she offers is how notions of privacy hide what is happening on the farm. And then there is Yamini Narayanan‚Äôs award-winning Mother Cow, Mother India: A Multispecies Politics of Dairy in India. In Animal Crisis: A New Critical Theory, feminist philosophers Alice Crary and Lori Gruen offer an exciting, accessible animal ethics that includes the argument that there can be no animal liberation without human emancipation. Laura Wright‚Äôs The Vegan Studies Project: Food, Animals, and Gender in the Age of Terror is a valuable feminist exploration of contemporary culture that considers how the vegan body is a contested site of meaning. I‚Äôd recommend the poetry of Kathryn Kirkpatrick, whose forthcoming Creature is a powerful meditation on creaturely existence. I think also of poet and activist Gretchen Primack‚Äôs Kind which includes a poem, ‚ÄúLove This‚Äù that stops my heart every time I read it (and which is included in The Sexual Politics of Meat). Your readers might be interested in the VINE Book Group. VINE, a LGBTQ-led farmed animal sanctuary, hosts a monthly book discussion, (VINE was the first to show roosters bred for cock fights could be rehabilitated and didn‚Äôt need to be killed. It‚Äôs a fascinating example of challenging human ideas about gender as they were imposed on these beautiful birds. Check out ‚ÄúThe Issues‚Äù at the Food Empowerment Project‚Äôs website, covering an exhaustive number of important topics associated with food production‚Äîfrom environmental racism to animal agriculture workers to colonization; the politics informing social justice veganism couldn‚Äôt be made clearer. And then, you can check out their Mexican, Filipino, Lao, or Chinese vegan recipes. Finally, Protest Kitchen is a book that might help your readers incorporate more vegan meals (and perhaps veganism?) into their lives. Virginia Messina and I wrote it to make the progressive case for veganism. We envisioned it as The Anti-Trump Diet, but back in early 2017, publishers said, ‚Äúhe won‚Äôt be around that long.‚Äù (It‚Äôs the first time one of my books was rejected because of optimism!) During a time when we feel in the midst of a perpetual political emergency, veganism may be the antistress and antidepression diet we need now. Share Leave a comment

author: Andy Smith
title: Member Spotlight: Freeburger
text:
Encouraging customers to widen their palette and see just how good vegan food can be, Freeburger do things a little differently.
The clue is in the name ‚Äì they quite literally offer up burgers at no charge, free of the kind of tarnishing environmental impact dairy or meat based products can often come with. To find out more about the Freeburger mission and how the operation works, we caught up with owner Leon: 
How did you get into hospitality? 
I got into hospitality because of my frustration that McDonald‚Äôs at the time didn‚Äôt offer a vegan burger. Through about 15 years of research, I had seen a lot of disturbing things in the meat and dairy industry so I slowly transitioned to a fully plant based diet. I decided to build a popup burger bar where all the vegan burgers are free. 
While I was building the stall it just so happened McDonald‚Äôs released the McPlant burger, almost like they saw me coming! It was a mad coincidence, but it was good to see a delicious vegan burger option on such a mass scale, and even better that vegetarians and meat eaters are trying it as an alternative to the norm. 
Earliest food related memory? 
One Christmas when I was about 4 years old mum and dad built this huge gingerbread house. It was far too big for us to eat so it ended up in the garage. Unbeknownst to them, across a period of a couple of days I kept going out there eating chunks of it until it was all gone. I felt so sneaky and it was such a treat. Come to think of it now they probably knew! 
One dish of yours that everyone has to try? 
Well it‚Äôs got to be my vegan burgers! I use different ones from all the supermarkets so people can try them all for free at my popups and if they like them I can tell them where they can buy them. 
What song best summarises your business? 
Rage against the Machine, Killing in the Name Of. The artist name ‚ÄúRage Against the Machine‚Äù reflects my passion to reveal the truth behind the hugely powerful and secretive intensive livestock farming industry. And the killing part is, of course what the industry is based on, but people are often too afraid to look. 
My aim is to increase awareness, without any judgement, so that people can make more informed decisions about what they eat, regardless of what they choose in the end. 
Craziest meal you‚Äôve ever served? 
Being a burger bar my meals are pretty straightforward, basically delicious burgers and fries, but the Spicy Thai Badboy burger that I did at one event went down a storm! 
Are you more of a breakfast, lunch or dinner person? 
For me it‚Äôs got to be a big vegan all day breakfast, which naturally I will eat any time of the day. But I like to spend time making proper from scratch dinners when I‚Äôve got a bit more time. 
Your ultimate guilty food pleasure? 
Pot noodles for sure! 
An independent hospitality business that inspires you? 
Vegan Filth, based in Swansea and Cardiff do the most incredible takeaway fast food. It‚Äôs nicer than anything I‚Äôve ever eaten, even before I went vegan. I‚Äôve met them as well and they‚Äôre next level. 
How do you manage the work / life balance? 
I stop work at 5pm every day and I try not to work weekends. I‚Äôm a carpenter by trade and freeburger is a labour of love which I do for free in my spare time. I try and live a simple life and not chase big houses or showy cars. As such I can spend a bit more time on giving back through the freeburger stall. 
What does success look like to you? 
Success to me is taking some moments to be mindful and grateful for what we have. And if we are fortunate enough, to try to give something back to people, to animals and the planet. 
¬† 
Follow their journey here and find out more about Freeburger here. 
The post Member Spotlight: Freeburger appeared first on NCASS.

author: itstimholman
title: What do vegans eat?
text: From¬†eu.usatoday.com Veganism has attracted millions of participants for decades, which is especially impressive when you learn just how restrictive a vegan diet can really be. And while there are certainly overlapping foods that both¬†vegetarians¬†and vegans avoid, most vegans go a lot further than most vegetarians in terms of what they choose not to eat.¬† Here's what veganism is, what benefits it provides and some of the downsides associated with practicing the lifestyle.¬†Though it may be declining ever-so-slightly in popularity, its supporters are anything but quiet. What is vegan? What do vegans eat?¬†While all vegans share the same goal of wanting to avoid animal products in their diet, their motivations, dietary decisions and overall approach to veganism "can vary from person to person," says Dr. Uma Naidoo, director of nutritional and lifestyle psychiatry at Massachusetts General Hospital and the Harvard-trained nutritional psychiatrist behind "Calm Your Mind with Food." In other words, some vegan diets are most strict and restrictive, while others are more casual and flexible.¬† Generally, though, vegans opt exclusively to eat a¬†plant-based diet¬†‚Äì choosing to not only avoid eating animal meat (as vegetarians do) but to also avoid any foods that come from animals, including dairy products and¬†eggs. Even honey is usually avoided, as it's produced by bees.¬† Vegans also often avoid foods that many people don't think of as being associated with animals. "These include animal-based ingredients like gelatine (used in Jello, supplement capsules, marshmallows, etc.), casein,¬†whey proteins¬†(because they are milk-derived) and food colourings like cochineal ‚Äì a red pigment made from crushed red beetles that's used in food colourings, candies and alcoholic beverages," says Jen Messer, a nutrition consultant and registered dietitian at¬†Jen Messer Nutrition.¬†"Other tricky examples that take careful label reading include kimchi (fish sauce, fish paste), Worcestershire sauce (anchovies) and Caesar dressing (anchovies)."¬† Naidoo says that some vegans also go beyond dietary restrictions by also avoiding the use of any cosmetics that were tested on animals or animal-derived clothing such as leather belts, shoes or fur coats. Overall, "vegans eat plenty of fruits, vegetables, grains, beans, nuts and seeds," says¬†Lisa¬†Young, a registered dietitian nutritionist, author of "Finally Full, Finally Slim" and an adjunct professor of nutrition at New York University. Vegans also commonly eat plant-based substitutes "such as tofu, tempeh, seitan and textured vegetable protein; opt for vegan dairy options like almond, soy or oat milk; and choose plant-based oils, herbs, spices and sweeteners such as maple syrup and¬†agave," adds Messer.¬†¬†   What are the health benefits of being vegan?A vegan diet can be healthy, Messer says, because it is rich in beneficial nutrients that are low or missing from a standard American diet. "Vegan diets tend to be high in dietary fibre¬†from the high intake of legumes, fruits, vegetables and whole grains," she explains; "and they are rich in vitamins and minerals such as vitamin C, potassium and magnesium." Plant-derived phytochemicals and¬†antioxidants¬†commonly consumed in vegan diets also help reduce inflammation and support overall health. Messer says that plant-based diets can also lower one's risk of chronic health issues like heart disease, type 2 diabetes,¬†hypertension, certain cancers and obesity due to a "lower intake of saturated fat and a higher focus on nutrient-dense foods." "And veganism can be beneficial for healthy weight management, due to a high intake of fibre-rich, nutrient-dense foods that are both low in calories and filling," adds Young.¬†   Are there any downsides to being vegan?At the same time, a vegan diet requires careful planning to avoid downsides that come from completely cutting out too many food groups. "Veganism is a form of an elimination diet and with any elimination diet, there are risks of nutrient deficiencies," says Naidoo. For instance, vegan diets can be low on levels of protein,¬†vitamin B12, iron, calcium, omega-3 fatty acids, vitamin D and zinc, says Young. This usually requires vegans to eat fortified foods or take a variety of supplements, especially for nutrients like¬†vitamin B12, which is only found in animal products. Beyond nutrition gaps, there are other downsides of the lifestyle to consider including cost, "as many specialty vegan products like meat substitutes can be expensive," says Messer, "and adopting a vegan lifestyle might be more time-consuming." What's more, "dining out or attending social events can be more challenging to find suitable options, but a bit of planning can mitigate these challenges," she adds. "While veganism comes with potential downsides, including nutrient deficiencies and lifestyle adjustments," says Messer, "it can be a healthy and ethical choice with proper planning."¬† https://eu.usatoday.com/story/life/health-wellness/2025/02/11/what-do-vegans-eat/78089916007/¬†

title: Helping Over 21 Thousand People! Doctor Alan Goldhamer: Vegan Since 1975
text:
**A Life Transformed: Dr.‚Å§ Alan Goldhamer‚Äôs Vegan Journey and the Healing Power ‚Å£of True North** 
Imagine making a life-changing decision‚Å¢ at just 16 years old, one that would not only transform your health ‚Äçbut also set the foundation for a lifelong career dedicated to helping tens ‚Äãof thousands of‚Å§ people find their path to wellness. That‚Äôs exactly the story of Dr. Alan Goldhamer, the visionary behind the True North Health Center. Vegan since 1975, Dr. Goldhamer‚Äôs journey‚Äîfrom ‚Å¢an ambitious teenager looking for ‚Å£an‚Äç athletic edge to a globally recognized advocate‚Å£ for healthful living‚Äîhas been nothing short of inspiring. With over 21,000 people‚Å£ having undergone his fasting‚Å¢ protocols, his‚Å¢ work has proven‚Å£ to be a beacon of hope for those‚Å£ seeking ‚Å£a safe, natural ‚Äåway to revitalize their health.  
In a recent interview, Dr. Goldhamer retraces his roots, from ‚Äçbeing inspired by health pioneers like Dr. William Esser and‚Å¢ Herbert Shelton to studying under experts in Australia and eventually ‚Äçco-founding the True North Health Center with his wife, Dr. Marano. Join us as we explore the ‚Å¢key takeaways from‚Å£ Dr. Goldhamer‚Äôs compelling YouTube talk, delving into his early discoveries, his‚Å£ commitment to documenting the power of lifestyle ‚Äåmedicine, and what it means to truly live in harmony with our bodies. Whether you‚Äôre a wellness enthusiast‚Äå or someone curious about plant-based living, this is ‚Å£a ‚Å£story that will leave you deeply inspired. Let‚Äôs ‚Äådive in! 
Pathways to Healthful‚Å¢ Living Inspired by a Teen Vegan Journey
 

Adopting a health-centered lifestyle at just 16, Dr. ‚Å§Alan Goldhamer delved into the principles of **healthful living**, exploring how diet, exercise, and sleep create the ‚Äåfoundation for longevity and well-being. Inspired by the works ‚Å¢of ‚Å£Herbert Shelton and renowned figures like Dr. William Esser, he discovered how natural hygiene practices could shape a‚Å£ thriving life. His personal journey, fueled by youthful‚Å§ curiosity and a competitive basketball spirit, illuminated the transformative power of ‚Äça vegan lifestyle‚Äînot just for ‚Äåthe game but ‚Äãfor health ‚Äãon a broader‚Äå scale. 
Dr. Goldhamer‚Äôs TrueNorth Health Center has ‚Äçbecome a haven‚Å§ for those seeking holistic recovery. Boasting over **39 years of dedicated practice** and results backed by **peer-reviewed research**, ‚Äçthe center‚Äôs fasting protocols and ‚Äåplant-based‚Äå diets have helped more than **21,000 individuals** regain vitality. Key to success is embracing fundamental‚Å§ habits ‚Äåof healthful living, which include: 

Nutrition: Emphasizing whole, plant-based foods.
Restorative Sleep: Supporting mental and physical recovery.
Physical Activity: Regular‚Å§ exercise tailored to individual‚Å§ needs.

Dr. Goldhamer and his team continue to innovate, blending evidence-based practices with the timeless wisdom of ‚Å¢natural health pioneers‚Äîproving that ‚Å£wellness is more than the absence of illness; it‚Äôs‚Å§ an ‚Å£active pursuit of vibrant living. 

The Pioneers of‚Äã Hygienic Medicine and Their Lasting Legacy
 

Long before nutritional and health trends‚Äç gained mainstream attention, **visionaries like Dr. William‚Å£ Esser, Herbert Shelton, and Dr. Alec Burton** laid the ‚Äågroundwork for ‚Å¢what‚Å§ we now understand as hygienic medicine. These trailblazers championed ideas of health as a result of *healthful living*,‚Å£ emphasizing the power of diet, sleep, and exercise. Their revolutionary ‚Äåapproach became the ‚Å§foundation for practices such as supervised fasting‚Å¢ and whole-food, plant-based ‚Äãlifestyles. These concepts resonated‚Å¢ deeply with a young‚Äç Dr. Alan Goldhamer, sparking a lifelong mission‚Å£ to help others recover and maintain their health ‚Å¢naturally. 
At the heart of this legacy is True North Health Center,‚Å§ co-founded by‚Äã Dr. Goldhamer and Dr. Jennifer Morano. Over the past 39 years, the‚Å§ clinic has guided over **21,000 individuals** through transformative fasting protocols, combining cutting-edge medical research with time-tested principles. Here‚Äôs a glimpse into the pioneers ‚Å¢who inspired this movement: 

Dr. William Esser: Known as the‚Å£ grandfather of hygienic practices, he operated one‚Äã of the first ‚Äçfasting supervision facilities.
Herbert Shelton: Advocated a logical and ‚Å£compelling view of health through natural living.
Dr. ‚ÄåAlec Burton: Mentored Dr. Goldhamer in‚Å§ Australia, teaching the integration of fasting and diet in treating illnesses.

Fasting and Plant-Based Diets‚Å¢ A ‚ÄçModern Approach to Restoring Health
 

At ‚Å§the True North Health Center, fasting synergizes seamlessly with‚Äç a plant-based diet to‚Äå restore health and vitality. Dr. Alan Goldhamer, ‚Å§a pioneer in the field, has been ‚Å£implementing‚Å¢ this holistic approach for decades, ‚Äãinspired by health‚Äã legends like Herbert Shelton and ‚ÄãWilliam Esser.¬†Guided by these principles, the ‚Å£foundation ‚Äãof restoring health lies in embracing‚Äç a lifestyle where diet, sleep, and exercise come together as the cornerstones for longevity and‚Äç well-being.  
Dr. ‚Å§Goldhamer, along‚Äç with his wife, Dr. Morano, has led extensive research and overseen fasting protocols‚Å¢ with over 21,000 individuals at their facility. Their ‚Å¢comprehensive‚Å£ approach has shown that the‚Å§ transformative effects ‚Äåof fasting can be amplified through a low-sodium, whole-food, plant-based eating plan. Consider a few of the core principles they advocate: 

Plant-Based Eating: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains to enhance‚Äç natural healing processes.
Supervised Water Fasting: A safe and effective way ‚Äçto reset ‚Äãthe body under professional‚Å§ care.
Science-Driven Care: Methods‚Äç backed‚Å£ by peer-reviewed research to‚Äç ensure efficacy ‚Äåand safety.

Inside True North Health Center Transforming Lives Through Science and Care
 

At True North Health Center, the transformative power of health-focused living is at the core of everything they do.‚Äç Under the leadership of Dr. Alan Goldhamer, a dedicated vegan since 1975, the ‚Å§center has assisted over 21,000 individuals through its innovative fasting protocols ‚Å§and plant-based ‚Äãdiets. Inspired by‚Äã pioneers such as‚Å§ Dr. William‚Å£ Esser and mentored by Dr. Alec Burton, Dr. Goldhamer‚Å£ integrates‚Å§ science and care to address chronic health concerns while emphasizing the importance of fundamental elements like diet, sleep, and exercise for‚Å§ sustainable well-being. 
True North Health Center not ‚Å§only‚Å§ delivers remarkable patient outcomes but is also at‚Å£ the forefront of clinically documenting its methods. By publishing peer-reviewed research, ‚Äåthe‚Äã team ensures that their approach is recognized ‚Å£as a safe and effective path for ‚Å§health‚Å£ recovery ‚Äåand maintenance.‚Å£ Highlights of their approach include: 

Guided water-only fasting protocols
Plant-based, ‚ÄãSOS-free (Salt, Oil, Sugar) diets
Personalized care‚Å§ supervised by medical professionals

Empowering Lifelong Wellness Lessons from 21000 Success Stories
 

Dr.‚Äå Alan Goldhamer, a pioneering force‚Å¢ in long-term health optimization, credits early inspirations ‚Äçlike Dr. William Esser and Herbert Shelton for igniting‚Äç his journey ‚Äçinto‚Å§ hygienic living. His ‚Å¢philosophy‚Äå centers around the idea that ‚Äã**healthful ‚Äãliving‚Äîdiet, sleep, and exercise‚Äîdetermines both ‚Å£the longevity and quality of life.** With over‚Äå 39 years of ‚Å§dedication and 21,000 success stories from ‚Äçhis TrueNorth Health ‚ÄçCenter,‚Å£ Dr. Goldhamer has‚Å¢ been consistently pushing boundaries to prove the efficacy of fasting and plant-based nutrition. 

Key pillars ‚Äãof wellness: Combining fasting, plant-based diets, and lifestyle modifications.
Scientific ‚Äåfoundation: Published research in peer-reviewed journals to ‚Å¢validate these methods.
Global influence: TrueNorth has become a haven for individuals seeking effective, natural approaches to health recovery.

Builds credibility in natural health ‚Å£approaches



From his teenage dream of becoming a better basketball ‚Å£player to‚Äå helping thousands reclaim their‚Å§ health, **Dr. Goldhamer‚Äôs journey exemplifies the transformative power of a committed,‚Äã evidence-based approach.** His work at TrueNorth ‚Äåcontinues to be a beacon for those seeking sustainable and holistic health solutions. 

The Way Forward
As we wrap up this journey into the remarkable work and perspective ‚Å¢of Dr. Alan Goldhamer, it‚Äôs clear that ‚Å£his efforts at the True North Health Center have touched thousands of‚Å§ lives‚Äîover 21,000, to be exact. From his early adoption of veganism ‚Å§at age 16 to his ongoing commitment to‚Å¢ fasting, diet, and healthful living, Dr. Goldhamer‚Äôs story is one of dedication, curiosity, and the drive to help‚Äç humanity rediscover its potential for wellness.‚Å¢   
Inspired ‚Å£by health pioneers like William Esser, and armed with decades of experience and ‚Å§clinical‚Äå research, ‚Å¢Dr. Goldhamer has not only championed plant-based living but has‚Å¢ helped solidify its place in modern healthcare. Whether ‚Å§it‚Äôs through his fasting protocols or his relentless pursuit of publishing peer-reviewed‚Äã data ‚Å§to validate these ‚Äãmethods, his work reminds us of‚Äã the power of intentional, natural choices ‚Å£in cultivating long-term health. 
While ‚Å£his ‚Å£goal of outplaying his friend Doug Lyle in‚Å¢ basketball might remain elusive, it‚Äôs undeniable that Dr. Goldhamer has scored major victories in the game of life‚Äîhealing, educating, and guiding people, one step at a‚Å§ time, toward a more vibrant existence. So whether you‚Äôre new to the concepts of fasting and plant-based nutrition ‚Å£or already well-versed, there‚Äôs ‚Å£always something to learn from his story and his scientific approach to health. 
Here‚Äôs to continuing the exploration‚Äç of‚Äç wellness, and perhaps, along the way, discovering the tools to live not only longer but better. After all, health truly ‚Äçis the result of ‚Äåhealthful‚Å¢ living.

author: VegNews Editors
title: Michelin Guide Honors 'Superb' Plates London as UK‚Äôs First Vegan Star Recipient
text:
Plates London, a plant-based fine dining restaurant in Shoreditch, has made history as the first vegan establishment in the UK to receive a Michelin star. The prestigious honor, announced at the Michelin Guide Great Britain and Ireland ceremony in Glasgow, recognizes chef Kirk Haworth‚Äôs innovative approach to plant-based cuisine. 
Plates London | Facebook 
Michelin inspectors praised Haworth for ‚Äútaking his classical training and inventively adapting it to a vegan diet.‚Äù The restaurant, co-founded by Haworth and his sister Keeley, offers an intricate seven-course tasting menu for ¬£75 (approximately $93), featuring dishes such as barbecued maitake mushrooms with black bean mole and a raw cacao gateau. Plates London is known for its emphasis on seasonality and innovation, using high-quality produce to create refined dishes that push the boundaries of plant-based gastronomy. 
‚ÄòIt‚Äôs just about flavor‚Äô
At the awards event, Haworth spoke passionately about his culinary philosophy. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just about flavour, that‚Äôs all it‚Äôs about. Flavour, excitement, innovation, and trying to take it to a new space of deliciousness,‚Äù he said. His commitment to plant-based fine dining stems from personal experience, having developed chronic Lyme disease, which led him to embrace a healthier, plant-focused diet. His background working in Michelin-starred restaurants, including The French Laundry and Restaurant Sat Bains, has informed his approach to creating dishes that rival traditional fine dining experiences. 
Plates London | Facebook 

‚ÄúThe service team at Plates have a knack for seeming fully relaxed yet being constantly efficient and switched-on,‚Äù¬†wrote the Michelin inspector. ‚ÄúThey are friendly, personable and slick, allowing the experience to unfold as smoothly as possible. During this particular visit, we were sat at the counter so had the opportunity to engage with the chefs, including Kirk Haworth himself. He is clearly passionate about what he‚Äôs doing here; as someone who‚Äôs going to eat plant-based food for the rest of his life, he‚Äôs on a mission to make sure it‚Äôs as delicious as possible.‚Äù 
According to the inspector, there were a number of things that impressed the team about the cooking at Plates, ‚Äúbut the one that struck me was the strong culinary technique underpinning all the dishes,‚Äù they wrote. ‚ÄúHaworth is a classically trained chef, and you can see that in his impeccably made sauces; what‚Äôs most interesting is how he has adapted this to plant-based ingredients in such a clever way. What‚Äôs more, the depth and balance of the dishes was superb; each one came with layers of flavor and texture that all worked together in brilliant harmony.‚Äù 
Plant-based fine dining on the rise
The rise of plant-based dining has coincided with a surge in vegan food sales, as supermarkets and restaurants expand their offerings to cater to growing consumer demand. According to the Plant-Based Foods Association, sales of plant-based foods in the UK have seen double-digit growth annually, with meat alternatives and dairy-free products becoming staples in mainstream grocery stores. 
Plates London | Facebook 
Large food conglomerates are investing in vegan product lines, and high-end restaurants are recognizing the potential of plant-based cuisine in fine dining. Major retailers such as Marks & Spencer and Tesco have significantly expanded their vegan product ranges in response to this demand. 
Plates London was among an increasing number of plant-based restaurants to receive Michelin recognition in recent years. London has long been home to innovative vegan fine dining, with restaurants such as Pied √† Terre on Charlotte Street offering an extensive plant-based tasting menu. While Pied √† Terre is not exclusively vegan, its dedication to plant-based haute cuisine has earned it a Michelin star and a devoted following. The restaurant‚Äôs inventive dishes, such as miso-roasted aubergine with smoked tofu and truffle-infused risotto, have won widespread acclaim. 
Pied √† Terre 

Beyond the UK, Michelin has acknowledged the excellence of vegan cuisine in major cities worldwide.¬†Eleven Madison Park in New York City transitioned to a fully plant-based menu in 2021 and retained its prestigious three-star rating. Gauthier Soho, under chef Alexis Gauthier, made a similar transition in London, proving that fine dining and veganism are no longer mutually exclusive. The restaurant is known for its vegan take on French classics. 
The increasing presence of plant-based restaurants in the Michelin Guide reflects shifting priorities among both chefs and consumers. Sustainability, ethical sourcing, and innovative flavor combinations are now at the forefront of high-end dining. According to a report by the Good Food Institute, investment in plant-based food innovation has skyrocketed in recent years, with global funding for alternative proteins reaching more than $1.6 billion in 2023. High-profile chefs who once specialized in meat-focused dishes are now pivoting toward plant-based cuisine to meet changing consumer expectations.

author: Nadeem Badshah
title: Plates London becomes first vegan restaurant in UK to win a Michelin star
text: Chef Kirk Haworth impressed judges by ‚Äòtaking his classical training and inventively adapting it to a vegan diet‚Äô A vegan restaurant in London has become the first in the UK to be awarded a Michelin star. Plates London, located on Old Street, serves a fully plant-based menu and chef Kirk Haworth impressed judges by ‚Äútaking his classical training and inventively adapting it to a vegan diet‚Äù, Michelin said.
