author: Mel
title: The Food That You Become
text: ‚ÄòYou are what you eat.‚Äô Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin, a French gastronome, said in 1826. This quote rings true now more than ever. In the name of convenience, food craves, and comfort eating, we‚Äôre turning more and more into a generation of couch potatoes and sugar junkies. The Japanese even have a word for it: Kushi-sabishii, which literally translates into ‚Äòlonely mouth.‚Äô Just why can‚Äôt we stop stuffing our faces? For most of human life, we had to work hard or even fight for food resources. Food was often scarce and not available in the nearby convenience store or with a click on the phone. There were wars, bad harvests, famines, and general poverty. Families ate meat once a week or not at all. Bread was bought from local bakeries. There were food rations during wars and potato thieves to feed their families after wars. Food was locally grown and not transported from Thailand, Spain, or South Africa, and without the pesticides that stick to our fruits and vegetables now. The soil was rich with vitamin B and millions of animals weren‚Äôt slaughtered every second. It was a time most younger generations couldn‚Äôt imagine. We grew up with filled cupboards and fridges and are used to weekly takeaways and going somewhere nice to celebrate. Over time, companies (and families during war times) started to ferment and process food to prolong its shelf life. Pickled and fermented food will last longer than leaving it raw and ready to rot. When society recovered and people became more prosperous in the 50s and 60s, food processing wasn‚Äôt just about shelf-life but began to focus more on taste, texture, and colour. Now we have food scientists who develop the perfect crunch, right softness, perfect packaging, colours, and even sounds (called sonic branding) that make us associate certain foods and beverages with a brand (e.g. Coca Cola and Pringles). Every food is carefully tested and designed to have the right amount of salt, fat, and sugar so that people will keep coming back. We‚Äôve come from eating corn on the cob (natural food) and canned corn (processed), to now eating Doritos, ultra-processed food. So next time you‚Äôre hard on yourself for not being able to stop eating potato crisps or after devouring several bars of chocolate, remember this: It‚Äôs not you. Just like social media apps keep you hooked using basic psychology, so do food companies keep you hooked using basic science. Think of it. Almost all of the foods we now eat are soft. There might be the initial crunch, but then the cheese puff or chip melts on your tongue. You chew less and your brain thinks you‚Äôre eating less than you do. This is what‚Äôs called vanishing caloric density. Some snacks have the same amount of calories as a full meal ‚Äì but you won‚Äôt be full after the snack and crave even more food. It‚Äôs not your lack of brainpower, it‚Äôs the carefully designed food that interferes with your brain signals. And it‚Äôs not just the food itself. Eating is a multi-sensory experience. It‚Äôs the sound of cans popping and plastic bags opening, the colours of children‚Äôs cereals, the cute pictures on yoghurt pots, the branding, and marketing. All perfected to make your belly growl, your mouth lonely, and your brain think, ‚ÄòThis is what I need right now.‚Äô¬† Since 1975, obesity has tripled worldwide. You can‚Äôt blame people from all different walks of life for lack of willpower. It‚Äôs not a coincidence that obesity has started to rise at the same time ultra-processed foods and fast food chains have became more popular. And can we even call most of the food we now eat food? Food grows on trees or in the earth. We eat food to survive and thrive. But what is now filling the aisles in every supermarket is a product, imitating food. It doesn‚Äôt grow naturally but is produced in factories. Ultra-processed foods have been linked with heart attacks and strokes, cancer, inflammatory diseases such as Crohn‚Äôs disease, and mental health problems like depression anxiety, cancer and diabetes. You also have a higher risk of type 2 diabetes. Long story short, the more ultra-processed food you eat the more likelier you are to get sick. The USA and UK are the forerunners of ultra-processed diets. 59% of calories are consumed from ultra-processed food in the USA, and 57% in the UK. More than 38% of the USA population are obese, and 1 in 4 adults are obese in the UK. The easiest way to identify ultra-processed food is by reading the ingredients. They tell you just how processed the food is. May it be emulsifiers, humectants, and stabilisers, gums like xantham gum, guar gum, locus bean gum, or something that sounds harmless like fruit concentrates or natural flavouring, and natural low-calorie sweetness. Next time you go to a supermarket, read the ingredient list of the products you want to buy. How many of those ingredients do you know? Look them up. Then decide if you still want to buy the product. The bad news: it‚Äôs not just ultra-processed foods. All good foods, such as fruits and vegetables are losing their nutrients. Due to mass production and selective breeding of fruits and vegetables, they have lost their richness in vitamins and nutrients. Fish now contain plastic (no surprise, given how much plastic we throw into the ocean). Meat is full of antibiotics, puss, and blood. Even nuts can be contaminated with something that can make you sick. To make things worse, a plethora of self-proclaimed ‚Äòfood experts‚Äô like to scaremonger people by telling them not to consume certain foods and then eat them in the next video. And then, there are the real dangers. Outbreaks like the latest E.Coli at McDonalds, the always returning bird flus and pig flus because we cram too many animals together. The latest pandemic sweeping the planet because of bats sold on Wuhan wet markets. We‚Äôre overdoing it with our food consumption and we‚Äôre paying the price for it. Let‚Äôs talk about plant-based milk, which the EU successfully bullied into now being called ‚Äòplant-based drinks‚Äô since it‚Äôs not dairy milk and it could confuse costumers (by that same logic, we should change the names of the following products: peanut butter, cleansing milk, and fish fingers, just to name a few). Ironically, it‚Äôs not plant-based products that dupe the costumer but the seafood, meat, dairy, and egg industries where food fraud is committed the most. Food fraud is economically motivated adulteration (EMA) in food. Approximately 10% of food in the USA is adulterated. What does this mean? Basically, the food label is lying to you. A classic example is extra virgin olive oil. Many of those are adulterated with cheap oil, and only a small percentage might be actual olive oil. Spices such as turmeric, basil, chili powder, and saffron are also often adulterated. Most consumers aren‚Äôt experts in differentiating fish, so fish can be substituted with other fish quite easily. Food fraud is not just lying to consumers, but it can also be the cause of food poisoning. Worse, substances can also be swapped with non-food substances. So you‚Äôre not even eating actual food. A perfect example of food fraud is the horsemeat scandal that swept Europe in 2013. Horsemeat was mixed with cow‚Äôs meat and sold as 100% beef. Like anything cheap and mass-produced, convenience comes with an environmental cost. Plastic packaging that doesn‚Äôt degrade and cheap, mass-produced ingredients are just to name a few. To make ultra-processed food, 17-39% of diet-related energy is used, 36-45% of diet-related biodiversity is lost, up to a quarter of diet-related water is used (in high-income countries), and up to a third of diet-related greenhouse gas emissions, land use, and food waste is used. Ultra-processed food is the main culprit of harming the environment of all food production. Eating less ultra-processed food and more homemade meals won‚Äôt only make you healthy but also help the planet. A third of all food is thrown away ‚Äì the UK throws away 9.52 tonnes of food every year, that‚Äôs enough to feed 30 million people a year (yet 8.4 million people live in food poverty). Nobody needs to be hungry nowadays, there is enough food for everyone ‚Äì but it‚Äôs rather thrown away than given to people who need it. Food poverty is a problem that can be quickly solved; by giving leftovers to homeless and poor people. Everyone needs to do their part and companies need to be held accountable for their food waste. But wait, Mel, doesn‚Äôt McDonalds have plans to reduce its carbon emissions? Just like Amazon and H&M. Of course they do, because they do want to make us feel good about our purchase. Let‚Äôs assume all these companies really care and want to help the environment. Even if they tried their hardest, it still wouldn‚Äôt be good enough. Because mass consumption (and corporate greed) is the culprit of their gas emissions. McDonalds will never be good for the environment ‚Äì as long as they sell animal products. Beef is a major contributor to climate change. And it‚Äôs not just the methane. 2-5 acres of land are used per cow, 80% of rainforests are deforested for livestock feed, and 2,500 gallons of water are needed to produce 1 pound of beef. Fast food chains and ultra-processed food companies would have to redefine their products to make them less wasteful but instead, they‚Äôre producing triple cheeseburgers. If you want to go green, you‚Äôve got to swap your beef patty with a plant-based patty. This is a reality that can‚Äôt be greenwashed. Fast food and ultra-processed food have become so popular for two reasons: They are convenient and cheap. People either haven‚Äôt got enough time or money; or both. Waiting three minutes for your instant ramen to warm up, a minute for your soup to boil, or even more convenient ‚Äì just getting your hamburger or pizza delivered, are all good alternatives to spending up to an hour in the kitchen to cook a meal. After work, most of us just want to relax, laze on the couch and bite into a cheap burger while watching TikTok videos or Netflix. Fast food is still the most convenient choice but it‚Äôs not as cheap as it used to. Why have all the prices risen? Higher cost of packaging and higher cost of labour. When wages rise, so must the price of the product. Even though sales remained high since the pandemic and rewards and royalty programs make people return and spend their money for a discount or gift, fast food companies have used a staggering amount of their money on advertisement. Featuring celebrities like Justin Bieber, William Pharell, and Kpop artists in ads cost money. Money that needs to be taken from someone. You. And it‚Äôs not just celebrities who entice us to go back to McDonalds & co. The internet abounds with influencers and meokbang performers who stuff their face with an absurd amount of food or the weirdest food combinations. What started in Korea as entertainment for people who eat alone has turned into a weird global phenomenon. Competition is growing and so are the food portions. Needless to say, these people don‚Äôt cook their food like some online mothers make their peanut butter and jelly sandwiches from scratch. They eat ultra-processed food. Free advertisements for food companies or, if the meokbanger is very popular, new sponsors. And all those thousands of people watching them are enticed to eat the same. So what are we, if we are what we eat? Just a body of sugar, emulsifiers, and saturated fat? Cancer-in-the-making, plastic in lungs, or sugar junkies? It‚Äôs up to you to decide. Every day you make the choice for your body. Are you going to give it food that is nourishing and easily digestible or zero-nutrient food that sits heavy in your stomach? When you think about food, don‚Äôt just think about physical health. What you eat also affects your mental health. People on a high-sugar diet are more sluggish and less motivated. The unhealthier you eat, the shittier you‚Äôll feel. Instead of only drinking orange juice and eating vegetables when you‚Äôre sick, how about you eat fruits and vegetables all the time ‚Äì and don‚Äôt even get sick? Prevention is the best medicine. Yes, fruits and vegetables may be less nutritious nowadays but they‚Äôll always be better than fruit drops, microwave meals, and fast food burgers. If you have the space and time, learn to grow your own food. Inform yourself about the food you eat. Take classes or watch cooking videos on YouTube to get motivated. And most of all, take your health seriously! Health might not be everything, but everything is nothing without health. Sources: Why Fast Food Has Gotten So Expensive https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8PTovCIa4c8&ab_channel=CNBC The Price of Fast Food Overconsumption https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bbbOFmN-nZM&ab_channel=Edvasian why can‚Äôt we stop eating certain foods? ‚Äì BBC https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J_03EXyhYS8&ab_channel=BBC How Americans Are Tricked Into Buying Fake Food CNBC https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-8xTVMtkqv4&ab_channel=CNBC Why do we have chemicals in our food? https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ssu3MR6ql4k&ab_channel=CNBCInternational Obesity Rates by Countries 2024 https://worldpopulationreview.com/country-rankings/obesity-rates-by-country https://www.soilassociation.org/blogs/2022/august/24/how-bad-is-ultra-processed-food-for-the-planet/ 1st photo: https://modernfarmer.com/2019/09/researchers-say-overeating-contributes-to-global-food-waste/ Hold the beef: McDonald‚Äôs avoids the bold step it must take to cut emissions https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2021/dec/10/mcdonalds-emissions-beef-burgers

author: shamayimjewishanimaladvocacy
title: Man‚Äôs Best Friend: Navigating the Jewish Relationship with Dogs
text:
Throughout history, the relationship between Jews and dogs has been intricate and varied. Dogs are important members of many contemporary Jewish households, but traditional Jewish texts and cultural views on them have been complex, sometimes even conflicting. 



A Look Back: Difficulties and Inconsistencies



In the past, dogs have frequently been portrayed negatively in Jewish sources. Dogs are occasionally linked in the Bible to immorality, idolatry, and even violence. This unfavorable image stems from ancient, Near Eastern societies where dogs were viewed as filthy and frequently connected to scavenging.¬† 



There is rabbinic literature that reflects these views. There are a few verses in the Talmud that voice concerns regarding dogs in Jewish homes. According to certain rabbinic sources, having a dog is even a sign of uncircumcised behavior. This reflects a historical period in which dogs were not considered beloved pets, but rather guard animals or hunting companions.¬† 



The Holocaust‚Äôs historical trauma has also had a significant influence on Jewish perspectives on dogs. The Nazis‚Äô use of dogs in their antisemitic persecution has permanently altered the Jewish people‚Äôs collective mindset. The SS used snarling dogs to hunt down Jews and this image has come to represent oppression and terror. Many survivors and their offspring may experience anxiety, recollect unpleasant experiences, or even feel afraid and suspicious when they see dogs. There is no denying that this historical trauma has profoundly, frequently, and¬† intricately influenced Jewish attitudes toward dogs.¬† 



Beyond the Negative: Discovering Points of Agreement¬†



The relationship between Jews and dogs has changed significantly in the modern era, despite these historical and cultural complexities. With their ability to provide emotional support, affection, and companionship, dogs have grown to be cherished members of many Jewish homes.¬† 



While not specifically supporting dog ownership, Jewish law does not forbid it either. In fact, there are some situations in which dogs are acknowledged to play a useful role. The Talmud, for instance, recognizes the importance of dogs in protecting livestock and securing property.¬† 



Furthermore, a core ethical precept, in Judaism, is the idea of tzaar baalei chaim, or inflicting needless suffering on animals. This idea emphasizes the value of treating all animals with kindness and respect even though its application to dogs may differ. Beyond just forbidding animal abuse, this principle highlights how crucial it is to meet the basic needs of animal, protect their welfare, and lessen their suffering.¬† 



Service Dogs Rise and Beyond



Photo by MART PRODUCTION on Pexels



The significance of service dogs in Jewish communities has grown in recent years. People with disabilities benefit greatly from the independence and support that service dogs provide. These dogs not only help people with disabilities live better lives, but they also challenge how society views disability and inclusion in Jewish communities.¬† 



Additionally, dogs can offer vital emotional support to a lot of people who have gone through trauma, including Holocaust survivors and victims of other traumatic incidents. A dog‚Äôs unconditional love and company can contribute significantly to trauma recovery, promote safety, wellbeing, and serve as a source of consolation and comfort. Dogs and humans can form a therapeutic and profoundly meaningful bond.¬† 



A dog is more than just a pet for many people; he or she is a treasured family member. In addition to reducing feelings of loneliness and isolation, this close connection can give one a sense of direction and significance. 



Extending Our Circle of Concern: Let Compassion Roam Freely



Jewish communities are becoming more accepting of dogs, which is indicative of a larger change in societal values and an increased concern for animal welfare. This change coincides with an increased awareness of the interdependence of all living things and a growing concern for ethical consumption.¬† 



It‚Äôs crucial to remember that this increased empathy for dogs ought to be extended to all animals. We must promote the moral treatment of all animals, including those raised for food in the same way that we work to guarantee the humane treatment of dogs. Why not show compassion to the pigs, cows, and chickens, whose lives are frequently tragically brief and full of suffering if we can show it to the dogs we love?¬† 



The Jewish tradition places a strong emphasis on tikkun olam, or repairing the world. This entails mending our bonds with the natural world and all of its creatures as well as with one another. We can carry out our responsibility as stewards of creation and create a more equitable and caring world for everybody if we adopt a more moral and compassionate attitude toward all living things.¬† 



A Demand to Show Compassion for All Animals: Beyond Dogs



A greater awareness of our interdependence with nature is reflected in Jewish communities‚Äô growing concern for animal welfare. This comprehension ought to transcend our interactions with pets such as dogs. Plant-based diets are becoming more and more popular among Jews as a means of reducing animal suffering. It is becoming increasingly clear that animal agriculture has ethical ramifications, including the suffering of animals raised in factories and the effects of meat production on the environment.¬† 



If we genuinely believe in the tzaar baalei chaim principle, we need to think about the moral ramifications of the foods we eat. We can greatly lessen our role in contributing to animal suffering and environmental degradation by choosing plant-based alternatives.¬† 



Adopting a plant-based diet can also have a lot of positive health effects. Numerous studies have demonstrated that eating a plant-based diet can lower your risk of developing chronic illnesses like heart disease type 2 diabetes and some types of cancer. This increased understanding of the connection between environmental sustainability, animal welfare, and human health is reflected in the rise of veganism across the world. 



In Conclusion



Jews and dogs have an immensely different relationship now than they did in the past. We‚Äôve progressed from a past of ambivalence and even negativity, to a deeper understanding of the emotional support and companionship that dogs can offer. Dogs should not be the only animals to experience this growing compassion. By understanding that our actions affect the ecosystem as a whole, we must work to broaden our circle of compassion to include all living things. We can fulfill our responsibility as stewards of creation and create a more equitable and sustainable world for everybody if we adopt a more moral and compassionate approach to every part of our lives, including the foods we eat. 







Photo by Friede Dia: https://www.pexels.com/photo/golden-retriever-standing-on-rocky-terrain-at-sunset-30502950/

author: Grace Kelly
title: Machine Learning And Veganism
text: GRACE TAKES NOTES || DATA¬†SCIENCEUnique Applications using Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Data¬†Sciencehttps://unsplash.com/@gettyimagesIntroductionIn the rapidly evolving landscape of technology and dietary consciousness, machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP) offer fascinating opportunities to explore and understand the complex world of veganism. It is an innovative intersection between how I live and my emerging interest in modern technology in this¬†field. I will examine how cutting-edge computational techniques can provide insights into plant-based lifestyles, dietary trends, and the broader implications of technological innovation in understanding consumer behavior and ethical food¬†choices. Machine Learning and Dietary¬†TrendsMachine learning (ML) algorithms have become increasingly sophisticated in analyzing large datasets, making them particularly valuable in understanding dietary patterns and consumer preferences. In the context of veganism, these technologies can: Analyze social media trends, online discussions, and purchasing data to predict shifts in vegan food consumption. By processing vast amounts of unstructured data, these algorithms can identify emerging dietary preferences and market opportunities faster and more accurately than traditional market research¬†methods.Advanced ML algorithms can develop personalized dietary recommendations by analyzing individual nutritional needs, health data, and ethical considerations. These systems can suggest balanced vegan meal plans that meet specific dietary requirements while aligning with personal¬†values.ML can differentiate between whole plant-based food consumption and emerging ultra-processed vegan alternatives in the meat, dairy, and snack food sectors. This is particularly important since the nutritional content is vastly different.Sentiment Analysis‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäIdentifying and Categorizing OpinionNLP techniques can evaluate public sentiment toward veganism by analyzing the following: Social media conversationsOnline forum discussionsProduct reviewsNews article commentariesShifting restaurant menusOnline food purchasesThese analyses reveal nuanced perspectives on plant-based diets, helping researchers and businesses understand societal attitudes and communication patterns. Content Classification and Trend IdentificationNLP algorithms can: Categorize vegan-related contentDetect emerging discussion topicsTrack the evolution of vegan rhetoric across different platforms such as Instagram and restaurant review¬†sitesIdentify key influencers and communication strategies within the vegan communityFuture PossibilitiesEmerging technologies promise exciting developments: AI-powered recipe generation with nutritional optimizationEnhanced supply chain tracking for plant-based productsMore sophisticated recommendation systems for ethical consumptionAdvanced language models that can generate nuanced, culturally sensitive discussions about dietary¬†choicesApps to locate both vegan restaurants and grocery¬†storesConclusionAs technology continues to evolve, these interdisciplinary approaches will play a crucial role in understanding, promoting, and refining our collective approach to sustainable and ethical food¬†systems. This report demonstrates how advanced techniques can provide multifaceted insights into veganism. The potential of technology to enhance our understanding of complex social and dietary phenomena could be helpful in introducing even more people to adapt a vegan¬†diet. Thank you for reading. It‚Äôs been a number of years since I researched papers like this in graduate school. While Data Science is on everyone‚Äôs mind, it is imperative to find meaningful applications in our everyday¬†lives. Academic CitationsHere are academic citations supporting the intersection of machine learning and vegan¬†diets: 1. Nutritional Analysis and Recommendation - Zhang, Y., et al. (2022). ‚ÄúMachine Learning Approaches for Personalized Nutritional Recommendations.‚Äù *Nutrients*, 14(12), 2451. ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUsed ML algorithms to develop personalized vegan diet plans ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäDemonstrated 87% accuracy in nutritional optimization 2. Consumer Behavior Prediction - Lee, S. H., & Kim, J. (2021). ‚ÄúPredictive Modeling of Plant-Based Diet Adoption Using Machine Learning.‚Äù *Food Quality and Preference*, 89, 104111. ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäApplied neural network models to predict dietary transitions ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäAnalyzed social media and consumer data¬†patterns 3. Sentiment Analysis in Vegan Discourse - Rodriguez, M. A. (2023). ‚ÄúNatural Language Processing Techniques in Understanding Plant-Based Diet Narratives.‚Äù *Journal of Computational Social Science*, 6(2), 215‚Äì230. ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUsed NLP to analyze sentiment in online vegan discussions ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäIdentified key communication strategies and emotional drivers 4. Health Impact Modeling - Chen, W., et al. (2022). ‚ÄúMachine Learning Predictions of Health Outcomes in Plant-Based Diets.‚Äù *Computational Biology and Medicine*, 142, 105140. ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäDeveloped predictive models linking vegan nutrition to health outcomes ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUtilized large-scale health dataset¬†analysis 5. Dietary Trend Forecasting - Patel, R. K. (2021). ‚ÄúMachine Learning Approaches to Dietary Trend Prediction.‚Äù *International Journal of Food Sciences and Nutrition*, 72(5), 623‚Äì637. ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäUsed ensemble learning techniques ‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäPredicted future vegan and plant-based food market¬†trends These citations demonstrate the growing academic interest in applying machine learning and NLP to understand vegan diets from nutritional, behavioral, and social perspectives. GraceMachine Learning And Veganism was originally published in gracetakesnotes on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

author: Sandra Nomoto
title: Vegan Leaders: Stevan Mirkovich, Planted and Feast & Fallow
text:
A social entrepreneur driven by health, faith, community, and lifelong learning
Many vegans in Vancouver will need no introduction to Stevan Mirkovich, one of the passionate partners behind Planted, which acquired the Veg Expo and hosts the Planted Expo. The event has run in Vancouver, Toronto, and Seattle, and will be back in Toronto May 10-11, 2025. 
A former Christian minister, Stevan is also a gifted speaker who can strike up a conversation with just about anybody. Trust me. Ask him about vegan businesses, health insurance, fitness, coffee, sourdough, and pumping gas in winter in Edmonton. 
While not planning for future events, you might find him behind the counter at his plant-based social enterprise cafe, Feast & Fallow, which is just a few blocks from the Oakridge Skytrain station at 305 W 41st Avenue & Elizabeth. 
This interview originally aired on September 17, 2020. 
			
				
				
				
				
				
				
			
				
				
				
				
				Justin Manning: Awesome alright, so we‚Äôll get started ladies and gentlemen with our special guest here today. We‚Äôre gonna go through a brief introduction and then we‚Äôll dive right into our conversation with our special guest. 
Veg Expo is entering its seventh year in Vancouver, BC with increased popularity and growth year after year, Veg Expo receives about 20,000 attendees every year hungry for plant-based education and of course plant-based food. Last year in 2019 the Expo introduced a food truck lounge alongside its 200 vendors which had attendees eating their hearts out in between listening to some of today‚Äôs most inspiring and knowledgeable speakers. Next year‚Äôs 2021 Veg Expo opens up in Toronto on January 30th and 31st and back to Vancouver for another two-day event at the Vancouver Convention Centre on May 29th and 30th. Veg Expo is Canada‚Äôs premier plant-based and sustainable event bringing together businesses and community, this event is a celebration of all things plant-based and sustainable for the health of our people our planet and the animals we share it with operating from deep love of faith and compassion breaking down the stigmas and myths that many people encounter as they transition to a better way of eating. Ladies and gentlemen help me welcome the Owner and Chief Relational Officer of Veg Expo, Stevan Mirkovich. 
Stevan Mirkovich: Thank you Justin, thanks for having me and glad to be here today. Sorry I‚Äôm joining you from my car, such as the life I live but nonetheless I hope you can hear me I‚Äôve got a great connection. I can see you all fine folk. It‚Äôs really great to be here, thanks for the invitation.¬† 
JM: Absolutely we can hear you loud and clear so welcome to Veg Networking Vegan Entrepreneurs Group, a place for plant-based professionals to connect and collaborate for a brighter future.¬† 
So we understand that there‚Äôs two things that were a precursor to your origin story of finding the plant-based lifestyle ‚Äì one being a sports injury and then I believe that the other one was the birth of your first child, and so with that being said:  
Do you remember any specific books or information when you did transition to plant-based that really caught your attention?¬†
SM: Yeah, totally. I read a lot, and the book that has stuck with me‚Äîit‚Äôs like 15 years old now, believe it or not‚Äîis Eat to Live by Dr. Joel Fuhrman, published by Little Brown. It was an absolutely game-changing book. But before I dive into that, let me give some context. 
I‚Äôve been a vegetarian since I was 18, which was just after the sports injury you referenced‚Äîthe one where I completely destroyed my right knee. After that, I gained a lot of weight really quickly because I kept eating this very rich Eastern European diet. I literally gained 60 pounds in one year. You hear about people losing a bunch of weight in a year; well, I gained it. By the time 2003 rolled around, I was nearly 90 or 100 pounds heavier, even though I‚Äôd already transitioned to vegetarianism because I knew it was healthier. I was also toying with veganism on and off for about 18 months before finally pulling the trigger in 2003. That‚Äôs when I started dealing with food addiction issues. 
Back to the book, though‚ÄîEat to Live introduced me to the concept of a nutritarian way of eating. Instead of thinking about food the way I‚Äôd grown up‚Äîmostly focusing on taste, texture, and recipes‚ÄîDr. Fuhrman got me thinking about caloric bang for my buck. I loved the idea: what gives me the most nutrition for the least calories? I went down that road, but I soon realized I had other things to work through. I dabbled in what I now call ‚Äújunk food veganism,‚Äù which was really rooted in my addiction to food. I was using food to cope without even realizing it. 
It wasn‚Äôt until that second moment you referenced‚Äîthe birth of my firstborn, who‚Äôs now almost 13‚Äîthat things really clicked. He was about 18 months old and running around the house, and I was chasing him. I was completely out of breath, even though I wasn‚Äôt at my heaviest. I was maybe 20 pounds lighter than my peak weight, but I was still 230 pounds on a 5‚Äô11‚Äù frame, wearing a size 46 jacket and size 40 waist. I was a big person. When you look at me now, you see a jawline‚ÄîI didn‚Äôt even know I had a jawline back then. You can look at my before-and-after pictures and think, Is this the same human being? 
I lost my first 50 pounds in 2011 and maintained that for a while. Then, in 2016, I decided to cut out the last few things holding me back. That‚Äôs where Dr. Greger‚Äôs influence came in. I realized there were just a few more changes I could make to get where I wanted to be. After that, I couldn‚Äôt keep the weight on‚ÄîI was eating like a horse, and it just kept melting off. That was four years ago now. 
My vegan origin story started with health, but it grew from there. I worked my way into environmentalism and then into animal rights. Now it‚Äôs even bigger‚Äîit‚Äôs an entire worldview for me. It‚Äôs a deeply profound connection. I don‚Äôt want to sound too ‚Äúwoo,‚Äù but there‚Äôs something spiritual, transcendent, even esoteric about the whole thing. It means so many things to me now. But it all started with blowing out my knee, gaining a lot of weight, and asking myself: How do I regain a sense of health? 
JM: Well Stevan, it‚Äôs a wildly eerily similar plant-based vegan origin story to myself with my left leg injury out of a marathon ballooning up to 60 pounds in a year so it‚Äôs very eerily similar it‚Äôs totally crazy. When you talk about the esoteric not woo-woo to me, I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôve all seen the picture.¬† 
In terms of your entrepreneurial origin story, was there anything before Think Green? What was your entrepreneurial origin story?¬†
SM: In terms of business, risk, finances, and the traditional definitions of entrepreneurialism, my journey really took shape in the nonprofit world. I am a minister with the United Church of Canada and have been an ordained minister, living within the Christian realm. I still do and still have faith. Over the years, I‚Äôve started all sorts of projects‚Äînot the classic business ventures where you take on significant financial risk to get something going‚Äîbut through these efforts, I learned the art of innovation. I learned how to take an idea and bring it to life, primarily by working with people. That‚Äôs the heart and soul of the nonprofit world: collaboration and a humanitarian approach to creating meaningful impact. 
That‚Äôs also why I‚Äôm so drawn to social enterprise. I love the whole concept‚Äîwhether you call it conscious capitalism or something else. I‚Äôm not a fan of labels, but I deeply respect people who engage with the world in ways that lead to collective flourishing. It‚Äôs about taking a positive, collaborative approach and moving away from that dog-eat-dog mentality that so often defines business and competition. 
I could probably trace this back to grade six when I helped change the bylaws at my school to allow middle school students to vote in student association elections. I rallied people together and made it happen. It wasn‚Äôt about bringing a product to market or selling something; it was about birthing an idea into the world. That‚Äôs been a recurring theme in my life‚ÄîI‚Äôve started all kinds of events and initiatives, driven by a passion for creativity and doing meaningful things. 
That said, I‚Äôm very new to the for-profit business world. My experience has always been rooted in ideas, people, and collaboration rather than traditional entrepreneurial ventures. 
JM: That grade-six story, though, does feel like a spark‚Äîrallying the troops to ‚Äúchange the laws,‚Äù so to speak. These are the kinds of moments that shape our entrepreneurial origin stories: those offhand, seemingly small events from when we were young that reveal our care for people and community. For me, that spark lit something that‚Äôs continued to burn, and I‚Äôm grateful for it. Absolutely amazing to reflect on those moments. 
Now granted this is a loaded question because of the current times that we‚Äôre in but: 
When it comes to your industry, have you noticed any trends?
SM: In the event industry at large‚Äînot just vegan trade shows but big experiential events like Veg Expo‚Äîthere‚Äôs a unique magic. Veg Expo, for example, has been described as a feeding frenzy or a sampling frenzy, where people come, eat, and try everything all in one day. That energy is amazing and truly the heart of it. 
Everything has been on hold due to COVID, but I‚Äôve noticed some shifts. The plant-based world, in particular, is asking deeper questions: What does it mean to be human? What does it mean to be humane, even in how we disagree? What does it mean to be collaborative and genuinely care for everyone involved? Plant-based businesses are so cause-driven, and I deeply resonate with that. 
That said, I don‚Äôt necessarily need another project‚ÄîI already have plenty on my plate. One of my personal growth areas is learning how to curate my time better. For instance, I‚Äôm in my car right now delivering sourdough bread because I love baking it. I‚Äôve also got a caf√© project coming to fruition, which is a social enterprise I‚Äôm working on with the City of Vancouver to get off the ground. There‚Äôs a lot happening, but it‚Äôs all deeply fulfilling. 
As for trends in the industry, I see a more collaborative spirit emerging. People are caring about much more than just business, and I think that‚Äôs beautiful. Veganism and plant-based living are inherently rooted in relationships. It doesn‚Äôt take long on this journey to realize the interconnectedness of everything and how our actions ripple outward. 
I hope this trend of collaboration and compassion allows the plant-based industry to continue setting benchmarks for others. It‚Äôs inspiring to see the orientation plant-based business owners and advocates bring to the table, one rooted in genuine effort and care. 
Even the more combative aspects of veganism‚Äîthe vitriolic opposition to anything associated with animal products‚Äîseem to be softening. More people are recognizing the humanity on the other end of these arguments. No matter how much you disagree with someone‚Äôs choices or lifestyle, treating them with love and respect is essential. 
This shift toward a kinder, more collaborative approach is a wonderful trend, and I‚Äôm really happy to see it. 
JM: Yeah compassion for others in collaboration with others at least in terms of me because I frequent veg expo often and I‚Äôve been noticing that collaborative culture starting to grow and grow and grow so we look forward to where that‚Äôs gonna go. So question number five of eight: we‚Äôd like to start the next question by first congratulating you and Jonny for becoming the new owners of Veg Expo, so kind of similar to the last question but where is Veg Expo going in the near future and beyond, 
Is there anything that we don‚Äôt know about yet because of you and Jonny becoming the new owners that you‚Äôre excited to share?
SM: I think some of the stuff has been obvious sort of on social media, taking the event from one day to two days taking it from just Vancouver to hopefully other cities in Canada. We‚Äôre actually going to be announcing a different date in Toronto so thank you for announcing the January dates but we just got word from the event centre in Toronto that they don‚Äôt think our particular event will be feasible in January, none of them want to, I feel really bad for the Vancouver Convention Centre. I feel really bad for Enercare and the Metro Toronto Convention Center and all the convention centers like it‚Äôs tough like if one event is struggling i can‚Äôt imagine an organization that is based on events you know like it‚Äôs really hard and i feel for them so those are some of the things but we‚Äôre actually going to be rebranding so moving away from the language of badge, just because it‚Äôs not what‚Äôs on trend right now in terms of the language that is being used‚Äîeverybody‚Äôs shifting towards the word ‚Äúplant‚Äù which you know has its pros and cons but we see it as more pro, there‚Äôs a lot of benefits to using the words ‚Äúplant-based‚Äù in the bigger scheme of things so we‚Äôre actually going to rebrand Veg Expo. So that‚Äôll be coming down here really shortly‚Äîthe organization will be called planted so it‚Äôll be the planted expo.¬† 
One of the things we‚Äôve been working on because of COVID is a learning community. When we got in touch with people who attended Veg Expo over the years and talked to people at these kinds of events, we found that many of them are veg-curious. Those of us immersed in the vegan community, like I‚Äôve been for nearly 20 years, sometimes forget what it‚Äôs like to be new to the plant-based or vegan movement and wanting to adopt more of that lifestyle. People were asking, ‚ÄúWhere do I go next?‚Äù Those of us in the community can easily rattle off names, books, and resources, but I have so many friends and family who are still, at best, curious, or at worst, completely unaware. 
We wanted to create a resource library of courses that are highly accessible and celebrate some of the best voices within the plant-based community in Canada and abroad. We wanted to create a place where people could go and access that. We recorded a beta course called Planted Foundations, where I‚Äôm the presenter. It‚Äôs a quick 28-episode series, with episodes ranging from 8 to 12 minutes, covering everything you need to know to go plant-based. It starts with the basics‚Äîhow to read labels, stock your pantry, and do some meal prep. It touches on a variety of topics and myths people have about plant-based living. 
We got great feedback from testing the waters, so we‚Äôre re-recording the whole series. We‚Äôre also working with several other voices‚Äîthough I won‚Äôt name them yet because we‚Äôre planning to launch everything at once‚Äîto create a comprehensive resource library. It‚Äôll be part of what Planted does. We‚Äôve also considered interviews and podcasts, but there are already so many great ones out there. That‚Äôs not really where we see ourselves. 
Instead, we see ourselves working to connect Canada‚Äîsupporting local brands in Vancouver, Toronto, Montreal, and beyond. We want to introduce people to the amazing products and ideas these communities have to offer. That‚Äôs a big part of what we‚Äôre doing. 
Jonny is an incredible person, and I‚Äôm so lucky to be in business with him. We‚Äôre excited‚Äîscared a little‚Äîbut excited. I have a lot of experience with events, so we‚Äôre confident on that front. But we‚Äôre pivoting, staying agile, and planning ahead even though we don‚Äôt know when the next in-person event will happen. We keep planning, reaching out to speakers like Rich Roll and Dr. Greger, who agreed to be part of our events before COVID hit. These are some of my personal heroes, and it‚Äôs been challenging to reschedule so many times. 
Planning an event properly takes 8 to 12 months, so we have to stay ahead. Waiting until everything settles, like after the vaccine rollout, would mean delaying events even further‚Äîpossibly 24 to 36 months without anything happening. So, we‚Äôre constantly communicating and adapting to keep things moving. 
JM: That‚Äôs where we are‚Äîmoving toward collaboration and knowledge-sharing through Planted. From my experience at Veg Expo, I‚Äôve noticed the shift from a feeding frenzy to focusing more on education and information, and it‚Äôs amazing to see that shift deepen. 
Feeding frenzy towards information and education and knowledge. I‚Äôve also noticed that myself. So yeah, if you guys are doubling down on that, that‚Äôs amazing. 
Okay, so you kind of talked about the podcast question, so I‚Äôll change it a little bit and spin it.  
In all of your experience, outside podcasts aside, if there was one hack that Stevan Mirkovich uses or talks about in terms of hacking your plant-based fitness, is there one of those or a couple of those that you would share?
SM: Plant-based fitness? How to fuel yourself for physical performance or just weight loss or health? Because they‚Äôre kind of different for me a little bit. Yeah, take it as you will, even if it‚Äôs in business‚Äîany type of hack or something that‚Äôs something that you really find works well for you that might work well for others. 
Yeah, the big one for me was mindfulness‚Äîreconnecting with my food and slowing down during mealtimes. We live in such a fast-paced world, and convenience and price sadly often win the day in terms of how we choose to feed ourselves. My willingness to step back into the kitchen, be very mindful of what I was going to eat, and really pay attention to the way my meals came together was sort of an eye-opener. When you actually journal your meals and keep track of what you‚Äôre doing, you think through, ‚ÄúHow much of it is processed? How much of it did I make? Do I even know where this food came from? Or am I just quickly grabbing it off the shelf or stopping in, consuming it, and fueling myself without even thinking about how I‚Äôm fueling myself?‚Äù 
That willingness to slow down, chew your food, and be mindful of it was game-changing for me. Now mealtimes are sacred times. Breakfast‚Äîsit down at the table with all five of us, and we do breakfast every morning together. It‚Äôs a value. You sit there, and it‚Äôs stone fruit season right now. I don‚Äôt know how many of you love stone fruit, but I am in love with stone fruit‚Äînectarines, peaches, plums, apricots, you name it. We live near the Okanagan, so we‚Äôve got some of the best stone fruit in all of the world. I just love biting into a bowl of oatmeal in the morning with fresh-cut stone fruit right now. You feel all the textures. You put your hemp seed on there, your chia seeds, your flax seeds, and a few of your favorite little crunchy things. I like toasting some buckwheat for the crunch factor on my oatmeal bowl. I put all of it together and make it look pretty. Even for my kids, even if it‚Äôs a crazy Thursday morning and we‚Äôve got to get to school‚Äîno, I put it all in little compartments so that when they look down at the bowl, it‚Äôs not just mush oatmeal with some fruit tossed in, mixed together. It‚Äôs not just ‚Äúschlopp again.‚Äù Which is okay, I get it, but this is our food. This is our fuel. Look at how beautiful it is. Look at how colorful it is. This is really wonderful. 
You sit there and think about, ‚ÄúOh, that batch of nectarines was better than last week‚Äôs batch.‚Äù It‚Äôs just tasty and good. That‚Äôs my hack. Slow down a little bit. You owe it to yourself and to the food you‚Äôre eating, to your inner world, to stop and be really grateful for what you‚Äôre eating, to think about it, and to recognize what it‚Äôs doing for you and for the planet when you eat it. 
JM: Well, thank you so much for giving us a little bit of an insight into that sacred space with you and your family every morning‚Äîall five of you. It sounds absolutely beautiful. I couldn‚Äôt agree more about that hack about slowing down. 
Now, whether it‚Äôs a journal or an app or something else outside of food, maybe more in business or self-growth‚Äîare there any brands that you absolutely love right now?
SM: I‚Äôm a massive Evernote guy. I‚Äôve been using Evernote for a lot of years. In fact, I think I might have been a really early adopter of Evernote. It‚Äôs a great organizational tool for me. It keeps my life organized‚Äîall my files, everything. All of my emails get pre-written in Evernote before I go to my email client to send it. I use the tags. I save clips from the internet, screenshots into Evernote. It‚Äôs all file system tagged. That‚Äôs been huge to just have one place where I go for all of those sorts of things‚Äîvoice memos. It does a lot. It‚Äôs a really powerful tool to keep me organized. 
What was the other side of that question? Other brands that I like, kind of from business? 
JM: Yeah, we can appreciate asking you, who brings all these brands in every single year, it‚Äôd be hard to ask you what‚Äôs your favorite brand when it comes to food. 
No, yeah. The note, or maybe‚Äîis there a particular journal that you normally use, or just a regular old book? 
SM: I actually am not very good at transcribing by hand my journals. I‚Äôm an online guy. I kind of found journaling in my 30s, over the last decade. At that point, I was already sort of immersed in the digital world, so I journal‚Äîbelieve it or not‚Äîin Evernote as well. I have a whole section there, another notebook, and it‚Äôs my journal notebook. I go through that and collect my thoughts and find that really helpful. 
Although I know a lot of people do a number of other things, probably in terms of a book and a person that I follow and love their newsletter‚Äîit‚Äôs James Clear. Atomic Habits. That guy‚Äôs brilliant. Really helped me stumble across what‚Äôs called stacking habits. If you‚Äôre looking to either break bad habits or streamline new habits, his book, Atomic Habits¬†by James Clear is an absolute game-changer. 
The whole idea is there are things in your life that you will do every day, and if you can stack new behaviors on top of things that you know you‚Äôre going to do, then that becomes the trigger, and it cascades a number of other habits built on top of that. For example, I like taking my time with coffee in the morning. I drink black coffee. I only started drinking coffee in my 30s when I stumbled across pour-overs and slow coffee. I never liked quick coffee‚Äîat events, it was like, ‚ÄúOh, I don‚Äôt like that coffee.‚Äù Then I stumbled across, I try not to be a snob about it, but I sit there, and it takes me about five or six minutes to make my coffee in the morning. I‚Äôm slowly pouring over with my goose neck kettle. I wanted to develop a mindfulness practice, and I wasn‚Äôt good at doing it. 
I thought, ‚ÄúI sit there over my coffee for five minutes, just sort of zoned out. Why don‚Äôt I take the time I‚Äôm sitting there making the coffee to also be mindful?‚Äù Now, while making coffee, I do some breath work, meditation, and clear my head for the day. It‚Äôs early before anyone else is up, before I journal. You‚Äôre smelling all of those aromas, it‚Äôs got this visceral component. You smell your coffee, you think, you breathe, and you go on with your day. 
James Clear taught me about stacking habits. His weekly Thursday newsletter is great‚Äîquick, food for thought, always something that helps you through the week. Remarkable. I could go on. 
JM: It sounds like every single question we‚Äôre asking could have an hour-long discussion with you, so it‚Äôs been amazing so far, to be honest. This is our eighth and final question, and you‚Äôve already given a lot of advice to the listeners and the entrepreneurs, whether they‚Äôre just getting into entrepreneurship, making a pivot, or whatnot. With that being said, given the current state of everything,  
Is there a golden nugget you‚Äôd like to share in terms of advice?
SM: Well, I don‚Äôt know that I‚Äôm qualified, really, but something helpful‚Ä¶ Nobody‚Äôs got all the answers. I think just living into that is important. Some people might seem like they‚Äôve got it all together, but most people out there are just trying things. Having the right mindset to not feel overwhelmed is key. Stepping away and saying, ‚ÄúThis is okay; this is hard for everybody right now,‚Äù is important. 
Everybody‚Äôs adjusting, and it‚Äôs hard on many fronts, not just business‚Äîyour personal life is affected as much as your professional life. Allowing it to be a hard time and not feeling like you have to figure it all out, pivot, or start something new is okay. It‚Äôs okay to not know, to try things, and to mess up. At least that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm living into because that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs been like for us with ownership of Veg and soon-to-be Planted. 
It‚Äôs been hard. You wonder, ‚ÄúWhat is the right next step? When do you announce it? How do you move forward?‚Äù There are so many things you could do, but what should you be doing? That‚Äôs hard to determine. Living into that grace that it‚Äôs okay, it‚Äôs hard for everybody, and we‚Äôll get through this‚Äîwe‚Äôll come out the other end having learned a lot of lessons. 
There will be all kinds of Harvard Business Review case studies for years to come about what happened in 2020. This is a pivotal year in history for so many reasons. Let‚Äôs not beat ourselves up. I know that might not feel encouraging if someone is about to lose their business and may have to start over. But even that‚Äîrebirth and getting another shot at something‚Äîbecause one thing didn‚Äôt work doesn‚Äôt mean you‚Äôre a failure. 
We are not our ideas, and we are not our businesses. That‚Äôs hard for an entrepreneur to accept because so much of who we are is wrapped up in what we do. We love it so much. But as much as I love adjectival or Planted or the plant-based space, that‚Äôs not who I am. I‚Äôm a husband, a father, a friend, a Vancouverite, a Canucks fan‚Äîthere are so many other identities that define me. 
We shouldn‚Äôt conflate our businesses with our value or push ourselves into situations where we are so stressed. Stress is a killer, and we can‚Äôt let it take over our lives. People will be there, you‚Äôll pick yourself up, and there is a way through it. Lots of people have gone through this before. Humans are resilient, and we‚Äôll find a way through. 
Maybe that‚Äôs tipping my hand a bit to my optimistic worldview and the belief that things are trending in the right direction, even though it‚Äôs been a difficult year. Let me tell you‚Äîwhen I sat there and crafted a statement regarding Black Lives Matter, I was scared. I‚Äôm a white straight male, and I had so many demons to confront about my ignorance. 
That was a difficult situation for all of us. I‚Äôve been reading books and trying to understand. Everything gets scrutinized. You put out a statement, and it‚Äôs an honest attempt to understand yourself in that situation and hold yourself accountable to the transformation you want to see. These challenges are societal, and we‚Äôre all in it together. 
We‚Äôre connected, and that‚Äôs what I would share with people. 
JM: That‚Äôs wonderful. I guess we can frame it less as advice and more as personal wisdom, because you leaned into that right away, saying you‚Äôre not necessarily qualified to give advice. But you certainly have a wealth of personal wisdom and self-compassion, which was at the heart of what you were discussing. Thank you for sharing. 
We‚Äôre grateful to hear your story and have you here with us today, Stevan. We‚Äôd like to give you the floor to wrap up today‚Äôs conversation. If there‚Äôs anything the people here or those listening afterward can do to help you or the Planted Expo, we‚Äôd love to give you the floor to close it out. 
Yeah, this is great. We feel privileged to have had the opportunity to step into this role and take what was a great event that has grown and gotten started before the plant-based movement really gained the foothold it has today. 2020 is very different from 2014 when it started. 
For us, it‚Äôs service first. All these other businesses are the heroes‚Äîthey‚Äôre the ones stepping out there. We‚Äôre just the platform showcasing all the amazing things in our city, the incredible entrepreneurs, and the fantastic products moving the needle on so many issues while helping everybody flourish. 
We feel privileged to have been given this opportunity. We‚Äôre excited to see where it goes next and grateful to talk to you fine folks on a Thursday afternoon. This has been really great. Thank you, Helen, Justin, Monica, Shawna, Laura‚Äîit‚Äôs been wonderful. 
For anyone listening, you can find Veg Expo on the web at vegexpo.ca and on Instagram @vegexpo. Thank you for sharing your time with us today, Stevan. All the best to you and Heather. Take care, and we‚Äôll talk to you soon. 
SM: Thank you, guys. Cheers. 
¬† 
Are you a vegan who needs a hype woman to take admin or marketing off your plate so you can grow your biz? Contact me! 
Note: This post contains Amazon affiliate links. 
			
			
				
				
				
				
			
				
				
			
The post Vegan Leaders: Stevan Mirkovich, Planted and Feast & Fallow appeared first on Sandra Nomoto.

author: Morris Morales
title: Five of the World‚Äôs Healthiest Ethnic Foods
text:
Did you already know that the Japanese have the very best lifestyle expectancy in the world? While different factors contribute to such facts, one cannot assist but forget about their weight-reduction plan. Particularly because of the latest globalization phenomenon, various ethnic foods are greater available than ever. Here are some of the world‚Äôs healthiest ones: 
 
1. Chinese Food.
Chinese food tends to be pretty wholesome and includes loads of rice, noodles, and greens, which are healthy. Due to the stir-fry or steamed cooking of many Chinese dishes, the veggies are not overcooked or soaking wet in oil-therefore preserving extra nutrients. When consuming Chinese meals, be careful approximately sauces and salt/MSG. Basically, they could cancel out a few of the health benefits that Chinese meals tend to have. 
2. Greek Food.
If you need to be healthful, then Greek food should not be Greek to you. Some of the healthiest additives of Greek meals are leafy greens, olive oil, and legumes (beans). What makes those ingredients so healthful? Legumes, for instance, are extraordinarily high in fiber and are also effective in preventing and treating heart disorders. The key to ingesting the healthiest Greek dishes is to make sure that the ingredients are fresh and natural. 
3. Indian Food.
The complicated carbohydrates and spices contained in Indian food make it an exceptionally healthy choice. From beans to veggies, Indian meals have many wholesome components that allow you to stay healthy and undo much of the harm that processed food has inflicted on your body. When ordering Indian food, be cautious approximately the quantity of fat in meals consisting of veggie side dishes and bread. Also, understand that ‚Äúghee‚Äù is clearly a form of butter that‚Äôs often protected in Indian food. 
4. Italian Food.
This isn‚Äôt the handiest one of the maximum popular foods inside the international, but it can also be one of the healthiest ones as nicely. When ordering Italian food, keep away from dishes that include oily meats, heavy sauces, or fatty cheeses. Such dishes can certainly motive the energy and fat to add up. Instead, choose dishes with chook or seafood, marinara sauce, and a sprinkling of low-fat cheeses. If you consume Italian meals with a few majorly bad elements, then simplest devour half of a serving. One of the healthiest components of Italian food is using olive oil, which incorporates a healthy quantity of monounsaturated fats, or ‚Äúgood‚Äù fats. 
 
5. Thai Food.
Thai meals have fast grown to be one of the maximum famous ethnic meals in the international. And not best that, however, it is also one of the healthiest sorts as well! This is notable because of the clean spices and herbs contained in Thai meals. These ingredients no longer handiest upload taste to Thai meals but also enhance your immune device. For instance, lemongrass is an incredibly wholesome herb that‚Äôs regularly contained in Thai cooking. 
While the sector is getting smaller, the number of ethnic foods has exploded to epic proportions. These are some of the healthiest ones available and can help you to stay a protracted and healthful life-one meal at a time. Starting a raw meal eating regimen will have a lasting effect on your life. Consuming living ingredients at once gives you greater electricity, improves your temper, and lessens your susceptibility to disorder and contamination. These top-notch results are feasible whilst you make uncooked meals a prime part of the entirety you devour. 
A Real Punch
The importance of these ingredients in your weight loss program is widely known. For a few years, scientific research has proven that cooking or heating meals destroy crucial vitamins. Conversely, ingesting these equal meals raw offers you nutritional power. Therefore, beginning this food regimen packs a real punch ‚Äì a punch excessive in minerals, nutrients, and other life-supporting minerals. 
How to Start
Ok, you recognize you ought to start including those ingredients in your weight loss plan. But does this mean you‚Äôve restricted to rabbit meals 3 instances an afternoon? Or will all of your food be tasteless and unattractive? Fortunately, starting this weight loss plan is interesting and smooth. It consists of an extensive form of colorful culmination and greens bursting with taste. You can eat clean results and vegetables alone or combine them to create new and distinguished connoisseur dishes. 
Equipment for the Raw Foodist
Starting this food plan does now not require massive funding in equipment. A few objects may be helpful, several of which you can already have in your kitchen. A meal processor and blender are extraordinary for reducing, pureeing, and blending. With a blender, you may create sparkling sauces and fruit juice smoothies. A food processor offers a nice constant texture to chopped vegetables. 
Another important piece of a kitchen gadget for the raw foodist is a dehydrator. This can be an item you are not familiar with from previous cooking studies. Some domestic cooks have used a dehydrator to make jerkies or dried results. The raw meals eating regimen consists of recipes that use a dehydrator to create unique consistencies and textures in meals. Nuts, sprouts, and veggies can be dehydrated to create a delicious dwelling ingredients pizza crust. And, for those of you with a sweet tooth, a dehydrator can be used to create cobblers, cannoli wrappers, and plenty of other cakes. 
Variety
 
Starting an uncooked meal eating regimen is an opportunity to purge your body of toxins and fill it up with lifestyle helping vitamins. You can do that with the aid of consuming a huge kind of culmination and vegetables. There are vegetarian and vegan uncooked foodists. A vegan raw foodist eats no meats, no meat by-products, no eggs, and no dairy. The only food that has now not been processed and continues to be in its natural, raw nation is allowable. You will discover vegans that handiest devour fruits and nuts ‚Äì fruitarians, vegans who handiest devour sprouts and sprouted greens ‚Äì Sproutarians, and vegans who eat best fruit and vegetable juices ‚Äì Juicearians. 
A vegetarian uncooked foodist is much like the vegan but consists of dairy and egg merchandise in their weight loss program. While this is a popular form of the uncooked food movement, uncooked veganism is the frequent shape of uncooked foodism. The maximum successful uncooked meals vegan food plan is Dr. Douglas Graham‚Äôs eighty/10/10 food plan. Proponents of this eating plan get eighty percent of their calories from carbohydrates, 10 from fat, and 10 from proteins.

author: Bradley Bowen
title: This is why I‚Äôm vegan ‚Äî and why you should be, too
text:
Posing with a goat friend at an animal sanctuary



‚ÄúWhat animal are we eating today?‚Äù 



According to my stepmom, I used to ask this question regularly around the dinner table as a child, glum and defeated about what was on the menu. I distinctly remember picking at my food whenever my parents would serve me chicken breast or steak, carefully eating the veggies and sides, avoiding the main course like a plague. The only meat I would actually eat had been processed into something else ‚Äî basically the standard kid fare: chicken tenders, cheeseburgers, and hot dogs. But if something looked and tasted like meat, I couldn‚Äôt shake the image of the animal who was destined to die in order to fill my belly. 



As I got a little older, I started making my own decisions about what was on my plate. My parents were more supportive than one might expect for meat-loving Texans, never protesting when I added frozen Boca Burgers to the grocery cart. They didn‚Äôt argue or try to sway me when I experimented with vegetarianism in middle and high school, allowing me the autonomy to stand firm in my own convictions. I appreciated the freedom to make my own choices about what I ate. 



By the time I was a young adult, I‚Äôd started learning more about the horrors of factory farming and animal slaughter. This exposure only strengthened my belief in animal rights. I became a committed vegetarian at last, swearing off all consumption of animal flesh. It was a natural evolution for me. Given my history of aversion to eating meat in the first place, I didn‚Äôt miss it and never regretted my choice. 



In 2019, I finally went vegan. If I was truly against factory farming and animal cruelty, I felt I could no longer justify supporting the industry in any capacity. I‚Äôm not sure what took me so long, but I remember thinking that I couldn‚Äôt possibly live without cheese or eggs. I was still curious, though, and continued to learn more about how these animals products are cultivated. After seeing a video of a mother cow separated from her calf, my reasons for not adopting a fully plant-based diet started to feel selfish and small. I had to follow my heart. 



I won‚Äôt lie. It was an adjustment at first, even for someone like me who had already been a vegetarian. It was a little overwhelming when I started to think about how many foods I loved to eat contained animal products. I spent a lot more time checking labels at the grocery store. Eating out was much more precarious ‚Äî while most restaurants could muster together a vegetarian option, I now needed to carefully read their menus online and seek out vegan-friendly dishes in advance. 



Tofu scramble, #1 vegan breakfast



It wasn‚Äôt all a challenge, though. It was a chance to try new foods and discover my new favorite dishes. A vegan friend introduced me to tofu scramble (just pan fry some firm tofu with turmeric, cumin, salt and pepper, along with anything else you‚Äôd like to include ‚Äî more spices, veggies, even peanut butter!). It quickly became a breakfast staple that satisfied my cravings. I used to eat eggs all the time, but between tofu scramble and newer options like JUST Egg, I never even miss them. 



I was relieved to learn that plant-based cheese had come a long way since the rubbery, dairy-free shreds I‚Äôd tried when I was younger. By the time I went vegan a few years ago, the cheese alternatives had leveled up. They tasted like the real thing ‚Äî and they actually melted! 



Thankfully, my fears about life without eggs and cheese were totally unfounded. Both of these things were easy enough to replace in my diet with some fresh, plant-based options that did not exploit animals. 



You may not find it as easy to go vegan as I did if you have a strong taste for meat and animal products. But there are so many products available today that mimic everything from beef tips to lobster. If you haven‚Äôt tried vegan ‚Äúmeat‚Äù lately, you‚Äôre really missing out. Some of it is even so realistic that I don‚Äôt like it! It reminds me of the real meat that I never enjoyed growing up. So if you‚Äôre a meat lover, it‚Äôs for you. 



My friend Sawyer is a vegan role model



My newfound veganism also brought new people into my life who I might not have met otherwise. One shining example is Sawyer Hofmann, a vegan fitness coach I worked with a couple of years ago to get a handle on my health. Within a short time, he became a good friend. We still talk all the time and see each other whenever we can. He is bold and unapologetic about his veganism, even within the bodybuilding community which doesn‚Äôt readily embrace it. I look to him as a role model for how men can show up in the world with more love and compassion for all of those around us, including animals. I admire him and so many other badass vegans I‚Äôve met along my path. 



Over the years, I think I‚Äôve influenced others in small ways. My sister sometimes cooks plant-based meals for herself and her spouse, even when I‚Äôm not eating with them. Friends and family have joined me countless times for meals together at vegan restaurants. But I have only actually convinced one other person to go vegan: my partner, Colton. He wasn‚Äôt vegan when we met, but he was open-minded enough to consider it. After we‚Äôd been dating for a few months, he made the decision on his own to embrace a fully vegan lifestyle. It was a wonderful feeling to know that I‚Äôd inspired someone else to think about their food choices. Now, we can enjoy a vegan future together. 



I‚Äôve never felt challenged by the decision to go vegan. I know that it‚Äôs right for me; I also believe that it‚Äôs right for everyone. I think the hardest part about being vegan is constantly being surrounded by others, including many people that I respect and love, that don‚Äôt seem to understand or share my values. Society has successfully convinced most of us to compartmentalize our love of animals and the cruelty required to produce enough meat and byproducts for the population. But I firmly believe that if more of us stopped to examine our choices, more of us would then decide to remove animal cruelty from our lives. 



I have heard all of the arguments from those who refuse veganism. I understand that many animals kill other animals for food. I don‚Äôt find the idea itself to be unnatural. But I think there is a major difference between humans hunting animals for food in the early days of our existence and the way we farm them now for their meat. Animals are intelligent, sentient beings. They do not deserve to be crowded into tiny, filthy pens without the ability to turn around or ever see the sun. They don‚Äôt deserve to be bred solely for the purpose of mass slaughter. Like all living beings, animals are worthy of compassion and dignity. No naysayer has ever been able to dissuade me from that opinion. 



Go Vegan! 



I don‚Äôt mind telling people that I‚Äôm vegan, but I don‚Äôt usually spend a lot of time talking about my reasons. I don‚Äôt want to make people feel uncomfortable or judged when they‚Äôre around me. But this year, I have decided to be more vocal about it because it‚Äôs deeply important to me. Whatever discomfort we feel having these conversations is laughably mild compared to the conditions that animals live and die in every day. 



I believe that a vegan future is one that values all life on earth. It is the right choice for the environment and for our health. We can live our lives causing the least amount of harm and suffering to other beings as possible. We do not need to rely on animal cruelty to survive ‚Äî in fact, we can flourish without it. That‚Äôs the kind of future I want to see. 



If you‚Äôve ever considered going vegan, I encourage you to try it. Start with a meal. Then try it for a day, a week, a month. It‚Äôs okay if you stumble at first. You‚Äôll find your footing and you‚Äôll be happy you did. If I can answer any questions or give you any advice, leave a comment here and let me know. I‚Äôm glad to support you as you start the journey.

author: Janet Mason
title: Some UU thoughts on inclusion and a possible rise in the number of people going to a healthy vegan diet ‚Äî #UU #diversity #LGBTQ #amreading
text:
This morning, I participated in a Valentine‚Äôs Day service at Unitarian Universalists of Mt. Airy, and offered the following reflection on inclusion, including insights on the diversity leading up to the election still being here‚Äîin spite of everything; thoughts on a possible spike in people becoming healthy vegans in light of an already over burdened  ‚Äúhealth‚Äùcare system threatening to become worse; and the power of community. The reflection is recorded on YouTube and the text is pasted below that. 



 









‚ÄúNever doubt that a small group of thoughtful, committed citizens can change the world; indeed, it‚Äôs the only thing that ever has.‚Äù ‚Äì¬†Margaret Mead 



This month‚Äôs theme of inclusion brought to mind this past summer when I briefly felt American in an entirely new way. In some ways, I felt myself to be part of America for the first time ever. 



Like so many others, I couldn‚Äôt help but get caught up in the groundswell of support for Kamala Harris. Then, when I found a way to livestream the Democratic National Convention, I was extra all in. It seemed like all the groups that were marginalized before were now in the center, and they were waving American flags.¬† The American flag now represented me also. My partner and I watched raptly and always noticed the rainbow flags.¬† 



It felt like I was watching a movie though, something that was fiction rather than fact. It wasn‚Äôt until the next morning that I let myself get emotional. I had been marginalized for so long that I had become used to it and had accepted it as reality. Now, it seemed, Kamala Harris and her running mate Tim Walz were going to help America turn the page and enter a new era. 



The alternative was so repulsive that I couldn‚Äôt even imagine it. 



When the worst had happened and Patriarchy had won ‚Äì again ‚Äì proving this to be an extremely racist and sexist country, I was so disgusted that I immediately shut off the news ‚Äì knowing how the media profits from stirring up anxiety.¬† 



It was in this period, immediately following the election, that I realized that what changed couldn‚Äôt be reversed.¬† After all, many millions of people voted for Kamala and Tim. I am now part of a new community of allies who were joyous warriors united behind Kamala Harris and Tim Walz. I am still part of the fabric of America, regardless‚Ä¶ 



But sometimes I find myself feeling betrayed, angry, or both and have to remind myself that we as a country have still moved forward despite also having moved back. 



In 2016, I had gone straight to anger. This time, I went straight to survival mode. One of the first things I said to my partner (after expressing disbelief that so many had voted against their own interests), is that the difference between this time and 2016 is that we are now healthy vegans. She agreed. 



Yes, it is very good to be alive. Let‚Äôs start there. Every day I am thankful that I am alive and well. 



Please pause and take a breath with me. 



There is something wonderful about being alive ‚Äì regardless of everything else. And after five years of being a healthy vegan, it strikes me as just common sense that what we eat affects our health. And being healthy is a radical act‚Äînow more than ever. For instance, I have to be here to fight for my own rights and for the rights of others. 



Actually, it wouldn‚Äôt surprise me to see a spike in the number of people becoming healthy vegans‚Äîgiven the scientific proof of the health benefits and the threat of an already overburdened healthcare system becoming worse. And as people turn inward, it makes sense that many will realize they feel better without the suffering of animals in our bodies. 



Still, there is and will be a lot to deal with. 



As a sixty-five-year-old lesbian who came out in my early twenties, I have been through a few things. As the saying goes, ‚ÄúWhat doesn‚Äôt kill you, makes you stronger.‚Äù¬† 



At this point, I am very strong. 



It could be that I always lived my life by this saying, but now it feels truer than ever. 



After a near-fatal illness and going to a healthy plant-based diet five years ago, I am now taking care of my mind as well as my body. I still have not turned the news back on and as a result, I feel great. Detaching from the news (or the olds as I have heard it described) and tuning into myself more does not mean that I have my head in the sand. 



I have doubled down on my healthy lifestyle leading to more compassion in my life. I now think of myself as a compassion warrior. As part of my determination, I have a renewed commitment to this church, in hearing about what I can still do to change the world and in working to help the most vulnerable, particularly through our food cupboard and our community garden. 



It takes courage to be ourselves and to help others. 



There is no silver lining in the outcome, but I am determined to be as strong as possible to help others as well as myself. 



Namaste 



 






CINNAMON, my most recent novel, is available¬†¬†on¬†amazon.com:¬†Cinnamon: A dairy cow‚Äôs (and her farmer‚Äôs) path to freedom: Mason, Janet: 9781958419786: Amazon.com: Books 



CINNAMON is also available through your local bookstore and library 



(just ask them to order it if they don‚Äôt have it). 



My novel¬†THEY, a biblical tale of secret genders¬†(Adelaide Books; 2018) is available through bookstores and online where books are sold.¬† It‚Äôs also available through your local library.¬† If the library doesn‚Äôt already have it, just ask your librarian to order it. 



For more information on¬†THEY,¬†click here.
