author: itstimholman
title: Veganism has deep roots in Japan‚Äôs history. It‚Äôs beginning to resurface
text: From¬†grist.org¬† In this excerpt, Grist‚Äôs Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Joseph Winters explore how vegan diets are gaining a foothold in Japan ‚Äî and the cultural barriers that still stand in the wayThe vision‚ÄúI want people to understand that vegan food isn‚Äôt just for a select few. It‚Äôs an inclusive eating style. Reaching beyond the vegan community is essential for creating a vegan-friendly world.‚Äù ‚Äî Azumi Yamanaka, a vegan activist in Tokyo ¬†  ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† The spotlight When you think of Japanese cuisine, your mind might go straight to sushi. Or pork ramen. Or, if you‚Äôre a little fancy, maybe Kobe beef. The country is famous for top-of-the-line meat and fresh fish. But did you know that, for 1,200 years, meat-eating was banned in the country? An emperor ended the ban In the late 1800s, as part of an effort to Westernize and open the island nation up to the world ‚Äî against protests from Buddhist monks that eating meat amounted to ‚Äúdestroying the soul of the Japanese people.‚Äù The result: A rapid rise in consumption of meat, egg, and dairy products. Eating meat became a symbol of power and status, and eventually the cultural norm. Today, Japan ranks 11th in global beef consumption, and vegan options are difficult to find, especially outside of major city centres. Two-hundred years ago, plant-based eating in Japan had a lot to do with religion and practicality. But today, some advocates are trying to renew the country‚Äôs interest in veganism ‚Äî for climate and animal welfare concerns. Grist fellow Sachi Kitajima Mulkey is Japanese and American, and spent years living in Kyoto where her family is. ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre an American living in Japan, your friends visit all the time. They‚Äôre so stoked to have a free place to stay,‚Äù she said, adding that many of her American friends were vegetarian or vegan. ‚ÄúAnd I just remember how hard it was,‚Äù she said. Meat, eggs, and dairy were difficult to avoid, not to mention the dashi, or fish broth, that forms the base of many dishes. But then, something shifted. Around five years ago, she started noticing vegan products at the stores and restaurants she went to. ‚ÄúAlmond milk was suddenly available, when it wasn‚Äôt before,‚Äù she recalled. Earlier this month, she teamed up with Grist‚Äôs Joseph Winters¬†to write a feature on the rise of veganism in Japan. Interestingly, the push to include more vegan options in restaurants and supermarkets seems to be fuelled in part ‚Äî again ‚Äî by the country‚Äôs desire to cater to outsiders. ‚ÄúA lot of the new vegan initiatives are driven by an increase in tourism and trying to accommodate tourists,‚Äù Winters said. For instance, in the lead-up to the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo (which wound up being held in the summer of 2021), the government developed a set of guidelines and certification marks to help restaurants offer more vegan options for visitors, and even offered subsidies for them. But the push to increase plant-based options is also a part of meeting national and local climate goals ‚Äî Japan has pledged to halve emissions by 2030. In the city of Kyoto, which has its own aggressive emissions targets, plant-based eating is part of the plan to get there. Still, barriers exist for Japanese residents who want to go vegan. Some mirror the barriers that many face in the U.S. ‚Äî a lack of accessible options, and a stigma that meat-free diets are not nutritious ‚Äî but some are also unique to Japan‚Äôs customs. ‚ÄúIt is a culture where bucking the norm is really looked down upon,‚Äù Mulkey said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very difficult to feel like you‚Äôre asking for any kind of special accommodations. It‚Äôs all about humility and the group and fitting in.‚Äù Mulkey even experienced this herself when she was home visiting family and reporting the story. She tried to eat vegan as much as she could, but was concerned about offending her loved ones by turning down meat, or inconveniencing them by dragging them to yet another vegan restaurant. Winters joked that this is often what it‚Äôs like traveling as a vegan. ‚ÄúIt just becomes a food travel experience,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou have your list of all of the sights, and it‚Äôs just vegan restaurants ‚Äî and then like, ‚ÄòOK, I guess we‚Äôll go see the Sistine Chapel or whatever.‚Äô‚Äù As far as the impact of the story, Winters hopes that reporting on veganism and the way it‚Äôs showing up in different parts of the world can help make the idea more accessible for people. And Mulkey noted that she was particularly excited to frame the story with a Japanese audience in mind (the piece was co-published with The Japan Times). ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs exciting to see a culture that is so slow to change kind of move quite quickly on this, actually,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt is nice to think that, in a moment where the country does want to open itself up for more travel and have people visit, it can accommodate people more.‚Äù In the excerpt below, Mulkey and Winters delve into the history of Japan‚Äôs relationship with meat, and also what vegan advocates and chefs are cooking up ‚Äî and working against ‚Äî today.¬†Check out the full piece on the Grist site, here. ‚Äî Claire Elise Thompson  In meat- and fish-loving Japan, veganism is making a comeback (Excerpt)All is quiet at 10:30 a.m. on a Thursday in Shibuya, Tokyo‚Äôs famous commercial district. In an alleyway just steps from one of the busiest train stations in the world, a short line of tourists huddles outside of a bar. Finally, half an hour later, the door cracks open and, greeted with a soft¬†irasshaimase, or ‚Äúwelcome,‚Äù the parties shuffle in to sample one of the rarest dishes in Japan: faux-fish sushi. ‚ÄúNowadays, there are many vegan ‚Äòmeat‚Äô products,‚Äù says Kazue Maeda, one of the four founding employees of the restaurant, Vegan Sushi Tokyo. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm Japanese. What I really used to love is sushi and salmon.‚Äù Her restaurant attempts to fill a relatively unclaimed niche in the local food scene. Even in Tokyo, where much of the country‚Äôs vegan population lives, plant-based versions of traditional Japanese food remain challenging to find ‚Äî most vegan options are¬†y≈çshoku, a popular cuisine that puts a Japanese twist on Western dishes like hamburgers. Vegan Sushi Tokyo is open only for lunch: Although rave reviews keep pouring in from customers, the small business still doesn‚Äôt have a storefront of its own and rents out the interior of a bar by day. It serves 10-piece nigiri lunch sets, which include a plant-based Japanese-style ‚Äúegg,‚Äù ‚Äúshrimp‚Äù tempura, and beads made out of seaweed that look nearly indistinguishable from salmon roe. For all its differences from the United States, Japan‚Äôs culinary culture takes after America‚Äôs in a key way: It‚Äôs difficult to avoid meat and dairy. Of course, soybean products like tofu are the star of many dishes. But beef, pork, chicken, eggs, or dairy also feature in nearly everything, from ramen to¬†okonomiyaki, a savoury cabbage and pork pancake. And then there‚Äôs the fish ‚Äî served raw in sushi and sashimi, grilled as fillets, fried in tempura, shaved as a garnish, and present in nearly all other dishes as dashi, a savoury broth made of dried tuna flakes and kelp. Maeda became a vegan six years ago, due to her growing concern over environmental and animal rights issues. It‚Äôs a familiar origin story for those who have come to defy the typical Japanese diet by giving up animal products. ‚ÄúIn terms of the vegan movement, I think we‚Äôre maybe behind other countries. The number of vegans is very small,‚Äù Maeda says. ‚ÄúBut there are more and more vegetarian and vegan restaurants in Tokyo, I think because of tourists ‚Äî especially from countries with many vegetarian people.‚Äù Outside large cities like Tokyo, Osaka, and Kyoto, vegan options quickly vanish. In a culture that prizes convention and scrupulous attention to detail, individual accommodations ‚Äî like vegan menu substitutions ‚Äî are often frowned upon. And as in many other countries, vegan options are sometimes stigmatized as less nutritious. But recently, things have been changing. The anticipation of a tourism boom for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo pushed the Japanese government to encourage new vegan businesses and menu options in major cities. And in the years since, restaurants like Maeda‚Äôs have sprung up, offering novel adaptations of traditional dishes. Under pressure from Japan‚Äôs pledge to nearly halve its carbon emissions by 2030, the government has also begun collaborating with vegan activists and advocates and¬†awarding grants¬†to alternative protein start-ups. Though challenges remain, it‚Äôs gotten easier and easier to go vegan in Japan over the last decade. ‚ÄúClimate issues and animal issues are growing,‚Äù Maeda said. ‚ÄúFor me, I can‚Äôt imagine going back to eating meat again.‚Äù The first guests of the day line up outside the door of Vegan Sushi Tokyo in Shibuya.¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist Convincing people to eat less meat is key to reaching international climate goals. Up to¬†20 percent¬†of planet-warming greenhouse gases emitted annually come from animal agriculture alone ‚Äî all the cows, pigs, lambs, chickens, and other animals (not including fish) that people raise for meat, milk, eggs, and the like. According to one¬†study from the University of Oxford¬†that looked at the diets of over 55,000 people, vegans ‚Äî defined as those who eschew all animal products ‚Äî create 75 percent less climate pollution through their food choices than those who eat a meat-heavy diet. For most of the last two millennia, the Japanese diet was a model of climate-friendly eating due to Buddhist and Shinto¬†objections to meat and dairy consumption¬†‚Äî although fish has long been a staple. Beginning in 675 A.D., meat-eating was banned by official imperial decree. The ban set the stage for the flourishing of¬†sh≈çjin ry≈çri, a traditional cuisine that arrived in the sixth century along with Buddhism and aligns with the religion‚Äôs prohibition against killing animals. In the 13th century, the cuisine developed into a spiritual movement focused on simplicity and balance between one‚Äôs mind and body. ‚Äú‚ÄòSh≈çjin ry≈çri‚Äô literally means ‚Äòfood for spiritual practice,‚Äô‚Äù one Japanese studies professor¬†told the BBC. A typical sh≈çjin ry≈çri set meal is vegan, highlights seasonal produce, and is designed around sets of five ‚Äî five colours, five flavours, and five cooking methods. While it can still commonly be found in the dining halls of Buddhist temples, modern chefs have taken sh≈çjin ry≈çri into the mainstream, including in¬†Michelin-starred restaurants, where they emphasize the concept‚Äôs focus on harmony with nature by using local ingredients and minimizing waste. It wasn‚Äôt until 1872 that Emperor Meiji lifted the meat-eating ban, seeking to usher in an era of¬†Westernization. Meat consumption grew quickly as domestic beef production boomed, and animal products became a symbol of power and status. As reports spread that Emperor Meiji¬†drank milk twice a day, dairy consumption became more popular, too. Today, Japan¬†ranks 11th in beef consumption globally, and its per capita milk consumption is¬†68 percent higher¬†than that of the average East Asian country. Japanese people buy¬†eight times more meat than they did in the 1960s, and in 2007, families began eating it¬†more than fish. (Japanese people still only eat half as much meat, not including seafood, as Americans.) But interest in plant-based foods appears to be growing, as it is¬†in Western countries. Japan‚Äôs¬†market for plant-based foods tripled¬†between 2015 and 2020, and the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries expects it to¬†double again by 2030. These shifts have taken place as the Japanese population at large has expressed a readiness to shift toward plant-based products for health, animal welfare, and climate-related reasons, according to a¬†2022 analysis¬†in the Journal of Agricultural Management. Although no official government statistic exists, a 2021 survey found that¬†2.2 percent¬†of Japanese people identify as vegan ‚Äî a potentially higher percentage than in the United States, where estimates range from¬†1 to 4 percent. But even though vegan restaurants have been on the¬†upswing since 2017, Japanese vegans seem to have fewer options than their American counterparts. According to¬†HappyCow, a popular directory of vegan and vegetarian restaurant options, Japan has fewer than six vegetarian restaurants per 1 million people in Japan, more than a fifth of them in Tokyo. By comparison, there are nine vegetarian restaurants per 1 million people in the U.S. ‚ÄúEven many chefs still don‚Äôt know what vegan is, they don‚Äôt know the concept,‚Äù said Azumi Yamanaka, a vegan activist in Tokyo. She met with a reporter from Grist for a late lunch at Brown Rice, a sleek vegan restaurant with an organic, health-focused menu near Harajuku, the country‚Äôs famous fashion capital. For her meal, she ordered the weekly¬†teishoku¬†special, which came with a selection of small seasonal vegetable dishes, rice, and miso soup. ‚ÄúThey don‚Äôt realize that adding a small piece of bacon or fish is still meat. I still have to explain it,‚Äù she said, while picking at a slice of roasted lotus root with her chopsticks. When Yamanaka became vegan 16 years ago, she said, most people in Japan hadn‚Äôt even heard of the term ‚Äúvegan.‚Äù Pronounced¬†bi-gan, it joins a lexicon of Western loan words that have been integrated into the language with Japanese phonetics, such as¬†ko-hii¬†(coffee) or¬†chi-zu¬†(cheese). But in recent years, she said, being vegan has become a somewhat fashionable subculture ‚Äî judging from social media trends and an upswing in¬†photogenic vegan cafes, which she said get more young people interested in becoming vegan, too. ‚Äî Sachi Kitajima Mulkey and Joseph Winters https://grist.org/looking-forward/veganism-has-deep-roots-in-japans-history-its-beginning-to-resurface/

author: yeahwritemark
title: Midtown Vegan Deli & Market
text:
A Meat Free Joint That Is Full Of Heart 







The corner of 5th Street and Rosemont has been a spinning food circus of meat-centric operations. Mainly consisting of Kosher delis, that space has been known for its delicious food for decades upon decades, all centered around cured beefy bits, creamy salads and other animal forward dishes. 



After the last deli closed its doors in the shake wake of Covid, a new concept moved in soon after. Only this time it would be completely animal product free. Like 100% plant based. 



Nothin‚Äô but goodness at Midtown Vegan Deli & Market



Midtown Vegan Deli and Market opened its doors in 2021 to a rousing sigh of cruelty-free relief. Now, don‚Äôt get me wrong, the guy typing these words is a strident omnivore, but after constant bouts with drippy burgers, endless birria tacos and the illustrious Sonoran hot dog, it‚Äôs really nice to take a break from all that flesh forward food and give the animals involved a break as well. 



Owner Tanya Barnett says that Midtown was born from hosting vegan cooking nights with her friends. At first they were monthly, then every other week, then every week as the vegan nights began to grow in fun and popularity. When the former occupant of 5071 E. 5th Street vacated, Barnett drew up a plan and the cogs of Midtown began turning. 



The Death Free Foodie bagel, uh‚Ä¶yes please!



‚ÄúThe idea for Midtown was more out of necessity than to make money,‚Äù says Barnett who is also a licensed real estate agent. ‚ÄúVeganism is a still growing movement and I knew that people, be them vegan or meat eaters, would appreciate a place that just serves up really delicious food that just happens to be plant based and cruelty free.‚Äù 



The response to Midtown Vegan Deli and Market was an almost immediate embrace. Sure there are plenty of restaurants that are vegan, or at least offer vegan delights, but Midtown serves up fat kid comfort food and you would never know that a finned or four legged friend wasn‚Äôt involved. 



A supreme Crunchwrap Supreme to that other crunchwrap supreme. You know what I mean?



For breakfast (yes they totally serve breakfast) you gotta try the Chicken and Waffles. Its Southern fried goodness over a fresh waffle, a waffle that happens to contain no dairy, and the chicken itself is a wizard construct seeing that it is chicken but it totally isn‚Äôt. 



Speaking of vegan sorcery, Midtown has paired with local blogger Hannah Hernandez, aka the Death Free Foodie, to create the Death Free Bagel, easily one of my favorite items on the all day menu. A house made bagel of your choice is then stuffed with, get this, bacon, egg, cheese and sausage, none of which employ the use of a critter, then its finished with jalapenos, microgreens and maple syrup. So good. 



Midtown‚Äôs burger of the month will always make your day



For sandwiches you can get a full on Reuben, Philly ‚Äúcheesesteak‚Äù, and even a tuna melt that goes by the name Tuno because there aint no tuna in this thing. Yet, somehow, there is. 



Of course Midtown has a full run of salads and wraps, because what good well intentioned flesh free eatery wouldn‚Äôt? And, of course, they offer up a smoothie menu, a fruity cavalcade of cold sippin‚Äô yum, a necessity in the Tucson heat, even though it is officially winter as I type this. And 90 degrees. 



For all your vegan cooking needs



If you‚Äôre craving a diner experience without the diner slop, get you a basket of tater tots or fries and order up one of Midtown‚Äôs infamously thick and tasty milkshakes that have, you guessed it, no milk. Because you dip your fries or tots in your milkshake right? Yeah. Its like the best thing ever but sounds weird on tape. Sort of like, well, chicken and waffles and our beloved Sonoran hots dogs. 



Oh. That‚Äôs right. Midtown has a Sonoran hot dog! And the Sonoran hot dog is absolutely scrummy! No dogs were harmed in this dish because that‚Äôs not the modus of Midtown‚Äôs motivation. Or should be anyone‚Äôs really. 



Way too much cool stuff in their market



Every Tuesday and Thursday you can order up a beefed up (without the beef) crunchwrap that is supremely better and bigger than that run for the border corporate snore. Midtown also does a burger of the month so stop in at least every four weeks to see what the kitchen magicians have concocted. Personally I have experienced fast food style, Mediterranean influenced, slathered with chili, double decker and kitchen sink everything rampage burgers. All of which are equal in amazingness yet being totally different from one another. 



You now know about the deli, lets get down to the market. 



You gotta fight for your right to not eat your fuzzy/finned/feathered/four legged friends!



When you walk in, on either side of Midtown, you are treated to a color whirl of environmentally conscious products, be them local or from a far off exotic location. Sauces, cereals, bulk food, frozen dinners, juices, condiments, desserts, you name it. They even have a rotating selection of fine craft beers. Because nothing goes better with an egg salad sandwich that is completely devoid of egg and Buffalo style crinkle cut fries than a tall cold one. Ammirite? 



Midtown does their own baking and offers up sweet treats like cookies and cakes but they have partnered with Holden‚Äôs Rise Above bakery so there is a full selection of their vegan goodies on display at the deli counter. 



If you consume meat or have completely gone green in your diet, either way you must make Midtown Vegan Deli and Market a destination no matter what part of town you are currently calling home in, what proteins you consume or politics you lean toward. Everything here is all so very very good. 



Enjoy! 







Midtown Vegan Deli & Market 



5071 E. 5th Street @ Rosemont 



http://www.midtownvegandeli.com 



(520) 849-5553 



http://www.instagram.com/midtownvegandeliandmarket 



http://www.facebook.com/midtownvegandeli/ ¬† 



Monday ‚Äì Saturday: 9am ‚Äì 9pm 



Sundays: 9am ‚Äì 4pm 



 



Words and photos by Mark Whittaker 



yeahwritemark@gmail.com 



520-861-4198

author: Amala Justy
title: Looking to enjoy a vegan brunch in India?
text:
Veganism, a way of life that does not include any animal products, has been rapidly growing in popularity around the world, especially in India. Many people find that going vegan is easy because traditional Indian food has so many plant-based recipes. Ethical, environmental, and health concerns are all part of the modern vegan movement, which extends beyond simple dietary choices. 



More and more people in India are becoming vegan as they learn about the health benefits of a plant-based diet, the negative effects of animal agriculture on the environment, and the suffering of animals. The advantages of going vegan have been widely disseminated thanks to documentaries, social media influencers, and worldwide initiatives. 



Vegan food options, restaurants, and cafes have proliferated in response to this trend in India‚Äôs market. Vegan restaurants have proliferated in recent years in several Indian cities, including Bangalore, Mumbai, and Delhi, serving creative and tasty plant-based cuisine to customers of all dietary restrictions. 



A Guide to Vegan Brunch Spots in India 



Vegan brunch menus have been expertly crafted by a number of cafes and restaurants around India in response to the growing vegan movement. The restaurants here do more than just serve tasty food; they also advocate for environmentally and socially responsible eating habits. 



Vegan Cafes and Plant-Based Restaurants  




Carrots, Bangalore Brunch options at Carrots, one of the first vegan eateries in India, range from tofu bhurji and vegan pancakes to smoothies and other healthy options. A fresh and healthy meal is guaranteed by their emphasis on organic and locally produced ingredients.





Greenr Cafe, Delhi and Mumbai Located in both Mumbai and Delhi, Greenr Cafe is famous for its plant-based, farm-to-table cuisine. Their brunch menu includes vegan burgers, salads, and drinks that are crafted by artisans. People who care about the environment love this cafe because of its sustainable methods and its simple furnishings.





Earth Cafe @ Waterfield, Mumbai Indulge in a variety of vegan pastries, avocado toast, smoothie bowls, and more at Earth Cafe‚Äôs vibrant brunch buffet in Bandra. The cafe has hip decor and a healthy food, so it draws in a wide range of customers.



The Real Green Cafe, Pune Omelettes, sandwiches, and desserts are just a few of the vegan brunch options offered at this picturesque cafe in Koregaon Park. Veganism is on the rise in Pune, and businesses there are responding by stocking their menus with organic, cruelty-free options.




Popular Vegan Restaurants in Bangalore 



Bangalore, sometimes called the ‚ÄúSilicon Valley of India,‚Äù is known for its abundance of vegan restaurants and has recently become a popular destination for vegans. 




Sant√© Spa Cuisine Sant√© Spa Cuisine is an Indiranagar restaurant that serves vegan and health-focused cuisine. A lot of people prefer the vegan sushi, quinoa salad, and almond milk smoothies.





Go Native Go Native has an emphasis on farm-to-table eating and has numerous locations throughout Bangalore. Millet pancakes, tofu scramble, and cold-pressed juices are some of the vegan breakfast options available. Brunch here is the ideal way to unwind, thanks to the rustic furnishings and peaceful atmosphere.





Green Theory Located on Convent Road in a picturesque colonial bungalow, Green Theory provides a tranquil setting and a menu featuring a range of vegan options. Pasta dishes, pizzas topped with cashew cheese, and mouthwatering desserts are all part of their vegan brunch menu.





Yogisthaan Cafe The Indiranagar establishment Yogisthaan Cafe offers a culinary and health-conscious experience. Vegan brunch options include gluten-free baked goods, salads, and smoothies. A holistic experience is provided by the serene environment, which includes yoga classes.





Copper + Cloves Copper + Cloves is an organic restaurant that employs products grown or harvested close to Ulsoor Lake. Avocado toast, vegan smoothie bowls, and raw desserts are some of the vegan brunch options. Bangaloreans love this cafe because of its trendy decor and dedication to health. 




Conclusion: The Future of Vegan Brunch in India 



More and more people in India are choosing veganism as a way of life since it is more ethical and environmentally friendly. The rising demand for plant-based dining options is mirrored by the proliferation of vegan brunch establishments nationwide. 



The vegan movement in India is booming, and the country‚Äôs cuisine is adapting to meet the needs of its growing vegan population. Vegan versions of classic dishes are popping up on menus as chefs and restaurant owners try new things to attract customers. 



More vegan brunch spots serving a variety of tasty plant-based options are sure to pop up in India in the near future. Vegan brunch in India has something for everyone, from die-hard vegans to those just trying to eat healthier. 



Ultimately, the increasing number of vegan brunch options in India highlights a larger trend towards a more conscious approach to food and lifestyle choices. Vegan brunettes are becoming increasingly popular as the country discovers new ways to combine its traditional cuisine with eco-friendly methods.
tags: ["Bangalore","Around The World","Food","Health & Beauty","Healthy recipes","bangalore","healthy","Healthy Food","SEO-Articles","vegan brunch in india","vegan food","Vegan restaurants in Bangalore","vegan restaurants in India"]

author: David Beaver
title: 25 Latest Vegan Industry Statistics for the UK (2025)
text:
In recent years, plant-based diets have moved from niche to mainstream in the UK, and the vegan lifestyle is more popular than ever. Whether driven by concerns over health, animal welfare, or environmental sustainability, more and more Brits are choosing vegan or plant-based options. But what do the latest UK vegan statistics reveal about how this trend is shaping the market, and what‚Äôs next for plant-based eating in the UK? 
Here, we‚Äôve compiled 25 compelling statistics about the UK‚Äôs growing vegan movement. From market trends to consumer attitudes, these figures shed light on why veganism is here to stay‚Äîand why more people are making the switch to plant-based foods in 2025 and beyond. 
1. Vegan Population Growth in the UK
Since 2022, approximately 4% of the UK population identified as vegan. This marked a steady rise from previous years, demonstrating the ongoing shift towards plant-based diets in the UK. A decade ago, only a small fraction of people embraced veganism, but now it‚Äôs rapidly becoming more mainstream. (Statista) 
2. Veganism: From 0.25% to 4% in Just a Few Years
Back in 2014, just 0.25% of the UK population‚Äîaround 150,000 people‚Äîfollowed a vegan lifestyle. However, by 2016, the number had more than doubled to 276,000 (0.46%). This rapid growth signals how quickly veganism has become a lifestyle choice for many in the UK. (The Goodness Project) 
3. Saving Animals Through Veganism
A staggering 600,000 vegans in the UK collectively save an estimated 22.2 million animals every year by avoiding meat and dairy products. This statistic highlights how significant the impact of the vegan community is in terms of animal welfare. (Food Matters Live) 
4. A Rising Tide of Reduced Meat Consumption
A third of Brits‚Äîapproximately one in three‚Äîhave either stopped eating meat or significantly reduced their consumption of animal products. This shift is an important part of the broader trend toward plant-based eating in the UK. (The Guardian) 
5. Plant-Based Interest Soars
In 2019, 19% of Brits said they would consider going vegan, a sign of growing interest in plant-based diets. While not everyone who expresses interest makes the leap, it‚Äôs clear that veganism is on the radar for more people than ever before. (The Guardian) 
6. The Challenges of Going Vegan
However, 61% of Brits said they were unlikely to switch to a fully plant-based diet. This suggests that while interest is growing, challenges such as taste preferences, availability, and lack of knowledge about plant-based options remain barriers for many. (British Nutrition Foundation - BNF) 
7. Europe‚Äôs Largest Meat-Free Market
The UK boasts the largest meat-free market in Europe, valued at an impressive ¬£437 million. This market has grown significantly, driven by a surge in demand for plant-based alternatives to traditional meat products. (Statista) 
8. Vegan Purchases on the Rise
In 2021, 5% of British consumers bought vegan products. While this might seem like a small proportion, it represents a significant portion of the population contributing to the overall growth of the vegan market in the UK. (Appinio) 
9. The UK‚Äôs Future Vegan Forecast
Sainsbury‚Äôs has projected that by 2025, vegans and vegetarians will make up a quarter of the UK population. With this growth forecasted to continue, it‚Äôs clear that plant-based eating is becoming a permanent feature of the UK‚Äôs food landscape. (Sainsbury‚Äôs) 
10. Age Demographics of UK Vegans
The majority of UK vegans fall within the 30-39 age group, which accounts for 4% of the population. Other significant groups include 20-29-year-olds (3%) and 40-49-year-olds (3%). This shows that the vegan movement spans a wide range of age groups, with young adults being particularly prominent. (Statista) 
11. Veganuary: A Gateway to Veganism
In 2021, 125,000 people in the UK took the Veganuary pledge to eat only plant-based foods throughout January. This challenge, which has gained immense popularity in recent years, acts as an entry point for many to explore a vegan lifestyle. (The Guardian) 
12. Barriers to Plant-Based Meat Alternatives
Despite the growing availability of plant-based meat substitutes, some UK consumers remain hesitant to try them. A survey found that 59% of people were put off by concerns over taste, 37% found them too processed, and 29% felt that vegan options were too expensive. (UBS) 
13. Reasons for Going Vegan
A 2021 survey of 1,040 British adults found that 51% of people who switched to a plant-based diet did so for animal welfare reasons. Meanwhile, 49% cited health as their primary motivation, and 31% were driven by environmental concerns. (Mintel) 
14. Vegan Consumer Habits Extend Beyond Food
It‚Äôs not just food that Brits are choosing to make vegan; 56% of UK adults reported checking if their toiletries were cruelty-free and made vegan-friendly. This shows that plant-based attitudes are extending to a wider range of consumer choices. (Opinion Matters) 
15. Supporting Veganism in Schools
A significant 69% of UK parents expressed support for introducing more vegan meals in schools. This demand reflects broader societal trends towards plant-based eating, especially for younger generations. (The Vegan Society) 
16. The UK Vegan Food and Drink Market
In 2022, revenue from vegetarian food, plant-based alternatives, and vegan products reached an impressive ¬£1.1 billion. The demand for plant-based alternatives continues to fuel this growth, with increasing numbers of consumers choosing vegan options. (Statista) 
17. Growth in Vegan Product Launches
In 2019, a quarter of all new food products launched in the UK were vegan, compared to just one in six in 2018. This rapid increase in plant-based product introductions highlights the growing appeal of veganism for food companies. (Mintel) 
18. Tesco‚Äôs 300% Increase in Vegan Meat Sales
In 2020, Tesco reported a staggering 300% increase in vegan meat sales, demonstrating how quickly consumers are embracing plant-based alternatives to traditional meat. (BBC) 
19. Plant Milk Consumption on the Rise
By 2019, nearly a quarter of Brits were regularly consuming plant-based milk. This number had increased by 19% from 2018, showing that plant milks like oat, almond, and soy are now firmly part of the UK‚Äôs dietary landscape. (Mintel) 
20. Plant Milk Purchases Continue to Surge
In 2020, 62% of UK adults said they had bought plant-based milk, indicating that non-dairy options are becoming a standard choice for many households. (The Grocer) 
21. The Rise of Vegan Books
In recent years, the popularity of veganism has also been reflected in literature. In 2021, Waterstones recorded over 10,000 books with ‚Äòvegan‚Äô in the title, compared to just 944 in 2018, further demonstrating the growing interest in plant-based lifestyles. (Waterstones) 
22. The Surge in Vegan Restaurants
According to food delivery platform Deliveroo, the number of vegan restaurants available on their app more than doubled in 2021, with over 12,000 restaurants offering vegan-friendly options. This is a clear indication of how veganism is shaping the restaurant industry. (Deliveroo) 
23. Most Vegan Takeaway Orders in Major Cities
In the UK, cities like Brighton, Bristol, London, Manchester, and Edinburgh recorded the highest number of vegan takeaway orders. This highlights the concentration of veganism in urban areas, where plant-based dining options are more widely available. (Deliveroo) 
24. Vegan Meals Becoming a Common Part of British Diets
Between 2019 and 2020, the number of Brits eating a vegan meal for lunch or dinner increased by 46%. This reflects the growing acceptance and integration of vegan options into everyday meals. (Premier Foods) 
25. The UK‚Äôs Changing Eating Habits
The overall trend toward plant-based eating is becoming more entrenched, with more people swapping traditional meat and dairy products for plant-based alternatives. This shift is driven not only by individual health concerns but by a larger cultural movement that embraces sustainability, animal rights, and the desire for innovative food choices. 
Conclusion
The vegan movement in the UK is stronger than ever, with more people choosing plant-based lifestyles for a variety of reasons, from health and sustainability to animal welfare. These statistics clearly show that the plant-based food market is growing at an impressive rate and is expected to continue to do so in the coming years. With businesses, food brands, and restaurants tapping into this demand, the future of veganism looks incredibly promising in the UK. 
As the market evolves, it's crucial for both consumers and businesses to continue driving innovation, ensuring that plant-based options remain diverse, accessible, and delicious. If you're looking for convenient vegan meals that fit seamlessly into your lifestyle, consider trying delivered vegan meals that take the stress out of mealtime. Whether you‚Äôre a committed vegan or just exploring plant-based options, the UK vegan industry has never looked more exciting. 
In fact, exploring vegan frozen meals is an excellent way to stock up on plant-based options for busy days, offering delicious and nutritious meals right at your fingertips. Vegan prepared meals are also an easy solution

author: Nellie D. Ashmore
title: What weight loss plan is Carrie Underwood on?
text:
If there had been a ‚Äúmother bod‚Äù fact opposition, American Idol alum Carrie Underwood would win its arms down. But it takes tough work to stay in the extraordinary form, and the united states of America track celeb do a maximum of her heavy lifting inside the kitchen. 
 
In an interview with LIVESTRONG, Underwood revealed that she followed a commonly vegan food plan and described what she eats for the duration of an average day. For breakfast, she chows down on ‚Äútofu scramble with chopped peppers, onions, a few salsa, and toast.‚Äù Her lunch consists of a ‚Äúvegetarian meat and avocado‚Äù sandwich, and for dinner, she‚Äôs chowing down on as many vegetables as she will be able to. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm constantly roasting veggies, making sweet potatoes, veggie burgers, or spaghetti squash,‚Äù she defined. 
However, Underwood is not your regular flag-waving vegan. ‚ÄúSometimes you are at a birthday party, and there‚Äôs cake, and‚Ä¶you know, you cannot face up to,‚Äù she told Self in 2012. Underwood says her veganism is not a protest towards the animal farming enterprise but about where her meals come from. ‚ÄúIn my ideal world, I‚Äôd have webcams wherever food is processed, so I‚Äôd understand how easy it‚Äôs far,‚Äù she stated. She claims that she‚Äôll by no means eat meat again, but raising her personal cows and chickens for the eggs and cheese is on her wish-listing. ‚ÄúThe food could flavor higher because the animals would be glad,‚Äù she stated. 
To help keep her waistline from increasing, Underwood told Cosmopolitan that she is predicated on the MyFitnessPal app to preserve food intake heading in the right direction due to the fact she‚Äôs a ‚Äúbottomless pit‚Äù who ‚Äúcan out-consume anybody‚Äù she knows. She claimed that monitoring her food regimen pushed her to ‚Äúmake better picks‚Äù about eating. 
Underwood‚Äôs finest trick is staying far from rapid food joints and online ordering apps. ‚ÄúWe hardly ever [get] takeout or devour out due to the fact I do not want to,‚Äù she discovered, including ‚Äúit‚Äôs hard to tell while someone else makes it for you.‚Äù 
So, all in all, one aspect is for positive: don‚Äôt count on a McDonald‚Äôs or Taco Bell commercial in Underwood‚Äôs future. 
If there‚Äôs anything American Idol has taught us, it‚Äôs that occasionally losers are the biggest winners. From Jennifer Hudson to Chris Daughtry, Idol‚Äôs losers have made it all the way to the Grammys, the Oscars, and the Tonys. Even William Hung, who controlled to convert himself into a dwelling meme after being scorched by Simon Cowell in Season three, controlled to promote over two hundred 000 debut albums. 
The fact is that triumphing American Idol almost seems worse for your career than losing it. Winner Ruben Studdard hasn‚Äôt had a Hot one hundred hit because 2006, but Chris Daughtry, who didn‚Äôt even make the rostrum with a 4th location finish, penned the fastest-promoting rock record in Soundscan records. Similarly, Katharine McPhee boasts a predicted internet really worth four instances that of her Idol rival Taylor Hicks. 
For each Kelly Clarkson, who continues to personal the Billboard Top 40 over a decade after her Idol triumph, there may be a Justin Guarini, who still controlled to craft a fruitful profession after an unwell-suggested film deal. They won‚Äôt be the maximum headline-worthy stars (until you are Jennifer Hudson). However, those American Idol losers have prosperous careers. Here‚Äôs a look at what some idols‚Äô largest losers had been as much as because their defeat aired on TVs across America. 
Justin Guarini has come a long way when you consider losing to Kelly Clarkson for the duration of Season 1 of American Idol history. Somehow, his acting career continued to exist the infamous 2003 flop from Justin To Kelly. The movie, which holds a 10% score on Rotten Tomatoes, turned into so notoriously horrible that even Guarini trashed it after Twitter trolls criticized him for speaking out approximately Donald Trump. 
‚ÄúThe subsequent fool that tells me to ‚Äòstick with appearing‚Äô must be pressured to look at From Justin to Kelly until they agree I ought to ‚Äòkeep on with politics,'‚Äù he tweeted (via TooFab). 
From Justin to Kelly turned into reputedly only a small misstep for the singer-grew to become-actor, who found a domestic on Broadway with roles in principal productions like In Transit, American Idiot, and Wicked. Today, he is greater recognized for starring as Lil‚Äô Sweet in the ones Dr. Pepper ads ‚Äì wherein he joined the ranks of Flo from Progressive and the Geico gecko ‚Äî than he‚Äôs for his debut album, which peaked at No. 20 at the Billboard charts. 
Throughout his achievement, the famous person has managed to stay all the way shockingly down to Earth (blame it on crafting a profession from your most public L). According to People, Guarini married Reina Capodici, his junior excessive sweetheart, in 2009. The pair started an adorable blended circle of relatives that blanketed her child from a preceding marriage.

author: Phoenix & Rook
title: A Rare Job, Well Done
text:
‚ÄúCan you not see that the task is your task ‚Äì yours to dream, yours to resolve, yours to execute?‚Äù ‚Äï Upton Sinclair 



A garish ‚Äúroar‚Äù sounds out like the mating call of a wild boar. It‚Äôs the signature opening to a show for the ages. Big, block letters crash onto the screen like a comic-sans Tarzan swinging through jungle foliage: PRIMAL EATS. The letters overstay their welcome for a few moments, like a tombstone erected in the middle of a highway. It smooshes down on a cartoon caribou, blood splattering with eyes popping out cartoonishly out the sockets. The tableau of gore fades away slowly, giving way to the wide whites of a man‚Äôs eyes, surrounded first by a bearded face, then the massive bulk of his mountainous upper body. 



‚ÄúWHAT‚ÄôS UP, PRIMATES? I have something to show you today‚Ä¶. something mighty special.‚Äù He smirks softly, as if sharing a truly choice cut. 



The camera struggles to pan back past the star‚Äôs raw, oiled deltoids, lined with striations like a marbled flank of steak. The view reveals a sausage cooked in the midday sun, lain upon the asphalt like an offering to god. The meat‚Äôs casing gleams with the morning light, with a soft sizzlin‚Äô steam coming up off the surface. The man flips it over with a stainless steel spatula. 



‚ÄúHere we have CK Natural‚Äôs top of the line, primates‚Ä¶ A sausage that‚Äôll make a pornstar blush. It‚Äôs the whole hog, baby,‚Äù he assures with a white-enameled grin, and the slow conspirator‚Äôs nod. 



‚ÄúWe‚Äôre talkin‚Äô beastly, behemoth wild boars roaming the forests and fjords from Norway to Ireland‚Ä¶ Ripped and virile, caught at peak in mating season,‚Äù he tightens his fist before the camera, and continues, ‚Äúthen fed on algae collected from the Arctic, green and clean just like our ancestors ate. Untouched, unspoiled algae from the arctic permafrost. You don‚Äôt get more primal than that, folks. And‚Ä¶‚Äù He winks. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs made to keep RAW, nice and pink in the middle! Ultra low-temp process so all of your amino acids, your Vitamin C, are still intact, not destroyed by heat or any GMO-whatnots.‚Äù 



The roar sounds out once again, as some soundboard‚Äôs abortion of a stinger.¬† 




‚ÄúGet a look at that as it sizzles, practically begging to be eaten‚Ä¶ GET AT IT NOW, PRIMATES! I‚Äôm partnering with CK Naturals to get their Premium Pork Box out there into your grubby little hands. Just use the special code, PRIME-8, and get 20% off on your FIRST BOX!‚Äù 




 



‚ÄúThis is going into my own cabinet folks, so if you wanna be big like Prime Nate,‚Äù he pauses long enough to hoist a bulbous bicep before the camera, letting it bulge a vein for emphasis, ‚Äúact now.‚Äù 



A few minutes ensue of a very guttural, ravenous ‚Äòmukbang‚Äô as Prime Nate does unspeakable things to that road-cooked sausage, as the centerpiece of a smorgasbord of meats on an expansive, viking-Valhalla-esque long table of meats and minimal green garnishes.¬† 



‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs it folks, SMASH THAT LIKE N‚Äô SUBSCRIBE, and REMEMBER-‚Äù¬† 



The screen winks black.¬† 



‚Äî 



‚ÄúWhy do I watch this stuff?‚Äù¬† 



An unshaven man, likely in his early twenties, slides out of bed. He tosses his tablet to the side like a discarded lover, only to be interrupted by a snuffly French Bulldog that crawls onto his chest. It soon finds the wiry beard covering Andy‚Äôs chin and begins lapping, licking, shnorfeling him awake.¬† 



‚ÄúAh, Pascal! Pascal, stop,‚Äù he laughs, shooing the dog aside with a flap of his hand. The dog, ever the faithful creature, hops off the bed and trots over to its bowl. Before even rising, Andy on reflex reaches for a bag of premium canine chow and empties the bacon-and-egg flavored kibble into the waiting receptacle. Pascal then eats his breakfast, promptly forgetting his master as his little stub-tail wiggles. 



It‚Äôs time for Andy Newman to get ready for work.¬† 



His young bones creak from lack of use. He rises from bed, stretches his thin torso, and goes about his morning routine. First, he brushes his teeth, then ruins it with the worst, most bitter coffee in the world. Lastly, he sheds his plaid linen pajamas for the flat cotton-polyester of a striped corporate button-up. Once he‚Äôs shrouded his disheveled form in the pretenses of his early career, he‚Äôs ready to head out the door. A refurbished old Pinto awaits him in the alleyway outside his inner-city apartment, stuffed like a sardine behind a swinging bumper and the silver crest on the front of his neighbor‚Äôs cadillac. Forward-back, forward-back, he wiggles the old beast out of its parallel park like a hospital receptionist doing heart surgery. The cadillac bumps, just short of a scrape, and that means Andy is in the clear. 



The podcast on his way to work is not too far off the stream he watched in the morning‚Ä¶ the talking voice is just a little older, a little louder, and has a microphone instead of a longtable full of slaughtered beasts. The old prize fighter has Andy chuckling as he berates some woo-woo scientist touting his latest miracle cure scraped from the inside of a fish‚Äôs pancreas (or something like that). Andy gives it half his mind as his eyes track the traffic, his hands manipulate the wheel, and he shifts his bottom to find scant comfort in the old cracked pleather of his dad‚Äôs pinto.¬† 



Bright red, white, and blue plastic banners herald the entryway to his workplace. They line the road like a church‚Äôs choir greeting the priest, or a king‚Äôs parade complete with criers, bugles, and all:¬† 



‚ÄúCLINT KENDALL, THE NEW AMERICAN DESTINY‚Äù 



‚ÄúCLINT: LOW PRICES. TAMMY: HIGH PRICES.‚Äù¬† 



‚ÄúWE‚ÄôVE GOT NADS, DO YOU?‚Äù 



Smaller signs with ‚Äúvote yes‚Äù or ‚Äúvote no‚Äù on proposal 1, 2, 3, A-B-C dot below the bigger signs like punctuation marks in a dramatic reading of ‚ÄúSee Spot Run.‚Äù 



It wins a little smile from Andy. Despite his age, a number of those slogans came off of his old Lanobo‚Äôs word processor. Tight, aggressive slogans tested the best. He ran the demographic statistics, and even hosted some of the focus groups himself. Andy can even remember some of the bar graphs as they danced in the reflections of his thick-rimmed glasses. They all said one thing: up, up, UP. He was hired to be an intern. He knows, though, that the recommendation letter he gets will say ‚Äústatistician, analyst,‚Äù and someday‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúCampaign Manager.‚Äù 



Andy Newman knows he‚Äôs going places. For now, though, he‚Äôs making a run back to headquarters. While he was sleeping in and watching streams, Clint Kendall himself was at one of his biggest Ohio rallies yet. His campaign bus piled with merch is still nestled in the parking lot, emptied of a king‚Äôs ransom in hats, T-shirts, and playful little plastic balls that you hang from the hitch of your pickup truck. It all speaks back to an essential populist wisdom‚Ä¶ if your opponents try to paint you as a brutish, evil cro-magnon that bullies the weak, eats roadkill, and says dumb shit on TV, what do you do? 



‚ÄúYou fucking lean in,‚Äù Andy mutters under his breath, smirking like a cowboy in a Hollywood shootout. 



Andy doesn‚Äôt get to lean in for long today. The campaign doesn‚Äôt need him crouched in front of an old monitor, clacking at the keyboard, eyeballing statistics. No‚Ä¶ the campaign needs him to cater lunch.¬† 



‚ÄúHURRY THE FUCK UP, Andy!‚Äù His boss greets him as he enters the push-bar doors of the old office building. Her blond curls bounce as she berates him in a voice low enough to not carry down the hall. ‚ÄúCK‚Äôs on his way here right now, and he gets hungry after his rallies. And you know how these Ohioans are‚Ä¶ they‚Äôre frothing at the mouth for this tripe.‚Äù¬† 



She doesn‚Äôt elaborate, but Andy can imagine: hours on stage, shouting and joking, berating, even doing a little dance to the outro music‚Ä¶ Clint Kendall knows how to work a fucking crowd, and the crowd works him back. You would think it‚Äôs a joke when his crowds rave about the Deep State, scream until they turn blue, and hoist sample cups of boar semen like it‚Äôs his‚Ä¶ but then, you just don‚Äôt *get* the Clint Kendall thing. It‚Äôs like going to a world-stage concert, but better. You can cut loose. You can be the beast you don‚Äôt get to be in the boardroom or the bedroom‚Ä¶ and best of all? Your crazy ass is *changing the fucking world.* You think boar semen is silly? You don‚Äôt know campaign statistics. 



‚ÄúAndy? ANDY!‚Äù She snaps in front of his eyes. ‚ÄúSandwiches. Food. NOW. And remember, it‚Äôs gotta be high protein.‚Äú 



Andy is in charge of campaign logistics. And so, our noble intern protects his professional button-up with a tattered ‚Äúkiss the cook‚Äù apron. A noble hair net scoops in his proudly-coiffed side-sweep. He doesn‚Äôt do all of the cooking himself, of course. That would be a monumental task. Andy just‚Ä¶ picks up the grocery delivery box, sorts it out into portions, slices the meat, heats the meat, lays it across sandwiches, squirts a horrid-looking dark yellow mustard onto the meat‚Ä¶ 



Andy is an unpaid intern, you see. So everything he does is infinitely more efficient for the campaign from a cost perspective. If they hired cooks to travel with them, they‚Äôd need not only a minimum wage salary, but also transport, healthcare, their own lunch break‚Ä¶ No, this task is Andy‚Äôs cross to bear. It‚Äôs all for the credit hours. It‚Äôs all for victory. 



After a half-hour‚Äôs effort, he has a simple spread of triangle bologna sandwiches prepared along a smorgasbord of charcuterie. Little gherkins, sausages, cheeses, crackers‚Ä¶ anything that fits the grubby campaign manager‚Äôs small, manicured hands and that CK can scoop up with his hairy, liver-spotted paws. In theory. CK never actually eats the sandwiches. 



The pi√®ce de r√©sistance is a smoothie of jackfruit, carob, a√ßa√≠, spirulina, goji berry,and several scoopfuls of whey and collagen protein.¬† 



‚ÄúNothing like the ‚Äòol milk and bone to keep a man strong‚Ä¶‚Äù 



Andy wipes the sweat from his brow, and brings the tray out into the dining area. That‚Äôs when he arrives: Clint Kendall himself. 



He‚Äôs the kind of man you would be stunned to meet in his prime. Even if you‚Äôve never seen a TV in your life, you‚Äôd confuse him for a movie star, a newscaster, or a Wild West cowboy brought to life. His face is high-cheeked with leathery skin as shiny as a wax figure. His hair is always the exact same half-pompadour half-coif, with a little shock of grey running up the front. He‚Äôs a vision of charisma on TV, reading the filth of every man and woman in power, charting a vision for a New America. A fine twinkle in his eye greets his supporters, as his Kendall-blue irises fall upon each one of them in a slow, deliberate acknowledgment ‚Äî even to Andy. The years have melted and mottled his skin with gray stubble and red burnishes to his hide, but sure as shit, that chin dimple says ‚ÄúStar.‚Äù 



‚ÄúHey, kid, how‚Äôs it goin‚Äô? Good ad,‚Äù he congratulates Anne. ‚ÄúThe ‚Äònads‚Äô thing really got ‚Äòem.‚Äù 



Clint digs into his coat pocket, draws out a thin stick of meat, then cowishly chews into the Slim Jim as he stares down his nose at the table. 



‚ÄúThe heck‚Äôs this? Did we get catering from Joisey Joe‚Äôs again?‚Äù He picks up a finger sandwich, sniffs it once, twice, then drops it plainly back onto the table with a soft, wet Wunderbread-brand thud. ‚ÄúI keep tellin‚Äô y‚Äôall. One hundred and thirty-five degrees, max. This processed, overcooked bologna ain‚Äôt it.‚Äù¬† 



Leaving it for his staff, his big, silver fuzz-lined mit sweeps over and grabs up a glass of his signature smoothie. It‚Äôs what keeps him chuggin‚Äô. 



‚Äú‚ÄúAnyway. Bottom‚Äôs up.‚Äù 



Clint Kendall raises the green-frosted glass to his puckered lips, gingerly tilts the pink and purple smoothie back, and softly bobs his Adam‚Äôs apple up and down. It takes a solid five seconds for Clint to consider the bulbous goji, the slabs of jackfruit, and globs of clumpy protein powder‚Ä¶ until he sputters, coughs, and curls back his upper lip in the flehmen response. 



His face turns three shades redder. Like a bull lowering his horns, he knits his caterpillar brows together and puts them forward, eyes boring a hole in the wall with the under-whites of a Kubrick stare. 



‚ÄúThis smoothie‚Ä¶ ain‚Äôt it. No nutrition, no branched-chain amino acids, no creatine‚Ä¶ This protein‚Äôs like drinking a corpse, a pile of curled up maggots! Our ancestors weep at such a weak, mewling display‚Ä¶‚Äù His nostrils flare, showing wiry brushes of hair as if he needs all the oxygen in the room to feed his rage.¬† 



‚ÄúI TELL you all, again and again‚Ä¶. P-A-L-E-O. SImple as.‚Äù He sighs wearily. ‚ÄúWho did this?‚Äù He slowly sweeps the room with his bloodshot eyes‚Ä¶ 



CK‚Äôs ‚Äòhanger‚Äô is legendary amongst the staff, born no doubt from stress, the ravenous demands of his former boxer‚Äôs body, and just plain masculine dignity. The eyes in the room all drift sideways, one by one landing upon Andy as he clutches his hairnet in a fist behind his back.¬† 



Mortified, Andy wishes to blend into the wallpaper.¬† However, even his white button-up won‚Äôt let him blend into the sickly off-yellow and eggshell tones.¬† 



‚ÄúJeff, for the love of all that‚Äôs Holy‚Ä¶ how many times do I have to tell you?‚Äù Clint begins to pick up steam, tilting his head forward. He advances upon the intern, soon towering over him. The youngster‚Äôs sidesweep barely meets Clint‚Äôs barrel chest.‚ÄúReal men eat paleo, not powders. Got it?‚Äù He thrusts the jade-colored glass against Andy ‚Äî no, ‚ÄúJeff‚Äôs‚Äù ‚Äî chest.¬† 



Then, just when it seems Clint‚Äôs anger will reach some mighty crescendo‚Ä¶ he breathes out. Instead, he rests a mighty paw upon Andy‚Äôs shoulder and gives him a stern look, as if he wants to be proud of him, so long as Andy can show him his true potential.¬† 



‚ÄúJeff. Jeff. Jeff, jeff, jeff‚Ä¶‚Äù 



Andy doesn‚Äôt correct him. 



‚ÄúYou can go places in politics, as long as you think about others. Have empathy for their needs. Working a crowd, making headlines,‚Äù his grip tightens on his shoulder, ‚ÄúIt isn‚Äôt just about bravado. No! You need to have empathy, kiddo. Now,‚Äù he gently shoos the intern out of the room. ‚ÄúGet on, now. Let this be a teaching moment. We have campaign matters to discuss.‚Äù 



Andy doesn‚Äôt ascend from his status as ‚Äúextra‚Äù for very long. Some unseen hand pushes him out of the conference room, and the gymnasium-grade doors open and promptly slam shut behind him. Imperfect in their design, he can hear snatches of conversation: 



Ann, straight to business, begins, ‚ÄúNow, about the new health craze‚Ä¶ I think we should ride the wave. All these blog mommies touting wormwood as a cure would be great publicity.‚Äù 



‚ÄúAbsolutely not, Julie,‚Äù the distant voice of Clint dismisses. ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt be seen with that rabble. Wormwood? Get a grip.‚Äù 



‚ÄúOh, it‚Äôs harmless! How‚Äôs this any different from the Amazing Alkaline-Ammonia cure! Or‚Ä¶‚Äù 



Their words trail off. Andy usually loves this kind of candid repartee. CK may be a nut, but he‚Äôs a genuine nut. He appreciates the free exchange of ideas. Despite his hyper-masculine persona, Clint doesn‚Äôt just welcome disagreement, he encourages it. Like a real pioneer, he wants to be on the bleeding edge of everything, so all ideas are fair game. 



‚Ä¶ The exception, of course, is Andy‚Äôs big screw-up today. How could he have forgotten? Clint Kendall‚Äôs health routine is in all the ads, the youtube videos, even his website. Andy‚Äôs own blog has regurgitated it enough times, after all, with plenty of traffic as a result. Giving CK processed food is just not the ‚Äúdone‚Äù thing.¬† 



Running a hand across his wiry copper-colored beard, Andy tries to comprehend how he could let down one of the greatest leaders in a national campaign. Being on the road gives him a lot of forgivenesses and privileges, but mistakes with CK‚Äôs food aren‚Äôt one of them. How could he possibly make this right? 



‚ÄúI even got him those Rockie Mountain oysters last week‚Ä¶ how could I eff up a smoothie?‚Äù He moans, resting his head in his hands.¬† 



Distraught with his failure, and scared to death of seeing Anne again (lest she make him relive it), Andy makes his way back to the kitchen. There, at least, he can meditate on his mistake. He can measure portions, review nutrition labels, and come up with a whole new menu for the next state‚Ä¶ what is it, Arkansas? It‚Äôs home to the white-tailed deer, the bobcat, and the locals‚Äô famous pulled-pork. 



‚ÄúHe‚Äôd love that,‚Äù Andy mutters, as he takes a moment to tabulate the list in an app on his smartphone. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll write it up now.‚Äù Maybe that will keep Anne out of his netted hair‚Ä¶ 



The hour passes in mere minutes.¬† 



While scrolling through videos, hairs suddenly rise on the back of his neck.¬† 



Primal danger. He feels it snap tight in his brain like a piano wire. 



He hears the rhythmic stomp of elevated-heel dress shoes, leather clacking across concrete like the hooves of a septuagenarian centaur. Andy would know that gait anywhere.¬† 



Clint Kendall. 



Andy can‚Äôt bear to show his face. He needs to regain favor with Anne first, get her to put in a good word about ‚ÄòJeff‚Äô and his new ad campaign ideas‚Ä¶. Or, even better! He could shave. Then Andy could do a full reset. No more ‚ÄòJeff‚Äô for him! That guy left after the bologna and smoothie thing. No, Andy‚Äôs the new hotness in town, canny and clean shave- 



Thock. Thock. THOCK.¬† 



The door creaks open. 



Without thinking, Andy bolts into the pantry. His higher-order consciousness gives way to some rabbit-ish instinct in his hindbrain that says, ‚Äúhop, crawl in a hole, shove your face into a head of lettuce and never come back.‚Äù And just like that, he finds himself shrouded in the darkness amidst stacks of foodstuffs, with only the thin bars of light coming from the door slats crossing over his pallid face.¬† 



With his eyes winced shut, he hears only the rustling of Clint‚Äôs rummaging, the jostling of tableware, clinking glass‚Ä¶ It sounds like a bear rummaging through a dumpster. Then, it‚Äôs broken by the electric buzz of a blender WHIR WHIR WHIRRING to life 



Clint Kendall is absolutely pissed. He‚Äôs so pissed, he‚Äôs making his own food.¬† 



Oh fuck. Oh damn. Oh I‚Äôm the worst! 



The very thought is insane. It‚Äôs like watching a lion make a sandwich, and just as terrifying. The very peak of humanity is huddled over a stained kitchen counter, his rippling back stretching the bounds of his black blazer, threatening to tear a seam. His massive, liver-spotted fingers shake with an addict‚Äôs tremors as he fumbles with packages too small for his mighty grip. One by one he pulls out the goji berries, the jackfruit, the carob, and heaps it into a pile on the blender blades‚Ä¶ Now, the protein.¬† 



Clint‚Äôs narrowed, predatory eyes gaze down nutrition labels like he‚Äôs mapping the veins on the neck of a fresh kill‚Ä¶ and finding them wanting.¬† 



All of the real meat is in the pantry.¬† 



Andy struggles to still his breathing as the leader of men advances upon the thin, slatted door. It seems impossible to Andy that Clint doesn‚Äôt see him back‚Ä¶but the tilted slats offer him a one-way view, like a police commissioner watching a brutal interrogation through a two-way mirror, or a zookeeper watching the apes rip each other apart in their pen. It‚Äôs short-lived, as those tightly-manicured fingers wrap around the door handle‚Ä¶ 



And as fast as a claw tearing a throat, Clint‚Äôs massive hand sweeps in, and drags out his prize. 



Heart beating like the drum in a marching band, Andy gazes down to see the prey sliding away: a midsize subscription-order box of raw meat. Upon it, a culturally-confused cro-magnon pig dons the laurels of Julius Caesar, while holding a cartoonish sceptre of bone-in ham. He smirks like a true conqueror, despite his dead black-button eyes. The cannibalistic display is offset by a dollar-esque banner with letters stamped as if they could be on cattle brand: ‚ÄúCK NATURALS,‚Äù with a misprint warping the ‚ÄúT.‚Äù¬† 



You would think this meat should have been in the fridge, but CK Naturals takes ‚ÄúFresh, never frozen‚Äù to new levels‚Ä¶ after all, ‚ÄúLive meat never dies!‚Äù and ‚ÄúGreen, fed by the finest arctic algae! Feast on the vital proteins of your ancestors.‚Äù 



The eponymous CK swings the box onto the counter, heaping it like a cinderblock onto the foundation of a new development. He tears away the lid, grips the sausages mightily, and begins feeding the pig-links into the hungry clear plastic maw of the Mega-Bullet Blender. With a vicious zeal, he follows it up with a heap of bloody mincemeat, pulled pork, and the next sausage link.¬† 



CK‚Äôs breathing hastens. His cracked lips draw back, showing his whitening gums as he bares teeth, white splattered red by the stuffing, crunching, squelching of his punches pounding the morsels into the blender‚Ä¶ 



Veins pop and pulse on his temples as he places the lid, presses the button, and lets whirr again the hellish whine of spinning blades to macerate the flesh, tear the tendon, rip the skin‚Ä¶ Clint‚Äôs mouth and eyes water with a positively wriggling intensity, until soon his meal is turned to a fine pink- and red-marbled slurry.¬† 



There‚Äôs hardly a breath between the blend and the gulp. Clint tips it back, pausing only to loosen his crimson tie so his throat can bulge as he horfs down the drink. His Adam‚Äôs apple bobs up and down, guiding the sweet carnivorous juice, jumping up and down like a bullied kid being shaken by the ankles for his last few quarters.¬†¬† 



Clint Kendall, peak of perfection, lets out a relaxed sigh as the pinkish kill crusts his lips. 



There‚Äôs a blessed, pregnant pause. 



Then, hot breath beats down through the slats of the pantry door. 



The world fogs. Droplets of moisture cling to the intern‚Äôs glasses. 



‚ÄúANDY.‚Äù 



Shit. His heart beats like a metal band‚Äôs drum, threatening to end his career early. 



‚ÄúThis is how you EAT, Andy‚Ä¶ Dense nutrition, farm to table, whole and unprocessed‚Ä¶ fat is fuel, seasoned by nature!‚Äù Clint lets out a cackle, and sweeps Andy‚Äôs chin up into his paw, gripping his cheeks like a taco as he stares into his eyes. 



‚ÄúGreen AND good, it‚Äôs fueled by the algae of the ancients! We‚Äôre all just stardust, kid‚Ä¶ Ashes to ashes‚Ä¶ FARM TO TABLE.‚Äù His eyes widen, taking up Andy‚Äôs entire view: a pair of hellish, white stars taking up the sky in a supernova of madness. Then, to make the nightmare worse‚Ä¶ Ringed, wormy tendrils wriggle free from the sockets, fingering at the air, reaching, reaching for Andy, before finding the surface of Clint‚Äôs fleshy sclera and digging back into it like fresh, loamy soil‚Ä¶ Little flares of hungry life dig out then arc back in like solar flares. Below, the star‚Äôs lips widen into a Hollywood ‚Äúgrin that could kill‚Äù with its bone-chipped teeth, zig-zagging mites, and acrid odour‚Ä¶ the komodo dragon‚Äôs kiss. So close, and getting closer. 



‚ÄúFermentation is your friend, Andrew. Ferment with us.‚Äù 



Once fragile, now broken, Andy‚Äôs mind is cast adrift.¬† 



He lay for hours upon heaps of cauliflower flower, trying to reconcile the stress of his hellish life, and the madness that it has just shown him.¬† 



Andy lays limp in a dreamlike state, until the evening security finds him hyperventilating in the breakroom, and promptly wheels him out by the shoulders. Andy‚Äôs worn pleather shoes take him the rest of the way to the car.¬† 



While Andy‚Äôs brain fails him, his muscle-memory is more than adequate to pilot the steering wheel of the familiar old Ford Pinto.¬† The campaign signs wave at him as he departs, forlorn and blowing in the wind, but the words are twisted: 



GREEN AND GOOD. 



TAKE LIFE BY THE HORNS. 



RAW LIFE FOR RAW MEN. 



FERMENT WITH US. 



On the highway, on the TV screen, everywhere‚Ä¶ he sees Clint Kendall‚Äôs face.¬† 



Clint is the idol, the genius, no, he‚Äôs the monster that lives amongst the stars‚Ä¶ a supernova! The future. 



‚Äî 



On autopilot, Andy finds himself at the pet store.¬† 



Somehow, he has managed to block out the hardship of before. He‚Äôs an intern, after all. He is blessed with the superhuman ability to filter out traumatic experiences until, one day, he‚Äôll inevitably spill them all over a therapist‚Äôs notepad.¬† 



For now, Andy browses the aisles to find dog kibble for Pascal. As his eyes scan the labels, his thumbs type out the rest of his shopping list on his phone. Making lists has always been a calming practice for Andy. Today, it begins: 




Kibble for Pascal.

Diet-urinary-senior-sensitive digestion. Dr. Canin‚Äôs advanced formulae.





A rubber ball, round nubbins.



A stress stick.




His rubber heels skid to a stop in the medicinal aisle. A thin, white box with a happy canine has caught his eyes‚Ä¶ The label calls out to him like a siren, promising happy dogs with full bowls and healthy tummies. 



‚ÄúWorming solution,‚Äù he mutters to himself. He takes a beat to let it sink in. 



‚ÄúWorming solution,‚Äù he repeats, testing the words out in his mouth. 



Then he opens the app and adds: 




Fenbendazol, heart-friendly tapeworm treatment



Praziquantel ‚Äî worm formulae treatment dropper topical formula.¬†



Parentel pamoate, suspension



Jackfruit



Carob




He pockets his phone. 



Andy is certain will never mess up one of Clint Kendall‚Äôs meals again. Next time, he will use the heritage meats. Next time, he will find rare flesh. Next time, he will make his hero proud. 



A good analyst has to take care of his candidate.¬† 



Even in this moment, Andy‚Äôs eyes shine with a pollyannaish hope. It‚Äôs the same hope that has ended marriages. Lives. Empires. At the very core of his turgid optimism, four very dangerous words echo in this upstart‚Äôs unconscious mind, ricocheting off of neurons with the grace of a whirring blender. Even interrogated and beaten, Andy would never admit to them. However, if you could lay his heart on a table and slice it neatly in half, you would find written like a ransom note: 



I can fix him. 



When Clint Kendall gives him a second chance to make that smoothie, it‚Äôll be a drink he never forgets.¬† 



‚Äî 



‚ÄúHere‚Äôre yer pills, kid,‚Äù buzzes the heap-haired nurse as she slides a plastic cup across the window‚Äôs short plastic counter. 



Andy scoops it up in his hand and tosses his antipsychotics back with a gulp. 



Looking down, he sees a pair of sea-green scrubs bound by tight elastic, leading down to bare feet on speckle-tiled hospital linoleum.¬† 



Before he can contemplate his navel for long, a silver tray obstructs his view. It shepherds a gleaming glass of orange juice and, most prominently, a triangle sandwich.¬† 



The bologna is made just right: pink in the middle, just how he likes it. It has all of the Vitamin C, branch chain amino acids, and nutrients he could ever crave.¬† 



As shadows pass over the surface of the meat, Andy‚Äôs itching eyes catch the telltale wriggling of little ringed worms. The questing parasites pop up and burrow back down, like hungry groundhogs. That is, until they catch teh warmth of his hovering hand nearby. They pause, then raise up like long, wiggly fingers‚Ä¶ questing, craving his brain matter‚Ä¶¬† 



The worms lust for Andy‚Äôs aptitude in statistics. 



Fortunately, Andy is saved by all of the piquant melange of preservatives in the bread. The worms soon give up their reach, and then later give up their bodies with a crunch.¬† 



This isn‚Äôt the pork of the stars, after all. It‚Äôs just lunchmeat. 



It is, however, accompanied by a rolled up newspaper. It makes no mention of Clint Kendall‚Äôs near-poisoning, but it has plenty to say: 



‚ÄúCLINT KENDALL CONCEDES‚Äù 



‚ÄúWAR IN SAMOTHRACE‚Äù 



And finally, on page eleven: 



‚ÄúCLINT KENDALL NAMED NEW MINISTER OF HEALTH.‚Äù 



It‚Äôs a job well done.

author: James Cox
title: Diet, Health, and the Financial Impact on Life Insurance
text:
The purpose of life insurance is to manage risk. Individuals and families need protection in the event a primary bread winner passes away. 



Several factors drive what life insurance costs for an individual. Women tend to live longer, so their cost for life insurance is lower than it is for men. The healthier a person is, the less expensive it is for them to obtain life insurance. People who smoke pay significantly more for life insurance. 



Each person‚Äôs health situation is unique. Part of the process of obtaining life insurance is to collect medical samples for testing. The underwriter reviews records from your doctors over the past 5 years. They also examine driving records. 



Once all of the information is collected the underwriter evaluates the data at hand and assigns the insured person a health rating. The better the rating, the lower the premium you pay. 



So how much of an impact do health issues have on a person‚Äôs ability to afford life insurance? 







Assuming the insured lives in Pennsylvania and is applying for a 20yr level term policy with a death benefit of $500,000. Let‚Äôs examine a few hypothetical examples. 



First, lets compare 2 women who are 5‚Äô6‚Äù and have the same health profile, but the only difference being woman A weighs 164 lbs., and woman B weighs 190 lbs. Woman A is rated ‚Äúelite‚Äù and her policy costs $235/yr. Woman B is rated ‚Äúpreferred‚Äù and her policy costs $375/yr. The result is a 59% increase in the cost of protection. 



In the next example lets use the same 2 women as described above but let‚Äôs assume woman B has a major health condition, such as early stage diabetes. As a result, instead of woman B‚Äôs rating being ‚Äúpreferred‚Äù it is now reduced to ‚Äúnon-smoker‚Äù. Her cost of insurance for the same policy described above goes up to $445/yr. This is 89% higher cost compared to woman A who was rated ‚Äúelite‚Äù. 



Why is woman B rated ‚Äúnon-smoker‚Äù more expensive? Because statistically due to her health issues she is more likely to pass away and have the policy pay out its death benefit sooner, compared to someone rated ‚Äúpreferred plus‚Äù. 



In a last example, let‚Äôs assume woman B smokes cigarettes. As a result, she is rated ‚Äúsmoker standard‚Äù and her premium for the policy described above is $1090/yr. Her premium is 363% higher than woman A due to smoking. Why? Because there are significant health issues caused by long term cigarette use. 



Over time a person‚Äôs health can have a major impact on their financial security. Having poor health and not having life insurance can put a person‚Äôs family at risk when the person passes away. Having poor health, but obtaining life insurance can protect the family from the loss of a primary breadwinner, but there is a cost associated with that protection. Having good health and having life insurance is both cost effective and sensible from a protection standpoint. 



We all can utilize a variety of practices to improve our health. Diet, yoga, and exercise‚Ä¶ prevention and proactive strategies can add years to our life expectancy and reduce our expenses to protect our families. Financial security is more likely to result from good health. 



So what is a good first step? 



A recent study published in the JAMA found, ‚Äúthat the nutritional value of foods is more important to weight loss than whether you exclude fats or carbohydrates.‚Äù (1&2) 



‚ÄúWhat did matter across both groups was the type of carbohydrates or fats participants consumed: Those who ate the fewest processed foods, sugary drinks and unhealthy fats while eating the most vegetables lost the most weight.‚Äù 



‚ÄúIf you reduce starch and sugar and you increase minimally processed healthful foods like vegetables, weight will go down naturally,‚Äù said Dariush Mozaffarian, a cardiologist and nutrition expert at Tufts University who is not connected to the study. ‚ÄùAbout 10 pounds a year, which is pretty substantial.‚Äù 



What is most important is ‚Äúeating mindfully [and] getting rid of packaged, processed food,‚Äù said lead author Christopher Gardner. 



Take charge today of your well-being, both physical and financial. To learn more and discuss your situation reach out to me at james.cox@glic.com 



Retirement Income. Tax Efficient Planning. 



Life Insurance. Disability Insurance 



Socially Responsible Investing 



To learn more contact: James Cox Cell: 267 323 6936 Email: james.cox@glic.com PAS 150 South Warner Rd. Suite 120 King of Prussia, PA 19406

The opinions expressed are not necessarily of Guardian or any of it‚Äôs subsidiaries. 



Registered Representative and Financial Advisor of Park Avenue Securities LLC (PAS). OSJ: 150 S. Warner Road, Suite 120, King of Prussia, PA 19406 (610)293-8300. Securities products and advisory services offered through PAS, member FINRA, SIPC. PAS is a wholly owned subsidiary of Guardian. 



Consult your tax, legal, or accounting professional regarding your individual situation. All scenarios and names mentioned herein are purely fictional and have been created solely for training purposes. Any resemblance to existing situations, persons or fictional characters is coincidental. The information presented should not be used as the basis for any specific investment advice. Please note life insurance requires underwriting and all situations and circumstances will vary. This information is for illustrative and educational purposes only. Individual quotes will vary.
