author: Authority Magazine
title: Women In Wellness: Jeanna Valenti Of LightBox Media On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help‚Ä¶
text: Women In Wellness: Jeanna Valenti Of LightBox Media On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help Support People‚Äôs Journey Towards Better WellbeingAn Interview With Wanda¬†Malhotra‚Ä¶Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate. One of the simplest yet most important behavioral changes we can make is to drink more water. Water is vital to our health. It plays a key role in many of our body‚Äôs functions including bringing nutrients to our cells, getting rid of wastes, protecting our bones and organs and maintaining body temperature‚Ä¶Today, more than ever, wellness is at the forefront of societal discussions. From mental health to physical well-being, women are making significant strides in bringing about change, introducing innovative solutions, and setting new standards. Despite facing unique challenges, they break barriers, inspire communities, and are reshaping the very definition of health and wellness. In this series called women in wellness we are talking to women doctors, nurses, nutritionists, therapists, fitness trainers, researchers, health experts, coaches, and other wellness professionals to share their stories and insights. As a part of this series, we had the pleasure of interviewing Jeanna¬†Valenti. Jeanna Valenti, Principal at LightBox Media, is the author of The Yoga of Marketing: Balancing Heart, Mind and Spirit for Success by Indigo River Publishing with Simon & Schuster. She is a contributor to Marketing for Leaders: 10 Success Keys to Elevate You to the Next Level by Indigo River Publishing with Simon & Schuster. Thank you so much for joining us in this interview series! Our readers would love to ‚Äúget to know you‚Äù better. Can you share your ‚Äúbackstory‚Äù with¬†us? After over twenty years in corporate America, I started my own PR firm out of my house when my son was born in 2006. I‚Äôve been garnering media coverage for clients in the body, mind, spirit arena ever¬†since. Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you started your career? What were the main lessons or takeaways from that¬†story? In 2020, I organized my first TEDx Scottsdale Women event with ten inspiring female speakers. The title of the event was Re-Write Your Script: Stories of Inspiration, Transformation and Re-Invention. All was going well with the planning and implementation of the event except for one detail: We were executing the event right in the middle of the COVID-19 Pandemic. The main lessons learned/takeaways were to consider major public health threats and concerns and to take them very seriously. Due to the timing of our event, we had to take several major precautions which took an inordinate amount of time, energy and money to carryout. If we had simply re-scheduled the event for a different time, we would have likely been spared significant amounts of time, energy and¬†money. It has been said that our mistakes can be our greatest teachers. Can you share a story about a mistake you made when you were first starting? Can you tell us what lesson you learned from¬†that? Early on when I was first starting out in PR, I did not know anything about how to manage client expectations. I was able to get a client on The Oprah Winfrey Show, when she still had a television show. Shortly thereafter, the client kept wanting to know what else I could do for her. She kept expecting ‚Äúthe next big thing‚Äù in terms of media placements and coverage. I had not managed expectations well. Ultimately, getting the client on Oprah‚Äôs Show was literally a once in a lifetime opportunity. I had landed her the highest and best coverage that she could have ever wished¬†for. From that point on, I learned to create likely outcomes and scenarios for every marketing and public relations campaign I planned and executed. While dreaming and creating wish lists are inspiring and valid exercises, so are creating and researching likely and unlikely outcome scenarios so that clients can plan realistically. Let‚Äôs jump to our main focus. When it comes to health and wellness, how is the work you are doing helping to make a bigger impact in the¬†world? When I first started meditating in 2009, I thought I was undertaking the practice to better myself, calm down my nervous system and improve my overall health and wellbeing. I wouldn‚Äôt realize until nearly sixteen years later, that my meditation practice was helping the collective consciousness become more conscious, mindful and¬†aware. Can you share your top five ‚Äúlifestyle tweaks‚Äù that you believe will help support people‚Äôs journey towards better wellbeing? Please give an example or story for¬†each. 1¬†. Practice Primordial Sound Meditation. A 10-minute primordial sound meditation enhances my wellbeing by centering me and getting my energy in a grounded and positive state for the day. I first learned this practice at the Chopra Center for Wellbeing in Carlsbad, California. 2¬†. Step into nature. For at least ten minutes a day, find a way to get into nature. Getting into nature helps reduce stress, improves your mood, reduces anxiety and depression, boosts your immune system and increases your Vitamin D levels which improves serotonin levels. 3¬†. Try yoga. Yoga offers a whole range of benefits for physical and mental wellbeing. Improved strength, flexibility and balance are three of the primary benefits. The practice also reduces stress, enhances mood and improves heart¬†health. 4¬†. Eat a mostly plant-based diet. Eating a plant-based diet offers many health benefits including reduced risk of heart disease, weight management, improved blood sugar regulation and decreased inflammation. 5¬†. Hydrate, hydrate, hydrate. One of the simplest yet most important behavioral changes we can make is to drink more water. Water is vital to our health. It plays a key role in many of our body‚Äôs functions including bringing nutrients to our cells, getting rid of wastes, protecting our bones and organs and maintaining body temperature. If you could start a movement that would bring the most amount of wellness to the most amount of people, what would that¬†be? Getting people to move. Recently, someone said that sitting is the new smoking, and I believe in this¬†theory. What are your ‚Äú5 Things I Wish Someone Told Me Before I Started‚Äù and¬†why? Health and wellbeing are fundamental to living a meaningful life. Do everything within your power to live a clean and sustainable life.Meditation can change your¬†brain.Water and hydration make everything better.Nature heals.A body in motion stays in¬†motion.These simple practices create a solid foundation on which you can build a life of health, wellbeing and¬†purpose. Sustainability, veganism, mental health, and environmental changes are big topics at the moment. Which one of these causes is dearest to you, and¬†why? Mental health is dearest to me. I believe that health and wellbeing, physical and mental health, are the fundamental core of any wellness lifestyle. If we do not have our health, it‚Äôs difficult to put our attention on anything outside ourselves. What is the best way for our readers to further follow your work¬†online? https://www.lightboxpr.com https://theyogaofmarketing.com https://jeannavalenti.com Thank you for these fantastic insights! We wish you continued success and good¬†health. Women In Wellness: Jeanna Valenti Of LightBox Media On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help‚Ä¶ was originally published in Authority Magazine on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

author: dawnwatch
title: Ocean damage and pet rescue after fires, horseracing, veggie Denmark + more 2/2/2025
text:
Today‚Äôs, Sunday February 2, Los Angeles Times includes a heartwarming story about animal rescue after the Los Angeles fires, but it comes on the heels of a front-page story, on Thursday, of the ocean destruction those fires are wreaking. Today‚Äôs LA Times also has a story on the California horse racing industry, asking if it is too late to fix it. (Let‚Äôs hope so!)¬†The New York Times has run an in-depth story on the death of volunteer dog-rescue pilot Seuk Kim. And the Guardian has a story on efforts to encourage plant-based eating in Denmark, which could serve as a course in effective activism. 
‚Äî 
Today‚Äôs lead Los Angeles Times story on post-fire pet rescue, on page B1, is titled, ‚ÄúFurry, feathery tales from the fires front¬†lines.‚Äù 
Reporter Steve Lopez followed the work of rescuer Jessica Davis of¬†Boomer‚Äôs Buddies and has also shared other rescue stories, including a touching effort to save a goldfish. If you hit a paywall at the link above you can use this Yahoo link instead. 
‚Äî 
Thursday‚Äôs front-page Los Angeles Times story, ‚ÄúBlazes may worsen ocean pollution,‚Äù tells us: 
‚ÄúThe smoke that has choked Los Angeles, the debris piled up along decimated streets, the charred and toxic remnants of thousands of destroyed homes, businesses, cars and electronics ‚Äî nearly all of it, eventually, will come to rest in the ocean.‚Äù 
We learn that as the fires raged, ‚ÄúWildlife counts were temporarily suspended when the smoke became too thick to make out seabirds and marine mammals. 
Fire debris clouded the ocean‚Äôs surface as far as 100 miles offshore.‚Äù 
And we read: 
‚ÄúThe rain this week was the first significant precipitation in the region since May. In addition to the fires‚Äô ash and chemical residue, it was also the first flush of nine months‚Äô worth of daily pollution into the sea. 
‚ÄúLocal environmental groups like Heal the Bay¬†have urged¬†beachgoers to avoid water contact at any beaches from Malibu‚Äôs Surfrider Beach down to Dockweiler State Beach near L.A. International Airport. 
‚ÄúThe Los Angeles County Department of Public Health has issued¬†similar ocean precautions¬†and even¬†beach closures, along with¬†a map of closed or contaminated beaches.‚Äù 
Here‚Äôs a Yahoo link to that story in case the link above doesn‚Äôt work for you. 
Coverage of the Los Angeles fires continues to offer us opportunities to speak for animals in the Los Angeles Times so why not send a letter? Animals need our voices. 
‚Äî 
Folks passionate about the horse racing industry should respond to today‚Äôs Sports section article, by John Cherwa, titled, ‚ÄúNot in a Golden State: Declining purses, smaller field sizes and dwindling foal crops put California‚Äôs horse racing industry in trouble. Is it too late to fix it?‚Äù 
What‚Äôs missing from the story is the issue of animal cruelty. If you aren‚Äôt familiar with the dark side of the industry, please check out the Horseracing Wrongs website, which explains, ‚ÄúYou can love horses. 
You can love horseracing. You can‚Äôt love both.‚Äù And it details why. The article gives us the opportunity to do the same for Los Angeles Times readers. 
My thanks go, as always, to Elaine Livesey-Fassel for making sure we don‚Äôt miss a beat from the Los Angeles Times. 
‚Äî‚Äî- 
On Friday, the Guardian ran a story, ‚Äú‚ÄòInsanely tasty green food‚Äô: how the meaty Danes embraced a world-first plant-based plan.‚Äù As I noted above, I share it because it is so full of tips for effective activism. 
The article describes Denmark‚Äôs successful ‚Äúaction plan for plant-based foods‚Äù and we read: 
‚ÄúSo how did Denmark‚Äôs plan to promote beans and vegetables come to get widespread support and funding? 
‚ÄúFood is deeply personal and has enormous cultural significance, making it a minefield for climate action. So, the transition away from meat and towards plant-based eating had to be approached delicately, says Rune-Christoffer Dragsdahl, head of the Vegetarian Society of Denmark and one of the key actors in delivering the Danish plan. Dragsdahl says, appropriately enough, that carrots not sticks were crucial to getting agreement on the policy. 
‚Äú‚ÄôOne of the key reasons was talking about what we want more of, instead of talking about what we want less of, that is how we got broader support,‚Äô he says. ‚ÄòThere was a delicate balance. People had to feel welcome, even when they had not just differing opinions, but maybe even different versions of the truth. This was a tricky but important balance, because that‚Äôs how you secure the continued participation of people.‚Äô‚Äù 
The article is well worth reading and sharing, and, as you‚Äôll see in the last line, it pulls no punches even while guiding us to do so! 
Enjoy! 
Don‚Äôt hesitate to send an appreciative letter to The Guardian. 
I send thanks to Susan Costello for sending the article our way. 
‚Äî 
In other major media animal news shared to the DawnWatch X Feed and DawnWatch Facebook Page over the last week: 
The Washington Post shared a happy-ending story about a dog who was lost for seven years!¬†(Thanks to Lew Regenstein for sending that our way.) 
The Gateway Pundit shared, ‚ÄúAmerican Taxpayers are Still Funding Animal Tests at Iranian and Chinese Labs.‚Äù (Thanks to Cathy Lawson for making sure we saw that.) 
The New York Times covered the rescue of 1000 sea turtles in Florida. (Thanks to Teresa D‚ÄôAmico for that one.) 
KIRO 7 in Seattle covered the 96 year old Southern Resident Orca, Ocean Sun, who has lived through horrors including the Puget Sound orca kidnappings, which took her likely daughter Lolita/Tokitae to languish, for decades, at the Miami Seaquarium. 
The Center Square has covered bipartisan legislation brought by Senator Cory Booker, with strong support from Senator Rand Paul and others, to strengthen an earlier act aimed at replacing animal testing with kinder and more effective research methods. 
A Global Data story on the Yahoo Finance site tells us that a French Court ruled¬†to overturn a decree banning the use of traditionally meaty words to describe veggie products. Apparently French citizens are likely to work out that a ‚Äúhamburger vegetarien‚Äù contains no meat. 
And finally, Saturday‚Äôs Pittsburgh Post-Gazette brought us, ‚ÄúTake a bite of Veguary ‚Äî Black veganism has a month of its own: The Afro-Vegan Society promotes a plant-based diet for personal health and social justice in February.‚Äù¬†I urge all Pittsburgh area subscribers or others with a special interest in or expertise on that topic to send an appreciative letter to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette. 
Yours and all animals‚Äô, 
Karen Dawn of DawnWatch The post Ocean damage and pet rescue after fires, horseracing, veggie Denmark + more 2/2/2025 first appeared on DawnWatch.

author: Marianna Farag
title: Why I Went Vegan (And Why You Should Stop Comparing Yourself to a Cow)
text:
It was around 2010 when I moved to the U.S. after a lifetime in Europe that veganism piqued my interest. The reason was simple: as someone who already cooked a lot and had a good understanding of ingredients, I couldn‚Äôt ignore a strange little detail in my first years in the U.S.‚Äîthe meats and cheeses just looked and tasted different. And not in a good way. 



I specifically remember buying chicken breasts one day, only to find a strange layer of slime on them. I couldn‚Äôt recognize it, and that moment made me pause. Maybe, I thought, it would be a better idea to step back from meats and cheeses for a while. 



Unlike many others, at the time, who turned to veganism after watching Netflix documentaries about animal mistreatment or the dark side of the modern food system, I didn‚Äôt. (In fact, to this day, I‚Äôve only seen one of those documentaries.) My shift was more instinctive. I had a reference point‚Äîhow food tasted and felt in another part of the world‚Äîand something just seemed off. 



At around the same time, the civil war in Syria broke out. While I never lived there, my mother is Syrian, and I spent every summer there until the war began. Witnessing the violence from afar made me more sensitive to the sight of blood, even in my own home, and by extension: there would be no blood in my kitchen.  



Eventually, I transitioned to being fully vegan‚Äîa process that took several years. A trip to Jamaica, where I decided to eat strictly Ital, helped move me towards a plant-based diet too. And the more I replaced meat with vegetables, beans, and grains, the better I felt. The first thing I noticed? My energy levels improved significantly. 



Of course, over the years, people have constantly asked me the classic question every vegan hears at least a gazillion times: Where do you get your protein? 



And I‚Äôve also heard many vegans explain their protein sources to skeptics. One of the most common arguments? Cows eat grass all day, yet they‚Äôre big and strong‚Äîso we, vegans, don‚Äôt have to worry about getting enough protein either! 



Even now, I still hear people say this, and deep down, I want to scream: Please stop comparing yourself to a cow! 



Because cows and humans have very little in common. And honestly, using herbivores as an argument to justify veganism as a diet for strength just doesn‚Äôt hold up. 



Let‚Äôs break it down. 



For starters, why are some animals herbivores while others aren‚Äôt? One widely accepted theory is that in most ecosystems, plant matter is more abundant and accessible than animal protein. Animals adapt to their environment and avoid competition‚Äîso if they can survive on plants without having to fight for limited meat resources, they will. 



But here‚Äôs the key difference: herbivores, including cows, eat far more food than omnivores. The reason cows get so big is that they spend most of their lives eating‚Äîabout six hours a day. They eat about 2-3% of their body weight whereas humans ideally eat 1.5-3% of their weight (depending on factors like age, activity level, and metabolism).  



And on top of that cows are quite sedentary. A stark contrast to a cheetah or tiger, which expends huge amounts of energy hunting and moving. And I‚Äôd like to think, a stark contrast to an active lifestyle us humans should all embrace.  



Then there‚Äôs digestion. Cows have a four-chambered stomach (rumen, reticulum, omasum, and abomasum), which allows them to break down tough plant fibers through fermentation, regurgitation and microbial digestion. This process lets them extract nutrients from low-energy foods like grass. Humans, on the other hand, have a single-chambered stomach with acidic digestion, meaning we rely on enzymes and stomach acid to break down food quickly‚Äîwhich allows humans the option to become omnivores, if they wish to do so. 



And perhaps most interestingly, cows don‚Äôt just eat grass. They consume 25‚Äì50 different types of plants, intuitively selecting what their bodies need at any given time. This diversity in their diet is a huge reason they get the nutrients necessary for their size. And as we all know, the more diverse your diet, the more nutrients you absorb.  



So, if you‚Äôre willing to spend six hours a day eating 25‚Äì50 different plants and processing them through a four-chambered stomach, then sure‚Äîcome back and tell me how you‚Äôre getting enough protein to be ‚Äúbig and strong like a cow.‚Äù 



Otherwise, let‚Äôs retire the cow argument once and for all. 



I‚Äôm not suggesting you shouldn‚Äôt be vegan. In fact, I‚Äôm the first to celebrate and push a plant-forward diet (my specialty is making vegetables delicious and exciting after all), but rather than compare with a simplistic idea of a cow eating grass, let‚Äôs talk about the rich diversity of a plant-based diet available to humans, and what we can do to understand it better so we can tap into all the nutrients we need.  



Phew‚Ä¶ I finally got this off my chest.  



Feel free to leave a comment or e-mail me at thefoodcuriouslife@gmail.com

author: Authority Magazine
title: Women In Wellness: Dr Ami Patel On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help Support People‚Äôs Journe
text: Women In Wellness: Dr. Ami Patel On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help Support People‚Äôs Journey Towards Better WellbeingAn Interview With Wanda¬†MalhotraI wish I knew that managing my hormones was the foundation to my physical and mental health. It would have prevented me from blindly taking birth control for 7¬†years.Today, more than ever, wellness is at the forefront of societal discussions. From mental health to physical well-being, women are making significant strides in bringing about change, introducing innovative solutions, and setting new standards. Despite facing unique challenges, they break barriers, inspire communities, and are reshaping the very definition of health and wellness. In this series called women in wellness we are talking to women doctors, nurses, nutritionists, therapists, fitness trainers, researchers, health experts, coaches, and other wellness professionals to share their stories and insights. As a part of this series, we had the pleasure of interviewing Ami¬†Patel. Dr. Ami is a board certified pharmacotherapy specialist (BCPS) and a licensed clinical pharmacist specializing in women‚Äôs hormone health, internal medicine and preventative healthcare. Due to her own journey and struggles with PCOS, she is passionate about empowering women to take control of their hormone health, which she believes is the foundation to live a limitless life. As a Holistic Hormones Pharmacist, she provides consulting services to those with PCOS who want to conceive or freeze their¬†eggs. Thank you so much for joining us in this interview series! Our readers would love to ‚Äúget to know you‚Äù better. Can you share your ‚Äúbackstory‚Äù with¬†us? I was struggling with irregular periods and acne for a few years and was seeking answers to what could be the cause. The first doctor told me, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just stress, it will get better‚Äù but it didn‚Äôt. A second doctor told me, ‚Äújust take birth control for 3 months to ‚Äòreset‚Äô your cycle‚Äù which did not work either. A third doctor finally diagnosed me with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and told me ‚Äúhere‚Äôs birth control, it will ‚Äòregulate‚Äô your cycle and improve your¬†acne!‚Äù Despite finishing pharmacy school at the time myself, I didn‚Äôt learn anything about PCOS and hardly anything about what birth control really does. I blindly followed this provider‚Äôs advice for 7 years until I started to see my PCOS symptoms coming back. I started to get acne again, hair loss, difficulty losing weight, mood swings and seasonal depression. When I went to the Western health care system again expressing my concerns that the birth control pill is not helping anymore, I was told by multiple doctors ‚Äúwhy do you want to come off of it if you do not want to get pregnant right¬†now?‚Äù After finally finding a doctor to support my decision, I came off birth control and started implementing lifestyle changes to manage my PCOS. Seeing misinformation as a pharmacist on social media, wanting to break the stigma around PCOS as well as a desire to raise awareness, I started sharing my journey and information about PCOS on social media through Instagram and¬†YouTube. My experience, challenges and struggles drive my passion to empower women to take control of their hormone health, which I believe is the foundation to live a limitless life. Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you started your career? What were the main lessons or takeaways from that¬†story? Through my previous stories I shared, the common theme is that my concerns were dismissed and I was not getting the support I needed. Despite being a pharmacist who works in the Western healthcare system, I still struggled to advocate for myself and began to even question what I thought was best for my body and my¬†PCOS. The main lesson and take away is that only you know what is best for you and your body. It is okay to get a second and third opinion, including seeking help from providers outside the Western healthcare system. Only you can be your biggest advocate and don‚Äôt let anyone make you question your gut feeling and intuition. It has been said that our mistakes can be our greatest teachers. Can you share a story about a mistake you made when you were first starting? Can you tell us what lesson you learned from¬†that? On my journey to manage my own hormone health and PCOS, I made several mistakes! One was that I tried too many things at once and the second was that I was taking way too many supplements! I went gluten-free, dairy-free, cut back on my cultural foods, sugar and gave up caffeine‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääall at once! I became miserable! It all became overwhelming and impossible to manage. I knew I couldn‚Äôt keep up with this my whole life. Things were improving but I did not know what helped the most. The lesson I learned was to make small changes that I could maintain and was happy with making. I learned how to enjoy my cultural foods and desserts in moderation and in a way that still supported my hormones. I learned that supplements were only helpful in addition to an improved lifestyle and that also meant I did not need so many supplements. Ultimately it goes back to remembering that PCOS is a lifelong condition that impacts us all differently and to make changes that we can¬†sustain. Let‚Äôs jump to our main focus. When it comes to health and wellness, how is the work you are doing helping to make a bigger impact in the¬†world? My philosophy is ‚Äúbalance your hormones and live limitlessly‚Äù because without your health you cannot be the best version of yourself. Our health starts at our hormones. The work I do allows women to gain control of their health and their lives which allows them to become the best daughter, sister, partner, friend, mom and whatever they want to be! It allows them the energy, creativity, and confidence to live their fullest life! Imagine the positive impact women can have on the world if we were all living our happiest and healthiest lives! Can you share your top five ‚Äúlifestyle tweaks‚Äù that you believe will help support people‚Äôs journey towards better wellbeing? Please give an example or story for¬†each. I am glad you asked for 5! Because with my holistic approach I focus on 5 areas of wellness, this includes focusing on not just nutrition and exercise but also sleep, stress and¬†mindset! With nutrition, I support my clients with eating balanced meals which include protein, healthy fats, complex carbs and fiber. Focus on what you can add into your meal instead of focusing on what to eliminate to prevent feeling restricted. Focusing on adding in these different aspects will automatically decrease processed and sugary¬†foods. For movement, I say that the best exercise is the one you enjoy doing while giving your body some variety and rest! Movement can become part of your lifestyle and daily routine when you enjoy it instead of it feeling like a¬†chore. For sleep management, I bring to my clients‚Äô attention that you can do everything right with your diet and exercise regimen but if you are sleeping less than 6 hours a day or have poor quality sleep then that also has a negative impact on your hormone health! Quality and quantity of sleep are so important. My best tip here is to keep your phone outside the bedroom and get a real alarm clock for an alarm, this prevents mindless doom scrolling that throws off our sleep routines. For stress management, I remind my clients to incorporate more of the things that brought them joy as a child as a way to reduce stress whether it was playing sports, getting out in nature, doing art or playing an instrument. Lastly, mindset ties everything together because it‚Äôs our mindset that helps us stay consistent and accountable with our actions which lets us see the results we are looking for. We, especially women, tend to be really self-critical. One tip I have for improving our mindset in changing our inner dialogue and talking to ourselves like we would a loved one. That means on our health journey, motivating ourselves but also giving ourselves grace. If you could start a movement that would bring the most amount of wellness to the most amount of people, what would that¬†be? I would love for women to understand their menstrual cycles and live in a way that supports their hormones so their hormones and body can support them back. Our current society has taught us to hate our periods and just take birth control to shut it down, however it is actually our superpower. Our menstrual cycles are a report card of our health and impact everything from our mood, creativity, energy levels and long-term health. Now imagine the positive impact that would happen in the world if all women were feeling their best and giving their best to everything they do, without sacrificing their well-being. What are your ‚Äú5 Things I Wish Someone Told Me Before I Started‚Äù and¬†why? I wish I knew that managing my hormones was the foundation to my physical and mental health. It would have prevented me from blindly taking birth control for 7¬†years.I wish I knew that managing my hormone health is a lifelong journey because instead of focusing on perfection and short-term results, I would have started slower and in a more sustainable way of making lifestyle changes.I wish I knew that this process isn‚Äôt meant to be miserable but instead can actually be enjoyable because I do not want to feel like I am battling with my body everyday but instead I am supporting my body and it is supporting me.I wish I knew that self-care wasn‚Äôt selfish. Prioritizing my hormone health and mental health is all a form of self-care because this would have prevented me from my health below other people‚Äôs¬†needs.I wish I knew to trust my intuition and get the right help sooner. I wish I knew I did not have to go on this journey alone because it would have made it less isolating and having the right support system would help me not only reach my goals sooner but would support my emotional and mental wellbeing.What I love now is that I get to help my clients understand these lessons so they don‚Äôt have to learn them the hard way by experiencing them themselves. Sustainability, veganism, mental health, and environmental changes are big topics at the moment. Which one of these causes is dearest to you, and¬†why? All of these topics are important to me but one that is the dearest is mental health. Additionally, our hormone health has a big impact on our mental health. Having a hormone imbalance can contribute to lower levels of neurotransmitters like serotonin which can contribute to increased likelihood of anxiety and depression. It‚Äôs a double edged sword because hormone imbalance and PCOS can lead to symptoms like acne, hair loss, difficulty losing weight and unwanted facial hair growth which can have a negative impact on an individual‚Äôs mental health because it can lead to feelings of low self-esteem and low self-confidence. Personally, when my PCOS was unmanaged I struggled with anxiety, seasonal depression, mood swings, and an eating disorder. It was only after I learned to manage my PCOS did my mental health improve and this is another reason why I am so passionate in supporting others to improve their PCOS and hormone¬†health. What is the best way for our readers to further follow your work¬†online? The best way is to connect with me on Instagram at holistic.hormones.pharmacist. I also have free content through my podcast called the Holistic Hormones Podcast which you can also view on¬†YouTube. My website has information about other free resources like masterclasses, joining my email list as well as information to get personalized support. My website is www.dramipharmacist.com Thank you for these fantastic insights! We wish you continued success and good¬†health. Women In Wellness: Dr Ami Patel On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help Support People‚Äôs Journe was originally published in Authority Magazine on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

author: Authority Magazine
title: Women In Wellness: Heather Young Of Fasted Athlete On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help‚Ä¶
text: Women In Wellness: Heather Young Of Fasted Athlete On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help Support People‚Äôs Journey Towards Better WellbeingAn Interview With Wanda¬†MalhotraProgress Over Perfection: When I first started, I believed everything needed to be flawless before I could take the next step. Whether it was branding, product development, or marketing, I spent too much time perfecting every detail instead of focusing on progress. I‚Äôve learned that it‚Äôs better to launch, learn, and improve as you go. Perfection isn‚Äôt what connects with people‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääauthenticity and effort¬†do.Today, more than ever, wellness is at the forefront of societal discussions. From mental health to physical well-being, women are making significant strides in bringing about change, introducing innovative solutions, and setting new standards. Despite facing unique challenges, they break barriers, inspire communities, and are reshaping the very definition of health and wellness. In this series called women in wellness we are talking to women doctors, nurses, nutritionists, therapists, fitness trainers, researchers, health experts, coaches, and other wellness professionals to share their stories and insights. As a part of this series, we had the pleasure of interviewing Heather¬†Young. Heather Young is the CEO & Co-Founder of Fasted Athlete, a wellness supplement brand that‚Äôs changing the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù behind personal health. She created the company alongside her husband, Kevin Young, as a solution for their shared health issues: mental burnout, physical exhaustion, gut health struggles and more. They envisioned a line of supplements designed to support overall health and wellness without compromising on purity or performance. Heather has been a co-founder and investor of Fasted Athlete since its inception in 2022, and she now leads the company‚Äôs strategic direction as the new CEO and majority owner of the company. With her background in business strategy, she is working to make the wellness industry more inclusive and approachable for¬†all. Thank you so much for joining us in this interview series! Our readers would love to ‚Äúget to know you‚Äù better. Can you share your ‚Äúbackstory‚Äù with¬†us? Thank you for having¬†me! When I was younger, I didn‚Äôt have access to a healthy lifestyle or many wellness resources. But I always had a vision of how I wanted to look, and I was willing to do anything to achieve those body image goals. I worked out seven times a week, relied on highly caffeinated pre-workouts, and pushed through on very little sleep. My focus was purely on appearance, even if the things I was doing weren‚Äôt making me feel¬†great. It wasn‚Äôt until I met my health-conscious husband, Kevin, that I started to see wellness in a completely different way. He introduced me to the idea that health is about so much more than how you look‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about feeling good, having energy, and taking care of your body in a sustainable way for longevity. This shift in perspective changed everything for¬†me. Now, I approach health and wellness with moderation. I don‚Äôt work out seven times a week, count macros, or follow extreme diets. Instead, I focus on practices that make me feel balanced and energized. I became especially fascinated by gut health and its impact on so many aspects of well-being‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämood, skin, energy levels, and overall¬†health. This passion eventually led me to take on a leadership role at Fasted Athlete, where I‚Äôm now the majority owner. I was drawn to the brand‚Äôs commitment to quality and innovation, particularly with products like colostrum that support foundational health. It‚Äôs incredible how little attention we often give to gut health, even though it plays such a central role in how our bodies function. If your gut isn‚Äôt in balance, you can‚Äôt properly absorb nutrients, which impacts everything else. My goal now is to help others understand and prioritize this often-overlooked piece of health through education and high-quality products that support real, sustainable wellness. Can you share the most interesting story that happened to you since you started your career? What were the main lessons or takeaways from that¬†story? Early on in the company‚Äôs history, Kevin, the original founder, was at a crossroads. He needed to raise capital to take Fasted Athlete to the next level and was considering partnering with someone who had the financial resources to help. However, this potential partner didn‚Äôt share the same fundamental values as the¬†company. That‚Äôs when I stepped in. I told Kevin that I wanted to be more involved‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot just as someone who could provide the capital, but also as a partner with strategic insight and values that aligned with the mission of Fasted Athlete. Looking back, it was one of the best decisions I‚Äôve ever¬†made. The lesson I learned from this experience is that the people you choose to join you on a mission can truly make or break a company. Having partners and team members who are aligned in vision and values creates the foundation for long-term success. That moment solidified my role in the company and reaffirmed how important it is to stay true to your principles, even when facing tough decisions. It has been said that our mistakes can be our greatest teachers. Can you share a story about a mistake you made when you were first starting? Can you tell us what lesson you learned from¬†that? When I first became more involved with Fasted Athlete, we made a big mistake by focusing too much on perfecting complicated packaging rather than on what truly mattered‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääconnecting with our customers and building brand awareness. We spent countless hours assembling, adjusting, and reworking the packaging, but this came at the expense of more meaningful efforts to grow the¬†brand. As a result, more than 1,500 units ended up expiring and had to be disposed of. It was a tough and costly lesson, but it taught us the importance of prioritizing the essentials and keeping things simple. Now, we focus on creating packaging that is practical, efficient, and aligned with the needs of our customers so we can dedicate more time and energy to sharing our mission and building connections. Let‚Äôs jump to our main focus. When it comes to health and wellness, how is the work you are doing helping to make a bigger impact in the¬†world? At Fasted Athlete, our mission is to simplify wellness and make it more accessible to people in their everyday lives. The work we do focuses on addressing foundational health needs, starting with gut health, which is often overlooked but impacts everything from energy and mood to immunity and skin¬†health. One key aspect of our approach is advocating for occasional, moderate fasting as a sustainable practice. When done thoughtfully, fasting can help reset the body, support gut health, and boost longevity by giving the body a chance to repair and rejuvenate itself. We‚Äôre committed to helping people incorporate fasting in a way that feels achievable and balanced, rather than extreme or overwhelming. Through products like colostrum, we‚Äôre helping people take control of their health in a sustainable way. What excites me most is the ripple effect‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhen someone feels better, they have more energy to show up for their family, their work, and their community. That‚Äôs the kind of impact that goes beyond the individual and starts to make a bigger difference in the¬†world. We also strive to educate people about health in a way that‚Äôs approachable and empowering. Wellness can feel overwhelming, but we focus on small, actionable steps that fit into anyone‚Äôs lifestyle. By prioritizing simplicity, moderate fasting, and long-term health, we‚Äôre creating solutions that help people thrive‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot just in the short term, but for the long¬†haul. Can you share your top five ‚Äúlifestyle tweaks‚Äù that you believe will help support people‚Äôs journey towards better wellbeing? Please give an example or story for¬†each. 1¬†. Prioritize Gut Health: Your gut is often called your ‚Äúsecond brain‚Äù because it influences so much‚Ää‚Äî‚Äämood, energy, immunity, and even skin health. One simple way to prioritize gut health is to include nutrient-dense foods and probiotics in your diet. For me, the biggest game-changer was incorporating colostrum into my daily routine. I noticed improved digestion and clearer skin within weeks. It‚Äôs a small tweak, but when your gut is in balance, everything else starts to feel¬†better. 2¬†. Embrace Moderate Fasting: Occasional, moderate fasting can give your body time to reset, lower inflammation, promote recovery, and boost longevity. I used to think fasting meant starving myself, but I learned from my husband Kevin that it‚Äôs not about weight loss‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about supporting your body‚Äôs natural repair processes. For example, doing a 24-hour fast every now and then has helped me feel more energetic and balanced. It‚Äôs a practice I approach with intention, focusing on how it supports recovery and overall wellness without being¬†extreme. 3¬†. Simplify Your Wellness Routine: When I first got into health, I was guilty of overdoing it‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääworking out seven days a week and chasing complex diets. Now, I‚Äôve learned that less is often more. I focus on a few core practices that I can sustain long-term, like moving my body daily (even if it‚Äôs just a walk), staying hydrated, and eating whole foods. Simplifying my routine has helped me stay consistent without feeling overwhelmed. 4¬†. Make Sleep Non-Negotiable: I used to sacrifice sleep to fit everything into my day, but I‚Äôve come to realize that sleep is the foundation of wellness. For me, prioritizing a consistent bedtime and creating an evening wind-down routine‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike putting my phone away and drinking a calming tea‚Ää‚Äî‚Äähas dramatically improved my energy and focus. Better sleep has made every other part of my wellness journey¬†easier. 5¬†. Focus on Connection and Community: Wellness isn‚Äôt just physical; it‚Äôs emotional and social, too. I‚Äôve found that being part of a community or having meaningful connections can significantly enhance your overall well-being. For example, building Fasted Athlete into a mission-driven brand has brought me closer to others who are passionate about health, and those connections have been so fulfilling. Whether it‚Äôs joining a fitness group, spending time with loved ones, or volunteering, prioritizing connection makes a huge difference. These lifestyle tweaks aren‚Äôt about perfection‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääthey‚Äôre about small, intentional changes that add up over time. Each one has transformed my approach to wellness, and I hope they inspire others to make tweaks that align with their own¬†journey. If you could start a movement that would bring the most amount of wellness to the most amount of people, what would that¬†be? If I could start a movement, it would be a wellness program called ‚ÄúThe 180 Reset.‚Äù This program is designed to provide a sustainable alternative to extreme challenges like 75 Hard, focusing on balance and long-term health. The goal is to help people make a 180-degree shift in their lifestyle by adopting achievable habits that promote well-being without the pressure of perfection. The 180 Reset would¬†include: Work out 3 times a week: A mix of strength, cardio, or yoga tailored to individual needs.5,000 steps a day: A manageable way to stay active and encourage daily movement.Daily meditation: Just 5‚Äì10 minutes to reduce stress and improve mental¬†clarity.18-hour fast twice a week: To support recovery, lower inflammation, and boost longevity.A whole foods diet: Encouraging the consumption of unprocessed, nutrient-dense foods for overall¬†health.What sets The 180 Reset apart is its focus on sustainability and balance, not extremes. This program is about creating small, consistent changes that are realistic and fit into daily life. It‚Äôs designed to help people feel good, build better habits, and create lasting transformations in their health and wellness. With The 180 Reset, the journey isn‚Äôt about achieving quick results‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about developing a lifestyle that supports long-term vitality and happiness. What are your ‚Äú5 Things I Wish Someone Told Me Before I Started‚Äù and¬†why? Progress Over Perfection: When I first started, I believed everything needed to be flawless before I could take the next step. Whether it was branding, product development, or marketing, I spent too much time perfecting every detail instead of focusing on progress. I‚Äôve learned that it‚Äôs better to launch, learn, and improve as you go. Perfection isn‚Äôt what connects with people‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääauthenticity and effort¬†do.Your Team Is Everything: I wish someone had told me how critical it is to surround yourself with people whose values align with yours. Early on, we almost partnered with someone who didn‚Äôt share the same vision, and it would have completely derailed the company. Now, I‚Äôm intentional about working with people who are not only skilled but also deeply committed to the mission. The right team can amplify your¬†success.Know When to Say No: In the early days, I said yes to almost every opportunity because I thought more was always better. Whether it was partnerships, marketing ideas, or product features, I stretched myself and the team too thin trying to do everything. I‚Äôve learned that saying no to the wrong things creates space for the right opportunities. Focus and alignment are far more valuable than quantity.Build a Community, Not Just a Brand: I wish someone had told me how important it is to cultivate a sense of community. It‚Äôs not just about selling products or services‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about creating a space where people feel heard, supported, and connected to a larger mission. Building that community takes time and effort, but it‚Äôs what turns customers into advocates and a business into a movement.Take Care of Yourself First: Building a business or pursuing a wellness journey can feel all-consuming, but I‚Äôve learned that you can‚Äôt pour from an empty cup. There were times I sacrificed sleep, workouts, or even meals because I was so focused on the work. Now, I prioritize my own health‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbalanced eating, regular movement, and sleep‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbecause when I feel good, I can show up better for the company and my¬†team.Sustainability, veganism, mental health, and environmental changes are big topics at the moment. Which one of these causes is dearest to you, and¬†why? While all of these causes are important, mental health is the dearest to me because of my personal experiences growing up. My mom battled schizophrenia, and watching her struggle profoundly shaped my understanding of the importance of mental health. It taught me that mental wellness isn‚Äôt just about addressing symptoms‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about nurturing the whole person, including the connection between the mind and¬†body. One area I‚Äôve become particularly passionate about is the connection between gut health and mental health. Research increasingly shows that the gut and brain are closely linked through what‚Äôs called the gut-brain axis. Studies have found that an imbalance in gut bacteria can impact the production of neurotransmitters like serotonin, which regulates mood. In fact, the gut produces about 90% of the body‚Äôs serotonin, making gut health essential for mental well-being. I‚Äôve personally experienced the impact of gut health on how you feel. When I began focusing on improving my digestion and incorporating supplements like colostrum, I noticed a difference‚Ää‚Äî‚Äänot just in my energy levels but in my overall mood and clarity. This has fueled my passion for helping others understand how taking care of their gut can have a ripple effect on their mental¬†health. I want to continue advocating for this connection because small, actionable changes‚Ää‚Äî‚Äälike improving diet, managing stress, or incorporating probiotics‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcan empower people to feel better both mentally and physically. Mental health has always been close to my heart, and this holistic approach is something I believe can make a profound difference in people‚Äôs¬†lives. What is the best way for our readers to further follow your work¬†online? You can follow Fasted Athlete on social media at @fastedathleteco and @puregoldcolostrum, or visit our website at fastedathlete.com. Thank you for these fantastic insights! We wish you continued success and good¬†health. Women In Wellness: Heather Young Of Fasted Athlete On The Five Lifestyle Tweaks That Will Help‚Ä¶ was originally published in Authority Magazine on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

author: ThomasSTL
title: Burger flipper turned committed vegan launches animal welfare charity
text:
Andy Shovel, who worked at McDonald‚Äôs and co-founded THIS, says A Bit Weird aims to ‚Äòdisarm people through fun‚Äô



Esther Addley 







Andy Shovel‚Äôs career to date has been, you might say, a journey. A little over a decade ago he was working on the chicken station in a branch of McDonald‚Äôs. He then set up a burger delivery business in west London, which he and a co-founder would go on to sell for seven figures. 



A celebratory holiday in the Maldives and a period of research later, in 2019 they launched THIS, the range of meat-alternative packaged foods, which boomed from zero to more than ¬£20m of revenue, becoming the UK‚Äôs¬†fastest-growing food brand¬†in 2023. 



And now ‚Äì another sharp pivot. Shovel admits that his move from burgers into the plant-based market was strategic rather than ideological, but in the process he became a true believer ‚Äì and a committed vegan. Having¬†stepped back¬†from the day-to-day running of THIS last year, the one-time burger flipper is now launching an animal welfare organisation that he hopes will do as much for animal rights as his previous venture did for non-meat bacon. 



It‚Äôs called¬†A Bit Weird. Why? As the organisation‚Äôs knowingly silly¬†jingle¬†puts it, it‚Äôs ‚Äúbecause some of the stuff we do to animals are a bit weird‚Äù. That includes killing 30 million male chicks in gas chambers or macerators each year in Britain because they can‚Äôt lay eggs, something Shovel has set out to try to ban. The painful method by which male lambs are castrated to improve the flavour of their meat is next in his sights. 



He‚Äôs hoping to achieve this with a mixture of careful research ‚Äì the stint at McDonald‚Äôs was a very strategic attempt to learn about the fast-food business ‚Äì and fun. THIS may have forced its way into the nation‚Äôs freezer cabinets by leaning heavily on product innovation, but it also had an anarchic approach to marketing, such as when the company staged a¬†mock funeral procession for bacon¬†through the streets of central London. 



Shovel wants to do something similar for the welfare of animals. Hence the word ‚Äúweird‚Äù, rather than shocking or appalling or indefensible. People have been ‚Äúrepelled‚Äù by vegan campaigning in the past, he argues, ‚Äúbecause it‚Äôs all synonymous with judgment and sanctimony that people don‚Äôt enjoy‚Äù. 



For a start, he‚Äôs not trying to make you a vegan ‚Äì at least not yet. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not saying don‚Äôt eat animals. I‚Äôm not saying don‚Äôt eat dairy. It‚Äôs all good. A Bit Weird‚Äôs attitude is ‚Äì crack on.‚Äù It is an approach that has won him some criticism from longer-established campaigners, he admits, but his plan is ‚Äúto disarm people through humour and silliness and fun, so that they didn‚Äôt see us as another vegan brand lecturing them about their life choices‚Äù. 



Could a tiny organisation, just a month after launching, really hope to trigger large-scale change in the British egg industry? Shovel doesn‚Äôt see why not ‚Äì and his prior experience in food retail at least gets him through doors. Chick culling has already been banned in Germany and¬†France, and the technology exists to replace it, Shovel argues. Why not do the same in Britain? And why not try to make the campaign fun? 



He promises research-led engagement with the industry, lobbying of government, public awareness campaigns, legal challenges ‚Äì and stunts. 



‚ÄúI‚Äôve had this itch for years ‚Ä¶ there‚Äôs almost a gap in the market with animal advocacy, if I‚Äôm going to be a businessperson about it, for someone to take quite serious messages and market them in a not serious way. 



‚ÄúI have a general firm view which is that I don‚Äôt want my lunch to have felt fear or anguish or pain. And I think that‚Äôs an uncontroversial thing.‚Äù

author: Michael Woudenberg
title: Veganism: A First-World Luxury
text: Welcome to Polymathic Being, a place to explore counterintuitive insights across multiple domains. These essays explore common topics from different perspectives and disciplines to uncover unique insights and solutions. Today's topic looks straight into the diet of Veganism and finds some uncomfortable truths. We‚Äôll look at how natural it is, whether it can be achieved without first-world technology, and what it means globally. Buckle in for an adventure! Intro Veganism is pretty simple. You eat nothing that has animal protein of any nature. (some even include honey in that mix) It‚Äôs a diet that also attracts a lot of very opinionated and passionate people. It‚Äôs one that quickly falls into the psychology of religion in a great many conversations.1 That said, I don‚Äôt intend to debunk the diet or convince anyone to get off it. My goal for today‚Äôs investigation is to contextualize it. To that end, three things are required for veganism: You cannot be vegan off of whole foods alone. You must rely on globalization, as regional plants do not have the nutritional variety to support veganism. You require advanced chemistry, industrial laboratories, and ultra-processing to get all of the required nutrients. As such, you couldn‚Äôt have been a vegan except in the last fifty years of human history. Simply put, it‚Äôs not how our bodies evolved to ingest and process nutrients. This isn‚Äôt a deal-breaker for veganism; it‚Äôs just a contextualization since most people aren‚Äôt aware of these three facts. Let‚Äôs break them down one by one. #1: Whole Foods. Plant life is not nutritionally dense. This is true in general, but even our most nutritionally dense whole foods have often been bred over thousands of years to achieve that density. Moreover, plants lack the concentration of fats and protein we need as humans. This is why vegans must supplement their diets with highly concentrated pea protein and exotic plant fats like coconut and avocado oil. Most critically, there‚Äôs an essential vitamin, B12, that humans need, which you cannot get from plants or fungi. It has to be synthetically produced and fortified into a vegan diet. An issue is that synthetic B12 isn‚Äôt taken up by the body as well as B12 from animal protein.2 How essential is B12 for your health?3 Well, just about everything from your brain to nerves, to energy production, to DNA requires it. The National Institutes for Health describes it like this: Vitamin B12 is a nutrient that helps keep your body‚Äôs blood and nerve cells healthy and helps make DNA, the genetic material in all of your cells. Vitamin B12 also helps prevent megaloblastic anemia, a blood condition that makes people tired and weak.4 A counterargument is that there are many animals, like cows, koalas, and gorillas, that eat only plants. However, they eat constantly, around 18 hours a day, and their bodies have a metabolism to process it. The koala, for example, is sluggish because eucalyptus leaves are full of toxins, and they‚Äôve evolved to process them. Cows are more interesting: They‚Äôre actually chemical plants, fermenting grass with bacteria and then digesting the dead bacteria into the necessary fats, protein, and nutrients and not from the grass.5 Lastly, that gorilla eats over 40 pounds of food daily and has a vast gut track with bacteria that ferment cellulose into short-chain fatty acids.  Simply put, humans cannot ingest enough nutrients, amongst the rest of the calories, from whole food plant material to maintain a healthy diet without supplements.  #2: Globalized Food Chain Compounding the whole foods issue is that, without our highly advanced global food chain, even the number of whole food materials available would be greatly diminished. Remember those coconuts and avocados? They‚Äôve only recently become available in the quantities needed for a vegan diet. Fifty years ago, they were a novelty; even thirty years ago, they were hard to find fresh.6 Image by Markus Kammermann from PixabayThe issue is that plant life is highly regional and specified. Prior to the¬†Columbian Exchange, staples like potatoes, peppers, tomatoes, squash, pumpkins, and more wouldn‚Äôt have been known to Europeans. Likewise, soybeans and their subsequent fermented derivatives, like tofu, were limited to Asia. Native Americans didn‚Äôt have legumes, like peas, which comprise much of the protein and fats in vegan diets. Considering the global variety of foods required to balance a vegan diet, it was impossible to achieve enough nutritional diversity even fifty years ago, let alone for it to be a natural alternative for human evolution. Regional food is not diverse enough for a healthy vegan diet and requires a global supply chain. #3: Ultra Processing This last issue is the solution to the first two. Because we lack the nutritional density within whole foods and need to process and collect plant material worldwide, we rely on advanced processing technologies, extraction techniques, and laboratories to synthesize supplements. Even natural foods and plants often contain toxins that require processing. Cassava is a great example that can cause malnutrition and paralysis if not rendered properly.7 Corn (maize) is another example where the failure to nixtamalize corn results in pellagra, a crippling disease.8 Even the ubiquitous cucumber has been bred to remove the toxins from their skins over the centuries. Image by Chokniti Khongchum from PixabayThe next step of processing is often through concentration. Seed oils come to mind here, where plants like corn, rapeseed, grape seeds, and others are processed into concentrations that you couldn‚Äôt physically ingest consuming the whole seed. Rapeseed (Canola Oil) is especially egregious with solvent extraction processes using hexane, then refining, bleaching, and deodorizing steps to produce the final product.9 Sometimes, the processing of vegan food is straight out of a laboratory where they‚Äôre creating something that just doesn‚Äôt exist in nature. Let‚Äôs look at the Impossible Burger. I think it gets the name ‚ÄòImpossible‚Äô as a function of how hard it is to find out how they make it. I started on their website¬†and was presented with a lot of nice hand-waving about the process. They do admit to ultra-processing and using genetically modified ingredients, but this is all cloaked in the obfuscation of reality. The ingredient list starts off innocuously enough: Water, Soy Protein Concentrate, Coconut Oil, Sunflower Oil, Natural Flavors, and 2% or less of many vitamins and starches. Their main laboratory breakthrough is deriving heme from soybeans to mimic the ‚Äúblood feel‚Äù of a real burger; this is where it gets more complicated. Impossible Foods produces heme via fermentation in large batches. After fermentation, the protein is separated from the yeast and fermentation. This separation requires clean water to isolate target heme before being used as the key ingredient in the Impossible Burger. The Impossible Burger also uses genetically engineered soy to produce its heme.10 Let‚Äôs look a bit more closely at the production of heme: Extract DNA from the root nodules of soy plants, where heme is produced.11 Insert the DNA into genetically engineered yeast cells.12 Ferment the yeast to grow the volume for harvest13 Isolate the soy leghemoglobin from the yeast.14 Then, add the soy leghemoglobin to give them a meaty flavor.15 I‚Äôm not trying to scare you with the idea of ‚Äòchemicals.‚Äô I‚Äôve seen enough fear-mongering around misunderstandings that everything is a chemical and, yes, everything is processed to a point. I‚Äôm sure we all remember the Dihydrogen Monoxide parody over the years. My point is merely to show that Vegan food specifically requires exceptionally high-tech and precise laboratory conditions to ensure the majority of the nutrients vegans eat. Even if vegans don‚Äôt spend all their time trying to make their vegetables taste like meat and cheese, their diet still requires ultra-processing to achieve the required nutrition balance. The regular use of¬†nutritional yeast¬†requires advanced processing equal to the Impossible Burger to fortify the proper nutrients   Wrapping it Together, My main complaint about veganism is that it is not how we evolved. We also could not have eaten a healthy vegan diet just 100 years ago as we didn‚Äôt have the global supply chain and industrial processing capabilities that we have today. The other challenge is that, unless you live in an advanced technology culture like we enjoy in the First World, your ability to source a vegan diet is severely limited. To think about this another way, if you live in a third-world country or a tribal culture, you literally cannot be vegan for the very reasons we‚Äôve explored:16 17 You cannot be vegan off of whole foods alone You must rely on globalization, as regional plants do not have the nutritional variety to support veganism. You require advanced chemistry, industrial laboratories, and ultra-processing to get all of the required nutrients. However, if you‚Äôre willing to accept these points and feel that the vegan diet is a step in the right direction for humans, that‚Äôs still a viable decision. The challenge remains that it‚Äôs a difficult diet to sustain, and we haven‚Äôt developed the advanced genetic engineering, processing, and synthesis to make it healthy. Our bodies also haven‚Äôt adapted to consuming concentrated plant material in the quantities required. Another thing to consider is that I haven‚Äôt been able to find a healthy vegan who has been on the diet for over 20 years. It‚Äôs a common question I ask vegans, and it‚Äôs never been answered. Adding to this issue are two quick examples: A woman I know on the vegan diet was so anemic she had to go to the hospital for regular blood infusions. Ironically, donated by healthy humans who ate meat. Fellow Substacker  recently shared how growing up on a vegan diet likely caused lifetime pain and emergency surgery this past year. He writes about his experience in ‚ÄúHealthy Living Can Be Deadly.‚Äù Perhaps we can refine our nutritional processing to outperform whole plant and meat nutrition, but we aren‚Äôt there yet. It‚Äôs something to pay attention to as we advance and adapt. Still, we must also consider that evolution has developed humans to use our resources efficiently. In fact, our exceptionally large brains likely developed because we started to consume highly energy-dense animal protein.18 So, let‚Äôs continue to use that big brain of ours and look hard at how veganism is a first-world luxury supported by advanced processing and globalization. What are your experiences with veganism?  Drop a comment below! Did you enjoy this post? If so, please hit the ‚ù§Ô∏è button above or below. This will help more people discover Substacks like this one, which is great. Also, please share here or in your network to help us grow. Share Polymathic Being is a reader-supported publication. Becoming a paid member keeps these essays open for everyone. Hurry and grab 20% off an annual subscription. That‚Äôs $24 a year or $2 a month. It‚Äôs just 50¬¢ an essay and makes a big difference. Get 20% off forever Further Reading from Authors I AppreciateI highly recommend the following Substacks for their great content and complementary explorations of topics that Polymathic Being shares.  by : All-around great daily essays  by : Insightful Life Tips and Tricks  by : AI tips for Thinking and Writing  by : Integrating AI into education  by : Computer Science for Everyone 1 of The Vegan‚Äôs Voice is a great example of evangelism of veganism with no critical thinking or facts. He‚Äôs also a great example of cognitive dissonance as any critique results in a deflection or changing the subject. He pivots faster than a politician. 2Dr. Berg |Blog|, Vitamin B12: Methylcobalamin vs. Cyanocobalamin, 08/26/2024 3It‚Äôs so essential that the body stores 2-5 years worth just in case. This is why many vegans don‚Äôt notice health issues immediatly and why there‚Äôs a major drop of practicing vegans after 5 years when the nuerological health issues from B12 deficiency start to kick in. https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/vitamin-b12-or-folate-deficiency-anaemia/causes/ 4NIH Office of Dietary Supplements, Vitamin B12 Fact Sheet, Accessed 1/4/2025 5Moran, John, 2005, Tropical Dairy Farming: Feeding Management for Small Dairy Farmers in the Humid Tropics, p 312 Landlinks Press 6This is one reason why Millenials are known for Avacado Toast. It‚Äôs a luxury good that wasn‚Äôt available when they were kids and was a novelty as a young adult. 7Bokundabi G, Haskins L, Horwood C, Kuwa C, Mutombo PB, John VM, Mapatano MA, Banea JP. When knowledge is not enough: barriers to recommended cassava processing in resource-constrained Kwango, Democratic Republic of Congo. J Public Health Afr. 2023 Apr 28;14(5):2052. doi: 10.4081/jphia.2023.2052. PMID: 37404334; PMCID: PMC10316701. 8MedlinePlus Encyclopedia, Pellegra, Accessed 1/4/2025 9Saleem M, Ahmad N. Characterization of canola oil extracted by different methods using fluorescence spectroscopy. PLoS One. 2018 Dec 17;13(12):e0208640. 10Design Life-Cycle Website, Impossible Burger, Accyessed 1/4/2025 11John A. Cutting, H.M. Schulman, The site of heme synthesis in soybean root nodules, Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - General Subjects, Volume 192, Issue 3, 1969, Pages 486-493, ISSN 0304-4165, https://doi.org/10.1016/0304-4165(69)90398-5. 12American Society for Microbiology, The Microbial Reasons Why the Impossible Burger Tastes So Good, May 16, 2019, Accessed 1/4/2025 13Center for Food Safety, Our Beef with the GMO Impossible Burger, June 20, 2019 14Impossible Burger FAQ, How Do You Make Heme, Accessed 1/4/2025 15Wikipedia, Heme, Accessed 1/4/2025 16Some have suggested Jainism as an example of a Vegan culture, but they‚Äôre actually mostly vegetarian, and even the vegans eat milk products during religious ceremonies.  17(They're lacto-vegitaeians) Charukesi Ramadurai, Are Jains the original vegans? BBC, 4 January 2024 18Corydon Ireland, Eating meat led to smaller stomachs, bigger brains, The Harvard Gazette, April 3, 2008

author: Paul Youd
title: MY 100 ULTRAS CHALLENGE - 2024 PROGRAMME
text:
(Quick link to my donations page, click here:¬†Wonderful¬†)   Thanks for stopping by my blog.üëç I've done all my actual ultras - as opposed to my virtual ones - through¬†https://www.actionchallenge.comThey are a wonderful company who cannot do too much for you. Highly recommended. And I shall be doing 4 events with them this year:The London Winter Walk at the end of January (accompanied by my two granddaughters and one of their boyfriends!); Easter50 Challenge; the Thames Path100 Challenge¬†¬†(continuous); and the¬†Chiltern50 in September,¬†also in September.¬†üôÇ Here I try and detail all my ultra adventures - don't always succeed, as I'm not the most disciplined bloke in the world - both for my own amusement, and for anyone who is interested. I do ultra marathons for two reasons - one because they're bloody good fun, and, more importantly, they are also a means of fundraising for charities which are dear to my heart, and benefit the animals.¬† I appreciate that times are hard - but¬†these are also difficult times for charities, as I'm sure you'll appreciate. Through my ultras, I'm fundraising for Viva! who have been very active rescuing animals from Ukraine - and have an animal sanctuary in Poland. They also do sterling work exposing the horrors of animal abuse in farms and slaughterhouses. Here's a link for anyone who is in a position to donate, Wonderful¬†*¬†(whose services are completely free). Many, many thanks for the awesome support my efforts are receiving! And the animals thank you, also.*If you have any trouble with this link, please email me at paulwyoud(at)gmail.com. I have several people to whom I look for inspiration - and I found most of these on Rich Roll's podcast. Rich Roll himself, of course, is one of my heroes, being a vegan ultra runner and ironman extraordinaire. Through his podcasts I've been introduced to a whole range of endurance athletes and positive thinkers. David Goggins¬†and Fiona Oakes, stand out -¬†two of the most inspirational athletes around today. In September, I faced my biggest challenge yet - 100k continuous, along the Thames path, from Putney Bridge to Henley. 
My friends, Iain and Jo, and myself, rose early and met in the foyer of our hotel at 6.10 for the taxi, timed at 6.15. We arrived at the start just before 6.30, intending to join the first wave at 7.00am. However the queue for the baggage forwarding was huge, and we missed the cutoff time of 6.45, so we had to wait for the 2nd wave, at 7.30. 
Early morning, by the Thames, is quite special, especially on a bright sunny morning - with lots of runners, dog walkers, etc. 
My initial goal for this challenge was to beat the 61k I achieved 2 years ago, when I had to pull out at 61k, after tripping up on a malignant root.¬† 
The first 50k was pretty uneventful, but the views were amazing. We did this in about 11 hours 30. 
Leaving the halfway mark, in the gathering dusk, Jo and Iain took on the responsibility of guiding me safely along. We were warned, at the 50k briefing, of the haphazard appearance of dangerous roots right through the second 50. So, Iain took the lead, followed by Jo, and one or the other would announce the presence of danger. All the time I had my head bowed, looking at the circle of light cast by my head torch. When I heard Jo call out, ‚ÄòRoot‚Äô, I would immediately be super cautious. 
So my head was permanently lowered, which may help to explain what happened later. 
Sometime early in the morning, after the rest stop at 63k, I began to hallucinate. I began to be conscious of someone walking beside me - but when I looked round, there was no-one there. Later, this became a guy with a female on the far side of him. This was a constant from now on. Then, although we were walking on level ground, my senses told me we were going downhlll, so I started to speed up as (imagined) gravity took hold. So I kept closing up on Jo, who kept telling me to slow down. But my acceleration was involuntary. This went on for km after km - always imagining myself going downhill, and telling myself to slow down, over and over, ‚ÄúSlow, two, three, four - slow, two, three, four.‚Äù But it didn‚Äôt do any good, I still tried to go faster - with my two ‚Äòcompanions‚Äô alongside me. All the while, Jo was still calling out, ‚ÄòRoot!‚Äô And I‚Äôd try to take notice. 
Eventually, around 74k, down I went , face first into the path - this was about 2.30ish on the Sunday morning. Immediately I was surrounded by love! Jo and Iain, my two companions came to my aid, and also a young trek-master, Aisling, appeared, and took charge. She got hold of the chief medic at the next rest stop, who asked to speak to me. He asked if I could sit up - so I said I‚Äôd try - and another contestant, Natalie Padder (I now know) sat down on the trail and offered her knees for me to lean up against. I was asked if I could stand, and a guy I only know as Rich, came to help, and offered his strong left arm for me to hang on to. He was a Welshman, with a lovely sense of humour. I‚Äôm so grateful to these two especially, who had no thought of their own progress, but just wanted to help. Oh, and thanks to everyone who came past whilst this was going on, and stopped to ask if there was anything they could do. Then Trek-master Martin came by, and with his help I managed to walk back about 200 metres, to where the road came close to the trail. It wasn‚Äôt long before Driver Steve turned up in a mini-bus, and I was ferried over to rest stop 6. There I was eventually seen by a medic, Kyle, who, after a series of tests, released me in to the care of my son, who had driven up to collect me. Iain brought me a finishers medal and a T-shirt. 
So, that was the end of my 100k continuous dream - I‚Äôve since promised my very tolerant wife, Teresa, that I wouldn‚Äôt attempt another one - I‚Äôve given it two goes, and not made it, so I‚Äôll probably stick to 50k distances in future. 
Talking of which, I‚Äôve signed up to the Bath50 in March, so I‚Äôm training for this most days, averaging 40-50k per week. I covered 2226km in 2024, and I hope to improve on that on 2025. - 
Earlier, I mentioned the film ‚ÄòI could never go vegan‚Äô, in which I‚Äôm featured climbing Dunkery Beacon. You can watch it now, on Apple TV or Prime Video. 
[With a combination of virtual and actual ultras I‚Äôm on track to complete my goal of 100 ultras by my 100th birthday!] 
  
  
when (the still level) trail was formed of a compacted stone and earth, a larger rock stood proud - I hit it and went down, full-length on the path. Nothing major, but I had a large contusion on my forehead and a few other cuts and scrapes.¬† 
Here I want to give a huge shoutout to several people - firstly Jo and Iain, who were absolutely gutted; Jo went into shock for a little while, and had to sit down. Ashling the Trek-Master was quickly on the scene and contacted, I assume, the Control Room. I spoke to the Chief Medical Officer who asked me a lot of questions - I think I passed, because the decision was made to send the mini-bus to collect me, rather than an ambulance, which had been mentioned. In the meantime, Natalie sat down on the trail and offered her knees to lean back on, as I eventually managed to sit up. Then a lovely Welsh guy - Rich - appeared, and gave me a strong arm for support, as I stood up. Then Trek-Master Martin appeared, and repeated that strong arm, guiding me back 200m to where there was road access. 
Driver Steve helped me into the bus, and then across to the Medical Tent, where I was seen by Kyle, who asked me a lot of tests to determine my mental and physical acuity. Once again, I passed, and was released into the care of my son, who‚Äôd driven up to collect me. 
I got home, I think around 1-11.00am, and collapsed into bed. 
More to come, but I just need to reassure everyone that I‚Äôm merely achy and stiff - and I‚Äôm in very good spirits! And in the meantime, please take time out to admire this shiner! I mean, look at that gorgeous colour!¬† 
  
Here it is, 6 days after the event, and I've not properly thanked everyone who helped me after my fall - and those who offered help, as well.¬† 
I got to 74k, which is 13k more than the last time, when a malignant root was to blame for my fall and subsequent withdrawal. This time it was a rock I hit, and down I went - 
One of my sayings is, you‚Äôre never too old to have adventures - and adventures have their downs and ups, of course. Without my fall I may never have met: the young trek-master, Natalie, Rich, Steve and Kyle, and all the others who cared for me. And while most contestants go away with just the one trophy, I came away with three, as the accompanying pic shows. 
I‚Äôm already planning next year‚Äôs events - which, I‚Äôve promised my wife, won‚Äôt include any 100k ones! But there‚Äôs plenty on the calendar for me to relish poring over. So, see you on the trail! [This still needs some editing]  12th August 2024God, I'm hopeless - can't believe I haven't updated¬†since the beginning of the year! Now I'm hoping to do the Thames Path Challenge, mid-September, and the Chiltern50 at the end of that month.   2nd August 2024Signed up for a 161k walk along the NSW¬†coastline. Then in July I entered the Rocky Mountain Virtual Challenge - once again with Conqueror - 209k over the Rockies, which I finished on the 29th July. I finished the Land's End to John O'Groat¬†virtual in early June - took me 315 days! Then, in April, I teamed up with Iain and Jo to do the Easter Walk - which was a 50k loop around Windsor I posted this on Facebook on the 28th January:Winter Walk - first event of the yearI had 2 targets with this - the first was to have a fun day out with my 2 granddaughters (and one of their boyfriends); the second was to turn them on to the Action Challenge experience, in the hope they will want some more! And I succeeded with both. They all thoroughly enjoyed the experience, even though one of the GDs had done no training whatsoever.We completed the West Loop in 4:02, then had a very tasty veggie chilli, and repaired to a nearby pub to relive and savour the whole day.Thanks, Action Challenge - don‚Äôt know how you managed it, but the weather was just perfect. Can you do that with all your Challenges, please? December 2023Well, my health problems¬†didn't end with the¬†cellulitis - no¬†sooner had I recovered from that than I came down with my first dose of Covid-19! Thanks to my plant-based¬†nutrition, I wasn't badly affected - in fact I've had far worse colds - but, of course I had to stay¬†away from other people. So I ended up with just the one¬† So my 2 illnesses in the summer blew a big hole in my virtual trip to John O'Groats -hope to finish this round about May 2024. Monday 11th September 2023Now it's a month later, and I'm still not right.¬†The ankle is still slightly swollen, and there's still a patch of red by the ankle bone. The skin of the whole area from the knee down to the ankle is dry and peeling. I saw the doc on Thursday who¬†prescribed a¬†moisturising¬†cream, and¬†recommended I wear flight¬†socks - and I'm to keep my¬†leg elevated as much as I can.¬†With my next ultra only 12 days away I've taken the decision to defer it (again!) until next year. I did think of just doing the 10k loop around Henley, but it's a lot of faff and quite some expense, just for a 10k walk. So I'll be concentrating just on my¬†virtual ultras for the foreseeable. [More on that subject later.] I'm getting out for a 30-40 minute most¬†days, but the most I've done in the¬†day¬†is about 5k.¬† Friday 11th August 2023Well, my proposed ultra didn't happen after all. Two days before the event, I came down with a fever. On the Thursday morning, I had begun to experience a general feeling of unwellness, and retired to my bed - later that day I had a high temperature and an hour-long bout of violent, uncontrollable shivering. When I awoke on the Saturday, my right leg had turned a bright red, and each side of my calf itched like mad. On the Sunday my wife drove me to the Minor Injuries Unit (MIU)at Bridgwater Hospital, where I was seen immediately. The diagnosis was Cellulitis, and I was given a course of fairly strong antibiotics and told to rest with my leg elevated for at least two days. As I write, my condition is improving, and indeed, I've felt almost back to normal for the past couple of days, except I tire easily. The redness is now confined to my ankle, so I'm definitely recovering.My next ultra is the Chiltern 50 at the end of September, by which time I've no doubt I'll be raring to go! [Just to add, the MIU staff were absolutely brilliant - I was well looked after.
