I love the NHS!) 30th June 2023The last couple of virtual ultras were fairly short and over too soon, so I thought I'd go for a longer one this time - and started the Land's End to John O'Groats! A reminder - I need to do 3 actual ultras and 3 virtual ultras a year to meet my goal of 100 ultras by my 100th birthday. Saturday 10th JuneSerendipitous meeting tonight, outside the Youth hostel we were staying in. We were too late to see the Wheelbarrow race which takes place each year in Kington on this weekend, but Alan, Alex and I got chatting to a group who had come away after watching it. We started chatting to them, telling them what a friendly place Kington was. Before we knew it, one of the group, whose name was Adam, had invited us to the Olde Tavern, where he would buy all five of us a pint! They were insistent, so we grabbed Mick and Andy and hot-footed it down there. The place was absolutely buzzing - we found our friend, and, true to his word, he bought us all a pint of the local brew - and very nice it was too. I could have stayed on and made a night of it, but common sense prevailed, and we went back to the hostel.   The walk during the day was excellent preparation for my next ultra, the SWC50, with 17k of off-road hills and dales. ¬†   4th May 2023 
By the time the IoW challenge rolled around, I had walked over 750k in preparation. A few hill reps (not many) and quite a few stair climbs. - but I felt good and ready. This was my post on Facebook, the day before our adventure started: 
  
Well, it's all systems go - everything packed, taxi booked (for the a.m.), train tickets for trip to Basingstoke, where I'm to meet my son. Then it's down to Portsmouth, ferry to Fishbourne on the IoW, and then on to the hotel.¬† 
We're booked for a 7.30 start on Saturday morning, but we need to get there an hour before to register. 
This is the bit I don't particularly like - I'm not the most organised, and I won't really start to enjoy the adventure until we're registered - and we can join in the pre-event Zumba warm-up. Only then can I truly relax and turn to the job in hand - which is to get to the other side of the island in one piece. And then do the same again on Sunday - so we end up back where we started. 
  
With over 750k travelled in training this year, I should be OK.¬† 
But I've got a myriad things buzzing round my head. Will the taxi arrive? Will the trains run on time? Have I got all the bases covered, have I packed everything? Have I packed too much? I'm not so worried about the weight - I've been training regularly with 4kg in my rucksack, and I know I haven't got that much.¬† 
So now it's the waiting... 
Hope you like my new get-up!   I'll be flying both the Viva! and the Vegan Runners flag around the 106k route. 
I aim to do two things with my efforts this weekend (and the two other ultras I have planned for this year): I'm hoping that my efforts will attract a lot of support for Viva!, who do amazing work on behalf of the animals. And I also want to show what's possible on plant-based nutrition. I want to show you can be fit and healthy as a vegan, into old age - should I ever get there! 
  
As it turned out, everything went to plan. So, long story short, we gathered in the pre-event area, heard the intro from Dave the MC, did the Zumba to warm up and off we went. 
  The weather was perfect - temperature of around 20C for most of both days, overcast, with no rain. The island is beautiful, as we‚Äôd been told, and the coastline, although hilly in places, was quite manageable. The only downside was the thick, viscous mud - which we were advised to wade through, rather than try and skirt, because the sloping edges could be quite tricky to navigate. In fact we came across one guy who‚Äôd fallen and broken his leg - heard later he‚Äôd been looked after fine.   I was pretty pleased with the way I felt at the end of the second day - the atmosphere at the finish line was just amazing - and invigorating! So much so that I felt impelled to put in a sprint finish:        So that was my 9th ultra - next one is the SWC50 in early August, so I may do a Virtual one in the meantime - to keep me on track.   4th Feb 2023And it's 47k again this week - which included hill reps and stair climbing reps. Quite pleased with my speed today - I was going at over 6kph on a couple of stretches. Met a lovely family - dad and two kids - he was a runner and told me his MIL was a vegan and also a runner. Earlier in the week I met a group of traffic wardens and community police who were very receptive to my message. Probably shifted about 20 leaflets through the week, to dog walkers, parents with young children, people standing around - anyone I feel I can strike up a conversation with. As I offer a leaflet, after we've exchanged a couple of pleasantries, I'll often say something like, "I give these out to anyone I come across with a nice smile - and you've got a lovely smile!" Always goes down well. 27th Jan 2023No walk for me this morning, had to hang around whilst we had a couple of workmen over. But when my grandson went to bed this evening, his dad and I went out for a brisk 5k. Gives me 47k for the week, with possibly a few more tomorrow.¬† 26th Jan 202311.8k this morning - overcast, but not so cold at 4-5C. Met a guy, Ed, who told me he had been diagnosed with diabetes type 1 - and also that he'd had Covid recently and was finding it difficult to shake it off. I gave him a leaflet, and told him about the film What the Health, to help with the diabetes, and about Dr Dean Ornish's recent assertion that the effects of Covid - and long-covid - can be substantially mitigated by the adoption of some simple lifestyle changes [link to come]. I also shared my story with a lovely couple by the canal who showed me the enormous bag of litter they had picked up that morning! 43k so far this week - and with my son coming down for the weekend, I've no doubt I'll add a few more! 25th Jan 2023Just the 7k today - had a few chores to do before I could get out. Met 3 lovely young guys from the local arts college. Later I came across two broadband fitters, Bertie and ??, who were installing fibre optic cable - told me that we could expect them in our area in a month or so. 24th Jan 2023Once again a bright sunny day - just perfect for walking - so I got 14.2k in, mostly along the local canal. Met two walking groups, in one of which, the WI walking group , I came across Carole Smith, an old friend - another I knew through my old mentor, Stuart Gunn. I also met a postie, Jen, who was very keen to give veganism another shot. So I pointed out the challenge22.com part of my leaflet, which she was very pleased about. I must have handed out about 15 or more leaflets altogether - including to several dog walkers and a bird watcher who pointed out a kingfisher to me. 23rd Jan 2023I meet some lovely people, handing out my leaflets on my training walks. And this morning was no exception - 2 friendly scaffolders and a mum and dad with a young child on his training bike. 7k in bright sunshine - perfect weather for a brisk walk. 125k so far this year - aiming for 40-50k a week with still 3 months to go.¬† 17th Jan 2023I'm now officially in training for the IOW Challenge - even though there are still 3.5 months to go, I need something to motivate me to get out. So this is it. I did 31k the first week of the NY, and 44k the second, and I've done 16k so far this week, so my total is 81k. I don't have any set training programme - I'll carry on getting out there as often as possible - and just get the miles in! 1st January 2023 
I‚Äôd been looking for a Virtual Challenge, to give myself the motivation to keep moving, and also to keep to my goal of 3 actual ultras, and 3 virtual ultras a year. So I signed up for the Actioon Challenge Winter Walk to Lapland. There were various distances on offer - I chose the 250k route from Russia to Lapland. Much to my delight, the distance I had travelled from the 14th November which had been uploaded to Strava, were acknowledged - so I was already 74 kilometres into my challenge. By Christmas Eve I had covered 167k and my son and I decided to go for a walk over the Quantocks - aiming for up to 50k on the day. In the event, because of a few niggles, we called it a day at 40k. We were happy with that. This leaves 43k with 4/5 days left, since we‚Äôre seeing family over this period, It‚Äôs going to be a bit tight.   In the event, with the help of 30k on the day before NYE, and 9k on NYD, I finally managed it. Phew! So I've now¬†done 8 ultras - with three more next¬†year, ¬†I only need 1 more¬†Virtual to be up to date with my 100 ultras by my 100th birthday. 
  
My programme for next year is fairly set, I think - I‚Äôve signed up to the IoW 107k challenge, over 2 days, at the end of April; the SWC50 again (mainly because it‚Äôs on my doorstep); and the Chiltern50, deferred since last year. Sunday 10th September 2022¬†Yesterday, my son and I attempted the Thames Path Challenge 100k - continuous.The conditions were great, and we were both feeling good. We did the first 50k in under 10 hours - including pit stops, where we've learned not to sit down -¬†getting going again is so much harder when you've been relaxing in a chair. We figured if we could keep up 4k per hour for the next 50, we'd do the whole distance in under 24hrs.¬†That was¬†our mistake - we pushed on too fast in the dark - and at 58k I tripped over a malignant tree root and banged my head on¬†the¬†path. I got up feeling not too bad - but then I felt faint for a few seconds, so we¬†decided to quit. We¬†managed to get to the next rest stop at 61k - so that remains my one day distance record - up from the 58k on the Jurassic Coast Challenge. One day I'll manage the 100k continuous, but not this year, or¬†even¬†next, but maybe 2024, when we're thinking of¬†attempting the TPC again - figuring that if we take a lot more care after dark, we could do it.¬† Our next challenge is the IoW 107k over 2 days in April. After that, I've entered the SCW50 again, in August and the Chiltern50 at the end of September.  Sunday 7th August 2022Yesterday, I and my new friend, Tom Pickering - who took the place of my son Ben, who couldn't make it because of childcare duties - completed the 50k South West Coast Challenge in 14 hours and 40 minutes (including about an hour and a half at the rest stops). ¬†It was a complete blast, but I'll have to tell the story about this in the morning - I'm shattered, ATM!Saturday 6th August 2022
The South West Coast 50 Challenge: 
A loop from Dunster along the coast to Porlock, up over Dunkery Beacon, then back down to Dunster again.¬† 
  
Tom had come into the picture when he advertised on Facebook for older Vegan Runners - naturally I put my name forward. Tom is a film maker who is producing a film ‚ÄòI Could Never Go Vegan‚Äô, exposing¬† and rebutting all the myths surrounding Veganism. He had interviewed me in Taunton for the film, and wanted to see me in action. When my son had to pull out, Tom took his place - and a worthy companion he proved to be! 
We set off at 7.30, along with about 1200 others, along the road to Minehead, past Butlins, then joined the SW coastal path past Bossington, to Porlock Weir where we swung inland.¬† 
This is where the climbing began in earnest. I‚Äôd naively thought that after the climb from Minehead up Dunkery in July last the climb round the back of Dunkery would be easier. Well, it may not have been as steep, but it was steep - steep and long. The climb seemed to go on for ever. Some other ultra marathoners maintained that this was tougher than the first half of the Jurassic Coast Challenge, but I couldn‚Äôt agree with that.¬† 
Every so often, Tom would point his camera at me and ask how I was feeling. Thankfully I was always able to say, ‚ÄúDoing fine, thanks, Tom.‚Äù And every pit stop - which were roughly every 12-13k, I would do 25 press ups - just to show what a vegan can do - and Tom caught a couple of these sets on camera.   14th May 2022Well we did it - we now have the Jurassic Coast Challenge under our belts - albeit a truncated one (explanation to come). I'd like to welcome all the wonderful friends I made yesterday on the challenge to my blog. I handed out about 50 leaflets all told - about 15 or so to people I met on the journey, and had a conversation with; and the rest whilst waiting for the taxi scheduled to arrive at 1.45am. I just took all my remaining leaflets (which I had intended to hand out during the course of the 2nd day) and gave one to everyone sitting eating their meals - either on completion of their challenge - or fuelling up to carry them through the 2nd half. Everyone who took a leaflet was interested in my story - it was lovely to have that brief contact with you all, but I just wish I had had time to get to know you all and listen to your stories. Maybe on another challenge! Here's how I got started on my Ultra journey. It's a pretty long blog, but the gist of it is in the first few paragraphs.¬† I told many of you that my arthritis disappeared after I adopted plant-based nutrition - here is¬†a blog post I wrote about it. I've got more - much more - to write about, concerning the JCC, but that'll have to wait until tomorrow - I'm just a bit shattered ATM! 14th May 2022¬†What. A. Day!¬†The day, long anticipated (and will live long in the memory!), had finally arrived - and it got off to a very good start. The taxi driver who took my son and I from Wareham to Corfe Castle took ¬£4 off the bill to give us ¬£2 each for our chosen charities. Lovely woman! I'm not a worrier, but it's fair to say I'm always more concerned about the logistics of the event, rather than the event itself [talk about getting your priorities wrong, as it turned out! :)] So I'm always relieved when all the formalities are over and we've been checked in.¬† And there we were, surrounded by hundreds of eager, smiling faces, just waiting for the off. Bit of zumba type warm up exercise, a speech from Mike the MC (he of the purple suit) welcoming us to the event and telling us to enjoy ourselves - and we were off, at around 6.45. The terrain to the first pitstop at 11k ¬†and the second at 25k was relatively uneventful - couple of fairly easy climbs between each, but we were all fresh and keen to get the miles in. Danish pastries and hot drinks were on offer at the first pitstop - as a vegan we're told to ask for stuff, as it's put by for us. Huge plates of biscuits were also on offer - I grabbed a few bourbons, knowing they were vegan - not sure about the rest. We were very disciplined - we'd planned on only spending 20 minutes at each of the minor stops - we were on our way again after only 15. At the second stop, some form of vegan sausage rolls were available, which weren't great, since they left a film of grease on the palate. I had a couple of Greggs sausage rolls with me, so I had one of those. Not so disciplined this time, since we spent about 45 minutes at this rest stop.It was on the next leg - the 17k to Lulworth Cove, that we really began to be challenged. Each steep ascent and descent was swiftly followed by another. l'll let these pics tell the story:    Some of these hills, I have to say, were brutal! The walking poles were an absolute necessity for me on the steepest ascents - my technique was to put both poles a few inches in front of me, take two paces through the 'gate' they formed, then reposition the poles a little in front of me. It was slow going, but I found it the only way. Ben and I had intended to do the full 100k continuous, but, on the last leg towards the halfway point, Ben told me he didn't want to carry on after Weymouth - the halfway stage at 58k. He'd begun to feel unwell - but he'd done brilliantly since he'd only come off antibiotics the day before. So we were content with that 58k, achieved in 18 hours, with about 2 hours rest. As it turned out, it was a very wise (fortunate?) decision, since the weather turned nasty an hour or so afterwards, and the other contestants had to complete in pouring rain.¬†So that's our 4th ultra done and dusted - next one is the South West Coast 50k at the beginning of August. 6th May 2022Been out every day this week, clocking up an average of 20k each time - with a 30k day earlier. In the absence of decent hills, I'm doing lots of stair climbing in preparation for the fearsome hills on the JCC we've been warned about - my record is a stint of 36 times up the stairs and down the ramp. Carrying at least 3kg in the rucksack - which is about the weight I'll be carrying on the ultra. With only 8 days to go, most of our preparations are in place, and I think I'm as ready as I'm going to be - next week I'll probably just do about 10k a day, ticking over, as it were.¬†My programme this year also includes two 50k events - the SWC2C in August, and the Chiltern 50 in September. As I've opted for the full charity fundraiser, I need to raise ¬£600 for the 100k event and ¬£400 each for the two 50k events - so ¬£1400 for the year. As I write, I've already raised over ¬£1100, with 5 months to go, so my donors are doing me proud.  28th March 2022My story so far: After the wonderful weekend my son and I had on the South West Coast 2 Coast ultra marathon in July 2021, we've both become addicted, and cannot wait to repeat the experience. We followed this up with a 50k Virtual Trek to Kilimanjaro - actually a days hike over the Chilterns. Finally, for several weeks before Christmas we completed a 200k Virtual Trek to the North Pole. I've now set myself the goal of completing 100 ultra marathons by my 100th birthday. I'm 84 ATM, so that means 6 ultras -¬†I'm thinking 3 real ultras and 3 virtual ones¬†- every year, for the next 14 years. I'm extremely fortunate in that my son is keen to join me in this¬†endeavour, and our intention is to do the bulk of these together. We've already done 3 as I said - here's the story of the SWC2C and here's the Virtual Trek to Kilimanjaro story - and we've both signed up for the 102km Jurassic Coast Challenge in May. Unfortunately for my plans, at the end of December, I suffered a broken leg, so that's put my training on the back burner for the next couple of months. My leg has been placed in a fairly fragile cast to begin with, and I mustn't put any weight on it, which makes moving around on crutches quite tricky. I should get a more permanent cast next week sometime. Since we don't have a downstairs toilet, and it's hard work going up and down - and I get tired pretty quickly - I'm staying upstairs most of the time. I have to go up the stairs, backwards, sitting down, which is a tad undignified, I have to sayüòÄ. ¬†(But it ¬†does give me an extra workout!) Going downstairs is a lot easier, since we have two handrails, and I've found if I grip these, I can hop down okay. The cast finally came off on Feb 10th, and I've been walking daily since then. Beginning with an average of 5k a day, I'm now (28th March) doing over 10k a day. I'm also back to doing my press ups, and, since I haven't been doing them for 3 months, I need to catch up, so I'm doing 500 every evening.

author: ThomasSTL
title: How Warsaw became the unlikely vegan capital of Europe
text:
Karol Adamiak 







I¬†want to tell you about a relatively typical neighbourhood in my city. There are two vegan sushi restaurants, three vegan ramen spots. There are a few vegan delis. All the convenience stores have a vegan section. There‚Äôs an abundance of vegan bakeries. There‚Äôs a place that does vegan peking duck ‚Äì it‚Äôs good, I promise. Many of these vegan places proudly have a rainbow flag on display. I‚Äôm not talking about Los Angeles or New York. I‚Äôm not even talking about Copenhagen. My neighbourhood is called ≈ör√≥dmie≈õcie. The vegan paradise I‚Äôm talking about ‚Äì it‚Äôs Warsaw. 



If you don‚Äôt believe me, well, Warsaw has been ranked¬†among the top vegan cities¬†in the world by HappyCow (a vegan ranking website) for the past six years. In 2022, it was¬†National Geographic‚Äôs number one vegan city¬†in the world. Maybe your perception of Poland is all¬†kielbasa¬†(sausage) and conservative politics. Herring and hate. It‚Äôs more complicated than that. In the past two decades there has been a quiet vegan revolution in the country. 



In reality, it shouldn‚Äôt be too much of a shock that Polish food lends itself well to veganism. Prior to falling under the long shadow of the iron curtain, Polish cuisine was mostly plant-based. Only the aristocracy had easy access to meat, fish and dairy products. Most of the people in the country were peasants and they ate what they grew. The cuisine was full of root vegetables, potatoes and earthy greens.¬†This was a plant-based diet by default, not ideology. 



As today, this cuisine was heavy on soups and stews. An old favourite was a vegetable soup, flavoured with sugar and cinnamon to which beer was added at the end to create a yeasted acidity. That one didn‚Äôt stand the test of time. Cracovian Jews used to make¬†obwarzanek, parboiled rye dough shaped into a circle, and sell it from carts on the streets of the city. This fared a little better ‚Äì it likely inspired¬†what we know today as bagels. 



In the communist era, meat was a luxury, despite everyone‚Äôs alleged equality. Meat production was inefficient, which meant ordinary people did not have the money to afford the scant supply. This meant people craved meat as a status symbol ‚Äì particularly because the socialist elite did have access to animal proteins. When the USSR collapsed people wanted to eat meat ‚Äì and as market forces entered agriculture and people gradually gained disposable income, they spent heavily on it. 



But as¬†Poland¬†became a mature liberal democracy appetites changed. For the younger generation that grew up in a time of relative abundance, animal products were so commonplace they failed to have much lustre. 



‚ÄúI lived in Madrid as an Erasmus student and I found it hard to sustain my social life without eating meat ‚Ä¶ Whereas in Warsaw, I honestly cannot recall the last time I went to a restaurant that did not have a vegan option in their offering,‚Äù Micha≈Ç Korkosz, AKA Rozkoszny, told me. Rozkoszny is one of the most prominent vegetarian food influencers in the country ‚Äì¬†with more than 700k followers on instagram. His cookbooks Fresh from Poland and Polish‚Äôd, which offer vegetarian twists on classic Polish recipes, have sold 230,000 copies and been translated into three languages. 



In some cases, Rozkoszny celebrates the plant-based foods of old Poland.¬†Schabowy z kani¬†(parasol mushroom schnitzel) is a traditional recipe, one known to seemingly every Polish grandma. Similar to a regular schnitzel, the mushroom is prepped, paneed, and then fried, often served alongside young boiled potatoes and¬†mizeria¬†(Polish tzatziki). In other cases, he takes traditional dishes and gives them a modern twist to make them vegan.¬†≈ªurek¬†is a popular soup traditionally made with stock of smoked pork ribs and served with various kinds of¬†kielbasa¬†(sausage). But in¬†≈ºurek¬†as proposed by Rozkoszny, the soup is made with miso ‚Äì hardly a traditional Polish staple, but now widely available ‚Äì and roasted mushrooms. 



Before becoming a bestselling author and influencer, Rozkoszny studied politics and sociology. He‚Äôs attuned to the fact that what you eat can be a political statement. He once conducted a study in which he interviewed a number of Polish MPs on their diets and tried to map their politics. ‚ÄúThe more left-leaning a politician, the more likely they were to have a vegetarian diet and eat international cuisines,‚Äù he told me. A 2019 study by Ipsos showed similar results. Polish politicians were asked: ‚ÄúWhat actions are you willing to take to help fight climate change?‚Äù Among politicians from the left, 30% stated that they would give up meat, versus a mere 11% for the right wing Law and Justice party. 



‚ÄúVeganism tends to be perceived as a pejorative term,‚Äù according to Anna Spurek, the chief operating officer at the Green REV Institute, Poland‚Äôs first vegan thinktank. ‚ÄúThe meat lobby and interest groups use it to polarise society.‚Äù It has been a common refrain of rightwing politicians that veganism is anti-Polish ‚Äì that it is a similar form of propaganda to the ‚ÄúLGBT agenda‚Äù ‚Äì and that vegans are ‚Äúinsane and detached from reality,‚Äù she said. 



But veganism should be an idea that transcends neat political brackets. For one, Spurek thinks that the Polish idea of¬†solidarno≈õƒá¬†‚Äì solidarity, and the name of the political movement that helped bring down communism in Poland ‚Äì can also include the concept of interspecies unity and green politics. And in a way veganism represents a return to Poland‚Äôs peasant roots, and a more conscious and healthy way of eating. Across Poland, even in rural areas, diets are increasingly plant-based. 



While veganism has been caught in Poland‚Äôs increasingly polarised politics, its impact on the culture is obvious everywhere.¬†With Barclay Bram, I run a vegan Polish supper club in London called Bracia (it means brothers in Polish). Many people in London comment that this seems like something that could only happen here ‚Äì and we see their surprise when we tell them how vegan-friendly Poland is. Recently, we‚Äôve been doing events back in Warsaw. In February, we‚Äôre taking over Lotos, a traditional restaurant open since 1958, famous for its¬†n√≥≈ºki w galarecie¬†(legs in jelly ‚Äì literally a chicken soup served cold so the collagen has become gelatinous, with veg and carrots suspended in it). The owner, Hanna Szyma≈Ñska, told us she‚Äôs looking forward to putting out a vegan menu for the night: ‚ÄúYou have to move with the times.‚Äù

author: itstimholman
title: How Warsaw became the unlikely vegan capital of Europe
text: From¬†theguardian.com By Karol Adamiak A city associated with sausage and herring is now a haven for plant-based foods ‚Äì and Poland‚Äôs right-wing politicians aren‚Äôt happy¬† I¬†want to tell you about a relatively typical neighbourhood in my city. There are two vegan sushi restaurants, three vegan ramen spots. There are a few vegan delis. All the convenience stores have a vegan section. There‚Äôs an abundance of vegan bakeries. There‚Äôs a place that does vegan peking duck ‚Äì it‚Äôs good, I promise. Many of these vegan places proudly have a rainbow flag on display. I‚Äôm not talking about Los Angeles or New York. I‚Äôm not even talking about Copenhagen. My neighbourhood is called ≈ör√≥dmie≈õcie. The vegan paradise I‚Äôm talking about ‚Äì it‚Äôs Warsaw. If you don‚Äôt believe me, well, Warsaw has been ranked¬†among the top vegan cities¬†in the world by HappyCow (a vegan ranking website) for the past six years. In 2022, it was¬†National Geographic‚Äôs number one vegan city¬†in the world. Maybe your perception of Poland is all¬†kielbasa¬†(sausage) and conservative politics. Herring and hate. It‚Äôs more complicated than that. In the past two decades there has been a quiet vegan revolution in the country.  ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† A cafe in Warsaw, Poland.¬†Photograph: Nathaniel Noir/Alamy   In reality, it shouldn‚Äôt be too much of a shock that Polish food lends itself well to veganism. Prior to falling under the long shadow of the iron curtain, Polish cuisine was mostly plant-based. Only the aristocracy had easy access to meat, fish and dairy products. Most of the people in the country were peasants and they ate what they grew. The cuisine was full of root vegetables, potatoes and earthy greens.¬†This was a plant-based diet by default, not ideology. As today, this cuisine was heavy on soups and stews. An old favourite was a vegetable soup, flavoured with sugar and cinnamon to which beer was added at the end to create a yeasted acidity. That one didn‚Äôt stand the test of time. Cracovian Jews used to make¬†obwarzanek, parboiled rye dough shaped into a circle, and sell it from carts on the streets of the city. This fared a little better ‚Äì it likely inspired¬†what we know today as bagels. In the communist era, meat was a luxury, despite everyone‚Äôs alleged equality. Meat production was inefficient, which meant ordinary people did not have the money to afford the scant supply. This meant people craved meat as a status symbol ‚Äì particularly because the socialist elite did have access to animal proteins. When the USSR collapsed people wanted to eat meat ‚Äì and as market forces entered agriculture and people gradually gained disposable income, they spent heavily on it. But as Poland became a mature liberal democracy appetites changed. For the younger generation that grew up in a time of relative abundance, animal products were so commonplace they failed to have much lustre. ‚ÄúI lived in Madrid as an Erasmus student and I found it hard to sustain my social life without eating meat ‚Ä¶ Whereas in Warsaw, I honestly cannot recall the last time I went to a restaurant that did not have a vegan option in their offering,‚Äù Micha≈Ç Korkosz, AKA Rozkoszny, told me. Rozkoszny is one of the most prominent vegetarian food influencers in the country ‚Äì¬†with more than 700k followers on instagram. His cookbooks Fresh from Poland and Polish‚Äôd, which offer vegetarian twists on classic Polish recipes, have sold 230,000 copies and been translated into three languages. In some cases, Rozkoszny celebrates the plant-based foods of old Poland.¬†Schabowy z kani¬†(parasol mushroom schnitzel) is a traditional recipe, one known to seemingly every Polish grandma. Similar to a regular schnitzel, the mushroom is prepped, paneed, and then fried, often served alongside young boiled potatoes and¬†mizeria¬†(Polish tzatziki). In other cases, he takes traditional dishes and gives them a modern twist to make them vegan.¬†≈ªurek¬†is a popular soup traditionally made with stock of smoked pork ribs and served with various kinds of¬†kielbasa¬†(sausage). But in¬†≈ºurek¬†as proposed by Rozkoszny, the soup is made with miso ‚Äì hardly a traditional Polish staple, but now widely available ‚Äì and roasted mushrooms. Before becoming a bestselling author and influencer, Rozkoszny studied politics and sociology. He‚Äôs attuned to the fact that what you eat can be a political statement. He once conducted a study in which he interviewed a number of Polish MPs on their diets and tried to map their politics. ‚ÄúThe more left-leaning a politician, the more likely they were to have a vegetarian diet and eat international cuisines,‚Äù he told me. A 2019 study by Ipsos showed similar results. Polish politicians were asked: ‚ÄúWhat actions are you willing to take to help fight climate change?‚Äù Among politicians from the left, 30% stated that they would give up meat, versus a mere 11% for the right wing Law and Justice party. ‚ÄúVeganism tends to be perceived as a pejorative term,‚Äù according to Anna Spurek, the chief operating officer at the Green REV Institute, Poland‚Äôs first vegan thinktank. ‚ÄúThe meat lobby and interest groups use it to polarise society.‚Äù It has been a common refrain of rightwing politicians that veganism is anti-Polish ‚Äì that it is a similar form of propaganda to the ‚ÄúLGBT agenda‚Äù ‚Äì and that vegans are ‚Äúinsane and detached from reality,‚Äù she said. But veganism should be an idea that transcends neat political brackets. For one, Spurek thinks that the Polish idea of¬†solidarno≈õƒá¬†‚Äì solidarity, and the name of the political movement that helped bring down communism in Poland ‚Äì can also include the concept of interspecies unity and green politics. And in a way veganism represents a return to Poland‚Äôs peasant roots, and a more conscious and healthy way of eating. Across Poland, even in rural areas, diets are increasingly plant-based. While veganism has been caught in Poland‚Äôs increasingly polarised politics, its impact on the culture is obvious everywhere.¬†With Barclay Bram, I run a vegan Polish supper club in London called Bracia (it means brothers in Polish). Many people in London comment that this seems like something that could only happen here ‚Äì and we see their surprise when we tell them how vegan-friendly Poland is. Recently, we‚Äôve been doing events back in Warsaw. In February, we‚Äôre taking over Lotos, a traditional restaurant open since 1958, famous for its¬†n√≥≈ºki w galarecie¬†(legs in jelly ‚Äì literally a chicken soup served cold so the collagen has become gelatinous, with veg and carrots suspended in it). The owner, Hanna Szyma≈Ñska, told us she‚Äôs looking forward to putting out a vegan menu for the night: ‚ÄúYou have to move with the times.‚Äù   Karol Adamiak is a chef from Warsaw. Barclay Bram contributed research and writing to this article. They cook together as Bracia https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2025/jan/31/warsaw-vegan-capital-europe-city-poland-food

author: Tori Wynsell
title: Veganuary: Pioneering the Plant-Based Revolution
text:
Have you heard of that old saying ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt knock it till you try it‚Äù? It means that should give new things a try before you can decide whether or not you like them, and it‚Äôs true. But while this is a very simple idea, sometimes it can be hard to try new things, especially when it contradicts an action that has been done for a long time, like eating animals and animal-derived products. 



Getting food from animals has been the way of humans since we first walked the Earth. Excluding certain regions and cultures like India, Ethiopia, Eritrea, and parts of Africa and Asia, the vast majority of the world relies on an animal-based diet. But as recent studies have shown, ¬†our dependence on food from animals is becoming too costly in several ways: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Animal agriculture is a major contributor to climate change, producing more greenhouse gases than cars, trains, and airplanes (Center for Biological Diversity). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Animal agriculture destroys natural habitats and ecosystems to raise livestock and grow feed crops (Center for Biological Diversity). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† The livestock industry destroys forests and grasslands (Stanford University). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Livestock accounts for half of all antibiotic use globally, increasing antibiotic resistance to people who eat them (Stanford University). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† The livestock industry uses a lot of water and other natural resources (Vegetarian Times). 



The cost of maintaining a diet that relies majorly on animals is becoming too much to continue. However, research has shown that if everyone shifted to a plant-based diet, we would reduce global land use for agriculture by 75% (Our World in Data). But encouraging everyone on Earth to switch to a plant-based diet is nowhere near as simple as it sounds. That‚Äôs why this organization has staged an annual month-long event to inspire people to join the global plant-based revolution. 



‚ÄúExperiment with life by exploring and trying new things.‚Äù ‚Äì Robin S. Baker 



Simple Idea to Grand Movement



Formed in 2014, the founders of this organization were Matthew Glover, a passionate animal welfare advocate, and Jane Land, a dedicated environmentalist. The idea came from Glover‚Äôs desire to make a positive impact on animal welfare and the environment. Inspired by similar campaigns like Movember, a global charity event that takes place annually in November to raise awareness and funds for men‚Äôs health issues, they wanted to create an event that would encourage people to try veganism for a month. 



The first Veganuary campaign took place in January 2014, and it started as a small, crowdfunded initiative in the UK. They aimed to show that veganism is fun and easy and to help people understand the benefits of a plant-based diet. Over the years, Veganuary has grown into a global movement, with millions of participants from around the world, a shining example of a simple idea turning into a significant movement. 



31-Day Vegan Challenge



The 31-Day Vegan Challenge is the cornerstone of Veganuary‚Äôs campaign. Participants pledge to follow a vegan diet for the entire month of January. This means avoiding all animal products, including meat, dairy, eggs, and honey. 



Daily Support



Each day, participants receive an email filled with tips, recipes, nutritional advice, and motivational content. These emails are designed to guide participants through their vegan journey, providing support and inspiration. 



Resources



Veganuary offers a wide variety of delicious and easy-to-make vegan recipes. These range from breakfast options to main courses and desserts, ensuring that participants have plenty of meal ideas to choose from. 



Customizable meal plans are provided to help participants organize their meals and make grocery shopping easier. These plans cater to different dietary needs and preferences, such as gluten-free or high-protein diets. 



Educational Content



Participants receive information on how to maintain a balanced vegan diet and ensure they are getting all the necessary nutrients. Participants also receive educational content on the health benefits of a vegan diet, including potential improvements in heart health, weight management, and energy levels. 



Community Support



Veganuary‚Äôs social media platforms serve as a hub for participants to connect, share experiences, and find encouragement from others on the same journey. 



Throughout January, Veganuary hosts various events and webinars featuring vegan experts, chefs, and nutritionists to provide additional support and inspiration. 



Motivation and Inspiration



Participants are inspired by success stories from previous years, showcasing how others have benefited from trying a vegan diet. Fun challenges and activities are also included to keep participants engaged and motivated throughout the month. 



The 31-Day Vegan Challenge is designed to make the transition to a vegan diet as smooth and enjoyable as possible. It‚Äôs a great way for anyone curious about veganism to give it a try with plenty of support and resources. 



Meal Plans



Veganuary‚Äôs meal plans are designed to help participants easily transition to a vegan diet by providing well-balanced, delicious, and easy-to-make meals. These plans take the guesswork out of meal planning and ensure participants get all the nutrients they need. 



What the Meal Plans Include



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Weekly Menus: Veganuary provides weekly meal plans that outline breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snack options for each day. These menus are carefully curated to include a variety of flavors and ingredients, ensuring participants enjoy their meals and stay motivated. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Recipes: Each meal plan comes with detailed recipes, including ingredient lists and step-by-step instructions. The recipes are designed to be easy to follow, even for those who are new to vegan cooking. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Nutritional Balance: The meal plans are created to ensure a balanced diet, including sufficient protein, vitamins, and materials. Veganuary takes into account different dietary needs and preferences, such as gluten-free, high-protein, or low-carb options. 



Special Features



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Shopping Lists: To make meal planning even easier, Veganuary provides shopping lists for each week‚Äôs meal plans. These lists are organized by food category, making grocery shopping more efficient and less stressful. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Customizable Options: Participants can customize the meal plans to suit their tastes and dietary requirements. For example, if someone prefers more protein-rich meals, they can swap out certain recipes for others that better meet their needs. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Seasonal Ingredients: The meal plans often incorporate seasonal ingredients making it easier for participants to find fresh and affordable produce. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† International Flavors: To keep things exciting, Veganuary‚Äôs meal plans feature a variety of cuisines from around the world. This helps participants explore new flavors and discover new favorite dishes. 



Example Meal Plan



Here‚Äôs an example of what a typical day in a Veganuary meal plan might look like: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Breakfast: Banana Oat Pancakes with Maple Syrup 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Lunch: Lentil and Vegetable Soup with a Side of Whole Grain Bread 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Dinner: Chickpea and Spinach Curry served with Brown Rice 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Snack: Hummus with Carrot and Cucumber Sticks 



Benefits



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Simplifies Meal Planning: The meal plans make it easy to plan vegan meals without having to think too much about what to cook each day. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reduces Food Waste: By providing specific shopping lists and recipes, participants are less likely to buy unnecessary items, leading to less food waste. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Encourages Variety: With a diverse range of recipes, participants can enjoy a wide variety of meals and avoid getting bored with their diet. 



These meal plans are a fantastic resource for anyone taking part in Veganuary, as they make the transition to a vegan diet both enjoyable and manageable. 



Celebrity Cookbook



The Celebrity Cookbook is a collection of vegan recipes contributed by various celebrities who support the Veganuary campaign. These celebrities come from different backgrounds, including actors, musicians, athletes, and chefs. Their involvement helps raise awareness about veganism and provides participants with diverse and inspiring recipes. 



Content of the Cookbook



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Celebrity Contributors: The cookbook features recipes from well-known figures such as Joaquin Phoenix, Billie Eilish, Paul McCartney, and many others. These celebrities share their favorite vegan dishes, along with personal anecdotes and tips for maintaining a plant-based diet. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Variety of Recipes: The cookbook includes a wide range of recipes, from breakfasts and snacks to main courses and desserts. This variety ensures that participants have plenty of options to choose from, whether they are looking for something quick and easy or a more elaborate meal. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Nutritional Information: Each recipe comes with nutritional information, helping participants make informed choices about their diet. The cookbook also includes tips on how to balance meals and ensure proper nutrient intake. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Personal Stories and Insights: Alongside the recipes, celebrities often share their personal stories and reasons for adopting a vegan lifestyle. These insights can be motivating and provide a deeper connection to the campaign. 



Special Features



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Exclusive Recipes: Some recipes in the cookbook are exclusive and can‚Äôt be found elsewhere. This adds a unique element to the Veganuary experience. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Easy-to-Follow Instructions: The recipes are designed to be accessible, with clear, step-by-step instructions. This makes it easy for participants, regardless of their cooking experience, to recreate the dishes at home. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Beautiful Photography: The cookbook is filled with vibrant, high-quality photos of the dishes, making it visually appealing and inspiring. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Culinary Diversity: The recipes reflect a wide range of culinary traditions and flavors, showcasing the versatility of plant-based cooking. 



Example Recipes



Here are a few of the types of recipes you might find in the Celebrity Cookbook: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Billie Eilish‚Äôs Vegan Pancakes: A delicious and fluffy breakfast option made with simple, plant-based ingredients. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Paul McCartney‚Äôs Lentil Shepherd‚Äôs Pie: A hearty and comforting main dish that‚Äôs perfect for a family meal. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Joaquin Phoenix‚Äôs Chocolate Avocado Mousse: A rich and creamy dessert that‚Äôs both indulgent and healthy. 



Benefits



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Inspiration: The involvement of celebrities can inspire and motivate participants to stick with their vegan challenge. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Community: Knowing that well-known figures are also part of the vegan movement can create a sense of community and belonging. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Enjoyment: The variety and quality of recipes make the vegan journey enjoyable and exciting. 



The Celebrity Cookbook is a wonderful resource for anyone participating in Veganuary, offering delicious recipes and a connection to the broader vegan community. 



Coaching Emails



The Coaching Emails are a key part of Veganuary‚Äôs support system, designed to provide participants with daily guidance and motivation throughout their 31-day vegan journey. Participants who sign up for the 31-Day Vegan Challenge receive daily emails throughout January. These emails are crafted to offer a combination of practical advice, delicious recipes, nutritional tips, and motivational content. 



Key Components of the Coaching Emails



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Daily Inspiration: Each email begins with a positive and motivating message to keep participants encouraged and focused on their goals. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Nutritional Advice: The emails provide essential information on how to maintain a balanced and healthy vegan diet. This includes tips on getting enough protein, vitamins, and minerals, as well as advice on meal planning and preparation. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Recipes: Participants receive a variety of recipes for breakfast, lunch, dinner, and snacks. These recipes are easy to follow and designed to fit into a busy lifestyle. They help participants explore different flavors and cuisines, keeping their meals exciting and enjoyable. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Expert Tips: The emails often include advice from nutritionists, chefs, and long-term vegans. These experts share their knowledge on topics like eating out as a vegan, dealing with cravings, and finding vegan alternatives to favorite non-vegan foods. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Success Stories: To inspire and motivate participants, the emails feature success stories from previous Veganuary participants. These stories highlight the positive changes others have experienced, both physically and emotionally, by adopting a vegan diet. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Challenges and Activities: To keep things engaging, the emails may include fun challenges and activities. For example, participants might be encouraged to try a new vegan recipe, visit a local vegan restaurant, or share their vegan journey on social media. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Additional Resources: Participants are provided with links to additional resources, such as articles, videos, and podcasts. These resources cover a wide range of topics, from the environmental impact of veganism to tips for maintaining a vegan lifestyle beyond January. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Community Support: The emails encourage participants to connect with the Veganuary community through social media and online forums. This sense of community provides additional support and helps participants share their experiences and advice. 



Example Email Outline



Here‚Äôs an example of what a typical coaching email might look like: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Greeting and Motivational Quote: Start your day with a positive mindset! 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Nutritional Tip: How to get enough iron on a vegan diet. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Recipe of the Day: Spaghetti with creamy cashew Alfredo sauce. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Expert Advice: Tips from a vegan chef on cooking plant-based meals. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Success Story: How Jane lost 15 pounds and improved her energy levels during Veganuary. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Challenge of the Day: Try a new vegan snack and share your experience on social media. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Additional Resources: Link to a podcast episode about the environmental benefits of veganism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Community Connection: Join the Veganuary Facebook group to connect with fellow participants. 



These coaching emails are designed to make the transition to a vegan diet as smooth and enjoyable as possible, providing all the support and information participants need to succeed. 



Workplace Challenge



The Workplace Challenge invites organizations of all sizes to encourage their employees to take part in the 31-Day Vegan Challenge together. This initiative helps foster a sense of community and shared purpose within the workplace while promoting a healthy and sustainable lifestyle. 



Key Components



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Registration and Pledge: Companies can register their interest in the Workplace Challenge on the Veganuary website. They receive information and resources to help them promote the challenge internally and encourage employee participation. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Team Building: By participating in the challenge as a group, employees can support and motivate each other. This shared experience can strengthen team bonds and improve workplace morale. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Health and Well-Being: The challenge promotes a healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. This can lead to improved health outcomes for employees, such as increased energy levels, better digestion, and potential weight loss. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Sustainability: Adopting a vegan diet has significant environmental benefits, including reducing carbon footprints, conserving water, and protecting forests. By taking part in Veganuary, companies can demonstrate their commitment to sustainability and corporate social responsibility. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Educational Resources: Veganuary provides companies with a range of educational resources to share with their employees. These include nutritional guides, recipes, cooking tips, and information on the environmental and ethical benefits of veganism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Workplace Events: Companies can organize events and activities to make the challenge more engaging and fun. These might include vegan cooking classes, potluck lunches, or guest speakers on topics related to health and sustainability. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Internal Communication: Regular communication within the workplace, such as newsletters, emails, and intranet updates, can keep employees informed and motivated. Sharing success stories and tips can help sustain momentum throughout the month. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Support from Veganuary: Veganuary offers ongoing support to participating companies, including marketing materials, advice on how to engage employees, and access to a community of other businesses taking part in the challenge. 



Example Activities



Here are some activities that companies might organize as part of the Workplace Challenge: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Kick-Off Meeting: Start the challenge with an informational meeting where employees can learn about Veganuary and sign up. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Weekly Vegan Lunches: Host weekly vegan lunches where employees can share and enjoy plant-based meals together. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Recipe Sharing: Create a digital or physical space where employees can share their favorite vegan recipes and cooking tips. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Guest Speakers: Invite nutritionists, chefs, or environmental experts to give talks and provide additional insights into veganism. 



Benefits for Companies



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Improved Employee Health: A plant-based diet can contribute to better health outcomes, leading to increased productivity and reduced absenteeism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Enhanced Team Morale: Participating in a shared challenge can boost team spirit and create a more positive work environment. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Corporate Social Responsibility: Demonstrating a commitment to sustainability and ethical practices can enhance a company‚Äôs reputation. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Engagement and Retention: Fun and meaningful initiatives like the Workplace Challenge can improve employee engagement and retention. 



The Workplace Challenge is a win-win for both employees and employers, promoting health, sustainability, and a stronger sense of community within the workplace. 



Educational Resources



Veganuary‚Äôs educational resources are a treasure trove of information designed to help participants learn more about veganism, its benefits, and how to make the transition smoothly. 



Articles



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Informative Content: Veganuary offers a wide range of articles covering various aspects of veganism. These articles address topics such as health benefits, environmental impact, animal welfare, and his to maintain a balanced vegan diet. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Guides and Tips: Practical guides and tips on topics like vegan nutrition, how to read food labels, and making vegan choices when dining out. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Success Stories: Inspiring stories from people who have successfully transitioned to a vegan lifestyle, sharing their experiences and the positive changes they‚Äôve seen. 



Videos



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Cooking Tutorials: Step-by-step video tutorials demonstrating how to prepare delicious and nutritious vegan meals. These videos make it easy for participants to follow along and learn new recipes. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Expert Interviews: Interviews with nutritionists, chefs, and long-term vegans who share their knowledge and insights on various aspects of veganism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Documentaries and Clips: Short documentaries and clips that highlight the benefits of a vegan lifestyle, the impact of animal agriculture on the environment, and the ethical considerations of veganism. 



Podcasts



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Educational Episodes: Veganuary‚Äôs podcasts feature episodes on a wide range of topics, from nutritional advice to environmental sustainability. These podcasts are perfect for listening on the go, providing valuable information in an engaging format. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Guest Speakers: Episodes often include guest speakers such as vegan athletes, doctors, and environmentalists who share their expertise and personal experiences. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Q&A Sessions: Interactive podcast episodes where experts answer common questions about veganism, offering practical advice and debunking myths. 



Additional Resources



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† E-Books and PDF Guides: Downloadable resources that participants can keep for reference. These might include e-books on vegan nutrition, meal planning guides, and shopping lists. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Infographics: Visually appealing infographics that summarize key information about veganism, making it easy to understand and share. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Webinars: Live and recorded webinars that participants can join to learn more about specific topics, ask questions, and engage with experts. 



Benefits of These Resources



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Comprehensive Learning: The variety of formats (articles, videos, podcasts, etc.) ensures that participants can access information in a way that suits their preferences and learning styles. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Accessible Information: The resources are designed to be user-friendly and accessible to everyone, whether they are new to veganism or looking to deepen their knowledge. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Ongoing Support: By providing continuous education and support, Veganuary helps participants stay informed, motivated, and confident in their vegan journey. 



These educational resources are an integral part of Veganuary‚Äôs mission to make veganism accessible and enjoyable for everyone. They provide participants with the knowledge and tools they need to succeed and make a positive impact. 



Social Media Support



Veganuary‚Äôs strong social media presence plays a crucial role in keeping participants engaged, inspired, and supported throughout their vegan journey. 



Platforms



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Instagram: Veganuary‚Äôs Instagram account is filled with vibrant photos, videos, and stories showcasing delicious vegan recipes, participant success stories, and behind-the-scenes looks at Veganuary events. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Facebook: The Facebook page offers daily posts with tips, articles, and videos. It also hosts a supportive community where participants can share their experiences, ask questions, and receive encouragement from fellow vegans. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Twitter: On Twitter, Veganuary shares quick updates, interesting facts, and links to longer articles and resources. They also engage with followers through retweets, replies, and hashtags. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† YouTube: Veganuary‚Äôs YouTube channel features cooking tutorials, interviews with experts and celebrities, and informational videos about the benefits of veganism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Pinterest: On Pinterest, Veganuary curates boards with recipe ideas, meal plans, and infographics. This platform is particularly useful for participants looking for visual inspiration and easy access to vegan content. 



Content



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Daily Tips: Each day, Veganuary posts practical tips to help participants stay on track. These might include advice on meal planning, finding vegan-friendly products, and navigating social situations. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Recipes: Regular recipe posts provide participants with a steady stream of meal ideas. These recipes are often accompanied by beautiful photos and step-by-step instructions. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Motivational Content: To keep participants motivated, Veganuary shares inspirational quotes, success stories, and testimonials from people who have benefited from trying a vegan diet. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Interactive Features: Social media platforms allow Veganuary to engage directly with participants. This might include live Q&A sessions, polls, and interactive challenges. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Educational Posts: Informative posts cover a wide range of topics, from the environmental impact of veganism to nutritional advice. These posts help participants learn more about the reasons behind their dietary choices. 



Community Engagement



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Hashtags: Veganuary uses specific hashtags (#Veganuary, #TryVegan, etc.) to create a sense of community and make it easy for participants to find and share content related to their vegan journey. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† User-Generated Content: Participants are encouraged to share their own photos and experiences using these hashtags. Veganuary often features this user-generated content on their social media channels, celebrating individual achievements and fostering a sense of connection. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Support Groups: On platforms like Facebook, Veganuary manages support groups where participants can connect, share advice, and provide mutual support. These groups are moderated to ensure a positive and inclusive environment. 



Benefits



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Accessibility: Social media makes it easy for participants to access information and support wherever they are. Whether they‚Äôre at home, at work, or on the go, they can stay connected and informed. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Engagement: Regular posts and interactive features keep participants engaged and motivated throughout the month. The variety of content ensures that there‚Äôs always something new and interesting to look forward to. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Community: The sense of community created through social media helps participants feel less isolated in their vegan journey. Knowing that others are sharing the same experience can be incredibly encouraging. 



Veganuary‚Äôs strong social media presence is a key part of its strategy to support and inspire participants. It ensures that everyone has access to the information, motivation, and community they need to succeed. 



Community Events



Community events are an important aspect to foster a sense of camaraderie and shared purpose among participants. These events are designed to bring people together, share experiences, and celebrate the joys of plant-based living. 



Types of Community Events



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† Workshops and Cooking Classes 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Cooking Demonstrations: Participants can join live or virtual cooking classes led by professional vegan chefs. These classes teach how to prepare delicious and nutritious vegan meals, from simple dishes to gourmet creations. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Workshops: These may cover a wide range of topics, such as vegan nutrition, meal planning, ethical considerations of veganism, and sustainable living practices. 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† Meet-ups and Social Gatherings 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vegan Potlucks: Local communities organize potluck events where participants bring their favorite Vegan dishes to share. This is a great way to try new recipes and connect with others who are on the same journey. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Social Meet-Ups: Informal gatherings at cafes, or community centers where participants can chat, share experiences, and support each other. 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† Public Events and Festivals 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vegan Festivals: Veganuary often partners with vegan festivals and fairs that feature food stalls, product vendors, guest speakers, and entertainment. These events celebrate vegan culture and provide opportunities to learn and explore. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Pop-Up Events: Temporary events, such as vegan food markets or pop-up restaurants, that showcase the diversity and creativity of vegan cuisine. 



4.¬†¬†¬†¬† Fitness and Wellness Activities 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Yoga and Meditation Sessions: Veganuary offers guided yoga or meditation classes that focus on wellness and mindfulness, often incorporating plant-based nutrition into the overall theme. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Fitness Challenges: Group fitness activities, such as running clubs or fitness boot camps, encourage participants to stay active while embracing a vegan lifestyle. 



5.¬†¬†¬†¬† Educational Talks and Panels 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Guest Speakers: Experts in nutrition, environmental science, animal welfare, and other related fields give talks and presentations to educate and inspire participants. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Panel Discussions: Interactive sessions where experts and long-term vegans discuss various aspects of veganism and answer questions from the audience. 



6.¬†¬†¬†¬† Volunteer and Outreach Activities 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Community Outreach: Participants may get involved in local outreach efforts, such as distributing vegan food samples, organizing informational booths, or participating in charity events. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Volunteer Opportunities: Veganuary encourages participants to volunteer with animal shelters, environmental organizations, or food banks that support plant-based initiatives. 



Benefits of Community Events



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Support and Encouragement: Community events provide a supportive environment where participants can share their challenges and successes, gaining encouragement from others. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Learning and Inspiration: Attendees learn new skills, gain valuable knowledge, and find inspiration from experts and fellow participants. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Networking and Friendship: These events help participants build connections and friendships with like-minded individuals, creating a sense of community and belonging. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Celebration of Veganism: Community events celebrate the diversity, creativity, and joy of plant-based living, making the vegan journey fun and rewarding. 



By organizing a variety of community events, Veganuary ensures that participants have ample opportunities to connect, learn, and celebrate together. These events are a wonderful way to make the vegan journey more enjoyable and sustainable. 



How Many People Have Been Encouraged to Try Veganuary



Since its start in 2014, Veganuary has turned into a global movement that has exponentially gained participants over the years. In just over a decade, Veganuary has shown many successes, especially in 2024: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Roughly 25 million people worldwide chose to try vegan 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Over 10,000 media stories featured Veganuary around the world 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 102 million international social media reach 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1.8 million people worldwide received Veganuary‚Äôs resources & support through emails, social media, podcasts, and YouTube channel 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Over 2,100 new vegan products & new menu items launched for Veganuary globally 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 300 businesses and organizations took part in the Workplace Challenge 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 17.5 million coaching emails were sent 



These successes add up to Veganuary‚Äôs biggest achievement ‚Äì 25% of people who complete Veganuary stay vegan with 78% intending to cut their meat-eating by half (The Sensitive Foodie Kitchen). This is proof that Veganuary is successfully pioneering a plant-based revolution. 



How to Help and Why



We can help Veganuary in its mission to help the world go vegan in several ways: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Sign up for the 31-Day Vegan Challenge and give the vegan lifestyle a try in January. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Share your Veganuary journey on social media to inspire others. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Encourage friends and family to join you in the Veganuary challenge. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† If you have a blog or a publication, share your experiences and the benefits of veganism to reach a broader audience. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Volunteer at local vegan events, potlucks, meet-ups, and any other activities that promote veganism in your community. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Offer your skills to Veganuary, whether it‚Äôs through graphic design, social media management, or writing content. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Make a one-time donation or become a regular supporter to help Veganuary continue to provide resources and support, and run campaigns. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬†Organize fundraising events or campaigns to raise money for Veganuary. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Encourage your workplace to take part in the Veganuary Workplace Challenge. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† If you own or manage a business, consider sponsoring Veganuary or offering vegan options to employees and customers. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Organize workshops or cooking classes to teach others about veganism and how to prepare plant-based meals. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Give talks or presentations at schools, community centers, or events to educate others about the benefits of a vegan lifestyle. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Support vegan businesses by purchasing their products and services so it helps create demand and encourages more businesses to offer vegan options. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Write positive reviews for vegan products and restaurants to help others discover them. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Follow Veganuary on social media, subscribe to their newsletter, watch their videos, and keep up with their latest news and campaigns. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Read and share Veganuary‚Äôs articles, watch their videos, and listen to their podcasts to stay informed and help spread awareness. 



Encouraging the entire world to transition to a plant-based diet isn‚Äôt going to be as easy as encouraging someone to try a new shirt at the store. It may even verge on the realm of impossibility, but if we can achieve that, we can create a world that benefits people, animals, and the planet. And that world is one worth striving for, no matter how hard and no matter how long it takes to create. 



‚ÄúOur vision is simple; we want a vegan world. A world without animal farms and slaughterhouses. A world where food production does not decimate forests, pollute rivers and oceans, exacerbate climate change, and drive wild animal populations to extinction.‚Äù ‚Äì Veganuary 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† What inspired you to try Veganuary, or what would motivate you to give it a try? 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† What challenges have you faced (or do you anticipate facing) while adopting a vegan lifestyle, and how did you overcome them (or plan to)? 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Which Veganuary resource or activity do you find most helpful or exciting, and why? 



Please leave your answers in the comment section! 



If you liked this blog post, please leave a like, subscribe, and share it on your social media to spread awareness about Veganuary and its vision of a vegan world, then you can become an Exemplar of Change! 



If you want to learn more about Veganuary and its work in pioneering the plant-based revolution, look at the links below!

author: Camille Rose
title: 5 EASY VEGAN SWAPS TO EAT LESS MEAT
text:
My first introduction to veganism was in high school. My best friend at the time (band camp!) was vegan and at first I gave her shit but naturally, as best friends do, I wanted to do it too, sorta. I started out as pescatarian and that lasted for 2 years until I graduated and moved to the midwest (not the most plant-based diet accommodating region at the time). 



I continued to be pescatarian off and on until this past year when I made the jump, all in, to veganism. Let me be honest, I‚Äôm a fat vegan. I love all my veggies and my health has improved, my poops are fantastic, and our grocery bill smaller, but ya girl likes pizza (and ice cream, and burgers, and CHEESE). So, I‚Äôm always on the hunt for really good vegan dupes of those animal products.  



I should mention, I don‚Äôt cook. I can toast toast, scramble some JUST egg (vegan brand), and I‚Äôm getting better at crisping up some tofu (to add to my 90-second rice and frozen veggies). My wonderful husband Cody is my personal chef. And paid chef for others but I‚Äôm pretty sure he cooks his best meals for me. Cody is not vegan, but because of my changes, he has dramatically reduced his consumption of animal products. He loves the challenge of cooking with new ingredients and will let me know what he likes and doesn‚Äôt. For example, he‚Äôs not a fan of vegan cheese: the affordable stuff, everyday-use cheese can be gummy. Living in WV, options are limited. But, there are many options (even in WV) that have surprised us for being both vegan and tasty. 



With all that said, here are 5 of my favorite vegan dupes that helped me transition from animal products to veganism. These are Cody approved as well! 




Tofu I know. The dreaded enemy. I was NOT a tofu girlie until I went vegan. Now, I crave it. And there are so many ways to cook this affordable food. There is a learning curve, but the internet has so many great recipes and tips/tricks, making tofu a staple in many of our meals now.  With some rice and veggies, it‚Äôs a quick and satiating lunch after a workout, which is perfect for someone who may not have the time (or skills).



Gardein F‚Äôsh Sticks Hear me out on this one. Trust me, I looked at that box and laughed. Not only is real frozen fish hit or miss, but a dupe!? It‚Äôs so good. Yes, you read that right: It‚Äôs soo good. Look, if you‚Äôre not a fish person, this probably isn‚Äôt for you. But me, the former pescatarian, seafood was the last animal flesh I wanted to leave in the past. These f‚Äôsh sticks make up for those nights when a good ol‚Äô fish and chips hits the spot. These hit the spot. 



Impossible Meat Impossible is out here doing their thing. Impossible Whopper at Burger King, Impossible burger options at restaurants. Even Cracker Barrel has an Impossible substitution available. The taste, look, everything is the same. Price? Pricier than the animal flesh option, but a great swap for Meatless Mondays. 



MorningStar Chik‚Äôn Nuggets MorningStar is accessible and affordable, available in any chain grocery store. I frequently buy their bacon but Cody does not like it. It definitely is not the crispy skin we grew up with, but does the job for me. Their standout product is their nuggets. The buffalo, THE BUFFALO chick‚Äôn wings are it. Load me up. They get me in the mood for sports and summer and hanging out with friends. Perfect option, especially for those chicken nugget kiddos (they have not-buffalo flavor as well). 



Country Crock Plant-Based Cream AND Butter This suggestion came from the chef himself. I know, technically this list is now ‚Äú6 Easy Vegan Swaps‚Äù but we have been surprised with how comparable these are to the animal version. I don‚Äôt use the cream but Cody has used it to make white chik‚Äôn chili, Swedish meatballs, mashed potatoes, and anywhere heavy cream is needed. Many receipes call for coconut cream to replace cow cream, but it doesn‚Äôt quite do the job like this stuff. And their butter!? I‚Äôm pretty sure it‚Äôs just margarine‚Ä¶but it‚Äôs good. And softens quickly out of the fridge which is great for someone like me who forgets to soften butter for those cookies I want to bake RIGHT NOW.

author: NutraPhoria School of Holistic Nutrition
title: Is a Plant-Based Diet Right for You? Exploring the Power of Plant-Based Nutrition.
text:
With growing awareness of how the foods we eat impact our health, more and more people are considering a switch to a plant-focused style of eating. From veganism to vegetarianism to a complete raw food diet, the world of plant-based nutrition certainly offers a diverse array of choices. But is a plant-based diet the right choice for you? In this blog post, we‚Äôll explore the different types of plant-based diets, we‚Äôll discuss some of their potential benefits and risks, and offer some basic tips on how you can make a successful transition into this new style of eating.¬† 
 
Understanding Plant-Based Nutrition
Plant-based diets may differ in specifics, but the one thing they have in common is a focus on whole, unprocessed plant foods, such as fruits, vegetables, grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds. Here are the primary types, and how they can be customized to suit your individual preferences and nutritional needs: 
¬† 

Veganism: Vegans abstain from all animal products, including meat, dairy, eggs, and even honey. This diet is based solely on plant foods. Some vegans even abstain from wearing clothing that has been made with animal fur or skins, such as leather and wool. 

Vegetarianism: Vegetarians avoid meal, but may include dairy and eggs in their diets. This is referred to as a ‚Äúlacto-ovo vegetarian.‚Äù 

Pescatarian: Pescatarians consume fish along with plant-based foods, but they avoid other types of meat. 

Flexitarian: Flexitarians primarily follow a plant-based diet, but they occasionally include a small amount of animal products.
Raw Foodists: Raw foodists consume uncooked and unprocessed plant foods, believing that cooking destroys essential nutrients.

 
Potential Benefits of Plant-Based Diets, and a Note on Bio-Individuality
Switching to a plant-based diet can lead to remarkable health improvements for many individuals. However, the reasons behind these changes can often be multifaceted. For those coming from heavily processed diets, the shift to more natural, plant-based foods naturally marks a significant improvement. Nonetheless, each person‚Äôs unique bio-individual chemical makeup means that what works for one may not work for another.¬† Factors like genetics, metabolism, lifestyle, and response to stress all play a role, underscoring the importance of personalized nutrition. While reducing processed foods alone can enhance well-being, the specific impact of switching to a plant-based diet for the long haul will still vary from person to person. Staying attuned to the body‚Äôs signals and being open to adjustments along the way allows individuals to fine-tune their dietary choices and optimize their health even further on their plant-based journey. 
That said, here are some of the potential health benefits one might experience through switching to a more plant-based style of eating: 
¬† 

Improved Heart Health: Plant-based diets are often associated with lower cholesterol levels, reduced risk of heart disease, and lower blood pressure. 

Weight Management: A plant-based diet rich in whole, unprocessed foods can aid in weight loss, and maintenance of a healthy weight. 

Enhanced digestion: The fiber and enzyme content in whole plant foods supports a healthy microbiome and digestive system. 

Increased Nutrient Intake: Plant-based diets provide a wide varieties of essential nutrients and antioxidants.

 
Potential Risks of Plant-Based Diets:

Nutrient Deficiencies: Inadequate planning may lead to deficiencies in nutrients like vitamin B12, iron, calcium, and omega-3 fatty acids. Proper supplementation and dietary choices can mitigate these risks, and this is one reason working with a qualified practitioner when making this change can be so beneficial. 

Protein Intake: Plant-based diets can provide ample protein, but it is essential to combine various protein courses for a complete amino acid profile. 

Food allergies: Relying heavily on certain plant foods can exacerbate allergies or sensitivities. 

Eating Disorders: Those with a history of eating disorders should approach any restrictive diet, including plant-based diets, with caution and professional guidance.

¬† 
A Balanced Approach to Plant-Based Nutrition 

When transitioning to a plant-based diet, it is essential to recognize that there can be both healthy and unhealthy approaches. Opting for a balanced switch involves a thoughtful incorporation of plant-based foods rich in nutrients, vitamins, and minerals. This may include a variety of fresh fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts and seeds. These whole foods offer a wealth of nutritional benefits and can form the foundation of a nourishing plant-based diet. 
On the other hand, an imbalanced shift may involve relying too heavily on processed meat alternatives, which can be laden with additives, preservatives, and high levels of sodium. Consuming excessive starches, refined carbohydrates, and sugary vegan snacks can also be detrimental to health. This kind of plant-based diet can lack the essential nutrients required to for overall well-being, and can lead to potential health issues if not carefully balanced. 
To make a successful transition to a plant-based lifestyle, individuals should prioritize whole, minimally processed foods while being mindful of their nutrient intake. Consulting a registered practitioner can be incredibly beneficial in ensuring that the dietary choices you make align with your unique health goals. 
 
Tips for Transitioning to a Plant-Based Diet

Gradual Approach: Start by incorporating more plant-based meals into your diet, and gradually reducing animal products. 

Variety is Key: Explore a wide range of plant-based whole foods to ensure you get a diverse array of nutrients. 

Educate Yourself: Learn about the nutritional requirements of a plant-based diet to make the best-informed choices for your health. 

Seek Support: Join a community, work with a practitioner, or connect with others in plant-based nutrition forums to gain insights and encouragement from others.¬†

¬† 
Final Thoughts
A plant-based diet can be a powerful choice for promoting personal health and longevity. By understanding the different types of plant-based diets, their benefits and potential risks, you can make the best-informed decisions that align with your unique goals and values. And remember: A successful transition involves education, support, and an open mind, so whether you‚Äôre a curious beginner or a seasoned enthusiast, our Plant-Based Nutrition program is available to support and empower you along your journey.¬† 
Embrace the power of plants and embark on an exciting path to vibrant well-being!
