author: safrestaurant
title: The Impact of a Vegan Lifestyle on Lowering Pollution and Soil Degradation
text:
As the planet faces increasing environmental challenges, one of the most effective yet often overlooked solutions is the adoption of a vegan lifestyle. While many people focus on the health benefits of plant-based eating, the environmental impact‚Äîespecially in terms of pollution and soil degradation‚Äîis profound. 



In this article, we‚Äôll explore how choosing a vegan lifestyle can help reduce pollution and soil degradation, two critical issues that threaten the planet‚Äôs ecosystems and biodiversity. 



Understanding Pollution and Soil Degradation



Before we dive into the specifics, it‚Äôs important to understand what we mean by pollution and soil degradation: 




Pollution refers to the presence of harmful substances or contaminants in the air, water, and soil, typically as a result of human activity. This includes chemicals, waste products, and greenhouse gases that harm ecosystems and contribute to global warming.



Soil degradation occurs when the soil‚Äôs health and fertility are compromised due to factors like erosion, loss of nutrients, and contamination. Agricultural practices, especially industrial farming, are a primary driver of soil degradation, leading to reduced agricultural productivity and long-term environmental harm.




Both of these issues are strongly linked to agricultural practices, particularly those associated with animal farming. The good news? Adopting a vegan lifestyle can help alleviate both pollution and soil degradation in significant ways. 



How Animal Agriculture Contributes to Pollution and Soil Degradation



To fully appreciate the impact of veganism on pollution and soil health, it‚Äôs crucial to understand how animal agriculture contributes to these problems: 



1. Water Pollution and Runoff



Animal farming produces massive amounts of waste‚Äîfeces, urine, and leftover feed‚Äîthat often ends up in rivers, streams, and lakes. This waste contains harmful chemicals like nitrogen and phosphorus, which can cause nutrient pollution in water bodies, leading to algal blooms and ‚Äúdead zones,‚Äù where aquatic life cannot survive. 



Moreover, the chemicals used in growing animal feed‚Äîsuch as pesticides, herbicides, and fertilizers‚Äîoften wash into waterways, further polluting the environment. 



2. Soil Erosion and Overgrazing



Intensive farming, particularly livestock grazing, leads to soil erosion. Overgrazing by animals like cattle, sheep, and goats prevents vegetation from growing back, which exposes the soil to wind and water erosion. This process not only depletes the soil of essential nutrients but also reduces its ability to retain water, making it less productive over time. 



In addition, the large-scale production of feed crops (corn, soy, and alfalfa) for livestock also leads to soil degradation. Monoculture farming, in which the same crop is planted repeatedly in the same soil, depletes the soil‚Äôs nutrient content and increases the need for chemical fertilizers and pesticides. 



3. Air Pollution



The livestock sector is a major source of air pollution, releasing harmful gases like methane, ammonia, and particulate matter into the atmosphere. Methane, in particular, is a potent greenhouse gas that has a far greater warming potential than carbon dioxide. Animal waste and manure also release ammonia into the air, which can contribute to acid rain and harm local ecosystems. 



How Veganism Helps Reduce Pollution and Soil Degradation



Switching to a vegan lifestyle can have a profound and positive effect on both pollution and soil degradation. Here‚Äôs how: 



1. Reducing Water Pollution



By choosing plant-based foods over animal products, we reduce the demand for factory farming, which is a leading cause of water pollution. Without the need for large-scale livestock operations, less animal waste will end up contaminating our water sources. Additionally, growing crops for human consumption requires far fewer chemicals and fertilizers than feed crops for livestock, leading to less runoff and reduced water contamination. 



Moreover, plant-based farming generally uses less water than animal farming, especially when it comes to water-intensive livestock like cattle. This means that less water is used for both irrigation and livestock maintenance, ultimately lowering the risk of water pollution caused by overuse. 



2. Preventing Soil Erosion and Promoting Healthier Soil



By reducing the need for grazing and intensive animal agriculture, a vegan lifestyle helps preserve the integrity of the soil. Vegan diets emphasize plant-based crops like vegetables, fruits, grains, and legumes‚Äîmany of which can be grown in more sustainable farming systems that emphasize crop rotation, organic farming, and reduced use of harmful chemicals. 



Furthermore, plant-based agriculture tends to be less disruptive to the soil than animal agriculture. For example, crops like legumes can actually improve soil health by fixing nitrogen in the soil, enriching it with the nutrients it needs to remain productive. These farming practices help to reduce soil erosion and degradation, ensuring that the land remains fertile for future generations. 



3. Lowering Greenhouse Gas Emissions and Air Pollution



Livestock farming is one of the largest sources of methane emissions, which significantly contribute to global warming and air pollution. By adopting a vegan diet, you directly decrease the demand for animal products, leading to lower methane emissions. The plant-based foods that replace animal products‚Äîgrains, legumes, fruits, and vegetables‚Äîgenerate far fewer emissions. 



Additionally, reducing animal farming lowers the need for massive manure storage and management, which are major sources of ammonia emissions. With fewer factory farms, we reduce both air and water pollution, which benefits not only the environment but also public health. 



4. Encouraging More Sustainable Agricultural Practices



Veganism also supports more sustainable agricultural practices by reducing the demand for monoculture farming and large-scale animal feed production. As plant-based diets become more popular, there is a shift toward diverse, sustainable farming systems that prioritize soil health, crop biodiversity, and regenerative agriculture techniques. 



Farmers who grow plants for direct human consumption are increasingly adopting methods like no-till farming, agroforestry, and permaculture. These techniques help to preserve soil structure, reduce erosion, and improve water retention. By choosing vegan options, we encourage these sustainable farming practices and reduce the environmental harm caused by industrial agriculture. 



Conclusion: A Vegan Lifestyle for Cleaner, Healthier Soil and Air



Adopting a vegan lifestyle is a powerful tool for reducing pollution and soil degradation. By decreasing the demand for harmful practices like intensive animal farming, we can significantly lower water pollution, prevent soil erosion, and reduce the emission of greenhouse gases and other pollutants. 



Not only does veganism offer a direct way to lower your environmental impact, but it also promotes a more sustainable and resilient food system that can better withstand the challenges of climate change. The shift toward plant-based eating is not just good for your health‚Äîit‚Äôs essential for the health of the planet. 



At SAF Restaurant, we‚Äôre proud to offer a variety of delicious, sustainable, plant-based options that help our guests contribute to a cleaner, greener future. Together, we can make a difference, one meal at a time.

author: safrestaurant
title: The Impact of a Vegan Lifestyle on Reducing Your Carbon Footprint
text:
As the world grapples with the challenges of climate change, one powerful and increasingly popular way individuals can reduce their carbon footprint is through adopting a vegan lifestyle. The environmental benefits of a plant-based diet go far beyond simply choosing ‚Äúgreener‚Äù foods; they play a crucial role in tackling one of the most pressing environmental issues we face today: global warming. 



In this article, we‚Äôll explore how shifting to a vegan lifestyle can significantly reduce your carbon footprint and contribute to a more sustainable future for our planet. 



What is a Carbon Footprint?



Before diving into the specifics, let‚Äôs clarify what a carbon footprint is. It refers to the total amount of greenhouse gases‚Äîsuch as carbon dioxide (CO2) and methane (CH4)‚Äîemitted into the atmosphere as a result of human activity. These gases trap heat in the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere, contributing to the greenhouse effect and accelerating global warming. 



In everyday terms, your carbon footprint includes everything from your energy consumption (electricity, heating, etc.) to the food you eat, the products you buy, and even how you travel. The food industry, particularly animal agriculture, is a significant contributor to global carbon emissions. 



View Post 



The Environmental Toll of Animal Agriculture



Animal agriculture, especially beef and dairy production, is responsible for a large portion of global greenhouse gas emissions. Here‚Äôs why: 




Methane Emissions: Livestock like cows, sheep, and goats produce methane during digestion, a potent greenhouse gas that is 28 times more effective at trapping heat in the atmosphere than carbon dioxide.



Land Use and Deforestation: To raise animals for food, vast areas of land are cleared, often through deforestation, particularly in tropical regions like the Amazon rainforest. Deforestation releases carbon that was previously stored in trees, adding to the overall greenhouse gas emissions.



Feed Production: Growing crops to feed livestock (especially corn and soy) also generates emissions, not to mention the heavy use of fertilizers and pesticides that further contribute to the carbon footprint.



Energy Consumption: The industrial-scale operation of factory farms requires significant amounts of energy for maintaining animal housing, processing meat, and transporting products.




How Veganism Reduces Carbon Emissions



Adopting a vegan lifestyle helps reduce your carbon footprint in several important ways: 



1. Lowering Greenhouse Gas Emissions



Livestock farming is responsible for a substantial portion of global methane emissions. By eliminating meat and dairy from your diet, you directly reduce the demand for these high-emission industries. Studies have shown that switching to a plant-based diet can reduce an individual‚Äôs food-related carbon emissions by up to 73%. 



For example, producing a single pound of beef generates more than 20 pounds of CO2-equivalent emissions. In contrast, a plant-based food like lentils or beans has a significantly lower environmental cost, contributing far fewer greenhouse gases to the atmosphere. 



2. Reducing Land Use and Deforestation



As demand for meat and dairy products decreases, so does the need for massive amounts of land to raise animals and grow their feed. By choosing plant-based foods, we help reduce deforestation and habitat destruction, which are critical for slowing climate change. Forests act as carbon sinks, absorbing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. Protecting forests and allowing them to thrive helps mitigate global warming. 



3. Energy Efficiency in Food Production



Growing crops for human consumption generally requires far less energy than raising animals for food. While animal agriculture relies on energy-intensive processes such as raising, feeding, and processing animals, plant-based agriculture has a much lower energy demand. Additionally, plant-based foods typically require fewer resources for transportation, as they can be grown locally and do not require refrigeration or extensive processing. 



4. Encouraging Sustainable Agricultural Practices



As the demand for plant-based foods rises, farmers are incentivized to shift toward more sustainable farming practices. Crop rotation, organic farming, and regenerative agriculture are becoming more common as part of this movement. These methods help preserve the soil, reduce pesticide and fertilizer use, and minimize the carbon footprint associated with food production. 



5. Promoting Sustainable Diets



A global shift toward plant-based eating could have far-reaching effects. If more people adopted vegan diets, there would be a significant reduction in the resources required to feed the planet, making food systems more efficient and environmentally friendly. This transition would help address the inefficiencies in global food production, which is especially crucial as the world faces an increasing population and the threat of food insecurity. 



Veganism in Numbers: The Climate Impact



To better understand the impact, consider these statistics: 




A study by Oxford University found that switching to a vegan diet could reduce your personal carbon footprint from food by up to 73%.



The United Nations has highlighted the fact that reducing meat consumption is one of the most effective ways individuals can help fight climate change.



According to research from the Environmental Working Group, beef production is the most carbon-intensive food, producing more than 10 times the greenhouse gas emissions per calorie than plant-based foods like grains, vegetables, or legumes.




Conclusion: Veganism as a Tool for Climate Action



The decision to adopt a vegan lifestyle can be a powerful and effective way to reduce your carbon footprint and take meaningful action against climate change. By reducing greenhouse gas emissions, lowering the demand for land, and supporting more sustainable agricultural practices, veganism directly contributes to a healthier planet. 



Every plant-based meal you consume adds to the collective effort to mitigate global warming and protect the environment. So whether you‚Äôre looking to cut back on meat for health reasons, ethical considerations, or environmental impact, know that your choices matter. 



By making small changes in our diets, we can all play a part in reducing the carbon emissions that are fueling the climate crisis. Every bite counts in the fight for a sustainable, healthy future for generations to come.

title: Foods That Help Prevent Prostate Cancer | Dr. Neal Barnard
text:
Foods That Help Prevent Prostate Cancer | Dr. Neal Barnard
Jeff Surak
Thu, 01/30/2025 - 10:31




  
    Featured Image
              Preventing Prostate Cancer ERL-2.jpg
          


  
    Summary
              Learn the foods that can help prevent prostate cancer and boost your digestive health. 
          



      
              
  
		
		


  
    

              


This episode of The Exam Room‚Ñ¢ Podcast is sponsored by The Gregory J. Reiter Memorial Fund, which supports organizations like the Physicians Committee that carry on Greg‚Äôs passion and love for animals through rescue efforts, veganism, and wildlife conservation. 
      
  

	

              
  
		
		


  
    

            Dr. Neal Barnard joins Chuck Carroll on The Exam Room Live to discuss the dietary factors that may influence your cancer risk. In this interview:Dairy Consumption: Studies from Harvard indicate that men who consume milk have a higher risk of developing prostate cancer, regardless of whether it's low-fat or whole milk. The insulin-like growth factor (IGF-1) in milk is a potential contributor to this increased risk. Meat Consumption: A diet high in red meat, such as hamburgers and fries, is also linked to a higher risk of prostate cancer. Protective Foods: Foods rich in lycopene, particularly tomato products, and soy products are associated with a lower risk of prostate cancer. Soy does not cause breast cancer in men and may actually reduce the risk of prostate cancer. Impact of Lifestyle Changes: Making dietary changes after a prostate cancer diagnosis can be beneficial in preventing recurrence. Dr. Barnard references Dean Ornish's studies that suggest dietary modifications can positively impact men with prostate cancer. Green Tea: Dr. Barnard notes that while green tea may have some protective effects, it is not a substitute for other dietary changes. Sugar: Sugar, particularly from dairy products, is discussed as a potential risk factor for prostate cancer.

author: CutiePie Blogs
title: Is Being Vegan Actually Good for You? Exploring the Benefits and Challenges
text:
5 minutes




In recent years, veganism has grown from a niche dietary choice to a global movement embraced by millions. A vegan lifestyle involves avoiding all animal products, including meat, dairy, eggs, and often even honey, in favor of plant-based foods. Advocates of veganism tout its health benefits, environmental impact, and ethical stance on animal welfare. But is being vegan truly good for you? In this blog, we‚Äôll explore the pros and cons of veganism, from health implications to broader societal impacts, to help you make an informed decision. 



The Health Benefits of a Vegan Diet



One of the main reasons people turn to veganism is for its potential health benefits. Here‚Äôs a closer look at how a vegan diet can positively affect your body: 



1. Improved Heart Health



Research shows that plant-based diets are associated with lower risks of heart disease. Vegans typically consume less saturated fat, which is found in animal products, and more fiber, which helps lower cholesterol levels. A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, nuts, and whole grains can support healthy blood pressure and reduce the risk of cardiovascular issues. 



2. Weight Management



Studies suggest that vegans often have lower body mass indexes (BMIs) compared to meat-eaters. Plant-based foods are generally lower in calories but higher in fiber, keeping you full longer and reducing overeating. As a result, many people find it easier to manage their weight on a vegan diet. 







3. Reduced Risk of Chronic Diseases



Vegan diets have been linked to a reduced risk of several chronic conditions, including type 2 diabetes, certain cancers, and hypertension. The abundance of antioxidants, vitamins, and minerals in plant-based foods plays a key role in preventing cell damage and inflammation, which contribute to these diseases. 



4. Better Digestion



High-fiber diets are a hallmark of veganism, promoting healthy digestion and preventing issues like constipation. Fiber supports gut health by feeding beneficial bacteria in the microbiome, which can also enhance immune function. 



5. Skin Health



A vegan diet rich in fruits and vegetables can lead to clearer, healthier skin. The high levels of antioxidants and water content in plant-based foods can help combat acne and improve skin hydration. 




Read more




The Environmental Impact of Veganism



Beyond personal health, veganism is often praised for its environmental benefits. The production of meat and dairy is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, deforestation, and water usage. Here are a few ways veganism supports the planet: 



1. Reduced Carbon Footprint



Livestock farming is responsible for approximately 14.5% of global greenhouse gas emissions. By switching to a plant-based diet, individuals can significantly lower their carbon footprint. 









2. Conservation of Resources



Animal agriculture is resource-intensive, requiring large amounts of water, land, and crops to produce meat and dairy. A vegan diet reduces the demand for these resources, contributing to greater sustainability. 



3. Protection of Biodiversity



The clearing of forests for grazing land and feed crops threatens wildlife habitats and reduces biodiversity. By choosing plant-based foods, you indirectly support the preservation of ecosystems. 



The Ethical Argument for Veganism



For many, veganism is less about personal health and more about compassion. Avoiding animal products aligns with a commitment to reducing animal suffering. Factory farming practices often involve inhumane conditions for animals, and veganism offers a way to take a stand against this cruelty. 



Furthermore, the movement has inspired innovations in food technology, including plant-based meat alternatives and lab-grown meat, which aim to provide ethical and sustainable options for consumers. 



Challenges of a Vegan Diet



While veganism has many advantages, it‚Äôs not without its challenges. Transitioning to and maintaining a vegan diet can pose difficulties, especially for those unprepared for the lifestyle shift. 



1. Nutritional Deficiencies



Certain nutrients are harder to obtain on a vegan diet, including: 




Vitamin B12: Found primarily in animal products, B12 is essential for nerve function and the production of red blood cells. Vegans need to rely on fortified foods or supplements.



Iron: While plant-based sources of iron exist (e.g., spinach, lentils), they are less easily absorbed by the body compared to animal sources.



Calcium: Dairy products are a major source of calcium, so vegans need to consume fortified plant milks or calcium-rich vegetables like kale and broccoli.



Omega-3 Fatty Acids: Found in fish, these essential fats support brain health. Vegans can obtain them from flaxseeds, chia seeds, and walnuts, but supplementation may still be necessary.




2. Social and Cultural Barriers



Eating vegan can be challenging in social settings or cultures where meat is a staple. Dining out or attending events often requires extra effort to find suitable options. 



3. Accessibility and Cost



While basic vegan staples like beans, rice, and vegetables are affordable, specialty vegan products (e.g., plant-based meats and cheeses) can be expensive and inaccessible in some areas. 




Get your affordable plant-based meat here!




4. The Risk of Highly Processed Foods



Not all vegan foods are healthy. Many processed vegan products, such as chips, cookies, and faux meats, can be high in sodium, sugar, and unhealthy fats. It‚Äôs important to focus on whole, nutrient-dense foods rather than relying on convenience items. 



Striking a Balance: Is Veganism Right for You?



The question of whether being vegan is ‚Äúgood‚Äù depends on your individual goals, needs, and circumstances. For those committed to improving health, reducing environmental impact, or aligning with ethical values, veganism can be a fulfilling choice. However, it‚Äôs essential to plan your diet carefully to avoid nutritional deficiencies and ensure that your meals are balanced. 



If a fully vegan lifestyle feels overwhelming, you can start with small steps, such as adopting a flexitarian or vegetarian diet. Initiatives like ‚ÄúMeatless Mondays‚Äù or reducing dairy consumption can still have a positive impact on your health and the planet. 



Let‚Äôs conclude 



Veganism is more than just a diet; it‚Äôs a lifestyle choice with far-reaching implications for personal health, the environment, and animal welfare. While it offers numerous benefits, it‚Äôs not without its challenges. By educating yourself, planning meals thoughtfully, and seeking support from the vegan community, you can create a sustainable approach to plant-based living that aligns with your values and goals. 



Ultimately, the decision to go vegan is a deeply personal one. Whether you choose to fully embrace veganism or simply incorporate more plant-based meals into your diet, every small step can contribute to a healthier you and a healthier planet. 


 

	




	



	




	



	




	



	




	



	




	

Rating: 1 out of 5.

January 30, 2025




				
					
						
							
							
								About CutiePie BlogsContact us

author: Kate Hilton
title: Diets Don‚Äôt Work; Here‚Äôs Why.
text:
Picture this; it‚Äôs the New Year, or perhaps it‚Äôs 12 weeks before a big holiday, or 6 months before a big event. You‚Äôve decided enough is enough. You will lose weight this time, and you will keep it off. You decide you are going to follow a new diet this time to help you lose weight; Kathy down the road did it and has lost 3 stone already! It could be keto, Slimming World, veganism, ultra-low calorie; the type of diet doesn‚Äôt matter. All that matters is this time, it will work.  



The first week goes really well. You feel super motivated; ‚Äúthis is easy!‚Äù, you think to yourself. You‚Äôre able to stick to the diet perfectly, portioning out your food, avoiding all carbs and processed foods, eating only your pre-prepared meals, drinking only water or black tea or coffee, feeling better already. You‚Äôve already lost 5lbs from this first week! You‚Äôll be at your goal weight in no time at this rate. 



The next week is a little tougher. There was a deadline at work which meant you had to stay late one day, meaning you had less time to make dinner. ‚ÄúNo matter‚Äù, you think. ‚ÄúI still managed to do it, even if it did mean I had to stay up later than usual. It‚Äôs still doable‚Äù. You lose a further 5lbs this week. This gives you the motivation to keep going. 



The following week, you get invited out for a meal and a few drinks with your friends. You think about it, tempted; it‚Äôs been so long since you saw them, and you‚Äôre craving some time to let your hair down. But, you have to think about your diet. You won‚Äôt make your goal weight if you give into the desire to go out. You decline. The day comes and goes and you feel sad that you‚Äôre stuck inside whilst your friends are out having fun. But it will be worth it when it comes to the weigh in.  



3lbs lost. Not quite as good as last week. But not bad. You still feel motivated, but perhaps not as much as before. 



The next week rolls around. You feel quite stressed because of work and family life. You find it difficult to find the time to make your meals and snacks for the week. You stick to the diet as best as you can; but, because it isn‚Äôt very flexible, you find there are a few meals you aren‚Äôt able to make perfectly fit the diet because the shops don‚Äôt sell something ready made, and after all, you don‚Äôt really have the time this week to meal prep. 



0lb lost. You‚Äôve plateaued.  



Your friends invite you out to eat again this week. Motivation is running low. ‚ÄúScrew it‚Äù, you think. ‚ÄúI am going to go and enjoy time with my friends. I just won‚Äôt eat anything, or if I do, it will just be a salad. I won‚Äôt drink any alcohol‚Äù. Inevitably though, the lack of weight loss this week eats away at you in your brain. Whilst you‚Äôre out, you get the familiar thoughts; ‚Äúwhat is the point in sticking to this if I‚Äôm not losing any weight? I might as well enjoy myself. I‚Äôll start again tomorrow‚Äù. And you do. You, if anything, eat more and drink more than you usually do. The diet has turned this food and drink into ‚Äúforbidden fruit‚Äù, and you‚Äôre hungry for more. 



2lbs gained.  



Inevitably, you don‚Äôt start again tomorrow. Your old habits slip back in. You continue down the path you‚Äôve always followed, and nothing has changed.  



Sound familiar? 



Why diets don‚Äôt work 



Diet‚Äôs don‚Äôt work because, generally, they don‚Äôt work with all parts of you and your lifestyle.  







There are hundreds of reasons we eat the way we eat; perhaps it‚Äôs due to taste, yes, but it‚Äôs also due to the time we have to buy, cook and prepare food, due to our finances, our families tastes and preferences, our social life, our work/life balance, our cooking knowledge and skill, our culture and upbringing, and so much more. 



The reality is, no diet which is pre-planned and has rigid rules will ever meet our needs for all of the reasons we eat a specific way. You might require more time than you have, more knowledge and skills than you have, more money than you have, or it might require you to make things your family doesn‚Äôt enjoy, things which don‚Äôt fall within your cultural tastes, or things you don‚Äôt enjoy in general.  



If you wish to change your habits and behaviours for life, you need to understand exactly why you make the decisions to eat the way you eat, and you then need to find a way of changing your diet which will still accommodate these.  



Be honest with yourself; do you eat that pizza for taste, or for convenience? Do you eat fish and chips because it‚Äôs what you really want to eat, or because it‚Äôs a cultural or social thing? 



Work out what you eat and why you eat it. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you don‚Äôt think it is a good enough reason to eat it; ultimately, it is still the reason. Once you understand these reasons, you may be able to find adjustments and small changes that will fit that reason. This will make you less likely to fail at sticking to the diet. Examples of these, and how you could respond to them, include; 




‚ÄúI eat takeaway‚Äôs because I‚Äôm exhausted and they are convenient as I don‚Äôt have to cook anything‚Äù >>> a healthy ready meal may be a better alternative, such as Field Doctor. Equally, if you have time on the weekend, you could meal prep for the week to ensure you have an alternative food source to fall back on, and prevent you from picking up the phone to the Indian or Chinese restaurant.



‚ÄúI eat lots of chocolate and sweets because I enjoy the taste‚Äù >>> what is it about these foods you enjoy? Be specific. Can you find any foods with similar qualities but less calories/ more nutritious? Have you tried having a smaller amount of these foods, and pairing them with protein and fibre to reduce hunger and improve the nutrition?



‚ÄúWhen I go out I‚Äôll order anything I want because it‚Äôs a treat‚Äù>>> why do you do this? Do you actually enjoy doing this? Would you feel better if you had a moderate amount of food and drink instead of stuffing yourself? Are there any underlying emotions there which may be impacting this decision?




But that isn‚Äôt the only reason diets don‚Äôt work 



Many people who struggle with their weight have other reasons they eat other than being hungry. It could be emotional, habitual, environmental; either way, these will throw a spanner in the works when it comes to any form of weight loss, because of the fact that there is often an unmet need there, especially when it comes to emotional eating. No traditional diet ever actually addresses these issues, and so you aren‚Äôt equipped with the skills to deal with them when they come along.  



How to make sustainable diet changes that stick 



The first thing you are going to want to do is get rid of the traditional notion of a diet; this temporary thing which requires extreme changes for a small amount of time which can be forgotten about after a while. Reframing this in your mind is a much healthier way of looking at nutrition and dietary changes, and can give you the freedom and flexibility you need. 



Instead, making small and sustainable dietary changes which work for you and your lifestyle is a much better habit. Building on these over the course of a few weeks, months, or even years, is an easier way to maintain the changes over time. Equally, identifying reasons for eating other than hunger (such as emotional or habitual eating) and working on improving these is vitally important to keep you on track. Stay tuned for further blog posts discussing both of these topics!

author: itstimholman
title: In meat- and fish-loving Japan, veganism is making a comeback
text: ¬†From¬†japantimes.co.jp Tourism, climate goals and animal rights concerns are sparking a plant-based renaissance in a country famous for sushi and pork ramen All is quiet at 10:30 a.m. on a Thursday in Shibuya, Tokyo‚Äôs famous commercial district. In an alleyway just steps from one of the busiest train stations in the world, a short line of tourists huddles outside of a bar. Finally, half an hour later, the door cracks open and, greeted with a soft ‚Äúirasshaimase,‚Äù or ‚Äúwelcome,‚Äù the parties shuffle in to sample one of the rarest dishes in Japan: faux-fish sushi.  ‚ÄúNowadays, there are many¬†vegan ‚Äòmeat‚Äô products,‚Äù said Kazue Maeda, one of the four founding employees of the restaurant, Vegan Sushi Tokyo. ‚ÄúBut I‚Äôm Japanese. What I really used to love is sushi and salmon.‚Äù Her restaurant attempts to fill a relatively unclaimed niche in the local food scene. Even in Tokyo, where much of the country‚Äôs vegan population lives, plant-based versions of traditional Japanese food remain challenging to find ‚Äî most vegan options are Western-inspired dishes like curry rice or vegan hamburg steak. Vegan Sushi Tokyo is open only for lunch: Although rave reviews keep pouring in from customers, the small business still doesn‚Äôt have a storefront of its own and rents out the interior of a bar by day. It serves 10-piece¬†nigiri¬†lunch sets, which include a plant-based Japanese-style ‚Äúegg,‚Äù ‚Äúshrimp‚Äù tempura and beads made out of seaweed that look nearly indistinguishable from salmon roe. Japan‚Äôs culinary culture¬†may be rich and diverse, but it remains reliant on animal products, especially when dashi, a savoury broth made of dried tuna flakes and kelp, is present in so many dishes. Maeda became a vegan six years ago, due to her growing concern over environmental and animal rights issues. It‚Äôs a familiar origin story for those who have come to defy the typical Japanese diet by giving up meat, fish and dairy. ‚ÄúIn terms of the vegan movement, I think we‚Äôre maybe behind other countries. The number of vegans is very small,‚Äù Maeda said. ‚ÄúBut there are more and more vegetarian and vegan restaurants in Tokyo, I think because of tourists ‚Äî especially from countries with many vegetarian people.‚Äù  Nigiri¬†served at Vegan Sushi Tokyo. Although rave reviews keep pouring in from customers, the small business still doesn‚Äôt have a storefront of its own, and rents out the interior of a bar by day. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist Outside large cities like Tokyo, Osaka and Kyoto, vegan options quickly vanish. In a culture that prizes convention and scrupulous attention to detail, individual accommodations ‚Äî like vegan menu substitutions ‚Äî are often frowned upon. And as in many other countries, vegan options are sometimes stigmatized as less nutritious. But recently, things have been changing. The anticipation of a tourism boom for the 2020 Olympics in Tokyo pushed the Japanese government to encourage new vegan businesses and menu options in major cities. And in the years since, restaurants like Maeda‚Äôs have sprung up, offering novel adaptations of traditional dishes. Under pressure from Japan‚Äôs pledge to nearly halve its carbon emissions by 2030, the government has also begun collaborating with vegan activists and advocates and awarding grants to alternative protein start-ups. Though challenges remain, it‚Äôs gotten easier and easier to go vegan in Japan over the last decade. ‚ÄúClimate issues and animal issues are growing,‚Äù Maeda said. ‚ÄúFor me, I can‚Äôt imagine going back to eating meat again.‚Äù Only for tourists?Convincing people to eat less meat is key to reaching international climate goals. Up to 20% of planet-warming greenhouse gases emitted annually come from animal agriculture alone ‚Äî all the cows, pigs, lambs, chickens and other animals (not including fish) that people raise for meat, milk, eggs and the like. According to one study from the University of Oxford that looked at the diets of over 55,000 people, vegans ‚Äî defined as those who eschew all animal products ‚Äî create 75% less climate pollution through their food choices than those who eat a meat-heavy diet. For most of the last two millennia, the Japanese diet was a model of climate-friendly eating due to Buddhist and Shinto objections to meat and dairy consumption ‚Äî although fish has long been a staple. Beginning in 675, meat-eating was banned by official imperial decree.  Kazue Maeda, co-founder of Vegan Sushi Tokyo, serves customers at the restaurant, where the recommended lunch set includes a tray of faux-fish sushi. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist The ban set the stage for the flourishing of¬†sh≈çjin ry≈çri, a traditional cuisine that arrived in the sixth century along with Buddhism and aligns with the religion‚Äôs prohibition against killing animals. In the 13th century, the cuisine developed into a spiritual movement focused on simplicity and balance between one‚Äôs mind and body. A typical sh≈çjin ry≈çri set meal is vegan, highlights seasonal produce and is designed around sets of five ‚Äî five colours, five flavours and five cooking methods. While it can still commonly be found in the dining halls of Buddhist temples, modern chefs have taken sh≈çjin ry≈çri into the mainstream, including in Michelin-starred restaurants, where they emphasize the concept‚Äôs focus on harmony with nature by using local ingredients and minimizing waste. It wasn‚Äôt until 1872 that Emperor Meiji lifted the meat-eating ban, seeking to usher in an era of westernization. Meat consumption grew quickly as domestic beef production boomed and animal products became a symbol of power and status. As reports spread that Emperor Meiji drank milk twice a day, dairy consumption became more popular, too. Today, Japan ranks 11th in beef consumption globally, and its per capita milk consumption is 68% higher than that of the average East Asian country. Japanese people buy eight times more meat than they did in the 1960s, and in 2007, families began eating it more than fish. But interest in plant-based foods appears to be growing. Japan‚Äôs market for plant-based foods tripled between 2015 and 2020, and the Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry, and Fisheries expects it to double again by 2030. These shifts have taken place as the Japanese population at large has expressed a readiness to shift toward plant-based products for health, animal welfare and climate-related reasons, according to a 2022 analysis in the Journal of Agricultural Management. Although no official government statistic exists, a 2021 survey found that 2.2% of Japanese people identify as vegan ‚Äî a potentially higher percentage than in the United States, where estimates range from 1% to 4%.  Vegan activist Azumi Yamanaka eats a vegan lunch at Brown Rice in Omotesando, Tokyo. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist Though vegan restaurants have been on the upswing since 2017, Japanese vegans still lack a wide variety of options. According to HappyCow, a popular directory of vegan and vegetarian restaurant options, Japan has fewer than six vegetarian restaurants per 1 million people in Japan, more than a fifth of them in Tokyo. By comparison, there are nine vegetarian restaurants per 1 million people in the U.S. ‚ÄúEven many chefs still don‚Äôt know what vegan is, they don‚Äôt know the concept,‚Äù said Azumi Yamanaka, a vegan activist in Tokyo, during a recent lunch at Brown Rice, a sleek vegan restaurant with an organic, health-focused menu in the capital‚Äôs Omotesando district. ‚ÄúThey don't realize that adding a small piece of bacon or fish is still meat. I still have to explain it,‚Äù she said, while picking at a slice of roasted lotus root with her chopsticks. When Yamanaka became vegan 16 years ago, most people in Japan hadn‚Äôt even heard of the term ‚Äúvegan,‚Äù she said. But in recent years, she said, being vegan has become a somewhat fashionable subculture ‚Äî judging from social media trends and an upswing in photogenic vegan cafes, which she said get more young people interested in becoming vegan, too. Even if trendiness is an effective way to draw people toward plant-based lifestyles, Yamanaka said Japanese who commit to veganism are motivated by a variety of issues, including sustainability and animal rights. The country imports between 40% and 60% of its meat but depends on domestic factory farming to produce much of its dairy supply. Its animal protection laws have been given low grades by international animal welfare organizations. Other factors include the country‚Äôs relatively high rate of lactose intolerance, which some estimate affects the majority of the population. Food allergies are also a factor for many of the country‚Äôs vegan converts. Between 2010 and 2019, the prevalence of allergies to eggs and milk, along with peanuts and wheat, nearly doubled among Japanese children. And eggs are the country's most common food allergy. Still, Yamanaka said city governments and companies don‚Äôt care about expanding vegan options until they want to market to tourists. ‚ÄúThey believe vegan products won‚Äôt sell, aren‚Äôt understood or have failed in the past,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúMany consider them only for foreign visitors.‚Äù  Mumokuteki, a natural lifestyle store with a cafe, serves up soy milk-based ramen on its all-vegan menu at its location on busy Teramachi shopping street in the city of Kyoto. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist Tourism is certainly a huge economic factor in Japan. In 2024,¬†37 million foreign tourists entered the country, outstripping the previous full-year record by almost 5 million. Over a quarter of these tourists hail from neighbouring parts of Asia with large vegan and vegetarian populations, like Taiwan, China and Singapore, due to the widespread practice of Buddhism. ‚ÄúBefore 2019, the vegan environment was not so good,‚Äù said Mayumi Muroya, chair of the Japan Vegan Society, the largest vegan and plant-based industry organization in Japan. ‚ÄúThe reality is that many of the foreigners visiting Japan are vegans and vegetarians. And with the Olympics coming up in 2020, the government knew the number of visitors was going to increase hugely.‚Äù In the run-up to the Games, which ultimately took place a year late because of the COVID-19 pandemic, the government created food guidelines to help restaurants offer more vegan options and distributed subsidies to help them pay for those options. In December 2023, Muroya‚Äôs organization became the first-ever permitted by the government‚Äôs Japanese Agricultural Standards to officially certify vegan products. Adoption requires in-person inspections, and fewer than 10 businesses have been certified. A different non-profit, VegeProject Japan, started unofficially certifying products as vegan in 2016, and its marker has become the most widely used vegan label in Japan ‚Äî showing up on instant curry pouches, protein bars and some cosmetics. Recently, in an effort to make dining easier for tourists, the Tokyo Metropolitan Government began offering subsidies to vegan businesses with foreign language menus available that want to be certified with one of these labels ‚Äî the Japan Vegan Society‚Äôs certification costs an estimated ¬•165,000 ($1,060). Inclusive eatingThe beloved and beleaguered tourism hub of Kyoto has also begun investing money into making the city‚Äôs vegan options more visible ‚Äî both to accommodate foreign visitors and due to the city‚Äôs pledge to meet the United Nations‚Äô Sustainable Development Goals. Japan has used SDGs as the basis for a public awareness campaign on climate change, conservation and sustainability. Despite its small size compared with Tokyo and neighbouring Osaka, Kyoto has long been considered an easier place to be vegan than the rest of the country. As both the former capital and a youthful university town, the city is awash with historic businesses maintaining the traditions of a preindustrial Japan and a distinctly crunchy-granola youth culture. Although the population is a sixth of the size of Tokyo‚Äôs, it has half as many vegan options. And recently, the local government partnered with Kyoto Vegan, an environmental organization that was founded in 2020 to expand and increase awareness of vegan options in the city. ‚ÄúAfter 2020, the city asked if they could collaborate with me,‚Äù said Chisayo Tamaki, who founded the group.  Kyoto Vegan founder Chisayo Tamaki says the city of Kyoto can't achieve its net zero carbon emissions goal without the support of vegans. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist Kyoto Vegan receives most of its funding from a subsidy from the country‚Äôs national tourism agency, but it is also supported by the city as one of its ‚ÄúDo You Kyoto 2050‚Äù projects. The initiative aims to cut carbon emissions down to zero by 2050. ‚ÄúThey can‚Äôt achieve that goal without the support of vegan lifestyles,‚Äù said Tamaki. In its plan to reduce its carbon footprint, Kyoto considers veganism to be the 11th most effective way to cut down its emissions, below expanding electric vehicle usage and above teleworking. The private sector is helping to advance those goals. For instance, Plant Based Lifestyle Lab ‚Äî an initiative backed by a group of companies ‚Äî began in 2021 to promote and research plant-based food technologies. For Tamaki, it‚Äôs a welcome change from just a few years ago when she was told vegans were ‚Äúdemanding‚Äù or ‚Äúpicky.‚Äù In many ways, people in Japan face the same barriers to veganism as anywhere else. There are the logistical limitations ‚Äî the lack of options on restaurant menus and at grocery stores. But there are also the psychological ones, like the stigma of being considered picky, exclusion from social activities and misinformation about health and nutrition. In 2021, Muroya ‚Äî the chair of the Japan Vegan Society ‚Äî tried introducing monthly vegan lunches at an elementary school near Tokyo, the first attempt of its kind in Japan. Despite working with the school‚Äôs nutritionist to design the menu, Muroya‚Äôs effort ran into barriers like the national school-lunch calcium requirements, which promote milk, and pushback from parents worried their children wouldn‚Äôt get adequate nourishment. (Research shows that well-balanced vegan diets are healthy for most people, as long as they take supplements to provide some vitamins and minerals.) Muroya‚Äôs program lasted for only a year, but she said the school still regularly does ‚Äúmeat-free Mondays.‚Äù  Two friends catch up over lunch at Choice Kyoto, a long-standing vegan cafe serving Western-style dishes in Gion, the city‚Äôs ancient entertainment district. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist Perhaps one of the biggest challenges to being vegan in Japan is the country‚Äôs culture of conformity ‚Äî which considers standing out to be troublesome. ‚ÄúHaving a different opinion from everybody else is very controversial. Everybody wants to move together as a community,‚Äù Yamanaka said. ‚ÄúSome people fear coming out as vegan at school or work due to potential bullying.‚Äù Although she said she hasn‚Äôt faced much adversity in recent years, former co-workers pressured her to eat meat. For Yamanaka, the best way to make a more sustainable, less meat-intensive Japan is to bridge the gap between vegans and nonvegans. She said that when people discuss various issues that can motivate veganism ‚Äî like sustainability, factory farming and allergies ‚Äî as well as the popularity of veganism among tourists, more local governments and businesses can be convinced to make more options available. Local plant-based businesses are already making an effort to appeal to as many customers as possible. At Universal Bakes, a cult-favourite plant-based bakery in Tokyo‚Äôs trendy Shimokitazawa neighbourhood known for its vegan croissants and savoury tarts, the ethos is to provide allergen-free food, not necessarily animal-free. ‚ÄúI want people to understand that vegan food isn‚Äôt just for a select few. It‚Äôs an inclusive eating style,‚Äù Yamanaka said. ‚ÄúReaching beyond the vegan community is essential for creating a vegan-friendly world.‚Äù  The first guests of the day line up outside the door of Vegan Sushi Tokyo in the Shibuya district. |¬†Sachi Kitajima Mulkey / Grist  Correction: This story originally mischaracterized the relationship between the city of Kyoto and the Plant Based Lifestyle Lab.https://www.japantimes.co.jp/environment/2025/01/29/sustainability/veganism-rise-japan-climate/

author: Zainab Shafiq
title: Ranji Trophy 2025: Virat Kohli orders chilli paneer for lunch on tournament return
text:
It was quite a nostalgic feel to New Delhi as one of India‚Äôs favorite cricketers, Virat Kohli stepped onto the cricket field for his hometown Delhi for the first time in 12 years in a Ranji Trophy match. He walked out before his fans‚Äô roars resonated through at the Arun Jaitley Stadium, much like the deep connection he now felt with cricket, a factor even reflected by the kind of meals he‚Äôd ordered. 



Former Indian captain Kohli, who has always been very particular about his fitness regime and diet, on Day 1 of the clash against Railways opted for a simple and homely meal during the lunch break. He, unlike chhole poori, a classic Delhi delight, avoided the dish altogether and shared a meal of kadhi chawal with teammates and support staff. His most specific request, however, was a plate of chilli paneer‚Äîa vegetarian alternative to the chilli chicken that he enjoyed until embracing veganism in 2018. 



Kohli‚Äôs food preference is more than just a dietary shift; it symbolizes his tenacious commitment to fitness, a transformation he undertook to sustain his high-performance standards in international and domestic cricket. The change, however, has not altered his affinity for the flavors he grew up with. 



Who cooked chilli paneer for Virat Kohli during Ranji Trophy?









Sanjay Jha, a veteran chef who had fed Delhi cricketers for decades, once explained how Kohli remains humble despite being a superstar. ‚ÄúVirat has been eating from our canteen since childhood. Even now, he prefers food from here rather than ordering from outside. He talks to us just like he used to before becoming a global icon,‚Äù Jha said. 



Kohli‚Äôs disciplined diet has been well-documented over the years. In a previous social media post, he listed his daily intake, consisting of vegetables, quinoa, spinach, eggs, and his all-time favorite dosas‚Äîthough always in controlled quantity. 



The moment transcended just another cricketing fixture when Kohli stepped out into the field for Delhi. It was a return to his roots, a reminder of his journey, and an affirmation that despite all the fame globally, he is still rooted at the deepest levels in his beginning-be it on the pitch or at the dining table. 



Also, see: Rohit Sharma opens up on India‚Äôs squad for Champions Trophy 2025 
The post Ranji Trophy 2025: Virat Kohli orders chilli paneer for lunch on tournament return appeared first on Newsblare.

author: Courtney Davison
title: Easy, Flavorful Vegan Vibes: Inside Jenn√© Claiborne‚Äôs New Cookbook
text:
Jenn√© Claiborne was 8 years old when she cooked her first meal (Szechuan chicken), and she‚Äôs rarely put down the spatula since. Her plant-based journey began in 2011, when the Atlanta native embraced veganism and started sharing vibrant, inventive recipes on her Sweet Potato Soul YouTube channel. While living in New York City, she became a sought-after personal chef for vegan and whole-food, plant-based clients while continuing to grow her online community. In 2018, she released her debut cookbook, Sweet Potato Soul. 



Now, as a mom balancing a busy life, she knows firsthand how challenging it can be to get healthy meals on the table every day. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt spend a lot of time in the kitchen if I‚Äôm not working, because I‚Äôm busy, just like everybody else,‚Äù Claiborne says. ‚ÄúIf I‚Äôm cooking just for my daughter and me, it‚Äôs going to be something quick and easy.‚Äù That ethos inspired her latest book, Sweet Potato Soul Vegan Vibes, which hits shelves February 4. 







The gorgeous collection of 100 recipes is all about creating big flavors with minimal effort, showcasing Claiborne‚Äôs imagination and resourcefulness as a chef. 



We caught up with Claiborne about the new book, her ingenious oil-free granola recipe, farmers-market obsession, and more. Read on for the full conversation! 



You went vegan for the animals, but I understand you experienced some health benefits, as well.



Jenn√© Claiborne: When I first became vegan, I thought I couldn‚Äôt be any healthier. I was only 24 years old. I did have a lot of gut issues, but I‚Äôd been to different doctors, and they never told me to stop eating dairy. I thought, OK, well, I have a bad stomach, but otherwise, I‚Äôm healthy, so if I‚Äôm going vegan, it‚Äôs just for the animals. I became vegan, and within a week, maybe two, I stopped experiencing all of my gastrointestinal issues, 100%. None of it has ever come back. 



You‚Äôve mentioned that the contemporary South was a big influence as you were writing this cookbook. How so?



JC: I left Atlanta for college in ‚Äô06 and I didn‚Äôt move back until 2021. I had been living in Los Angeles for four years, looking for inspiration for my second cookbook, but I wasn‚Äôt finding it. When I came back home to Atlanta, I was reminded of how diverse this place is, too, and it‚Äôs much more laidback, and the people are very friendly. ‚Ä¶ I go to the grocery store and I see produce from all around the world, and I drive down the street and there are 10 different restaurants from 10 different parts of the planet. That was super inspiring to me. 



You weren‚Äôt feeling LA?



JC: LA was not my place. It‚Äôs so far away from home. ‚Ä¶ What I do miss about LA, though, are the farmers markets. That was my No. 1 favorite thing about living there. I very rarely bought produce at the grocery store in those four years. ‚Ä¶ I live walking distance to, in my opinion, the best farmers market in Atlanta, and I‚Äôm lucky and I‚Äôm grateful for it, but there isn‚Äôt as much demand, so the variety [of produce] is not as robust. 



I‚Äôm a farmers market stan. I love them so much. ‚Ä¶ They [illustrate] the bounty and the abundance of eating plants, of what‚Äôs possible when you eat plants. My first time ever going to a farmers market was when I moved to Boston for college, and that‚Äôs kind of how I started eating plant-based, and eating healthier, and expanding my palate, because I was the pickiest kid. I hardly ate any vegetables. I didn‚Äôt like 90% of the fruits I had been exposed to. But when I started going to farmers markets, I was picking up produce like, ‚ÄúOoh, what‚Äôs this? I‚Äôve never seen this!‚Äù That totally changed my life. 



The new book includes your much-loved tahini-granola recipe, which is oil-free. What was the inspiration for that recipe?



JC: Tahini is one of my top-three favorite ingredients (Broccolini and sweet potatoes being the other two) because it is so versatile and it tastes amazing. I remember I lived in New York at the time when I first made that recipe. It was kind of a spinoff of my tahini cookie recipe, which is in my first cookbook, and it‚Äôs also on the blog. I‚Äôd been making that recipe for a long time, and I realized that you don‚Äôt have to form it into cookies. You can just sprinkle it on the tray and [bake it as] granola, because it crisps up so well, especially along the edges. 







The granola recipe calls for dried rose petals. What else can folks use those for?



JC: I love the essence of rose just in anything. I‚Äôve got some tea blends with mint and rose. You can put it in your water. You could use rose powder‚Äîwhich is just ground up dried rose petals‚Äîto color an icing. I recently [did that] because I don‚Äôt use artificial dyes in our food, and my daughter and nieces and I were making cupcakes. It made such a pretty pink, and that rose flavor, to me, is one of the best flavors. It‚Äôs floral, and it‚Äôs elevated. It‚Äôs heavenly. 



What recipes would you recommend from the new book for a romantic Valentine‚Äôs Day meal?



JC: One of my favorite recipes in the cookbook is the Perfect Pea Pesto Pasta. It is so easy to make, but it looks fancy. ‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs made with basil, mint, and frozen peas that you thaw and blend into a pesto. You can toss it with any pasta you‚Äôd like. I always do a nice short pasta like gemelli. And the Za‚Äôatar Cauliflower Steaks would be perfect for Valentine‚Äôs Day. They would be really nice served with that pea pesto pasta, because the za‚Äôatar has all these herbs in it, like parsley, and that pea pesto pasta has basil and mint, so those would really complement each other. Or you could serve the pasta with the Simple Oyster Mushroom Steaks. That recipe is also so easy. If you are doing a Valentine‚Äôs Day dinner after work, and you need to put something together in under 30 minutes, then that would work perfectly. You wouldn‚Äôt have to make anything in advance, and it would be beautiful. 







Would those dishes you just mentioned be adaptable for oil-free eaters?



JC: Absolutely. The pesto pasta does have olive oil in it, but it‚Äôs not required. You could remove that, and if you need to thin [the sauce] out, add a little of the pasta [cooking] water. The cauliflower steaks have tahini, so the tahini keeps them really nice and moist, without having to douse them in oil. There is some oil in that recipe, but you can totally take it out. And mushrooms don‚Äôt require any oil to cook at all. Sometimes I‚Äôll saut√© garlic in a little bit of oil before adding mushrooms to the pan, but the mushrooms themselves don‚Äôt need any oil because they‚Äôre full of liquid on their own. They‚Äôre super hard to burn. Mushrooms are amazing if you‚Äôre doing whole-food, plant-based and avoiding oil. 



Could you explain the 80‚Äì20 approach that you advocate for healthy eating?



JC: Eighty percent of the time, you want to focus on eating wholesome, minimally processed foods. No more than 20% of the time, you can let your hair down, go out to eat, or eat more highly processed foods. What I mean by highly processed is stuff you could never make at home. Tofu is a processed food, but it‚Äôs minimally processed. Same with tempeh‚Äîsuper easy to make at home. ‚Ä¶ When you get to Beyond Meat, and Impossible, and all of these replicas of meat and dairy, those are in the ultraprocessed category. We‚Äôre going to reserve that for 10‚Äì20% of the time, if not even less. The reason I advocate this is I think it‚Äôs helpful for people to transition into eating healthier, understanding that your diet doesn‚Äôt have to be perfect right away [or ever]. But I do want to encourage people to keep doing better and better, because you‚Äôll feel better. 



I also like to mention that if you have a health condition and your doctor has told you you need to avoid all oil, all [refined] sugar, or sodium, then, of course, follow the doctor‚Äôs advice. 



And you can easily fall into the trap of going to Costco, and there‚Äôs all this easy-peasy, ultraprocessed vegan food. You can tell yourself you‚Äôre just stocking the freezer for when you don‚Äôt feel like cooking and you‚Äôre only going to have it once a week, but then the next thing you know, you‚Äôre eating it every day because you have a container of 20. If you learn how to make easy, wholesome food that takes no more than 20 minutes, you don‚Äôt have to rely on those highly processed foods as much. 



Do you do a lot of meal prepping?



JC: Sometimes I will get the zoomies, and I‚Äôm like, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to meal prep!‚Äù But I don‚Äôt actually reliably do that on a regular basis. That is once in a blue moon. ‚Ä¶ But my kitchen is always well-stocked. For example ‚Ä¶ I always have [cooked] brown rice in the fridge. I have a lot of frozen veggies, so I might steam some frozen spinach and peas together, and then put that all in a bowl and top it with tahini sauce straight out of the jar. If I‚Äôm going to be fancy, I‚Äôll make a tahini dressing with lemon and miso. ‚Ä¶That is how I eat most of the time. Honestly, it‚Äôs delicious. 



Have you and your daughter, Jorji, made anything together recently?



JC: She has her own cutting board, knives, all the stuff she would need, but lately, she doesn‚Äôt even want to slice her own apples. Her favorite thing to do in the kitchen is just mix stuff, which is my favorite thing, too. My nana always let me do that. ‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt throw away outdated spices anymore. I save them for her, and she mixes stuff. 



Is there anything else you‚Äôd like to share with our readers?



JC: I‚Äôm glad you asked me about the adaptations for oil-free, because almost all the recipes in the cookbook, you‚Äôre able to just [omit oil], with the exception, I would say, of some of the baked goods. For those baked goods, you could replace [the oil]. For example, I‚Äôve got these chocolate sweet potato muffins‚Äîmaybe just use a little bit more sweet potato in that recipe instead of the oil. 



This cookbook definitely fits in that 80‚Äì20 philosophy of mine, where 80% to 90% of these recipes are more wholesome, not a lot of sugar, but [some are more decadent]. ‚Ä¶ There is a balance of recipes in this cookbook, because I really wanted it to be for everybody. 



Editor‚Äôs note: This interview has been edited for length and clarity.  



Photos copyright ¬© 2025 by Jenn√© Claiborne and used by permission of Rodale Books, an imprint of Random House, a division of Penguin Random House LLC, New York. All rights reserved.  
The post Easy, Flavorful Vegan Vibes: Inside Jenn√© Claiborne‚Äôs New Cookbook appeared first on Forks Over Knives.

author: Walking Disaster
title: Dry January is the Inverse Fight Club
text: As the month draws to a close, it is time to talk about a phenomenon that has popped up in recent years. Dry January is discussed and humble-bragged about nearly as much as veganism, CrossFit, or (god-forbid) soul cycle. But unlike its competition, Dry January gets all the mentions crammed into one month instead of throughout the year. If you have to challenge yourself not to drink, you either have deeper problems to address, or you‚Äôre 25. I‚Äôm a total hypocrite, as per usual, because I have done the whole Dry January thing before, but that is largely because I fell into the unspoken third category ‚Äì I was poor. It‚Äôs a super easy way to recoup some savings spent during the holidays.¬† Don‚Äôt get me wrong; there is something to be said about starting the year on a healthy note. I‚Äôm a big proponent of New Year‚Äôs resolutions, 90% of which are health-related and short-lived anyway. I‚Äôm also a big proponent of front-loading the year with your work and responsibilities, whether it‚Äôs in terms of fitness, sales, or whatever. I like to get the hard part out of the way early so I can relax later on in the year. That doesn‚Äôt mean it needs to be the topic of every conversation though!¬† I understand that any challenge attempted in January is extra hard because January is the longest and darkest month of the year. I don‚Äôt know how it just is. However, refraining from drinking shouldn‚Äôt be the Everest you‚Äôre making it out to be. You know what‚Äôs challenging? Refraining from dairy. Whether you‚Äôre lactose intolerant or not, it‚Äôs hard. Doing a thirty-day plank challenge is hard. Giving up caffeine is nearly superhuman, sociopathic, or both. My true Dry January would probably be detoxing from Bravo, which I might have to do anyway, but I‚Äôm weak.¬† Not for nothing, but Dry January isn‚Äôt a punishment for yourself either. Like other resolutions, it‚Äôs supposed to be either a goal to work towards or an attempt to change your habits. If you ‚Äútake a month off,‚Äù only to go full balls to the wall as soon as February hits, then there‚Äôs not really a point. You‚Äôre officially the adult equivalent to the sheltered kids who never went out in high school, so they spend their first college semester in one prolonged blackout. That Freshman Fifteen doesn‚Äôt refer to weight gain, but the number of days that a homeschooled kid actually remembers from their freshman year. You‚Äôre also not taking a month off if you substitute booze for weed or edibles. Dry or sober January means exactly that. Since you‚Äôre going to make me listen to this self-adulation at least stick to the premise and do the damn thing.¬† If you‚Äôre truly on your self-betterment journey, which you said a million times that you are, then maybe choose something to do for thirty days, or select something new to try for thirty days. Before you know it, you‚Äôll be entering your thirties and you‚Äôll be able to go two, maybe even three(!!), months without drinking and you won‚Äôt even notice. More importantly, you won‚Äôt even talk about it‚Ä¶which is all that matters.¬† This is my project 2025
