author: Tori Wynsell
title: Veganism: No Animals, No Problem
text:
It‚Äôs been since mankind first walked the Earth hundreds of thousands of years ago that we have sought food from animals. From meat to eggs to dairy to fish, animals have been a source of food for all civilizations throughout the ages. However, do you know the true cost of that steak on your plate? It‚Äôs much higher than you think, and not just in the financial sense. These are the true costs ¬†of our animal-based diet: 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Meat production requires a significant amount of water, around 1,800 gallons of water needed to produce 1 pound of beef (Water Footprint Calculator). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Livestock farming occupies 77% of global agricultural land but provides only 18% of the world‚Äôs calories. This leads to deforestation, habitat destruction, and soil degradation (WSP). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Livestock account for a varied estimate of 11.1% ‚Äì 19.6% of global greenhouse gas emissions (The Breakthrough Institute). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 99% of nearly 10 billion animals are raised on factory farms, which harms animal welfare, the environment, and public health (Farm Sanctuary). 



These statistics paint a grim picture: our animal-based agriculture for our ever-expanding population is having a devastating effect on the world. It‚Äôs clear that we need to make a change and the best way to start is at the source, our diet. 



It‚Äôs a simple equation: fewer animals and animal-derived products people eat equals fewer resources spent on resources on animal raising, bigger reductions in global emissions, and many more animals saved from inhumane treatment. The best way to reach this sum is to learn to cut more animals and animal-derived products from our diet and practice the way of veganism. 



‚ÄúIt requires 20 times more land to produce a gram of protein from cows or sheep than it does to produce it from pulses such as chickpeas or soybeans.‚Äù ‚Äì Henry Mance 



What Is Veganism?



Veganism is a way of living that seeks to exclude, as far as possible and practical, all forms of exploitation of and cruelty to animals for food, clothing, and any other purpose. This means that a vegan diet avoids all animal products, including meat, dairy, eggs, and honey, and often extends to not using products like leather and certain cosmetics that involve animal testing or animal-derived ingredients. 



Difference Between a Vegan Lifestyle and Adopting Some Vegan Practices



Vegan Lifestyle



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Diet: Completely plant-based, no animal products. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Clothing: Avoids leather, wool, silk, and other animal-derived materials. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Cosmetics and Household Products: Chooses cruelty-free and vegan products. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Entertainment and Services: Avoids activities and industries that exploit animals, such as circuses and zoos. 



Adopting Some Vegan Practices



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Diet: Might include some plant-based meals but still consume animal products occasionally. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Clothing: Might opt for synthetic or plant-based materials sometimes but still use leather or wool. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Products: May choose cruelty-free cosmetics occasionally but not exclusively. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† General Approach: Focuses on reducing animal product consumption or usage rather than complete elimination. 



For example, someone adopting some vegan practices might enjoy Meatless Mondays, opt for cruelty-free makeup when possible, and choose faux leather jackets over real leather. 



Whether a person chooses to go fully into a vegan lifestyle or simply reduce their animal consumption, any of these changes can make a positive impact on not only the world but also their health. 



Health Benefits



Adopting a vegan lifestyle can offer numerous health benefits, provided the diet is well-balanced and includes a variety of nutrient-dense foods. 



Heart Health



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Lower cholesterol levels 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reduced risk of heart disease and hypertension 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Lower blood pressure 



Weight Management



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Easier weight control or weight loss 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Lower body mass index (BMI) 



Digestive Health



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Improved digestion due to high-fiber intake 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reduced risk of constipation and other digestive issues 



Blood Sugar Control



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Improved blood sugar levels and insulin sensitivity 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reduced risk of type 2 diabetes 



Cancer Risk Reduction



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Lower risk of certain cancers, such as colorectal and breast cancer 



Nutrient Intake



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Higher intake of essential nutrients like vitamins C and E, magnesium, folic acid, and phytochemicals 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† More antioxidants, which can help protect against cell damage 



Inflammation Reduction



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Potentially lower levels of inflammation in the body 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Relief from certain chronic conditions like arthritis 



Longevity



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Potential for a longer lifespan due to overall health benefits 



Kidney Functions



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Improved kidney function and reduced risk of chronic kidney disease 



Better Mood and Energy Levels



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Potential improvement in mood and energy due to better overall health and nutrient intake 



It‚Äôs important to note that while a vegan lifestyle can offer these benefits, it‚Äôs essential to plan meals carefully to ensure you‚Äôre getting all the necessary nutrients. Consulting with a healthcare professional or a registered dietitian can help create a well-balanced vegan diet that meets your nutritional needs. 



Even adopting a few vegan choices to your diet can have a positive impact on your health, and enough of them can make a big difference for the planet. 



Environmental Impact



Reducing animal consumption can significantly impact the environment positively, reducing the damage done to it so it can survive and thrive. 



Greenhouse Gas Emissions



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reduced Emissions: Animal agriculture is a major contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, particularly methane from livestock and nitrous oxide from manure. By consuming fewer animal products, we can reduce these emissions. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Climate Change Mitigation: Lowering greenhouse gas emissions helps combat climate change, potentially stabilizing global temperatures. 



Land Use



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Deforestation: Large tracts of forests are cleared to create grazing land and grow feed crops for livestock. Reducing animal product consumption can decrease the demand for these lands, thereby reducing deforestation. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Habitat Preservation: Preserving forests and other natural habitats protects biodiversity and helps maintain ecosystems. 



Water Use



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Water Footprint: Animal agriculture requires significant amounts of water, from growing feed crops to hydrating animals. Consuming fewer animal products can reduce the overall water footprint. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Water Pollution: Animal farming operations can pollute waterways with runoff containing manure, antibiotics, and hormones. Reducing animal consumption helps minimize this pollution. 



Energy Use



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Energy Efficiency: Plant-based diets generally require less energy to produce than animal products. Reducing animal consumption can lead to lower overall energy use in food production. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Fossil Fuels: The production and transportation of animal products often rely heavily on fossil fuels, contributing to greenhouse gas emissions. Plant-based diets can reduce this dependence. 



Soil Health



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Soil Degradation: Intensive animal farming practices can lead to soil degradation through overgrazing and the overuse of chemical fertilizers for feed crops. Reducing animal consumption can help mitigate these effects. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Soil Carbon Sequestration: Healthier soil can sequester (remove) carbon, helping to mitigate climate change. 



Biodiversity



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Species Loss: Deforestation and habitat destruction of animal agriculture can lead to the loss of species and biodiversity. Reducing demand for animal products helps preserve habitats and protect wildlife. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Conservation: By protecting natural habitats and reducing the expansion of farmland, we can support conservation efforts for endangered species. 



Waste Management



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Animal Waste: Livestock produce large amounts of waste, which can create significant environmental hazards. Reducing animal consumption decreases the production of this waste. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Resource Efficiency: Plant-based diets can make more efficient use of resources, reducing overall waste. 



Reducing animal consumption, even partially, can contribute to a healthier planet by lowering greenhouse gas emissions, preserving forests, conserving water, reducing energy use, maintaining soil health, protecting biodiversity, and managing waste more efficiently. But going vegan is not just a matter of one‚Äôs personal health and the environment, it is also a matter of ethics. 



Ethical Considerations



Choosing a vegan lifestyle can be driven by numerous ethical reasons, including animal welfare and factory farms. 



Animal Welfare



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reducing Suffering: Avoiding animal products helps to prevent the suffering and exploitation of animals in industries such as farming, fashion, and entertainment. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Opposition to Factory Farming: Factory farms often subject animals to overcrowded, unsanitary, and inhumane conditions. Veganism stands against these practices. 



Environmental Responsibility



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Sustainability: Veganism supports more sustainable farming practices by reducing the demand for resource-intensive animal agriculture, which often leads to deforestation, habitat loss, and pollution. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Climate Change: By reducing greenhouse gas emissions associated with animal farming, veganism helps combat climate change and promote environmental health. 



Health and Well-Being



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Promoting Health: By choosing plant-based diets, individuals can improve their health and reduce the strain on healthcare systems. This is an ethical consideration for the collective well-being of society. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Food Security: Vegan diets can be more efficient in terms of resource use, potentially leading to improved food security and less competition for resources. 



Social Justice



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Equitable Resource Distribution: Animal agriculture often requires vast amounts of water, land, and crops that could be used more efficiently to feed a larger human population. A vegan lifestyle can contribute to more equitable resource distribution. 



Philosophical and Moral Beliefs



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Respect for Life: Some individuals choose veganism based on the belief that all sentient beings have a right to live and not be exploited or harmed for human benefit. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Ethical Consistency: Veganism aligns with values of compassion, kindness, and justice, providing consistency with moral and ethical beliefs. 



Cultural and Religious Reasons



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Spiritual Beliefs: Some cultures and religions advocate for non-violence and compassion towards all living beings, leading followers to adopt a vegan lifestyle. For example, many followers of Jainism practice a vegan lifestyle as part of their principle of non-violence (Ahimsa) towards all living beings. 



By choosing a vegan lifestyle, individuals can align their actions with their ethical beliefs, making a positive impact on animals, the environment, and society as a whole. 



Tips for Transitioning To Vegan



Adopting vegan practices, even partially, can be a rewarding and impactful journey, but it can be an adjustment period. So it‚Äôs a good idea to look up tips that can make it easier. Here are some practical tips to help you get started: 



Start Small



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Meatless Mondays: Begin by having one or two plant-based days per week. This is a manageable way to ease into veganism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Swap Ingredients: Replace dairy milk with plant-based milk (like almond, soy, or oat milk) and try meat alternatives like tofu, tempeh, or seitan. 



Explore New Recipes



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Experiment: Try new recipes and cuisines that are naturally plant-based, like Mediterranean, Indian, or Thai dishes. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Cookbooks and Blogs: Use vegan cookbooks and good blogs to find inspiration and delicious recipes. 



Educate Yourself



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Nutritional Knowledge: Learn about essential nutrients and how to get them from plant-based sources, such as protein from legumes and nuts, and iron from leafy greens. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Documentaries and Books: Watch documentaries and read books on veganism to understand the benefits and ethics behind the lifestyle. 



Plan Your Meals



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Weekly Planning: Plan your meals ahead of time to ensure you have all the ingredients you need and to make balanced, nutritious choices. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Batch Cooking: Cook in larger quantities and store leftovers for easy, plant-based meals throughout the week. 



Grocery Shopping



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Shop the Perimeter: Focus on the fresh produce section, grains, and legumes. Avoid heavily processed foods. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Read Labels: Check labels for animal-derived ingredients and seek out vegan-certified products. 



Find Alternatives



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Favorite Dishes: Veganize your favorite dishes but substituting animal products with plant-based alternatives. For example, use jackfruit as a substitute for pulled pork. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Snacks and Treats: Keep a stock of vegan snacks and treats to satisfy cravings without resorting to non-vegan options. 



Community Support



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Join Groups: Connect with local or online vegan communities for support, advice, and inspiration. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Dining Out: Research vegan-friendly restaurants or menu options at your favorite spots. 



Be Patient and Flexible



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Gradual Changes: Understand that it‚Äôs okay to transition slowly. Every small step counts. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Self-Compassion: Don‚Äôt be too hard on yourself if you slip up. The goal is progress, not perfection. 



Learn About Substitutes



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Cooking Substitutes: Discover substitutes for common non-vegan ingredients like eggs (use flaxseeds or chia seeds) and butter (use coconut oil or vegan margarine). 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Diverse Diet: Ensure you‚Äôre getting a diverse diet by incorporating a variety of fruits, vegetables, grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds. 



Advocate and Educate



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Spread Awareness: Share your journey and knowledge with others to inspire and encourage them. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Lead by Example: Show that adopting vegan practices can be enjoyable and beneficial through your actions. 



Changing your diet isn‚Äôt easy but it is well worth it. There are some misconceptions surrounding veganism that can discourage others but by simply addressing them, you‚Äôll find that they are anything but fact. 



Addressing the Misconceptions



There are multiple concerns and misconceptions about veganism like protein intake, taste, and expense, but with a little information gathering, anyone can see that it‚Äôs all false. Let‚Äôs clear each of these up. 



Protein Intake



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Misconception: Vegans don‚Äôt get enough protein. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reality: There are plenty of plant-based protein sources that can provide all the essential amino acids. These include beans, lentils, chickpeas, tofu, tempeh, seitan, quinoa, nuts, seeds, and even vegetables like spinach and broccoli. With a varied diet, vegans can easily meet their protein needs. 



Nutrient Deficiencies



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Misconception: Vegans are more prone to nutrient deficiencies. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reality: With proper planning, a vegan diet can provide all essential nutrients. Here are some key nutrients to consider: 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vitamin B12: Found in fortified foods (like plant-based milks and cereals) or taken as a supplement. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Iron: Plant sources include lentils, chickpeas, beans, tofu, quinoa, and fortified cereals. Pairing these with vitamin C-rich foods (like citrus foods) can enhance absorption. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Calcium: Available in fortified plant milk, leafy greens (like kale and bok choy), almonds, and tahini. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Omega-3 Fatty Acids: Found in flaxseeds, chia seeds, hemp seeds, walnuts, and algae-based supplements. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vitamin D: Sourced from fortified foods or supplements, especially in regions with limited sunlight. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Protein: As mentioned earlier, numerous plant-based sources can meet protein needs. 



Social Challenges



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Misconception: It‚Äôs difficult to maintain a vegan diet in social settings. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reality: While social situations can pose challenges, there are ways to navigate them: 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Dining Out: Research vegan-friendly restaurants or menu options before heading out. Many eateries are now offering vegan dishes. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Social Events: Communicate your dietary preferences to hosts in advance. Bring a delicious vegan dish to share, showcasing how tasty vegan food can be. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Travel: Plan ahead by researching local vegan-friendly spots and packing some plant-based snacks. 



‚Äì¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Family and Friends: Be patient and open in discussing your choices. Sharing the benefits and deliciousness of vegan meals can foster understanding and acceptance. 



Taste and Variety



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Misconception: Vegan food is bland and limited. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reality: Vegan cuisine is incredibly diverse and flavorful, involving a wide range of global spices. Spices, herbs, and creative cooking techniques can make plant-based meals exciting and satisfying. For example, dishes like vegan curry, stir-fry, and pasta can be bursting with flavor. 



Expense



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Misconception: A vegan diet is more expensive. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reality: Vegan staples like beans, lentils, rice, pasta, and seasonal vegetables are often quite affordable. While some specialty vegan products can be pricey, a balanced vegan diet can be budget-friendly with proper planning. 



Health



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Misconception: A vegan diet is not healthy. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Reality: A well-balanced vegan diet can offer numerous health benefits, such as lower cholesterol levels, reduced risk of chronic diseases, improved digestion, and better weight management. It‚Äôs essential to focus on whole, nutrient-dense foods for optimal health. 



By not being deluded by these misconceptions and planning carefully, adopting vegan practices or transitioning to a vegan lifestyle can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience. It‚Äôs also important to know that even if you don‚Äôt go fully vegan, it‚Äôs nothing to feel bad about, and you should learn so. 



No Guilt, Just Progress



Many people can feel overwhelmed or guilty for not going fully vegan, and it‚Äôs important to remind yourself that every positive change counts. 



Acknowledge Small Wins



Each plant-based meal you choose reduces your environmental footprint and promotes animal welfare. Celebrate these small victories without pressuring yourself to be perfect. 



Avoid All-or-Nothing Thinking



There‚Äôs no one-size-fits-all approach to adopting vegan practices. It‚Äôs okay to take gradual steps and find what works best for you and your lifestyle. 



Focus on Positive Impacts



Instead of feeling guilty about not being 100% vegan, concentrate on the positive impacts of your choices. Remember, collective small actions can lead to significant change. 



Be Kind to Yourself



Dietary changes can be challenging, and it‚Äôs important to be kind to yourself during this journey. Guilt and self-criticism can be counterproductive. Instead, encourage yourself to keep moving forward. 



Support and Community



Seek out supportive communities or groups where you can share your experiences, challenges, and successes. Surrounding yourself with like-minded individuals can provide motivation and reduce feelings of isolation or guilt. 



Transitioning to a vegan lifestyle, or incorporating more vegan practices, is a personal journey. It‚Äôs important to recognize and celebrate the progress you‚Äôve made rather than focus on what you haven‚Äôt yet achieved. Remember, every little bit helps ‚Äì whether it‚Äôs one vegan meal a week or fully embracing a vegan diet. Speaking of meals, there are a few that are easy to make and tasty to eat. 



Easy Vegan Recipes



If you‚Äôre worried about going vegan being complicated, rest assured it‚Äôs a lot simpler than you think. Here are some simple, common, and delicious vegan recipes you can try at home. 



Vegan Chickpea Salad Sandwich



Ingredients 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 can chickpeas, drained and rinsed 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 2 tablespoons vegan mayo 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 celery stalk, finely chopped 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 small red onion, finely chopped 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 tablespoon lemon juice 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Salt and pepper to taste 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Bread and lettuce leaves for serving 



Instructions 



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† In a bowl, mash the chickpeas with a fork until mostly broken down, leaving some chunks for texture. 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† Add the vegan mayo, Dijon mustard, celery, red onion, lemon juice, salt, and pepper. Mix well. 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† Serve the chickpea salad on bread as a sandwich or on lettuce leaves as a wrap. 



Vegan Lentil Bolognese



Ingredients 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 cup dry lentils, rinsed 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 tablespoon olive oil 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 onion, finely chopped 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 2 cloves garlic, minced 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 carrot, finely chopped 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 can crushed tomatoes 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 2 tablespoons tomato paste 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 teaspoon dried oregano 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 teaspoon dried basil 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Salt and pepper to taste 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Cooked pasta of your choice 



Instructions 



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† Cook the lentils according to the package instructions and set aside. 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† In a large pan, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the onion and garlic, and saut√© until softened. 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† Add the carrot and celery, and cook for a few more minutes. 



4.¬†¬†¬†¬† Stir in the crushed tomatoes, tomato paste, oregano, basil, salt, and pepper. Simmer for about 10 minutes. 



5.¬†¬†¬†¬† Add the cooked lentils to the sauce and mix well. Simmer for another 5 minutes. 



6.¬†¬†¬†¬† Serve the lentil bolognese over cooked pasta. 



Vegan Chocolate Avocado Mousse



Ingredients 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 2 ripe avocados, pitted and peeled 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬º cup unsweetened cocoa powder 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬º cup maple syrup 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬º cup almond milk (or any plant-based milk) 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 teaspoon vanilla extract 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Pinch of salt 



Instructions 



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† In a good processor, blend the avocados until smooth. 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† Add the cocoa powder, maple syrup, almond milk, vanilla extract, and salt. Blend until creamy and well combined. 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† Chill the mousse in the refrigerator for at least 30 minutes before serving. 



Vegan Buddha Bowl



Ingredients 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 cup cooked quinoa 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 cup roasted vegetables (such as sweet potatoes, broccoli, and bell peppers) 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬Ω cup chickpeas, drained and rinsed 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬Ω avocado, sliced 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Handful of mixed greens 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 2 tablespoons tahini 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 tablespoon lemon juice 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 tablespoon water 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Salt and pepper to taste 



Instructions 



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† Arrange the cooked quinoa, roasted vegetables, chickpeas, avocado, and mixed greens in a bowl. 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† In a small bowl, whisk together the tahini, lemon juice, water, salt, and pepper to make the dressing. 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† Drizzle the dressing over the Buddha bowl. 



Vegan Coconut Milk Ice Cream



Ingredients 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 2 cans full-fat coconut milk 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† ¬Ω cup maple syrup or agave nectar 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Pinch of salt 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† (Optional) ¬Ω cup dark chocolate chips (dairy-free) 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† (Optional) ¬Ω cup chopped nuts 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† (Optional) ¬Ω cup fresh or frozen berries 



Instructions 



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† Place the cans of coconut in the refrigerator overnight. This will help the coconut cream separate from the water. 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† Open the chilled coconut milk cans and scoop out the thick coconut cream into a mixing bowl, leaving the liquid behind. You can save the liquid for smoothies or other recipes. 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† Add the maple syrup (or agave nectar), vanilla extract, and a pinch of salt to the coconut cream. Use a hand mixer or whisk to blend everything until smooth and creamy. 



4.¬†¬†¬†¬† (Optional) If you‚Äôre adding mix-ins like chocolate chips, nuts, or berries, gently fold them into the mixture. 



5.¬†¬†¬†¬† Pour the mixture into an ice cream maker and churn according to the manufacturer‚Äôs instructions until it reaches a soft-serve consistency. 



6.¬†¬†¬†¬† Transfer the churned ice cream into a freezer-safe container, cover it, and freeze for at least 4 hours or until firm. 



7.¬†¬†¬†¬† Let the ice cream sit at room temperature for a few minutes to soften before scooping. 



8.¬†¬†¬†¬† (Note) If you don‚Äôt have an ice cream maker, follow steps 1-4, then pour the mixture into a shallow dish and place it in the freezer. Stir the mixture every 30 minutes until it reaches the desired consistency. 



These recipes are easy to prepare, popular in the vegan community, and packed with flavor. You can find variations of these recipes from different sources like vegan cookbooks and blogs. These recipes will help make becoming a vegan or adopting more vegan practices easier, along with the many other resources that can support you on your vegan journey. 



Resources and Support



Whether you plan to go fully vegan or adopt some vegan practices, the best thing you can have is a variety of resources and support along the way to make the transition easier. Here are some great resources to support your vegan journey. 



Websites 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† American Vegan Society: Offers a wealth of information on vegan living, events, and resources. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† The Vegan Society: Provides comprehensive guides, recipes, and support for those transitioning to or maintaining a vegan lifestyle. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vegan Foundry: A blog that shares reliable information and reviews on various vegan topics. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† VegNews: A popular vegan lifestyle magazine with news, recipes, and product reviews. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Plant Based News: Focuses on the latest news and developments in the plant-based community. 



Apps 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† HappyCow: A fantastic app for finding vegan and vegetarian restaurants worldwide. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Food Monster: Offers thousands of vegan recipes with meal planning features. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† 21-Day Vegan Kickstart: Curated by the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, this app provides recipes and tips for a healthy transition to veganism. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Dr. Greger‚Äôs Daily Dozen: Helps track daily servings of fruit, vegetables, nuts, and other plant-based foods. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vegan Friendly: A UK-based app to find vegan products and restaurants. 



Local Groups 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Meetup: Search for vegan meetups in your area to connect with like-minded individuals. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Local Vegan Facebook Groups: Many cities have dedicated vegan groups on Facebook where you can find events, support, and recipes. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Volunteer at Vegan Cafes or Animal Shelters: A great way to meet other vegans and contribute to the community. 



¬∑¬†¬†¬†¬†¬†¬† Vegan Potlucks and Gatherings: Look for local vegan potlucks or gatherings to share meals and stories with fellow vegans. 



These resources should help you find the support and community you need on your vegan journey. It will help make the change to a more vegan lifestyle much easier for you. 



The Vegan Way 



To be honest, I am not a vegan and I don‚Äôt see myself ever cutting meat and fish out of my diet, but I am still finding ways to make vegan adjustments to my life and diet. My blog post is not to convince you that everyone should be a vegan, it‚Äôs to help encourage you to try adopting vegan practices, inform you about the best way to do it, and provide you with the tips and resources needed to make it as easy as possible. 



Just remember, be respectful of others‚Äô dietary choices, vegan or not, it‚Äôs your choice to be a vegan and you shouldn‚Äôt do it because you feel like you have to, and don‚Äôt feel ashamed if you stumble on the journey. Do your best, even if your best isn‚Äôt perfect, because every step you take on this journey makes a positive impact on the environment, the welfare of animals, and your health. 



‚ÄúIf we could live happy and healthy lives without harming others, why wouldn‚Äôt we?‚Äù ‚Äì Pam Ahern 



1.¬†¬†¬†¬† What are your favorite vegan recipes that you would like to share? 



2.¬†¬†¬†¬† What tips do you want to give to anyone who plans to practice veganism? 



3.¬†¬†¬†¬† What have been your best resources for transitioning to veganism? 



Please leave your answers in the comment section! 



If you liked this blog post, please leave a like, subscribe for more posts, and share it on your social media to encourage more people to transition to a vegan lifestyle, then you can become an Exemplar of Change! 



If you want to learn more about the resources available to help you transition to a vegan lifestyle, look at the links below! 



American Vegan Society 



The Vegan Society 



Vegan Foundry 



The Minimalist Vegan 



Veganuary 



HappyCow 



Meetup

author: Jill Lupupa
title: Why are vegan places in London closing?
text:
At the end of this week and Veganuary, Unity Diner will close its doors on February 1st. Another beloved/hyped vegan eatery bites the dust. 



Picture this. It‚Äôs Veganuary, the annual challenge from 2014 that encourages people to go vegan in January with restaurants offering discounts on plant-based meals and stores placing more vegan friendly options and sections to choose from. Now, it‚Äôs Veganuary 2025, there‚Äôs been fewer if close to no restaurant offers and store adverts for new vegan brand products (Aldi‚Äôs own, Lidl‚Äôs own‚Ä¶) and instead, we‚Äôre seeing posts that another plant-based product is being discontinued and another vegan/vegetarian restaurant is closing shop. 



 




        View this post on Instagram            A post shared by Unity Diner (@unitydiner) 




 



Unity Diner in Aldgate, east London is the latest in a series of vegan favourites to announce its closure ‚Äì and in Veganuary of all times. From being recommended as a top London vegan restaurant in Vogue Magazine, Earthling Ed‚Äôs Unity Diner ultimately is ending in early closure after six years of business due to the constant problem: rising rent costs. 



When I first moved to London in July 2021, the capital was brimming with hyped vegan and veggie eating places to choose from. It was never a question of where (as chains were in multitude) but when. My friends and I would have weekly catch up dates at the next vegan restaurant on our list to try. In fact, Vurger co. in Shoreditch by the overground was my go to for friends visiting me in London before I did my infamous tours of Brick Lane, Rivington Street, Commercial Street and the best parts of central east. Vegan junk food was on the rise and restaurants exclusively for that purpose were more popular than ever, and this was at the beginning of the post-pandemic era. 



 




        View this post on Instagram            A post shared by Vegan Fast Food | VURGER  (@thevurgerco) 




 



In the three years since, countless favourites have dropped off the grid. Vurger co. in Shoreditch and Brighton, Rudy‚Äôs Vegan Diner (and store) in Islington then Camden slowly followed, Deliciously Ella‚Äôs restaurant in Mayfair, the Croydon and north west London chain of What the Pitta, and the Marylebone chain for Wulf & Lamb, while the Chelsea chain is currently temporarily closed.  



While most vegan eateries are closing due to money shortcomings, others went so ghost mode that I had to convince myself it really had existed to begin with. 



Rudy‚Äôs Dirty Vegan Diner, or Rudy‚Äôs Vegan Diner, first closed for renovations in Islington but was never to be seen again. Their socials even vanished, with their Rudy‚Äôs Vegan Butcher account left, albeit on private. It took until recent research to find out there was a fallout with the founders and the company itself: see here. 



 







 



Old haunts such as Mooshie‚Äôs in Brick Lane (pictured first) is a good example of a vegan junk food place which was great on the eyes but not so much on the taste ‚Äì the mixture of sauces were way too overpowering. Of course, this is also now closed, and their socials now focus on human rights politics. Meanwhile, Rudy‚Äôs reuben sandwich (pictured second) and Vurger‚Äôs burgers, shroom fingers and shakes (pictured third) reigned supreme. 



Maya Kokerov, 26, said: ‚ÄúI want vegan places to stay open but I think vegan options in non-vegan restaurants‚Äù (Caf√© Rouge, Meat Liquor, Honest Burgers and more from experience) ‚Äúare starting to be better quality than actual vegan food at vegan restaurants. 



‚ÄúEven though veganism is declining from mainstream popularity, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs becoming a huge problem but rather that vegans are choosing to eat less processed food and also save money.‚Äù 



It‚Äôs true that the booming options a few years ago were solely hinged on vegan junk food ‚Äì our friend group would note that at the time, so much so that we were thrilled to discover Wulf & Lamb, an all vegan and vegetarian actual restaurant. No junk food, but more cooked meals in smaller portions in true restaurant fashion. 



We tried others such as Stem & Glory in the Barbican area, but to no avail as the flavours and portions didn‚Äôt hit the same. An exception would be the traditional go to‚Äôs: Mildreds, Mallow, and Tendril ‚Äì a plant kitchen in Oxford Circus which has the best vegan tiramisu I‚Äôve ever had (in deep contrast to Unity Diner‚Äôs‚Ä¶). And most prominently, Jam Delish, a black-owned vegan caribbean restaurant in Angel/Islington ‚Äì they always keep their menu‚Äôs fresh and out of this world. 



Cecily Grace Morgan, 26, said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really disappointed to see so many vegan places in London close down, especially Wulf & Lamb in Marylebone and What the Pitta in Camden.  



‚ÄúI think the decrease in popularity of vegan places is probably linked to people‚Äôs growing wariness of ultra-processed foods but I hope we‚Äôll see restaurants that focus on plants instead of mock meats, like KIN in Fitzrovia, thrive.‚Äù 



The growing consciousness certainly seems to have moved towards being healthy within veganism ‚Äì the plant diet is not solely enough anymore ‚Äì especially now that we know that veganism is here to stay and it‚Äôs not a passing fancy that the mainstream is taking an interest in it.  



By this I mean back in 2018-2021 when vegan products and options were slowly being added to restaurants and stores. The transformation in that time alone sent me into disarray, I went from  fries as a side as my only option in 2018 Frankie & Benny‚Äôs (and even this was fried in animal fat, so it wasn‚Äôt an option) to numerous vegan only eating places as well as vegan menus in mainstream chains. Safe to say, no one was thinking about whether the food was processed or not back then, although we were looking at what it was made from (non vegans would hurl this question incessantly).  



Now, stepping back into the current climate, it‚Äôs important to preserve the good restaurants we still have, to fight against the closures. KIN, Jam Delish, Holy Carrot, Dauns and more listed on Happy Cow need us more than ever.

author: The VRG Blog Editor
title: The Vegetarian Resource Group‚Äôs $50,000 Scholarship Program for Graduating High School Seniors in the USA
text:
Due to the generosity of anonymous donors, The Vegetarian Resource Group each year will award $50,000 in college scholarship money to graduating U.S. high school students who have promoted veganism in their schools and/or communities. One award of $10,000 and six awards of $5,000, and additional runner-up prizes will be given. Entries may only be sent by students graduating from high school in SPRING 2025 
We will accept applications postmarked on or before FEBRUARY 20, 2025. Early submission is encouraged. 
Applicants will be judged on having shown compassion, courage, and a strong commitment to promoting a peaceful world through a vegan diet/lifestyle. Payment will be made to the student‚Äôs college (U.S. based only). Winners of the scholarships give permission to release their names to the media. Applications and essays become property of The Vegetarian Resource Group. We may ask finalists for more information. Scholarship winners are contacted by e-mail or telephone. Please look at your e-mail. 
If you would like to donate to additional scholarships or internships, go to www.vrg.org/donate 
Applications
Please click here to download a PDF of the application. However, applicants are not required to use an application form. A neatly typed document containing the information below will also be accepted as a valid application. 
However, applicants are not required to use an application form. A neatly typed document containing the information below will also be accepted as a valid application. 
Please send application and attachments to vrg@vrg.org (Scholarship application and your name in subject line) or mail to The Vegetarian Resource Group, P.O. Box 1463, Baltimore, MD 21203. 
If emailing, please put your essay in a separate attachment with your first name and last initial. A PDF or Word document is preferred, but if you send a Google document, make sure permission is given so readers can access it. For more information call (410) 366-8343 or email vrg@vrg.org.

author: jeremiah Cadwell
title: Just how To Develop The Perfect Event Catering Menu For Your Event
text:
Planning a successful event requires interest to detail, and one of the most considerable elements to take into consideration is the catering menu. Food is not simply a need; it is an experience that can boost your event from ordinary to phenomenal. If you are questioning just how to prepare an event catering menu that accommodates different tastes and nutritional demands, you are in the right place. Below are important approaches for crafting a memorable catering experience that your visitors will go crazy around long after the occasion finishes. 
First and foremost, understanding your target market is important. Consider the nature of your event and the choices of your guests. A company celebration may need a much more official food selection, while a wedding celebration might allow for even more imagination and customization. The secret to efficient occasion planning and event catering ideas is understanding that will certainly be attending and what they could take pleasure in. Involve with guests in advance when possible, to obtain insights into their food choices and any type of dietary restrictions they may have. 
In today‚Äôs varied culinary landscape, suiting nutritional demands in catering is more crucial than ever. Numerous guests might have allergies, intolerances, or specific dietary choices like vegetarianism or veganism. Be positive regarding learning these demands by consisting of an RSVP choice that permits visitors to specify their demands. This approach not just reveals your visitors that you care yet also allows your catering service to offer a well-rounded food selection that every person can appreciate. 
If you fancied this blog post and you want to acquire a lot additional information regarding personal chef kindly head to the article. One prominent fad is vegan food selection preparation for events. The expanding interest in plant-based diet regimens implies that a well-balanced vegan menu can delight also one of the most devoted carnivores. Include a range of vibrant choices such as baked veggie platters, vegan pasta salads, and flavorful grain bowls. Do not neglect treat; vegan delicious chocolate mousse or fruit tarts container be a delightful shock. With some creativity and quality components, vegan meals can be both pleasing and sophisticated. 
When putting together your catering food selection, equilibrium is vital. Aim for a selection of tastes and textures to maintain the eating experience amazing. Traditional choices like baked chicken or beef tenderloin can be complemented by exciting vegetarian meals and sides, making certain that all visitors have something delicious to appreciate. Think about incorporating seasonal ingredients for quality, and don‚Äôt forget to include gluten-free and nut-free choices to better fit dietary requirements in food catering. 
 
Timing is an additional critical aspect of how to plan a providing food selection properly. Depending on your occasion, you may pick to offer a buffet, layered dishes, or even family-style dining. Buffets permit visitors to pick what they want, making it an outstanding alternative for those with particular dietary requirements. On the various other hand, layered meals supply a more official touch and can be personalized for specific visitors. Whichever service design you choose, make certain it straightens with the general tone of the event. 
Don‚Äôt neglect the importance of discussion. A wonderfully organized providing spread can substantially boost the environment of your occasion. Focus on color, texture, and arrangement when intending your menu. Usage decorative serving meals, garnishes, and positioning to make the food appearance as appealing as feasible. Remember that we eat with our eyes first, so culinary discussion can bring an added layer of exhilaration to your event. 
For event hosts, catering suggestions extend beyond just the food. Think about having actually a marked area for drinks that complements your food selection. The best beverages can boost the dining experience and maintain visitors talking and engaged. Providing a selection of red wines, craft beers, or imaginative non-alcoholic drinks can offer a well-rounded experience. 
Finally, do not wait to work together with your event caterer. Sharing your vision and being open to their suggestions can result in a more natural and excellent menu. An excellent food catering group will certainly have the ability to provide suggestions on trending recipes, section sizes, and combinations that function well with each other. 
In conclusion, planning a catering food selection involves mindful consideration of your target market, nutritional requirements in food catering, and the overall event ambience. Whether you are preparing a business occasion, wedding, or casual event, a thoughtful food selection can make all the difference. By following these event preparation and catering tips, including a focus on vegan food selection options, you can make certain that every visitor leaves completely satisfied and amazed by the cooking experience you have actually developed. Happy preparation!

author: Prakarshi Pulkit
title: Switching to veganism is like embarking on a journey to a foreign land‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääexciting, intriguing, and‚Ä¶
text: Veganism: What to Expect During the First Several¬†DaysSwitching to veganism is like embarking on a journey to a foreign land‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääexciting, intriguing, and sometimes a little overwhelming. I remember my first week vividly. It wasn‚Äôt just about cutting out meat, dairy, and eggs; it was about learning a whole new way of thinking about food, my body, and the world around¬†me. If you‚Äôre considering going vegan or have just taken the plunge, you might be wondering: What‚Äôs the first week really like? Let me take you through it, with all the highs, lows, surprises, and lessons I wish someone had told¬†me. Day 1: The Honeymoon PhaseAh, the first day of veganism. You wake up feeling like a superhero, ready to save the planet one meal at a time. Your excitement fuels you as you prepare your first fully vegan breakfast. For me, it was avocado toast sprinkled with chili flakes and a side of black coffee. Simple, but I felt like a culinary¬†genius. What to¬†Expect: Excitement and Motivation: You‚Äôre likely feeling inspired, thinking about the positive impact you‚Äôre making on animals, the environment, and your¬†health.Grocery Store Adventures: Shopping for vegan food might feel like a scavenger hunt. You‚Äôll spend a lot of time reading labels, which can be eye-opening (why is there milk powder in everything?).Pro Tip: Stick to the basics at first‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääwhole foods like fruits, veggies, grains, and legumes. Fancy vegan substitutes can come¬†later. Day 2: The Energy¬†BoostBy the second day, I noticed something surprising‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI wasn‚Äôt dragging myself through the morning like usual. My body felt lighter, and my energy levels seemed to climb. Some people experience this ‚Äúvegan glow‚Äù early on, thanks to the fiber-rich, nutrient-dense foods flooding their¬†system. What to¬†Expect: Improved Digestion: All that fiber from plant-based foods starts to work its magic. (Yes, you might be visiting the bathroom a bit more often, but trust me, it‚Äôs a good¬†thing.)A Sense of Accomplishment: You‚Äôve made it through day one, and you‚Äôre already proving to yourself that you can do¬†this.I called my best friend on day two, gushing about how much better I felt. She joked, ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre two days in and already a vegan evangelist!‚Äù We laughed, but deep down, I was¬†proud. Day 3: The ‚ÄúWhat Do I Eat?‚Äù¬†MomentBy day three, the honeymoon phase might start to wear off. If you didn‚Äôt meal prep or plan ahead, you might find yourself staring into the fridge, wondering what to eat. This was the day I realized just how much I used to rely on cheese as a default ingredient. What to¬†Expect: Meal Planning Struggles: Without a plan, you might feel stuck or tempted to fall back on old¬†habits.Cravings Begin: If you‚Äôre used to eating a lot of meat or dairy, your brain might start craving those familiar¬†flavors.Pro Tip: Experiment with simple, satisfying meals like lentil soup, stir-fries, or pasta with marinara sauce and¬†veggies. Day 4: The Detox¬†PhaseLet‚Äôs talk about the elephant in the room: detox. As your body adjusts to a plant-based diet, you might experience a few bumps in the road. For me, it was bloating and a mild headache. This is normal‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyour body is getting used to the influx of fiber and the absence of animal products. What to¬†Expect: Physical Changes: Temporary bloating, fatigue, or even mild irritability are¬†common.Mental Clarity: Despite the physical adjustments, you might notice your mind feels clearer, which is a lovely¬†perk.On day four, I made a rookie mistake‚Ää‚Äî‚ÄäI ate a massive bowl of raw kale salad. While it was delicious, let‚Äôs just say my stomach wasn‚Äôt thrilled. I learned the hard way that cooking some veggies makes them easier to digest, especially in the beginning. Day 5: The ‚ÄúWhy Am I Doing This?‚Äù¬†QuestionBy the fifth day, the initial excitement might be replaced by doubt. This was when I started questioning my decision. Was I really ready to give up my favorite cheese pizza? Could I stick with this long-term? What to¬†Expect: Emotional Wobbles: Doubts are natural, especially if you‚Äôre facing criticism or teasing from friends and¬†family.Cravings Peak: If you‚Äôre going to cave, it‚Äôs usually around this¬†time.Pro Tip: Revisit your ‚Äúwhy.‚Äù Whether it‚Äôs for the animals, the planet, or your health, reminding yourself of your reasons can reignite your motivation. Day 6: The Confidence BoostBy day six, something shifted. I started feeling more confident in my choices and even tried cooking a more elaborate vegan dish: chickpea curry with coconut milk. It was a game-changer. Suddenly, I realized how flavorful and satisfying plant-based meals could¬†be. What to¬†Expect: Increased Confidence: You‚Äôre starting to find your groove and maybe even impressing yourself with your cooking¬†skills.Social Wins: If you‚Äôve navigated a dinner with friends or explained your diet to someone, you might feel a sense of¬†pride.I invited a friend over for dinner on day six. She was skeptical about vegan food but ended up loving the curry. That small victory made me realize this lifestyle wasn‚Äôt just for me‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit could inspire others,¬†too. Day 7: The Vegan¬†GrooveBy the end of the first week, you‚Äôll likely notice a few¬†things: Your taste buds are starting to¬†adapt.You‚Äôve discovered some new favorite¬†foods.You‚Äôre feeling lighter, more energized, and maybe even a little proud of yourself.This was the day I truly felt like I could stick with veganism. I had my go-to meals, a better understanding of nutrition, and a growing appreciation for this compassionate lifestyle. What I Wish I Knew Before¬†StartingNot Everything ‚ÄúVegan‚Äù Is Healthy Oreos? Vegan. French fries? Vegan. But that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre good for you. Focus on whole, plant-based foods for the best¬†results.You Don‚Äôt Have to Be Perfect I stressed so much about accidentally eating something non-vegan. (Spoiler: It happens. We‚Äôre all human.) What matters is your effort and intention.You‚Äôll Discover Amazing Foods Before going vegan, I‚Äôd never tried nutritional yeast, tempeh, or jackfruit. Now, I can‚Äôt imagine my life without¬†them.Tips for¬†SuccessStock Your Kitchen Keep your pantry and fridge filled with staples like beans, grains, nuts, and fresh¬†produce.Find Your Support System Join vegan Facebook groups, follow plant-based influencers, or connect with friends who share your¬†journey.Be Kind to Yourself This is a big change. Celebrate your wins and learn from your mistakes.Going vegan isn‚Äôt just about what you eat‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääit‚Äôs about aligning your actions with your values. It‚Äôs a journey of discovery, growth, and compassion. And while the first week can feel like a rollercoaster, trust me when I say it‚Äôs worth¬†it. By the time you reach the end of that first week, you‚Äôll have taken a step towards a healthier you, a kinder world, and a brighter future. So, if you‚Äôre thinking about going vegan, take it one day at a time and enjoy the ride.¬†üå± Switching to veganism is like embarking on a journey to a foreign land‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääexciting, intriguing, and‚Ä¶ was originally published in Plantmade on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

author: Market News And Updates
title: Exploring Dried Fruit Market: Trends and Future Outlook
text:
The global¬†dried fruit market¬†size is estimated to reach USD 16.55 billion by 2030, expanding at a CAGR of 5.6% from 2025 to 2030, according to a new report by Grand View Research, Inc. Rising number of health-conscious consumers, growing awareness about the health benefits of dried fruit, and increasing application of the product in the food preparation are some of the factors driving the market for dried fruit. Furthermore, introduction of innovative products, along with increasing purchasing power, has been boosting the demand for dried fruit over the world. 



In terms of product, raisins or dehydrated grapes held the largest share of over 35% in 2019. Countries including China, India, U.K., Germany, Turkey, and U.S. are the key consumers in the world. Vast application of these dried fruits in several foods, including dairy, bakery, snacks, and confectionary, has fueled the demand across the globe. The berries segment is expected to witness the fastest growth over the forecast period owing to their growing popularity of these dried fruits. 



Shifting consumer preference for organic food products has also influenced the market growth over the past few years. As a result, manufacturers are expanding their organic product lines. For instance, in August 2019, Solely, Inc. introduced a new line of organic fruit jerky at all the Whole Foods Market stores in U.S. This new product line includes six single and two-ingredient products. 



Key industry competitors include SUNBEAM FOODS, Sun-Maid Growers of California, AL FOAH, Bergin Fruit and Nut Company, Angas Park, Murray River Organics Gr, Red River Foods, Geobres, Kiantama Oy, Traina Foods, and SUNSWEET. Expansion of the product portfolio through the launch of innovative products has been a key strategy among the manufacturers. In addition, new players are entering the market in order to meet the growing demand. For instance, in October 2019, North Bay Produce, Inc. launched its first dehydrated fruit line. The company offers five products, including blueberries, cherries, cherries with zero added sugar, cranberries, and whole cranberries. 



Gather more insights about the market drivers, restrains and growth of the¬†Dried Fruit Market 



Dried Fruit Market Report Highlights



‚Ä¢ In terms of product, Dates dominated the global dried fruit industry with a revenue share of 45.1% in 2024. Significant roots in traditions and rituals regarding the use of dates in diet, increasing shift towards veganism. 



‚Ä¢ Asia Pacific is projected to experience the fastest CAGR from 2025 to 2030. The rising demand for convenient food products in countries like China and India. 



‚Ä¢ Europe dominated the global dried fruit industry with a revenue share of 29.5% in 2024 share of the global revenue. High adoption of on-go snacking options in countries, including Germany, U.K., and France, is expected to have a positive impact on the regional market growth. 



‚Ä¢ The online distribution segment is projected to experience the highest CAGR from 2025 to 2030 due to increasing penetration of e-retailers and smartphones at the global level. 



‚Ä¢ Major players operating in the market include SUNBEAM FOODS, Sun-Maid Growers of California, AL FOAH, Bergin Fruit and Nut Company, Angas Park, Murray River Organics Gr, Red River Foods, Geobres, Kiantama Oy, and SUNSWEET.

author: itstimholman
title: Trial and Error: Learning to Love Veganuary
text: From¬†varsity.co.uk/lifestyle Edie Castell¬†reflects on the highs and lows of the Veganuary experience¬† The first time I attempted veganism was when I was 12 years¬†old. It was the summer of yellow ochre, mom jeans, and those ‚Äòwe should all be feminists‚Äô tees: in other words, the perfect environment for half-hearted teenage activism. I didn‚Äôt particularly know¬†why¬†I was suddenly avoiding animal products past a general concern for their welfare, nor did I have the perseverance to sustain my new diet longer than a few weeks. The problem wasn‚Äôt a lack of passion, but rather one fatal flaw that I‚Äôve yet to relinquish: I am incredibly lazy in the kitchen. Especially at university, nothing beats the comfort of a bowl of pesto pasta. This month, however, I decided to work against my nature, and what better way to do so than to commit to a national movement (and an article) to hold myself accountable? Veganuary, for the unacquainted, is exactly what you‚Äôd presume it to be: a month-long commitment to a vegan diet. Since its conception in 2014, the movement has only attracted more fanfare ‚Äì it feels like half of my friends have given it a go at one point or another.  This month I decided to work against my nature, and what better way to do so than to commit to Veganuary?¬† ¬†Natasha Larsen for Varsity   There‚Äôs no arguing that the case for a vegan diet is compelling. Not only has it been linked to certain health benefits, like a lower blood pressure and cholesterol, but cutting out meat has a genuine environmental impact. It‚Äôs common knowledge that a reduction in our meat intake would lead to a better carbon footprint. These factors considered, I spent the better part of my New Year‚Äôs Eve excitedly sharing my new endeavour: to go into 2025 completely plant-based. As the new year dawned, I was admittedly over-confident about the ease with which I would take to this shift in my diet. As a passionate butter-hater and plant milk connoisseur, I felt like I was already halfway to veganism. What I hadn‚Äôt accounted for was waking up on New Year‚Äôs Day exhausted (mildly hungover) in the midst of a rain storm. My early morning supermarket plans foiled, I opted to make do with what I could find in my cupboards. A simple tomato and lentil pasta seemed like my easiest bet, and the dish came together smoothly. However, after struggling through half a bowl of tomato pasta sans cheese, I realised it was lacking the umami taste I craved. Going vegan, I was quick to note, eliminated many of my go-to embellishments for simple meals. Gone were the days where I could just chuck a load of cheddar over a mediocre dish and call it a¬†day. All hope was not lost, however, and to prevent you from succumbing to a similar fate, I have compiled a (tried and true) list of easy food embellishments: Absolutely anything pickled or fermented: gherkins, olives, onions, jalapenos, kimchi ‚Äì take your pick. Seeds and nuts: peanuts and sesame seeds were wins for me, though I can also envision cashews or pistachios complimenting a pasta dish or curry. Crunchy veg: Finely chopping up some celery, chillies, or bell peppers allows for a more diverse array of textures. Liberal seasoning:¬†even if you fail to venture past salt and pepper, being slightly more generous with your food-to-seasoning ratio can make all the difference. It didn‚Äôt take too long to adjust more fully to my new lifestyle (achieved by sitting down and writing out a proper meal plan). Among the highlights of my meals were colourful finely chopped salads and even ready-meal vegan curries from the supermarket. My attempt at veganism also gave me a chance to finally settle my long-held grudge against tofu. In the past, I have been victim to it at its least seasoned, and it took accepting a couple hours of marination to truly obtain the flavour I‚Äôd been searching¬†for. I let the cubes sit in a mix of sriracha and tahini, before popping them in the oven at 180 degrees celsius for half an hour. My biggest win was my discovery that hummus is, in fact, vegan, which widened the potential for out-of-meal-time snacking. Eating out whilst vegan can be, in better situations, limiting, and at worst, entirely fruitless. Whilst the pubs, restaurant, and markets of London, and indeed Cambridge, boast a plethora of vegan options, a local pub in Grays lacked the same menu. The sole vegan option, a faux-chicken burger (counterintuitively served with a saucer of mayo), was clearly not a bestseller. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no meat in that. You know that, right?‚Äù, the waitress clarified, in a tone that suggested I was making a grave error with my order. She wouldn‚Äôt have been all that incorrect ‚Äì it was by no means fine dining. I can appreciate a pack of Linda McCartney veggie sausages with the best of them, but I‚Äôve found over the course of this experience that meat mock-ups tend to pale in comparison to whole foods that just so happen to be vegan. In my eyes, a portobello mushroom serves as a much better burger filling than a Quorn patty. So, will I continue my veganism into February? The jury is still out on that one: whilst I‚Äôve enjoyed the challenge of straying from my comfort zone with my cooking, I haven‚Äôt been sold on going entirely plant-based just yet. However, whatever I end up deciding, this experience has certainly pushed me to be more mindful about what I consume. Putting extra consideration into the food I choose to buy and cook has shifted eating into a more deliberate practice, rather than just a functional one. I anticipate many trips to Mill Road (the heart of vegan cuisine) this Lent term. https://www.varsity.co.uk/lifestyle/28925

author: Suzana Gartner
title: New Year, New You: Why Go Vegan and How to Make Compassionate Choices
text:
A new year feels like a fresh start‚Äîan opportunity to make choices that reflect who we want to be. This January, I‚Äôm inviting you to join me in making one of the most impactful choices you can: going vegan. Whether you‚Äôre looking to improve your health, reduce your environmental impact, or show compassion for animals, going vegan this month is a great way to start. 



Why Go Vegan?



You might be wondering, ‚ÄúWhy go vegan?‚Äù The answer is simple: veganism can transform your health, reduce your carbon footprint, and help animals. By switching to a plant-based lifestyle, you‚Äôre making a positive impact on the environment, animal rights, and your health and well-being. Plus, it‚Äôs easier than ever to enjoy delicious, healthy, and cruelty-free meals! 



How to Start Your Vegan Journey This January



I understand that switching to a vegan lifestyle can feel overwhelming. So, how do you get started? Here are a few simple steps to help you take the plunge: 




Try Plant-Based Meals: Start with easy and tasty dishes like veggie stir-fries, pasta with dairy-free pesto, or plant-based burgers.



Substitute Dairy and Meat: There are many alternatives available‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs oat milk in your coffee or a hearty bean salad for lunch. Making the switch is easier than ever.



Tap Into Resources and Community Support: There are cookbooks, blogs, and apps to guide you along the way. Be sure to check out the list at the end for helpful tools!




Why Veganuary Is the Perfect Time to Go Vegan



That brings me to Veganuary‚Äîa global campaign that encourages people to try a plant-based lifestyle for the month of January. It‚Äôs a wonderful chance to experiment with new foods, explore the joys of plant-based eating, and see how you feel after a month of avoiding animal products. Whether you‚Äôre motivated by reducing your environmental impact, improving your health, or standing up for animal rights, Veganuary is the perfect time to explore veganism. 



Sharing My Personal Journey: Aligning Actions with Values



I was a vegetarian for years, since childhood, believing that I was doing my part for animals, the planet, and my health. But a few years ago, I learned something that shifted my perspective. I discovered the harsh realities of the dairy industry. I didn‚Äôt realize how cruel dairy production could be. Female cows are repeatedly impregnated for milk production, and their newborn calves are taken away almost immediately after birth. The heartbreak of this knowledge led me to stop drinking milk and eating dairy. I transitioned to a vegan lifestyle. It wasn‚Äôt always easy, but my commitment grew stronger, and when my husband joined me, it became even easier. Becoming vegan wasn‚Äôt just about food‚Äîit was about aligning my actions with my values. 



How Can You Make a Difference?



If you‚Äôre ready to make a positive change in your life, now is the perfect time. Whether you go fully vegan or simply reduce your animal product intake, every small change counts. Let‚Äôs make a lasting impact with compassionate choices. If you‚Äôre ready to try veganism or learn more, drop a comment below‚Äîlet‚Äôs support each other on this journey! Share your experiences, ask questions, and know that you‚Äôre part of a supportive vegan community cheering you on. 



Ready to start your vegan journey? Subscribe to my website for more tips, recipes, and resources to help you along the way! 



Resources to Help You on Your Vegan Journey




Vegan Starter Kit (Veganuary) ‚Äì A free resource to get you started with tips, recipes, and meal plans: https://veganuary.com



Plant-Based Recipe Websites:

Minimalist Baker ‚Äì Simple and delicious plant-based recipes: https://minimalistbaker.com



Forks Over Knives ‚Äì Healthy, whole-food plant-based recipes: https://www.forksoverknives.com





Apps:

HappyCow ‚Äì Find vegan-friendly restaurants, stores, and cafes near you: https://www.happycow.net



20 Minute Vegan ‚Äì Quick and easy vegan meal ideas: https://www.20minutvegan.com





Documentaries:

What the Health ‚Äì A documentary on how diet affects health and the environment: https://www.whatthehealthfilm.com



Cowspiracy ‚Äì A film exploring the environmental impact of animal agriculture: https://www.cowspiracy.com






This year, let‚Äôs make a lasting impact with compassionate choices. If you‚Äôre ready to try veganism or learn more, check out these resources, or drop a comment below‚Äîlet‚Äôs support each other on this journey! Share your experiences, ask questions, and be part of a vegan community cheering you on. Let‚Äôs make this year more compassionate‚Äîgo vegan for yourself.¬† 
The post New Year, New You: Why Go Vegan and How to Make Compassionate Choices appeared first on Suzana Gartner.

author: sednadragon5@gmail.com
title: Why The Vegan Based Diet Does Not Make Sense
text: ¬†As you have seen before that, I do have Christian posts so I think that there are readers who would think, ‚ÄòHold on, she‚Äôs a Christian, she should be more likely to be in agreement with a vegan diet. Who does she think that she is scrutinising veganism?‚Äô well let me say that God, Himself, stated that we are allowed to eat meat, it‚Äôs just human meat that is cursed to eat. As humans are the only creatures made in the image of God. He states that in Genesis nine. 9 Then God blessed Noah and his sons, saying to them, ‚ÄúBe fruitful and increase in number and fill the earth. 2 The fear and dread of you will fall on all the beasts of the earth, and on all the birds in the sky, on every creature that moves along the ground, and on all the fish in the sea; they are given into your hands. 3 Everything that lives and moves about will be food for you. Just as I gave you the green plants, I now give you everything. 4 ‚ÄúBut you must not eat meat that has its lifeblood still in it. 5 And for your lifeblood I will surely demand an accounting. I will demand an accounting from every animal. And from each human being, too, I will demand an accounting for the life of another human being. ( https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Genesis%209%3A1-5&version=NIV )   Which means that if God, Himself has stated that we can eat meat after the flood it must be for our benefit. After all, all that He does is for that. Yet I know that there are those that, for whatever reason you can not eat meat, but that is up to you to find out why that is. Which is something that I do recognise, but I will encourage you to find out why that is. Yet the truth of the matter is the majority who go on a vegan based diet end up having to come off it due to health related reasons as their bodies are not getting the nutrients that they need. This also translates to the breast milk also not being able to provide the nutrients either. Like for instance there was a couple who were raising a baby that was not healthy and the doctor told them that the reason that their baby was in the state that it was in was because it was malnourished. Also there was a case when a woman went on the raw vegan based diet which, after she died it was determined that she starved to death. Now enough of that, let‚Äôs get into another perspective. I would like for you all to ask yourselves this one question; when a lion or wolf is hunting, do they think about the morality of what they are doing while they are stalking their prey? The answer usually is no. They are thinking about which cattle are the best to feed upon. Which leads me to another point, in a Darwinist mindset, an animal is either a predator or a prey which is usually survival of the fittest.¬†   ( https://youtu.be/VMMrn4LI494?si=cjrOyM3zxdPc6Hkg )     ( https://youtu.be/BA9SZbtcFOs?si=X-0rp4aXhafHHsZN {I would have gone for a different video but there were all dark and this video is from a vegan perspective which I did admittedly interesting, not that I am against a vegan diet I just want to explain why it does not make sense from my perspective})   Now another topic that I do want to touch upon is just how many cattle based animals do eat meat, especially ones that we consider vegetarian, like for instance, chickens sometimes eat worms and are willing to eat other chickens! And pigs are willing to eat their own young. Yet there are videos of cows slurping up snakes like spaghetti or noodles. Then there was a case of a bunch of sheep eating birds.   (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9xDPrvhLNuU&pp=ygUkY2FzdWFsIGdlb2dyYXBoaWMgc2Nob29sIGxpZWQgdG8gdXMg)   So this must mean that nature does not care about you or how much you care about it. After all, this is a dog eat dog world and our stomachs need real meat and do not feel guilty about eating meat or eating that beacon either! If it isn‚Äôt you it‚Äôs the mother or father. As the truth of the matter is, the dark side of nature is simply that animals eat other animals and they do not care at all! Also there are those diets that are fruit and vegetables but they always have to take some animal based protein and this can depend upon where you live and not all environments can allow you the luxury of choosing if you eat soley vegetables and not all places can grow them. Which is why some places (especially cold places) have more meat than vegetables. So these are my thoughts on this matter. If you disagree, change my mind, but please do it in a civil way and explain why I am wrong and where I am wrong. Thank you.
