author: David Beaver
title: Diets Dissected: The Vegan Diet ‚Äì Everything You Need to Know
text:
The vegan diet is made up entirely of plant-based foods‚Äîno meat, no fish, no eggs, no dairy, and no other animal-derived products. But is it a healthy way to live, or are there risks of missing out on vital nutrients? In this article, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the vegan diet, exploring its health benefits, potential pitfalls, and tips on how to maintain a balanced, sustainable plant-based lifestyle. 
Over the last decade, veganism has skyrocketed in popularity, driven by growing concerns about the environment, animal welfare, and the increasing body of evidence showing the health benefits of a plant-based diet. Whether you‚Äôre considering going vegan or simply curious about how it works, this guide will walk you through everything you need to know. 
What is Veganism?
The term vegan was coined by the British Vegan Society in 1944, but the concept of plant-based eating has existed for centuries. Originally, members of the society were known as ‚ÄòNon-Dairy Vegetarians,‚Äô but they soon adopted the term vegan, which they felt better reflected the philosophy of excluding all animal products. Veganism is a lifestyle and ethical choice that goes beyond just food. For many, it‚Äôs not just about eating plant-based meals, but also avoiding animal products in clothing (like leather), personal care (such as cruelty-free cosmetics), and other aspects of daily life. 
But why do people choose to go vegan? There are three main reasons people adopt a vegan diet: 


Ethical reasons ‚Äì Many people choose veganism to prevent animal cruelty and exploitation. This includes avoiding animal-based products such as leather and honey, and opting for cruelty-free skincare and household products. 


Health reasons ‚Äì Research has shown that a plant-based diet can have various health benefits, from reducing the risk of heart disease to aiding weight loss. Many people choose to go vegan for these potential health improvements. 


Environmental concerns ‚Äì Veganism is seen by many as an eco-friendly way of living, as the production of plant-based foods generally has a smaller carbon footprint than animal farming. 


What Can You Eat on a Vegan Diet?
One of the common misconceptions about veganism is that it‚Äôs restrictive. In reality, there‚Äôs a huge variety of plant-based foods to choose from, many of which are both delicious and nutritious. 
Here are some examples of foods you can enjoy on a vegan diet: 
Fruits and Vegetables:
All fruits and vegetables are vegan-friendly, from apples and oranges to leafy greens like kale and spinach. You can also enjoy root vegetables like carrots and sweet potatoes, as well as non-starchy vegetables like peppers, mushrooms, and aubergines. 
Nuts and Seeds:
Almonds, cashews, peanuts, and sunflower seeds are all great sources of healthy fats and protein. They also provide essential vitamins and minerals like vitamin E and magnesium. 
Grains and Legumes:
Whole grains such as rice, barley, quinoa, and oats are staples in a vegan diet. Beans and legumes‚Äîsuch as lentils, chickpeas, and kidney beans‚Äîare excellent sources of protein, iron, and fibre. 
Dairy Alternatives:
There are plenty of non-dairy alternatives available today, such as plant-based milks (oat, almond, soy, coconut) and dairy-free cheeses made from nuts or soy. These can be used in place of traditional dairy products in most recipes. 
Processed and Convenience Foods:
Vegan junk food? You bet! Oreos, Jammie Dodgers, Pringles, and other processed snacks are all technically vegan (although not always the healthiest options). While it‚Äôs best to focus on whole, unprocessed plant foods, these snacks can help make the transition to a vegan diet easier. 
Surprising Vegan Foods:
Did you know that even some sweets and snacks are vegan-friendly? Popular brands like Skittles, Jelly Tots, and many supermarket doughnuts don‚Äôt contain any animal-derived ingredients, making them a surprising but tasty part of the plant-based diet. 
Health Benefits of the Vegan Diet
Veganism is widely recognised for its health benefits, especially when it comes to heart health, weight management, and reducing the risk of chronic diseases. 
1. Heart Health
One of the biggest benefits of a vegan diet is its potential to lower the risk of heart disease. Since plant-based diets are naturally low in saturated fats and cholesterol, they can help reduce blood pressure and lower the levels of bad cholesterol (LDL) in your body. 
The vegan diet is also rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds found in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, which can reduce the risk of developing cardiovascular diseases. Research has shown that vegans tend to have lower blood pressure, healthier cholesterol levels, and a reduced risk of stroke. 
2. Lower Risk of Obesity
A vegan diet can also help with weight management, as plant-based foods are generally lower in calories compared to animal products. Furthermore, the high fibre content in fruits, vegetables, legumes, and whole grains helps to keep you full for longer, making it easier to control your weight. 
However, it‚Äôs important to note that a vegan diet can still be unhealthy if you rely heavily on processed vegan junk food like vegan cheeses, fried foods, or refined sugars. The key is balance‚Äîensure that your diet is nutrient-dense with plenty of whole plant foods. 
3. Cancer Prevention
Eating a wide variety of fruits, vegetables, and legumes is associated with a reduced risk of developing certain types of cancer. For example, cruciferous vegetables like broccoli contain sulforaphane, a compound that may help to protect against cancer. Tomatoes are rich in lycopene, an antioxidant that has been shown to reduce the risk of prostate cancer. 
Additionally, the vegan diet excludes processed meats like bacon, sausages, and deli meats, which are known carcinogens. Many plant-based foods, including soy products like tofu and tempeh, contain isoflavones‚Äînatural compounds that may help reduce the risk of breast cancer. 
4. Gut Health
The high fibre content of a vegan diet is incredibly beneficial for gut health. Fibre is essential for feeding the healthy bacteria in your gut, keeping your digestive system running smoothly. A healthy gut microbiome is linked to better digestion, immune function, and even improved mental health. 
Can the Vegan Diet Be Unhealthy?
As with any diet, it‚Äôs possible for a vegan diet to be unhealthy if not carefully planned. Just because something is vegan doesn‚Äôt automatically mean it‚Äôs healthy. Highly processed vegan foods, such as white bread, crisps, and sugary snacks, can be high in fats and sugars, while lacking in essential nutrients. 
To ensure that your vegan diet is healthy, it‚Äôs important to focus on whole plant foods such as fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, nuts, and seeds. Be mindful of processed foods and limit your intake of refined carbohydrates and sugars. 
Key Nutrients to Watch on a Vegan Diet
When transitioning to a vegan diet, there are certain nutrients that need extra attention, as they are found in lower quantities in plant-based foods. Here‚Äôs a rundown of the key nutrients to be mindful of: 
1. Vitamin B12
Vitamin B12 is crucial for producing red blood cells and maintaining a healthy nervous system. As it‚Äôs primarily found in animal products, vegans need to find alternative sources. Vegan-friendly options include fortified foods like nutritional yeast, plant milks, and breakfast cereals. It‚Äôs also a good idea to take a B12 supplement, as deficiency can lead to serious health issues like anaemia and nerve damage. 
2. Vitamin D
Vitamin D is vital for maintaining strong bones and a healthy immune system. While our bodies produce vitamin D from sunlight, it can be harder to get enough during the winter months, especially in countries with limited sunlight. Vegans can look for fortified foods or take a vegan-friendly vitamin D supplement to meet their needs. 
3. Iron
Iron is essential for transporting oxygen around the body. While plant foods contain non-heme iron, which is not as easily absorbed as the heme iron found in meat, you can still get plenty of iron from plant sources such as lentils, chickpeas, tofu, and dark leafy greens. To improve iron absorption, pair iron-rich foods with vitamin C-rich foods like oranges or bell peppers. 
4. Omega-3 Fatty Acids
Omega-3 fatty acids are important for brain health and reducing inflammation. While omega-3s are primarily found in fatty fish, vegans can get them from flaxseeds, chia seeds, walnuts, and algae-based supplements. 
5. Protein
Despite the myth that vegans don‚Äôt get enough protein, plant-based diets can easily meet protein needs. Sources of vegan protein include lentils, chickpeas, tofu, tempeh, edamame, quinoa, and a variety of seeds and nuts. Just be sure to eat a diverse range of protein sources to ensure you're getting all the essential amino acids your body needs. 
Is the Vegan Diet Worth Trying?
With proper planning, a vegan diet can be a highly nutritious and sustainable way of eating. The health benefits are undeniable, including a reduced risk of heart disease, obesity, cancer, and other chronic conditions. Plus, a plant-based diet is better for the environment and kinder to animals. 
If you‚Äôre interested in making the switch, it‚Äôs easier than ever with the growing availability of vegan products, recipes, and even delivered vegan meals straight to your door. 
Ultimately, the vegan diet isn‚Äôt as restrictive as many people think, and with the right balance of nutrients, it can be an incredibly healthy and fulfilling way to eat. If you want to explore prepared vegan meals or vegan frozen meals, look no further than Root Kitchen. 
Are you thinking of going vegan? Or do you have any questions about veganism? Let us know in the comments below!

author: itstimholman
title: Embracing a Plant-Based Lifestyle; Environmental And Health Benefits
text: From¬†news18.com As the world continues to recognise the benefits of plant-based living, the industry is paving the way with innovative culinary creations and convenient snacking solutionsWith the increasing awareness of the environmental and health benefits of plant-based diets, more people are making conscious efforts to incorporate vegan choices into their lifestyles. January, often marked by resolutions and fresh starts, is an ideal time to explore the diverse and delicious world of plant-based eating.  Whether it's trying out a new plant-based dish at home or opting for guilt-free snacks, there has never been a better time to embrace a sustainable and health-conscious lifestyle   The Growing Appeal of Veganism Dheeraj Mathur, Cluster Executive Chef, Radisson Blu Kaushambi Delhi NCR, highlights the ethical and environmental motivations behind veganism, stating, ‚ÄúVeganism is becoming increasingly common as more people learn that they can help prevent animal suffering and deaths by replacing foods and other products of animal origin with options that don‚Äôt involve the exploitation of animals."  A plant-based diet offers numerous health benefits and contributes significantly to reducing carbon footprints. Mathur points out, ‚ÄúStudies demonstrate that a shift to plant-based diets rich in pulses, nuts, fruits, and vegetables could lead to substantial reduction of greenhouse gas emissions as compared to current dietary patterns in most industrialized countries." This transition not only helps mitigate climate change but also improves overall health by reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease, type 2 diabetes, and other diet-related noncommunicable diseases. The World Health Organisation also supports plant-based diets, emphasising that reducing livestock herds can lower methane emissions, a major contributor to global warming. Mathur further explains, ‚ÄúCattle produce methane as part of their normal digestive process, and when cows burp, the methane is released into the atmosphere. Methane is also produced when animal manure is stored or managed in lagoons or holding tanks." Exploring New Culinary Horizons For those looking to explore plant-based options, Mathur recommends taking advantage of the fresh produce available in January. ‚ÄúThe Indian market offers a variety of fresh vegetables such as carrots, spinach, sarson ka saag, hara choliya, turnips, beetroots, brinjals, methi, broad beans, radishes, green peas, mushrooms, cabbages, and cauliflowers." Some popular vegan dishes to enjoy during winter include poha, dosa, besan chila, and choley bhaturey. Mathur shares his personal favourites: ‚ÄúMy favourite dishes in January are aloo cholia, baingan ka bharta, saag, and beetroot ka halwa. I have also modified some dishes like tofu palak (replacing paneer), mushroom chettinad, and vegetable korma to align with plant-based choices." Healthy Snacking for a Plant-Based Lifestyle As plant-based diets become more mainstream, snacking has taken on a new significance. Salloni Ghodawat, Director & COO, Ghodawat Consumer Ltd., emphasizes the importance of innovative vegan snacking options. ‚ÄúWith the increasing adoption of plant-based diets during Veganuary, snacking has taken on a new significance in this journey. To Be Honest (TBH) offers an innovative range of vacuum-cooked, plant-based vegetable chips, from bold flavours like Tangy Chickpeas with Chili and Lime to Purple Sweet Potato with Pani Puri Masala." Ghodawat underscores TBH‚Äôs commitment to sustainability and health-conscious choices. ‚ÄúOur low-oil, nutrition-retaining cooking process reflects our commitment to sustainable practices and healthier choices. Veganuary inspires us all this January to make small but meaningful changes for our well-being and the planet. TBH is committed to supporting and participating in this collective effort by providing tasty, plant-based snacking options that align with these values." As the world continues to recognise the benefits of plant-based living, the industry is paving the way with innovative culinary creations and convenient snacking solutions. Whether it‚Äôs trying out a new plant-based dish at home or opting for guilt-free snacks, there has never been a better time to embrace a sustainable and health-conscious lifestyle. https://www.news18.com/lifestyle/food/embracing-a-plant-based-lifestyle-environmental-and-health-benefits-9202596.html
tags: ["ethical veganism","India","plant-based meaning","plant-based snacks","sustainability","vegan benefits","vegan lifestyle","vegan popularity","Vegan snacks"]

title: Lebanon‚Äôs Vegan Treasures: Must-Visit Plant-Based Restaurants
text:
Lebanon is home to a diverse range of vegan restaurants that offer delicious and healthy plant-based cuisine. From cozy caf√©s to vibrant social hubs, these establishments not only provide mouthwatering dishes but also promote mindful eating and sustainable living. Whether you're a dedicated vegan or simply curious about plant-based dining, these top vegan restaurants in Lebanon are sure to delight your taste buds and nourish your body. Discover the Heart of Healthy Living at Jinan Healthy Kitchen in Barouk, LebanonJinan Healthy Kitchen in Barouk, Lebanon, is a haven for healthy and delicious vegan cuisine. This charming kitchen offers a wide range of sugar, dairy, and cruelty-free dishes designed to nourish your body and delight your taste buds. They also provide diet plans and catering services tailored to individual needs, ensuring memorable and healthy events. 





















  
  






  Jinan Healthy Kitchen takes pride in their fresh and homemade vegan products, ideal for daily consumption and lunch boxes. Their superfood dishes, packed with nutrients and vitamins, help kickstart a vibrant day. Every Sunday, they host an open buffet featuring a variety of heartwarming dishes. The kitchen provides a cozy and productive atmosphere, making it a perfect spot to relax or work. Customers have praised the warm welcome, excellent service, and unique, healthy flavors. Located in Barouk, they are open all week from 8 AM to 3 PM, except Tuesdays. Reservations are recommended. Experience the magic of healthy living at Jinan Healthy Kitchen, where every meal is a step towards a better version of yourself. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Lebanese Vegans Social Hub: The Heart of Veganism and Activism in the Middle EastThe Lebanese Vegans Social Hub, located on Saydeh Street in Sinn Al Fil, Mont-Liban, Lebanon, is the first animal rights-vegan center in the Middle East. Founded by the Lebanese Vegans NGO, this hub combines a cafe, boutique, and event space to promote veganism and animal rights through activism, events, and relief campaigns. 





















  
  






  Since its establishment in August 2020, following the Beirut port explosion, the hub has distributed over 16,000 vegan meals and continues to support the community. All proceeds from the cafe and boutique go directly to fund their relief program. The cafe offers delicious vegan comfort foods such as Vegan Fish Burger, Taouk, Kebbeh Bi LaBan, and Shawarma sandwiches, demonstrating to non-vegans that they can enjoy their favorite foods without compromise. The boutique provides a variety of vegan products, supporting the hub's mission with each purchase. The hub serves as a welcoming space for both vegans and non-vegans, fostering community connections in a warm atmosphere with chill music. Visit the Lebanese Vegans Social Hub to enjoy a variety of vegan dishes and shop for vegan needs, knowing that every purchase makes a positive impact. The hub expresses deep gratitude to its supporters and emphasizes that there is no excuse for animal abuse. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Kamakan: Your Organic, Vegan Health Store & Caf√© in Ain AarKamakan in Ain Aar is a family-founded health store and caf√© that specializes in organic and vegan products. The caf√© menu features fresh, locally-sourced ingredients that provide a healthy twist on traditional Lebanese dishes, including specialty sandwiches, hearty soups, and a variety of salads. 





















  
  






  Key offerings include the Vegan Kafta Wrap, Herbal Infusions, Vegan Knefe, Vegan Mushroom Soup, Plant-Based Man'oushe, and the Vegan Mushroom Wrap. Kamakan also hosts an exclusive Vegan Brunch every Saturday, offering plant-based dishes like organic grilled potatoes paired with Belgian organic and gluten-free beer. With a warm and welcoming atmosphere, Kamakan is perfect for a relaxing meal or gathering with friends. Whether dining in, taking away, or ordering delivery, customers can enjoy a delightful experience at Kamakan. They are open from Monday to Saturday, 9 AM to 3 PM. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Coara Vegan Cuisine: A Sanctuary for Plant-Based Delights in Lebanon‚Äôs MountainsCoara Vegan Cuisine is a family-founded and operated vegan restaurant located in Lebanon‚Äôs mountains, specifically in Chouf-Kfar-Katra. Established in 2002, Coara offers a unique plant-based dining experience with fresh, farm-to-fork ingredients. The atmosphere is warm and welcoming, treating guests like family and providing a serene setting to reconnect with nature and enjoy plant-based Lebanese cuisine. 





















  
  






  Key offerings include the Vegan Kafta Wrap, Herbal Infusions, Vegan Knefe, Vegan Mushroom Soup, Plant-Based Man'oushe, and Vegan Mushroom Wrap. Coara also introduces the Meghle Tart, an innovative plant-based dessert perfect for gifting. Coara is more than just a restaurant; it‚Äôs a place to relax, savor moments, and engage in heartfelt conversations. The restaurant also hosts engaging events and offers a range of mouneh products and plant-based dairy alternatives. During the festive season, Coara brings together flavors and holiday cheer. Visit Coara's store or website at www.coara-eshop.com to explore their full range of organic and vegan offerings. Experience the beauty of plant-based cuisine in the heart of Lebanon‚Äôs mountains. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Vegan Cafeteria by Hayek Hospital: A Pioneer in Plant-Based HealthcareVegan Cafeteria by Hayek Hospital is the world's first vegan hospital cafeteria, established in 2021. Located at Hayek Hospital, it offers dine-in, take-away, and delivery options, providing healthy and delicious vegan food accessible to everyone. 





















  
  






  The cafeteria promotes health and well-being with its plant-based menu, crafted from fresh, locally-sourced ingredients that nourish the body and excite the taste buds. Signature dishes include Vegan Kofta and Potatoes, Vegan Shish Barak, Vegan Shawarma, and Vegan Mujaddara, offering a delightful twist on traditional flavors. Open from 7:30 AM to 3:30 PM, Monday to Saturday, the cafeteria focuses on vibrant, nutrient-rich meals that support sustainable, eco-friendly dining. Customers can enjoy a wholesome dining experience that is kind to both the planet and their well-being. For take-away and delivery, contact üì± 01 481 333 ext: 653. Experience the joy of flavorful, plant-based food at Vegan Cafeteria by Hayek Hospital. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Luna's Kitchen: A Vibrant Plant-Based Restaurant in HamraLuna's Kitchen is a vibrant 100% plant-based restaurant in Hamra, open from 10 AM to 2 AM, offering an exciting dining experience with games, live sports, an open stage, live music, a bar serving drinks and cocktails, and a pet-friendly environment.  





















  
  






  Start your day with offerings like a vegan brownie and espresso, or dive into their new menu items including Garlic Lovers Pizza, The Hot Dog, The Avocado Baguette, The Fig & Cheese Salad, and The Mushroom Rolls. Their Beyond Meat options feature dishes such as The Hot Dog with Soy Sausage, Spaghetti Meatballs with gluten-free/soy-free meatballs, Cheeseburger with Soy Patty, and Caesar Salad, Pesto Pasta, Alfredo Pasta, and Luna's Pasta with soy chick'n. Additionally, Luna's Kitchen introduces new additions like The Combo, Nachos, Zucchini Balls, Swiss Mushroom Burger, Avocado Toast, BLT, ChocoBa, Vegan Chick‚Äôn Burger, Penne Arrabiata, Sujuk Sandwich, and Mexican Burger. The restaurant aims to show that plant-based food can be both affordable and delicious.  





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Sendyani Vegan Caf√©: Savor the Vegan Way in Sarba, Jo√ºni√©





















  
  






  Sendyani Vegan Caf√© in Sarba, Jo√ºni√©, offers a delightful dining experience with a 100% vegan menu inspired by nature and friendly vibes. Open from Tuesday to Sunday, Sendyani emphasizes mindful eating and compassion for all living beings. Their menu includes highlights such as the Chickenless Burger, Tuna Sandwich Match, Vegan Garlic Cheese Bread, Go-To Bowl, Vegan Mozzarella Burger, Vegan Tawouk, Cruelty-Free Wings, JUST LIKE LAHME, Soujouk, Kebab Sandwich, Customized Eggplant Plate, and Vegan Wellington. The caf√© promotes nutrient-rich and incredibly tasty plant-based food, supporting healthier lifestyles. Contact them for delivery at 70 426 488 and visit to enjoy vibrant, tasty, and cruelty-free cuisine. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  Orenda, a cozy haven located in the vibrant neighborhood of Mar Mikhael, Beirut.





















  
  






  Orenda is a cozy caf√© and resto-bar in Mar Mikhael, Beirut, open from 1 PM to 12 AM. This plant-based haven invites you to bring friends, pets, and an appetite for cruelty-free cuisine. Orenda offers a warm and welcoming atmosphere with cozy corners and a garden perfect for gatherings. Their menu features innovative plant-based dishes like the Beyond Meat Burger, Vegan Chicken Tacos, Chicken Caesar Salad, Vegan Shawarma, Beetroot Carpaccio Salad, Musakhan Rolls, and Tuna Melt Wrap. Seasonal delights include fresh ceviche and bolognese pasta, best enjoyed with a glass of white wine. Orenda is an ideal setting for private events, from birthdays to joyful gatherings. For more information and reservations, call 03927886. Visit Orenda to experience plant-based cuisine and heartfelt connections in a serene environment. 





















  
  














































  

    
  
    

      

      
        
          
        
        

        
          
            
          
            
                
                
                
                
                
                
                
                

            
          
        
          
        

        
      
        
      

    
  


  





  ConclusionLebanon's vegan restaurant scene is thriving, with each establishment offering unique flavors and experiences. From the serene atmosphere of Jinan Healthy Kitchen to the vibrant and activist-driven Lebanese Vegans Social Hub, the warm welcome at Kamakan, the scenic charm of Coara Vegan Cuisine, the pioneering Vegan Cafeteria by Hayek Hospital, the lively ambiance of Luna's Kitchen, the friendly vibes at Sendyani Vegan Caf√©, and the cozy haven of Orenda, there is something for every vegan enthusiast. Embrace the joy of plant-based dining and explore these exceptional vegan restaurants in Lebanon, where every meal is a step towards a kinder, healthier and more sustainable lifestyle.

author: Aman Singh
title: Struggling to Hit Your Protein Goals on a Vegan Diet?
text:
Switching to a vegan diet was one of the most rewarding decisions I‚Äôve ever made, but like many, I initially worried about getting enough protein. If you‚Äôre reading this, you might be feeling the same. Rest assured, hitting your protein goals on a vegan diet isn‚Äôt as hard as it seems‚Äîonce you know where to look and how to plan, it becomes second nature. 



Let‚Äôs dive into how you can fuel your body with plant-based protein while still enjoying delicious, satisfying meals. 







Why is Protein So Important?



Protein is the building block of our muscles, skin, and hair, and it even supports your immune system. Whether you‚Äôre working out, chasing kids around, or simply trying to stay healthy, protein gives you the strength and energy you need. 



When I first went vegan, I realized that plant-based protein wasn‚Äôt just ‚Äúgood enough‚Äù‚Äîit could easily match or surpass my previous diet in quality and variety. 







My Go-To Plant-Based Protein Sources



Here are some of my personal favorites that help me hit my protein goals every day: 




Legumes I love making big batches of lentils, chickpeas, or black beans at the start of the week. They‚Äôre perfect for soups, salads, or even tossing into pasta.





Lentils: 18g protein per cup (cooked)



Chickpeas: 15g protein per cup (cooked)





Tofu, Tempeh, and Edamame These are lifesavers. I usually marinate tofu or tempeh overnight and air-fry or stir-fry them for a quick protein-packed meal.





Tofu: 10g protein per 1/2 cup



Tempeh: 15g protein per 1/2 cup



Edamame: 17g protein per cup (cooked)





Quinoa and Other Grains Did you know quinoa is a complete protein? I like to mix it with roasted veggies and a tahini dressing for a quick, satisfying dinner.





Quinoa: 8g protein per cup (cooked)





Nuts and Seeds I always keep a jar of almond butter and a bag of chia seeds in my pantry. They‚Äôre great for smoothies, oatmeal, or even snacking.





Almonds: 6g protein per ounce



Chia seeds: 5g protein per 2 tablespoons





Plant-Based Protein Powders I‚Äôm not going to lie‚Äîthere are days when I‚Äôm rushing out the door, and a protein shake saves me. My go-to is a pea protein blend with frozen bananas and almond milk.








How I Plan My Meals to Hit Protein Goals



If you‚Äôre like me and love a bit of structure, here‚Äôs a typical day of meals: 




Breakfast: A big bowl of oatmeal topped with chia seeds, almond butter, and fresh fruit. Sometimes, I make a tofu scramble with veggies if I‚Äôm craving something savory.



Lunch: A quinoa salad loaded with chickpeas, kale, avocado, and a zesty lemon-tahini dressing.



Snacks: Roasted chickpeas or a handful of mixed nuts always keep me satisfied between meals.



Dinner: Stir-fried tempeh with broccoli, carrots, and edamame, served over brown rice.



Post-Workout: My favorite recovery smoothie: pea protein powder, spinach, frozen mango, and almond milk.








Lessons I‚Äôve Learned About Vegan Protein




Don‚Äôt Stress About Perfection When I first started, I worried about getting ‚Äúcomplete proteins‚Äù in every meal. But guess what? Your body is smart‚Äîit combines amino acids from everything you eat throughout the day.



Meal Prep Makes Life Easier I‚Äôm a big fan of batch cooking. Having prepped lentils, grains, and veggies in the fridge saves so much time during the week.



It‚Äôs Okay to Lean on Convenience Foods While I love cooking, life gets busy. I‚Äôve learned to keep a stash of protein bars, frozen edamame, and even store-bought vegan burgers on hand for those hectic days.



You‚Äôll Discover Amazing New Foods Going vegan introduced me to foods I‚Äôd never tried before, like hemp seeds, nutritional yeast, and tempeh. They‚Äôre now staples in my kitchen.








Busting the Myths About Vegan Protein




Myth 1: You Can‚Äôt Build Muscle on a Vegan Diet



Truth: There are countless vegan athletes proving this wrong every day. Personally, I‚Äôve felt stronger and more energized since going plant-based.



Myth 2: You‚Äôll Always Feel Hungry



Truth: Plant-based proteins are incredibly filling, especially when paired with fiber-rich foods like veggies and whole grains.








You‚Äôve Got This!



Reaching your protein goals on a vegan diet isn‚Äôt just doable‚Äîit‚Äôs empowering. Once you get into the groove, you‚Äôll feel amazing knowing your meals are nourishing your body and aligning with your values. 



Whether you‚Äôre new to veganism or just looking to fine-tune your diet, remember that it‚Äôs all about progress, not perfection. Experiment with different recipes, enjoy the process, and trust that you‚Äôre fueling your body the right way. 



 Let‚Äôs inspire each other to stay strong and healthy.

author: Michael B.
title: Are Vegan Options Hurting The Challenge?
text:
The Battle of the Eras reunion had a random segment that looked at spicy comments Amanda made. One of these was a tweet where she expressed her disdain for the vegan options on the show. 



Clearly, this was targeted at Tori, who is a vegan and has allegedly had veganism written into her contract. So, Tori defended vegan options during eating challenges because there are equally gross foods that don‚Äôt hurt animals. Specifically, she pointed to the gross smoothie that they were forced to eat during Flying Around on the World Championship. 



The cast was split on this topic. Jordan said that being vegan is a choice, while Nehemiah (a devout vegan) thinks making the Challenge more inclusive of dietary needs is a good thing. 







If you‚Äôre a longtime Challenge fan, you‚Äôll know that eating challenges have historically involved meat or other non-vegan foods in some capacity. People have broken their vegan diets to compete over the years ‚Äî like Diem during the Battle of the Exes final, Kellyanne during the Family Dinner challenge on Bloodlines, or Nehemiah on the All Stars 3 final.  



Usually, these meaty meals appear to be gross, but they‚Äôre delicacies in other countries. Challenge seasons are set all over the world, but the locations often get ignored on more recent seasons. Sometimes, including these delicacies is the only real connection to the season‚Äôs setting, and relying on vegan-friendly foods can remove that connection.  



This can be seen on the Ride or Dies final when the cast was eating spaghetti and ice cream in Argentina.  







For many people, this is the turning point when veganism replaced meaty cultural dishes in the final. Likely because this is the season when Tori mentioned her vegan diet and it started to get discussed online.  



This forced Tori to be the face of Challenge vegans, even though there have been many others before her. In actuality, Tori likely isn‚Äôt the first person to demand a vegan option on the show. 



On The Challenge: USA ‚Äî the season filmed directly before Ride or Dies ‚Äî the final included an eating portion. This season was also filmed in Argentina, and the cast had to eat onions, garlic, and lemon juice. Most people found this disgusting, but vegan chef Angela had a delicious snack as she gleefully poured lemon juice on the onion. 







Likely, Angela is the vegan trailblazer. Veganism is part of her online brand, so it‚Äôs awfully suspicious that she was in the first final to skip the meat. 



This season set the precedent, and most of the eating challenges since then have been much less disgusting. Rather, they rely on massive quantities, super spicy foods, and smelly dishes. It should be noted that meat isn‚Äôt entirely off the menu; we saw tuna smoothies on Battle for a New Champion. It‚Äôs only omitted if one of the competitors doesn‚Äôt eat meat. 



I don‚Äôt think meat is necessary to make the challenge difficult, but the eating portion is supposed to be an equalizer. Allowing a small group of people to have influence on the menu kind of defeats the purpose. Usually, this also removes any cultural significance of the food and replaces it with dishes that are merely uncomfortable.  



At this point on The Challenge, the entertainment value of eating competitions is almost gone. It might just be better to exclude eating challenges altogether if the regional dishes aren‚Äôt vegan. Luckily, Vietnam had soy-based foods and durian to gross out people on season 40, but the vegan dilemma is probably the reason we didn‚Äôt see a real eating portion on the Battle of the Eras final in the Philippines.
tags: ["The Challenge","Amanda Garcia","Angela Rummans","Diem Brown","Jordan Wiseley","Kellyanne Judd","Nehemiah Clark","Tori Deal"]

title: Shocking Los Angeles Fires! [Blog #34]
text: The average global temperature has reached 1.6¬∞C above preindustrial levels, highlighting the urgent impact of climate change. Significant greenhouse gas emissions stem from animal agriculture. A shift to plant-based diets, supported by policy changes and consumer education, is essential for addressing this issue and promoting sustainable food systems.

author: Unknown
title: The Easiest Way to Eat Vegan? Go Global With Your Pantry
text: Ah, veganism. That magical land where people assume you live off lettuce and sad tofu while wistfully staring at other people‚Äôs cheeseburgers. If you've ever considered eating more plant-based meals but gave up because you thought it required monk-like discipline and an affinity for plain quinoa, I have excellent news: You‚Äôre doing it wrong. The easiest way to eat vegan isn‚Äôt by chaining yourself to the ‚Äúhealth aisle‚Äù at your local grocery store or committing to a lifetime of kale smoothies (though if that‚Äôs your jam, no judgment). The secret? Go global. That‚Äôs right. The simplest, most delicious, and least soul-crushing way to enjoy a vegan diet is to embrace international cuisine. Because, guess what? The world‚Äôs best plant-based meals were never designed to be sad replacements for meat‚Äîthey were just naturally perfect without it. So, let‚Äôs ditch the expensive, ultra-processed faux meats and dive headfirst into a pantry that can actually make your taste buds happy. 1. Step Away from the Bland and Step Into the Spice MarketFirst things first, let‚Äôs talk about what most people get wrong about vegan food: the lack of flavor. If you‚Äôve been suffering through unseasoned chickpeas and boiled vegetables, I have two words for you: spice rack. The reason people think vegan food is boring is because they refuse to season it properly. But global cuisines? Oh, they don‚Äôt play that game. From Indian curries bursting with cumin, turmeric, and garam masala to Ethiopian stews simmered in fiery berbere spice blends, the world has already figured out how to make plants taste amazing. So, if you‚Äôre serious about this, stock your pantry with cumin, coriander, smoked paprika, cardamom, turmeric, ginger, fennel seeds, sumac, and, for the love of all things flavorful, chili flakes. Your food should slap, not whisper. 2. Legumes: The OG Protein SourceIf one more person asks where vegans get their protein, I might stage an intervention. Before the world became obsessed with protein powders, entire civilizations were thriving off lentils, beans, and chickpeas‚Äîwithout feeling the need to blend them into a sad vanilla-flavored shake. Middle Eastern cuisine has hummus and ful medames. Ethiopian food has misir wat. Indian cuisine has dal in more variations than you have excuses for not cooking it. Mexican dishes revolve around beans that taste like actual joy. You‚Äôre not suffering. You‚Äôre just not using your pantry correctly. Keep your shelves stocked with red lentils, green lentils, black beans, kidney beans, chickpeas, and split peas‚Äîand learn how to actually cook them with spices instead of just boiling them into oblivion. 3. Rice, Noodles, and Flatbreads: Because You‚Äôre Not a RabbitLet‚Äôs kill this myth that vegan eating is all about munching raw vegetables like a sad, domesticated rabbit. The truth? Some of the most satisfying, carby, and downright indulgent meals on the planet are already vegan (or just a tweak away). Think Thai curries over jasmine rice, Vietnamese pho (easily made with vegetable broth and tofu), Ethiopian injera with rich, spicy lentil stews, Middle Eastern mujadara (lentils and rice with caramelized onions), Japanese miso ramen, and Indian dosas filled with spiced potatoes. None of these dishes make you feel like you‚Äôre sacrificing a thing. Why? Because they were already designed to be delicious. 4. Fermented Foods: Because Flavor is a LifestyleIf you‚Äôre going global with your pantry, you need to get into fermented foods. These umami-packed flavor bombs take plant-based meals from ‚Äúmeh‚Äù to ‚Äúholy crap, this is amazing.‚Äù A few must-haves: Miso paste (Japanese) ‚Äì Stir it into soups, marinades, and dressings. Kimchi (Korean) ‚Äì Fermented spicy cabbage that makes every rice dish sing. Soy sauce/tamari (Chinese/Japanese) ‚Äì Because bland food is a crime. Sambal oelek (Indonesian) ‚Äì A chili paste that‚Äôs not playing around. Preserved lemons (North African/Middle Eastern) ‚Äì Add them to tagines, stews, and salads for an instant upgrade. Fermented black beans (Chinese) ‚Äì A deeply funky, salty ingredient that makes stir-fries and braised dishes unforgettable. 5. Coconut Milk & Nut Butters: Because Creaminess MattersOne of the biggest misconceptions about vegan food is that it‚Äôs always light and boring. Nope. Global cuisine already knows how to make plant-based meals rich, creamy, and decadent‚Äîwithout relying on dairy. Enter coconut milk. Whether it‚Äôs simmering in a Thai curry, enriching a Caribbean rice dish, or forming the base of a creamy Indian korma, this is an MVP in any plant-based kitchen. Then, there‚Äôs nut butters. If you‚Äôve never added peanut butter to a West African groundnut stew or tahini to a Middle Eastern dressing, you‚Äôre seriously missing out. Almond butter, cashew cream, and sesame paste are here to ensure you never have to endure a sad, watery soup ever again. 6. Fresh Herbs & Citrus: The Ultimate Game-ChangersHere‚Äôs a hard truth: If your food feels ‚Äúmeh,‚Äù it probably just needs fresh herbs and a squeeze of citrus. Thai food isn‚Äôt complete without fresh basil and lime. Mediterranean dishes sing with mint and parsley. Mexican food without fresh cilantro and lime juice is an actual crime. Indian chutneys made from fresh coriander and mint elevate any meal instantly. The point? Keep your fridge stocked with cilantro, mint, parsley, basil, and green onions. Then, make sure you have lemons, limes, and vinegars (like rice vinegar, balsamic, and apple cider) on hand at all times. They‚Äôll save any dish from being basic. 7. Sauces & Condiments: Because You Deserve More Than KetchupLet‚Äôs be real: No one wants to eat plain rice and beans every day. The real secret to making vegan food addictive? Sauces. Some absolute essentials: Harissa (North African) ‚Äì A fiery chili paste that makes everything better. Gochujang (Korean) ‚Äì Sweet, spicy, and fermented magic. Tahini (Middle Eastern) ‚Äì A nutty, creamy dream for sauces and dressings. Chili crisp (Chinese) ‚Äì Crunchy, spicy, umami-packed goodness. Hoisin sauce (Chinese) ‚Äì Think of it as a sweet, thick, Asian BBQ sauce. Tamarind paste (South Asian/Southeast Asian) ‚Äì Adds a tart, sweet depth to curries and sauces. Final Thoughts: Veganism Doesn‚Äôt Have to Be a PunishmentAt the end of the day, going plant-based doesn‚Äôt mean you have to suffer through bland, uninspired meals. The real trick is to stop thinking like a vegan and start thinking like a global foodie. So, stock your pantry with flavors from around the world, learn how to actually season your food, and stop pretending tofu is supposed to taste like chicken. Because once you realize that the best plant-based dishes were never trying to be a sad imitation of something else, you‚Äôll never feel like you‚Äôre ‚Äúmissing out‚Äù again. Now, go forth and season your food properly. Your taste buds deserve it.

author: Maryanne
title: Another one bites the meat (or How I was totally wrong about veganism)
text:
Some may hate this post and try to convince me otherwise. Others may rejoice and agree.  



This post is not a cry for support, because I‚Äôm such a strong person I don‚Äôt need anyone to validate me. Nor do I care if people try to hurt me or insult me. This is the result of years of meditation; you just don‚Äôt care what people think of you, it‚Äôs all irrelevant. 



I share because this is my journey, and perhaps my journey will inspire someone else. Or not.  



Only sociopaths think they are right all the time.  



I was wrong. Dead wrong.  



During my four years of being¬†vegan, I tried to remain neutral and of the mindset ‚Äúwe can all get along.‚Äù 



I only had one¬†vegan¬†necklace and one ‚Äúf*ck eating animals‚Äù t-shirt. 



I didn‚Äôt go on any protests or vandalize anything. 



But I‚Äôm upset about two things: 




I had my photo taken by PETA holding a ‚ÄúMeat is Murder‚Äù sign at a Morrissey concert.



Telling countless people how great I felt being¬†vegan. (I also look much younger than my age and have great skin ‚Äî which I inherited; it wasn‚Äôt because I was¬†vegan). People were listening to me for that reason. 




Now I feel so guilty. I feel like an imposter. I gave out wrong information about how great it was being¬†vegan. 



For the first few years it actually was great. Then out of nowhere I was depressed for no reason at all! You read my blogs. I have it all, the great life, the amazing husband, career. To get up in the morning and not want to do the things you love and it‚Äôs all an effort. That is no way for anyone to live. And then my skin started drying out (something I never had a problem with) and I had lower backaches and joint pain.  



I said to my husband, ‚ÄúI think I‚Äôm going to add back fish.‚Äù  



I‚Äôm here now, just two weeks of adding back fish, eggs, chicken, grass-fed beef, and raw goat‚Äôs milk yogurt and butter (which I order from a farm).  Mentally I‚Äôm feeling amazing. I have my lust for life back. I‚Äôm happy go lucky me again. No more back pain and my skin is getting soft again.  



I watched many YouTube videos ‚ÄúWhy I‚Äôm no longer¬†vegan.‚Äù That helped me so much, as well as the testimonials on Reddit. Every day another person questions veganism it seems.  



These people don‚Äôt know me, but I want them to know how much I appreciate their honesty and bravery for coming forward. They are all godsends. I was told I was brave too.  



Years ago when I was vegetarian and then added meat back for the first time in 28 years, I lost ‚Äúfriends‚Äù and was verbally abused with comments like ‚Äúpeace begins on your plate‚Äù and a woman shoving an anti-butter article in my face, the same woman who came to one of my paleo lectures and challenged me from the audience. These people were not my friends.  



At the time, I felt so good adding the meat back, I should have stuck to that protocol. Then I got brainwashed into¬†veganism¬†again. I frequent a lot of health food stores and go to health expos, and there are¬†vegans¬†everywhere. I saw¬†vegan¬†athletes and told myself, if they are athletes and thriving, I can do this too because I love animals ‚Äî so I went¬†vegan¬†again with help from a¬†vegan¬†health coach.  



Now I know different, that animals die no matter what diet you‚Äôre on ‚Äî and I felt like garbage anyway. It‚Äôs a lose/lose. Do I continue to be a martyr for the animals, while my own cats pick up on my stress?  



But wait‚Ä¶.the truth is: VEGANISM KILLS ANIMALS. 



Yes, you heard that right. Veganism kills animals. More animals than the meat and dairy industry does.  



Also researching and learning how the agriculture industry kills so many rabbits, mice, etc., I accepted the hard truth that animals die for our food. Those fields are just as disturbing as the slaughter house. I‚Äôve seen the video footage and photos. And you can too by doing a search on YouTube.  



In a Utopian world, we‚Äôd all live happily among each other, and wouldn‚Äôt need animals to survive, but it‚Äôs not that way. We have to disassociate from the animals at large and just worry about our own pets. (My mom was a heart patient and an animal valve helped her live longer. And she loved animals, feeding the squirrels outside in her wheelchair in her later years before she passed). 



Other hard facts 




Organic vegetables. What is in the soil? Chicken bones, manure, compost. So much for vegan. 



In order for anyone to eat ‚Äî human or animal ‚Äî another animal dies. It‚Äôs a sad hard truth and the sooner you disassociate from the source of your food, the better off you‚Äôll be mentally. 




And before my vegan friends get mad at me, please read my words ‚ÄúMOST‚Äù not ‚ÄúALL‚Äù 



Sadly, MOST vegans do not think out of the box, it‚Äôs their way or the highway. They live by a script they refuse to deviate from. They are like heartless robots with no compassion. (I can share my negative views about visiting the PETA house, but I‚Äôll save that for another time). Vegans who are not heartless and judgmental, I feel are the exception to the rule ‚Äî as I was when vegan. Honestly, I never fit in with vegan culture and argued with many vegans because of their strict views.  



During my time as a vegan I remained friends with meat eaters, never pushed my vegan views on my family, never went on an illegal protest. I am proud of myself for that (Personally, because again I am not seeking acceptance with this blog post. It is not important).  



Worse of all, I do not like that vegans who force their cats to eat a vegan diet, which is not right. Cats can not be vegan. I never fed my cats vegan during my time as a vegan. (Though one of them loves pumpkin, that‚Äôs a treat, not a meal). 



And let me tell you another thing about vegans and cats ‚Ä¶.. 



Vegans hate cats. (Extreme vegans) 



They do not like animals who eat other animals.  



I tried so hard to get PETA to take down an influencer who was abusing her cat by teasing it and then sharing the videos of the cat hissing on Instagram and YouTube, thinking it was funny. All the evidence was there. She was easy to track down. 



PETA lied and said they were on it. They weren‚Äôt. They did NOTHING!  



Even if their petitions seem legit, don‚Äôt sign them. PETA is useless. And I hate myself for posing with a Meat is Murder sign at a Morrissey concert and they took photos of me.  



That‚Äôs one of my biggest vegan regrets. Even more regretful than getting sick on veganism.  



There‚Äôs a story about a vegan woman (you can Google and find it yourself, I‚Äôm not making this up) who fed her cat a vegan diet. Again, cats can not be vegan! She went out and the cat ate the hamster.  



Of course the cat ate the hamster. The poor sweet thing was starved for nutrition. You do not feed cats lettuce and expect a good result.  



So what did this nut case do? She took the cat to be euthanized!  



She said, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt have a cat. They eat other animals.‚Äù And she took the poor thing to be put down. Unbelievable!! How is that vegan? How is that not animal cruelty?  



The vegan hypocrisy goes on and on and on and on and on.  



Vegans do not love animals. They only love farm animals. (Or so they think).  



Duped by veganism.  



In the past two weeks of being non-vegan, the more I research and learn, I am disappointed at the vegan community for all the lies they spread (whether intentional, or in my case as a vegan ignorance). I wish I did all the research before going vegan again back in 2021. My husband used to joke, ‚ÄúShe‚Äôs a vegan but she hates vegans.‚Äù I thought that was hilarious. We had so many laughs over that with non-vegans.  



Why I was a vegan who disliked other vegans 



How they won‚Äôt listen to reasoning. How they judge everyone. How they argue so harshly and say the most vile things to people who aren‚Äôt vegan. They make stuff up just to win arguments and attack you personally, making stuff up. 



But more scary, AI and Google are not ideal for information. You have to talk to people and dig.  



If you‚Äôre considering being an ex-vegan 



If you‚Äôre considering being an ex-vegan, I highly recommend the book ‚ÄúThe Vegetarian Myth‚Äù by Lierre Keith. It‚Äôs an eye opener. The back of the book has an extensive bibliography backing up everything she wrote.   



I can‚Äôt turn back time, but I‚Äôm sorry I was ever vegan. Though I‚Äôm proud that I didn‚Äôt judge people and never let veganism taint my friendships with non-vegans; and that I still dined with non-vegans and never judged what was on their plates. 



I‚Äôll continue using cruelty free vegan make-up products because that‚Äôs what I was doing since the 1990s. Unless I learn otherwise, because I‚Äôm on a constant quest to up my game in all areas of my life.  



At first, I thought I‚Äôd always be a ‚Äúvegan at heart.‚Äù But I have to disagree with that mindset because it‚Äôs just not a good movement. There‚Äôs a vegan script you have to go by, and any deviation or questioning ‚Äî even if you‚Äôre vegan ‚Äî you‚Äôll get nailed to the cross. What does that say? Cult.  



This is all a learning experience. I‚Äôm now buying all my food from farms and mom and pop health food stores. I no longer go to Whole Foods or other supermarkets. Instead of supporting vegan restaurants, I‚Äôm now supporting farm-to-table restaurants. 



I‚Äôm looking forward to the day when I can ditch all the vegan supplements, save money, and just live my life without worrying about what nutrient I‚Äôm missing because I‚Äôm not eating right. Two weeks of being non-vegan may be too soon to give up on supplements, but I‚Äôll know when the time is right. 



Veganism is dropping by the masses  



I‚Äôm in a few anti-vegan groups now on social media. Every single day there‚Äôs at least one person saying they are no longer vegan. It‚Äôs a dying culture. Celebrities who were long time vegans are dropping out. Athletes admit they can‚Äôt be vegan anymore. I know someone personally who said they couldn‚Äôt be vegan because it gave them brain fog.  



Even supermarkets like Trader Joe‚Äôs and Whole Foods are ditching their vegan products because people aren‚Äôt buying them like they used to.  



Anthony William aka The Medical Medium (a diet heavy on fruits and protein in the evening only) had a video saying that veganism is going to be out by 2025. Which of course is this year.  



Ex vegans in the limelight include: Steve O, Miley Cyrus, Russell Brand, and Lizzo.  



Natalie Portman became an ex-vegan while pregnant.  



You can truly go down an ex-vegan rabbit hole. I‚Äôm finding more ex-vegan stuff everywhere than I see vegan stuff.  



I can go on and on, but choose to stop here.  



Again, if someone wants to send me hate mail, don‚Äôt waste your time because, again, I‚Äôm not affected by it and you won‚Äôt change my mind nor make me upset. Save your energy.  



Last but not least, do not call me a ‚Äúmurderer‚Äù because technically you are too. Unless you‚Äôre living on air, an animal had to die for your food, including your vegan food.  



And if you want to tell me I was never really vegan, I won‚Äôt argue with you. Maybe deep down I never really was.  



Contact Maryanne Christiano-Mistretta at: maryannechristiano@gmail.com
tags: ["Uncategorized","anti-vegan","diet","duped by veganism","food","health","how i was wrong about veganism","i was a vegan who disliked other vegans","inspiration","lierre keith","lizzo","miley cyrus","motivation","natalie protman","no longer vegan","not vegan","peta is a cult","raw milk","russell brand","steve o","the vegetarian myth","vegan","veganism","veganism is a cult"]

author: HOMEMAKERS Editor
title: Why You Should Consider Going Vegan.
text:
Decided it‚Äôs time for a lifestyle change? 

 
Here‚Äôs why you should consider going vegan.
 
 
There‚Äôs plenty of good to be said about reducing our meat consumption. Not only is it beneficial for the planet, but it‚Äôs also great for your health‚Äîand even your pocket. As with most things in life, you can either dive straight in and go cold turkey (pardon the pun) or ease into it with something like embracing Meat-Free Mondays. 
We spoke to well-known vegan chef, Chef Sue, about her journey and the advice she has for those just starting their vegetarian adventure and why she thinks you should consider going vegan. Chef Sue explains: 
‚ÄúI started my vegan journey nine years ago. After a festive season of overindulgence, I decided to sign up for Veganuary and try a plant-based diet. It turned out to be one of the best decisions I‚Äôve ever made‚ÄîI felt so energetic and good! As a South African entrepreneur and vegan chef, I‚Äôm thrilled to share my passion and explain the transformative benefits of this lifestyle. It‚Äôs good for your health, your pocket, the planet, and animal welfare.‚Äù 
Budget-Friendly Tips
Veganism is one of the most affordable diets to follow. To keep it budget-friendly, stock up on staples like lentils, beans, rice, and grains in bulk to reduce costs significantly. Shop for seasonal fruits and vegetables, and consider starting your own veggie garden‚Äîit‚Äôs rewarding and economical. Additionally, meal planning and cooking in batches can help stretch your food budget further. 
¬† 
A Flavourful Adventure Awaits
One of the most common misconceptions about veganism is that it lacks flavour and variety. ‚ÄúAs a chef, I can assure you that the world of plant-based cuisine is bursting with creativity and inspiration,‚Äù exclaims Chef Sue. ‚ÄúImagine vibrant dishes celebrating the rich tapestry of global flavours‚Äîfrom spicy Indian curries to hearty Italian pastas and everything in between.‚Äù 
Embracing a new diet is an opportunity to explore unique ingredients and cooking techniques. Chef Sue encourages: ‚ÄúExperiment with spices, fresh herbs, and seasonal vegetables that may never have crossed your plate before. You might find yourself whipping up a mouthwatering chickpea and lentil curry or indulging in a decadent vegan chocolate brownie made from sweet potato. The possibilities are endless, and I guarantee every meal will be a delightful discovery.‚Äù 
¬† 
Health Benefits You Can Feel
Transitioning to a vegan diet can have profound health benefits. Research shows that a well-planned vegan diet can reduce the risk of chronic diseases, including heart disease, diabetes, and certain cancers. By incorporating more fruits, vegetables, whole grains, legumes, and nuts into your meals, you‚Äôll be fuelling your body with essential nutrients and antioxidants that promote overall well-being. 
For those who feel overwhelmed by the idea of going vegan, remember it‚Äôs a journey. Start simple. Try one or two plant-based meals a week, then gradually expand your repertoire. You‚Äôll be amazed at how quickly your taste buds adapt and how much energy you‚Äôll gain from this wholesome way of eating. 
¬† 
A Sustainable Choice for the Planet
In a world increasingly affected by climate change, every small action counts. Adopting a vegan diet is one of the most impactful choices you can make for the environment. 
Chef Sue explains: ‚ÄúAs a South African entrepreneur, I am passionate about advocating for local and sustainable farming practices. By embracing veganism, you also support local farmers and businesses that prioritise ethical and sustainable food production.‚Äù 
Where to Start
If you‚Äôre unsure where to begin, visit Chef Sue‚Äôs website or her vegan restaurant, where the joy of plant-based cooking is celebrated. They offer a variety of dishes highlighting the vibrant flavours of South African cuisine‚Äîall made with love and creativity. 
‚ÄúAs we embark on this new year, I invite you to embrace veganism with an open heart and mind. Explore the deliciousness of plant-based cuisine, prioritise your health, support the planet, and practice compassion‚Äù Chef Sue says. 
Whether you go fully vegan or try a few plant-based meals, every step counts. Let‚Äôs make this year a celebration of flavours, health, and kindness, paving the way for a more sustainable and compassionate future. 
¬† 
‚ÄúTogether, we can make a difference‚Äîone meal at a time.‚Äù
‚Äì The Vegan Chef, Chef Sue
¬† 
Catch Chef Sue at the Homemakers Fair!
Chef Sue will share her vegan wisdom, tips, and hacks at this year‚Äôs Homemakers Fair. Visit her in the Food Theatre in Hall A from Friday, 28 February, to Sunday, 2 March. 
Read more about the expo here. 
FREE Delicious Vegan Recipe!
Chef Sue from The Vegan Chef has shared one of her most mouthwatering vegan recipes with us! 
Discover the most delectable recipe for Roasted Spicy Cabbage Wedges with Creamy Bean Pur√©e that‚Äôs sure to tantalise your tase buds. 
Find the full recipe here. 
¬†
