author: Charlotte Pointing
title: Is a Plant-Based Diet the Best for Senior Health?
text:
In stark contrast to much of the Western world, people who live on the Greek island of Ikaria have a good chance of making it into their 90s in good health. Experts speculate there are a few reasons for this. One is regular exercise (Ikaria is mountainous, so just visiting a shop is physically demanding). Another is a strong sense of community, which keeps rates of depression low. And another is diet. 
Jump to the foods 
Ikaria is one of the world‚Äôs five official Blue Zones. Like Okinawa in Japan and Nicoya in Costa Rica, its population follows a 95 to 100 percent plant-based diet. And we‚Äôre not talking vegan meats and processed foods, but rather fresh fruits, leafy greens, grains, beans, and legumes. 
So is a plant-based, whole-food diet the best for senior health? If Blue Zones are anything to go by, it certainly appears that way. Here, we take a closer look at why. 
Diet and aging
Research confirms that as we age, the type of food we eat becomes more important than ever. That‚Äôs because bodies start to change as they get older; muscles, bones, and organs need more support from vital nutrients.¬† 
Thinning skin, for example, is a common symptom of aging. But this makes it harder to absorb vitamin D from the sun. Vitamin D is important for calcium absorption, so this, in turn, can lead to a calcium deficiency. Both of these nutrients can be topped up through diet. 
Wellness Gallery Catalyst Foundation | Pexels 
Protein is also key, as it helps to preserve muscle mass. Without it, elderly people are at a greater risk of muscle deterioration, which can lead to mobility issues and slower recovery from illness. One study, published in The Journals of Gerontology, found that out of 2,900 senior people, those who ate the most protein were 30 percent less likely to become functionally impaired.¬† 
Potassium, omega-3, magnesium, and iron are also common deficiencies in older people. According to the British Geriatrics Society, 30 percent of people aged over 85 in the UK have anemia. 
A plant-based diet supports senior health
Diet can help to play a role in maintaining optimal senior health, which, may, in turn, reduce the risk of certain diseases. 
The World Health Organization notes that the risk of dementia, for example, is lowered when people follow a nutritious diet and limit their alcohol intake, among other healthy behaviors. And the Alzheimer‚Äôs Society acknowledges evidence that a diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and cereals, and low in red meat and sugar, may help to reduce the risk of developing the disease.¬† 
Adobe 

Research also suggests that a diet high in plant foods can reduce the risk of heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and some types of cancer, all of which are common causes of death among elderly people.¬† 
‚ÄúWhile some people may be tempted to believe that veganism is a diet for young people, the fact is that there are many benefits to eating vegan foods for seniors,‚Äù says registered dietitian Amber Dixon, MPH‚Äîwho is also a geriatric nurse and founder of Elderly Guides, a platform that provides health resources for seniors and their families. 
She reiterated that it may reduce the risk of dementia, as well as help people to maintain their weight. ‚ÄúEating vegan means you will be getting plenty of fiber and complex carbohydrates,‚Äù she notes. ‚ÄúWhich helps you feel fuller longer and also helps regulate blood sugar levels.‚Äù 
Are more seniors in the West looking to plant-based foods?
In general, the stereotypical boomer approach to food is healthier than modern diets. It makes sense: they grew up at a time when ultra-processed foods were scarce and most meals were cooked from scratch. ‚ÄúDiets were generally healthier than today, with people eating more vegetables and milk, and far less fat and sugar,‚Äù Katherine Howells, PhD, of The National Archives in the UK, told Metro. ‚ÄúPeople were more aware of the importance of seasonal produce, having been involved in growing vegetables during the war.‚Äù 
Back then, people did eat meat, but it was nowhere near as much as we eat today. Research suggests, for example, that a serving of meat would have been around 100 grams, and this would have been shared with all of the family members. But as boomers age, their diets are changing. Some are eating more processed foods, but others are leaning towards vegetarian and vegan diets.¬† 
Canva 
According to Vegetarian for Life (a UK nonprofit dedicated to supporting senior citizens who follow vegan or vegetarian diets), more than 31 percent of care homes in the UK currently have at least one vegetarian resident. This is a significant rise since 2014 when more than 22 percent of care homes had a vegetarian in residence. According to Vegetarian for Life, the numbers are set to grow even more. By 2031, the nonprofit notes the number of vegetarian residents could double. 
Vegan diets are less common in UK care homes, but they are still present ‚Äî the research noted that 2.6 percent of care homes have at least one vegan resident, and this is also set to grow in the coming years. By 2031, Vegetarian for Life notes that there could be 2,400 people in British care homes who follow a vegan diet. This is why the nonprofit is urging care homes across the UK to partner with nutritionists to offer more balanced plant-based meals to their residents.¬† 
This shift is not just happening in the UK, but in the US, too. For example, in 2020, data from Gallup noted that more than a quarter of Americans aged over 65 had tried plant-based meat.¬† 
Vegan diet for senior health
There are various types of vegan diets. For example, a diet that consists solely of French fries and plant-based doughnuts isn‚Äôt packed with nutrition, but it‚Äôs still vegan. For optimal senior health (and other ages, too), one specific type of vegan diet is recommended: whole foods, plant-based‚ÄîJust like the Ikarians. 
Like all people who follow a vegan diet, however, seniors may need to consider B12 supplementation. Research suggests that the likelihood of vitamin B12 deficiency increases with age, and affects six percent of people aged over 60. Vitamin B12 can be found in nutritional yeast and fortified cereals, but it is not found in fruits and vegetables. 
That said, a diet full of grains, leafy greens, beans, legumes, and other whole foods will help seniors get nearly all of the vital vitamins and minerals that are needed to help maintain good bone, muscle, and organ health.¬† 
The best foods for seniors, recommended by dietitians
Here are some of the best foods for seniors according to dietitians. 
Pexels 
1 High-protein foods, like tofu
‚ÄúTofu is one of the highest sources of protein amongst vegan foods,‚Äù registered dietitian Patricia Kolesa, MS RDN, says. This, she says, is because of seniors‚Äô higher protein needs. She notes that tofu, which contains roughly 8 grams of protein per 100 grams, ‚Äúcan be a helpful source in preventing the process of muscle breakdown.‚Äù 
‚ÄúProtein foods can also help with feeling full and satiated after a meal,‚Äù Kolesa adds. ‚ÄúAdditionally tofu is high in calcium, which can be helpful in maintaining strong bones in older populations that are at higher risk for fractures and arthritis.‚Äù 
For more guidance on how to cook with tofu, peruse our guide to the best preparation and cooking methods. Other high-protein vegan foods include tempeh, which has 19 grams of protein per 100 grams, and seitan, which has a whopping 75 grams of protein.¬† 
Pexels 
2 Beans and legumes
Kolesa also notes that beans are a good source of protein for older people. ‚ÄúCombined with rice, they can make for a complete protein,‚Äù she explains. Kidney beans are a particularly good source, with 24 grams of protein per a 100-gram serving. To find out which beans have the most protein, we‚Äôve created this handy bean guide covering everything from cannellini to edamame (plus high-protein recipes). 
But, protein aside, beans have other benefits, too. ‚ÄúBeans also contain fiber,‚Äù Kolesa says. ‚ÄúIn older populations, it can be more difficult to form a bowel movement and fiber can aid in the digestive process by helping to form poop and remove waste from the body. Another problem amongst seniors is anemia, which results from low iron. Beans are a huge source of iron and should be paired with a vitamin C food like red bell peppers for the body to best absorb it.‚Äù 
Dixon agrees that beans are a good source of nutrition for seniors, and also recommends other protein- and vitamin-rich legumes, like lentils and peas. ‚ÄúBeans and legumes are high in protein, fiber, and other nutrients that are important for seniors,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThey can be used in a variety of recipes and are easy to incorporate into everyday meals.‚Äù 
Unsplash 
3 Leafy greens
Dixon also recommends that seniors pack their diets with greens, like spinach and kale. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre high in vitamins A and C, which are important for eye health and preventing age-related vision loss,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThey also contain antioxidants that help fight free radicals, promote healthy skin, and reduce inflammation.‚Äù 
Other good examples are arugula, bok choy, cabbage, watercress, and romaine lettuce.¬† 
To pack in the leafy greens (with a side of all-important beans and legumes!), try this Zesty Vegan Salad With Blackened Chickpeas, this Vegan Spinach, Chickpea, and Lemon Pilaf, or this Vegan-Apple Chickpea Kale Salad With Mustard-Dill Dressing. 
Pexels 
4 Whole grains
Whole grains are another essential part of a balanced plant-based diet. They include foods like brown rice, wild rice, oats, barley, durum wheat, and rye. 
‚ÄúWhole grains provide many essential minerals and vitamins including calcium, magnesium, potassium, iron, zinc (which helps prevent anemia), selenium (which helps protect the immune system), B vitamins (which support energy production), chromium (which helps balance blood sugar levels), and manganese (which supports bone health),‚Äù Dixon notes. 
For examples of how to enjoy whole grains in your diet, check out this Vegan Garden Fried Rice, this Jamaican-Inspired Vegan Banana Oatmeal Porridge, or these Healthy Vegan Strawberry Chia Oat Bites. 
Unsplash 
5 A rainbow of fruits and vegetables
Other foods that can make up a healthy, whole foods, plant-based diet include berries, like bananas and strawberries, which are rich in vitamins like B6 and vitamin C, as well as colorful vegetables like peppers, sweet potatoes, butternut squash, beetroot, pumpkins, carrots, and more.¬† 
All of these examples have unique properties. Orange and yellow fruits and vegetables, for example, contain beta-carotene which is converted to vitamin A in the body. To maintain good health at any age, but particularly in the senior years, people should aim to, quite simply, make like Blue Zoners and eat the rainbow.

author: Aurora Quill
title: Keto diet, A complete Recipe guide for beginners.
text:
Keto diet, A complete Recipe guide for beginners.¬†
  
    
  
 
 
  
 The vegan keto diet is a plant-based, low-carb, high-fat diet that combines the principles of veganism and ketogenic eating. It can be challenging because vegan diets are naturally higher in carbs, but with proper planning, it‚Äôs possible to meet your nutritional needs while staying in ketosis.¬† Here‚Äôs everything you need to know.¬†Read More.¬† ¬†


  --- What is the Vegan Keto Diet? Vegan: Excludes all animal products (meat, dairy, eggs, etc.). Keto: Limits carbs (5-10% of daily calories), increases fats (70-80%), and includes moderate protein (10-20%).   --- Benefits of the Vegan Keto Diet 1. Weight Loss: Ketosis helps burn fat for energy.  2. Improved Blood Sugar Levels: Great for managing diabetes or insulin resistance.  3. Anti-Inflammatory Effects: Vegan foods like nuts, seeds, and vegetables reduce inflammation.  4. Heart Health: A plant-based approach can lower cholesterol and blood pressure.  5. Sustainability: Veganism supports ethical and environmental goals.    
  
    
  
  

  
  Challenges of a Vegan Keto Diet 1. Nutrient Deficiencies: Low intake of B12, iron, calcium, omega-3, and protein.  2. Restrictive: Limited food options due to avoiding both animal products and carbs.  3. Carb Control: Many vegan staples (grains, legumes, fruits) are high in carbs, making keto harder.    --- Foods to Eat on a Vegan Keto Diet Fats Avocados Coconut oil and coconut cream Olive oil Nut butters (almond, macadamia, etc.) Nuts (pecans, macadamias, walnuts) Seeds (chia, hemp, flax, sunflower)  Protein Sources Tofu and tempeh Seitan (if gluten is tolerated) Vegan protein powders (pea, hemp, or rice protein) Edamame (in moderation)  Low-Carb Vegetables Leafy greens (spinach, kale, lettuce) Zucchini, broccoli, cauliflower Mushrooms Asparagus, cucumber, and bell peppers  Plant-Based Dairy Alternatives Unsweetened almond milk Coconut yogurt (unsweetened) Vegan cheese made from nuts  Snacks Vegan keto fat bombs (coconut oil, cocoa, nut butter) Kale chips Roasted nuts and seeds   --- Foods to Avoid High-carb vegetables: Potatoes, sweet potatoes, corn. Grains: Rice, quinoa, oats, wheat, etc. Legumes: Lentils, chickpeas, black beans. Sugary foods: Fruits (except berries), sugary drinks.   --- Sample Vegan Keto Meal Plan


 Breakfast: Tofu scramble with avocado and saut√©ed spinach. Coconut milk smoothie with chia seeds and almond butter.  Lunch: Vegan keto salad (leafy greens, avocado, olives, pumpkin seeds, olive oil). Zucchini noodles with almond butter sauce and tofu.  Dinner: Cauliflower rice stir-fry with coconut cream, tempeh, and broccoli. Grilled eggplant with tahini sauce and hemp seeds.  Snacks: Handful of macadamia nuts. Vegan keto fat bomb (made with coconut oil and cocoa powder).   --- Supplements to Consider 1. Vitamin B12: Essential for vegans.  2. Iron: Plant-based sources may not be absorbed as efficiently.  3. Omega-3 Fatty Acids: From algae-based DHA/EPA supplements.  4. Calcium and Vitamin D: Especially important without dairy.    --- Tips for Success 1. Track Macros: Use apps like Cronometer to track carbs, fats, and proteins.  2. Meal Prep: Plan meals in advance to avoid carb-heavy vegan options.  3. Start Slow: Transition gradually to avoid the "keto flu."  4. Stay Hydrated: Drink plenty of water and replenish electrolytes.    --- Is the Vegan Keto Diet for You? The vegan keto diet may suit you if you‚Äôre motivated by health, weight loss, or ethical reasons, but it requires careful planning to avoid deficiencies. Would you like help designing recipes or meal plans?

author: Wonderman Diaries
title: Vegans Beware!
text:
¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†¬†The set of
friends we‚Äôve acquired since uprooting four years ago includes quite a few
vegans and, having heard their arguments in favour of a plant-based diet, I
have found myself taking tentative steps down that particular road to Damascus.
Although the ethical case for not eating other sentient beings is debatable,
the scientific case relating to better health for us and the environment is not.
And, as for best use of resources, it makes no sense to devote an estimated 36%
of the world‚Äôs grain production to feeding animals who, while being bred and
raised for slaughter, emit an awful lot of atmosphere-warming methane. 

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Our philosophy
discussion group began its new year on Tuesday with Socrates, whose principles
might have aligned him with ethical veganism, had it been proposed to him, but
that being the day after the presidential inauguration of the wannabe dictator,
Trump, our focus was on the decline of political ethics since the golden age of
Greece. When, in 380 AD, Emperor Theodosius mandated that Christianity must be
adopted throughout the Roman Empire, he effectively buried philosophical
discussion until the Renaissance. Now, faced with Trump‚Äôs triumphant onslaught
against the reasonable exchange of ideas, could we be in for a second Dark Age? 

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† Trump‚Äôs
vilification and stifling of opposition, along with his blatant attempts to
capture the institutions of state, are classic fascist tactics. His success (as
defined by winning the election) can be attributed, in part, to the paucity of
public education, insofar as it has kept enough of the voting population sufficiently
ignorant as to be easily manipulated. 

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† But the week
hasn‚Äôt been all doom and gloom. Professional Donald Trump impersonators are delighted
to be looking forward to four years of solid bookings. And, more widely, there
are the veteran Bob Dylan fans, like me, who bought tickets to a time-travelling
treat, A Complete Unknown, the biopic covering Dylan‚Äôs emergence in the
early sixties. The accuracy of some details in the film is questioned by experts
but, for me, it was enough that the overall re-creation of time, place and
events had sufficient credibility and more than enough atmosphere to elicit a
sometimes tearfully nostalgic response. As for Timothy Chalamet, his
impersonation/impression of Bob‚Äô singing and playing was astonishingly
convincing ‚Äì so unlike my amateur attempts in the heyday of my hopeful musical
ambition. So absorbing was the film that my Other Half, whose interest in Bob
has always been lukewarm and whom I suspect of having come along simply to see
Timothy Chalamet, afterwards admitted to having had something of a damascene
experience herself. 

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† I was at one
of Dylan‚Äôs Royal Albert Hall concerts in 1966, ten days or so after the more
famous Manchester gig at which a ‚Äòfolk purist‚Äô and erstwhile fan expressed his sense
of betrayal by shouting ‚ÄúJudas!‚Äù when Bob came onstage with his electric guitar
and backing band. The London audience was also divided but I sat on the fence,
more intrigued than outraged. In my view, Bob certainly had the last laugh. 

¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† As it turned
out, the week‚Äôs highlights were overshadowed by the constant stream of bad news
from the good old US of A, land of opportunity and centre of the free world, which
has seemingly acquired a king ‚Äì anointed by God when he diverted the assassin‚Äôs
bullet. Trump‚Äôs latest edicts include removing from official documentation the
option for citizens to register their sex as any other than either male or
female and denying the validity of those parts of the constitution that do not
serve his purpose, such as the 14th amendment, which grants US citizenship
to all those born in the USA. More ominous is the implementation of a Soviet
style ‚Äòsnitch‚Äô culture, whereby Federal employees are now obliged to inform on
colleagues they suspect of not whole-heartedly complying with Trump‚Äôs orders. At
this rate, it won‚Äôt be long before, at the behest of the agro-industry
lobbyists, Americans will be obliged to report anyone suspected of the
unpatriotic crime of veganism.

author: Lewis Bollard
title: In defense of the certifiers
text: The world‚Äôs three largest animal welfare groups are under attack. Their antagonists are not factory farmers, but other animal groups. And the ASPCA, HSUS, and RSPCA stand accused not of hurting farmers, but of hurting animals, through their work with GAP and RSPCA Assured, which certify animal products as being less cruelly produced. The attacks began last summer when the UK animal rights group Animal Rising released a report and footage showing abuses on RSPCA Assured farms. They‚Äôve since forced the RSPCA to cancel its 200th year celebrations, plastered portraits of RSPCA patron King Charles, and persuaded the ceremonial president and two vice-presidents of the RSPCA to resign in protest. (To understand their perspective, I recommend this interview with Animal Rising co-director Ben Newman.) A few months ago, PETA launched a new front in the war, taking out full-page ads in the The New York Times and The Washington Post slamming the ASPCA and HSUS for associating with GAP. (Ingrid Newkirk laid out PETA‚Äôs case here.) PETA activists have since picketed the homes of the CEOs of both groups, disrupted the organizations‚Äô fundraising events, and persuaded actor James Cromwell to throw away an HSUS award. ‚ÄúIt has to stop‚Äù is how I feel about PETA‚Äôs campaign against the ASPCA and HSUS. Image: PETA‚Äôs full-page ads in the New York Times and Washington Post. Source: PETA.With friends like these I originally planned to write a newsletter about infighting. I would have argued that our movement lacks the resources to spare some to attack one another. And I would have cited a 2023 survey by the Social Change Lab, in which 120 social movement academics rated ‚Äúinternal conflict or movement infighting‚Äù as the gravest internal threat to social movement success. But there‚Äôs an irony in criticizing infighting: you risk becoming an infighter yourself. And I‚Äôm hardly an impartial observer: I used to work at HSUS, and at Open Philanthropy we‚Äôve funded GAP, HSUS, the RSPCA, and RSPCA Assured ‚Äî but not Animal Rising or PETA. It‚Äôs too easy to decry infighting when it‚Äôs the other side doing it. So instead I‚Äôll refer you to my favorite scene in Monty Python‚Äôs Life of Brian, in which the People‚Äôs Front of Judea derides the Judean People‚Äôs Front. I also don‚Äôt want to attack Animal Rising or PETA. Animal Rising has mobilized thousands of young people to decry our society‚Äôs indifference to mass animal suffering. PETA put animal rights on the map, trained some of our movement‚Äôs best activists (including the CEO of HSUS), and won the first corporate cage-free victories. Instead, I want to engage with their criticisms of GAP and RSPCA Assured. Broadly, they make three: (1) the certifications are misleading, (2) they fail to stop cruelty, and (3) the involvement of the ASPCA, HSUS, and RSPCA legitimizes them ‚Äî and meat eating. I‚Äôll take each in turn. ‚ÄúHumanely raised‚Äù and misleadingly labeled Animal Rising and PETA are right about one thing: humane labels can be misleading. Put aside the semantic debate about whether meat can ever be ‚Äúhumane‚Äù; I suspect most consumers think certification labels mean more than they do. In a 2021 survey by Farm Forward, a GAP board member-turned-skeptic, 39% of respondents mistakenly thought that GAP labels mean that animals are raised with consistent access to the outdoors. Animal Rising also points out that the RSPCA Assured website claims ‚Äúwe do not allow factory farming on our scheme.‚Äù That‚Äôs a stretch. Most GAP and RSPCA Assured meat comes from higher-welfare indoor farms that still look an awful lot like factory farms. I‚Äôd prefer more specific labels. When GAP started, its labels listed welfare levels from one to five and explained what each level meant (‚ÄúStep 3, enhanced outdoor access‚Äù). But the labels now simply read ‚ÄúAnimal Welfare Certified,‚Äù regardless of the GAP level, perhaps because marketers at Whole Foods, which sells most GAP meat, saw that ambiguity doesn‚Äôt drive sales. The biggest obstacle to fixing this is that everyone else is doing it. Chicken certified by American Humane Certified, which has much weaker standards than GAP, is labeled ‚Äúhumanely raised on family farms.‚Äù This works: the same Farm Forward survey found that consumers thought that American Humane Certified was at least as strong as GAP. So if GAP weakens its label, consumers may just switch to worse meat with better labels. The answer is for the government to step in. The USDA recently tried to do so, but ultimately gave way to industry pressure to allow any label the industry believes is true. The EU and UK are considering bolder reforms: to create multi-tiered welfare labeling schemes, though the industry is lobbying to make them voluntary. For better models look to Denmark, whose three-tier scheme is voluntary but widely followed, and Germany, which just enacted a mandatory five-tier scheme for pork. In the meantime, retailers should stop the sale of misleadingly labeled meat. Whole Foods led the way in this, requiring all meat in stores to be labeled at its GAP levels. But while GAP was recently finalizing new stronger rules, Whole Foods announced that it would allow for other weaker, but better-sounding, meat certifications. The test for retailers should be simple: can consumers accurately work out the animals‚Äô welfare from the label? I suspect most current labels fail that standard. This chicken was not humanely raised on family farms or fed an optimal diet. Hormones and steroids weren‚Äôt added to that diet, but only because adding them to chicken feed is illegal. And the chicken likely suffered for lack of antibiotics in a wretched environment. But the label does look nice.Imperfect progress To Animal Rising and PETA, such label fixes are not enough. Their complaint is not just with GAP and RSPCA Assured‚Äôs labels, but the schemes themselves. They point out that the schemes‚Äô own standards allow for continued cruelties, like keeping animals permanently crowded in giant barns. This is true. But for me the question is not whether these certifications end all cruelty, but whether they reduce it. They do: their standards prohibit some of the worst cruelties common on standard factory farms, like battery cages and gestation crates ‚Äî and none of the recent investigations I‚Äôve seen found these on certified farms. RSPCA Assured farms are already free of frankenchickens and GAP farms will be by 2030.  Of course, GAP and RSPCA Assured could raise their standards. And both are. But if they go too far too fast, costs and prices will rise, and farms and consumers will defect to the biggest competitors of each scheme: American Humane Certified and Red Tractor, each of which has much weaker standards (see chart below). Overall, animal welfare would get worse, not better. This doesn‚Äôt mean we should just accept low standards. But the right target is not the certifiers but the retailers. As corporate campaigns push retailers to remove the cruelest products from their shelves ‚Äî as most UK retailers have now done with caged eggs ‚Äî certifiers can raise their standards without getting undercut by lower-welfare competition. Still, Animal Rising and PETA have a point that many GAP and RSPCA Assured farms aren‚Äôt following the standards they claim to. Their investigations have found repeated violations of standards requiring things like care for sick animals, and I doubt that things are better when investigators aren‚Äôt around. The RSPCA acknowledged as much in sanctioning nine of the 40 farms Animal Rising investigated and kicking another three out of the scheme. But the answer to this is more certification, not less. Animal Rising‚Äôs campaign has led RSPCA Assured to announce an upgraded enforcement regime, including more unannounced audits and greater use of CCTV. This is good. And soon AI tools will allow for certifiers to continuously monitor conditions in every certified barn. When they do, the certifiers should adopt them. In this comparison of broiler chicken welfare standards, RSPCA Assured standards have a lot more green squares than their competitors. I recommend checking out the full chart, plus similar ones comparing global certification standards for hens, pigs, and cows. Source: Compassion in World Farming.Sins of omission None of this explains why the ASPCA, HSUS, and RSPCA need to be involved with the certification schemes. Animal Rising and PETA argue that their involvement serves no purpose other than to legitimize the schemes ‚Äî and meat eating itself. I‚Äôm sympathetic to Animal Rising‚Äôs case here. They‚Äôve likened stamping meat packages with the RSPCA‚Äôs logo to stamping cigarettes with the British Heart Foundation‚Äôs logo. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs quite the same, but I suspect future generations may disagree. RSPCA Assured used to be called ‚ÄúFreedom Food,‚Äù and I think a name like that would avoid conferring the RSPCA‚Äôs hard-earned legitimacy on a controversial product. I‚Äôm less sympathetic to PETA‚Äôs case. I don‚Äôt think anyone buys GAP certified products because the ASPCA and HSUS are on GAP‚Äôs board. Indeed, I doubt many people even knew that the groups were associated before PETA‚Äôs campaign. I also don‚Äôt think endorsing less cruel standards means endorsing meat, just as I don‚Äôt think public health groups endorsed junk food when they joined Michelle Obama‚Äôs Let‚Äôs Move! initiative, which partnered with Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, and others to reduce sugar and sodium in their foods. And I doubt that many people care what the big animal groups think they should eat. If they did, they‚Äôd get a clear message: the ASPCA, HSUS, and RSPCA all say people should eat less meat. The HSUS runs the nation‚Äôs largest institutional meat reduction program, and has long endured industry attacks for being anti-meat, as have more recently the ASPCA and RSPCA.  Now that these groups face attacks from both sides, they may be tempted to just avoid controversial work for farmed animals. Nonprofits generally only get attacked for action, not inaction. Run a rescue group that refuses to take in unadoptable animals, and no one will complain. Run a shelter of last resort that euthanizes unadoptable animals, and everyone will. The easiest option would be for the big groups to dump the certification schemes. Easy, but wrong. The predictable result would be that the schemes would either cease to exist or be taken over by industry. Without the RSPCA‚Äôs support, RSPCA Assured would likely fold, its farms moving over to the weaker Red Tractor certification. Without the ASPCA and HSUS, GAP would fall more firmly under the control of Whole Foods and big producers. Neither outcome seems good for animals.  An end to one percent solutions I think the most compelling case against the certification schemes is that they cause us to focus in the wrong place: on individual consumer decisions rather than system-wide changes. Just as veganism has remained stubbornly stuck at around one percent of the US population, so has consumption of truly higher-welfare meat. The reality is that we can‚Äôt end factory farming one purchasing decision at a time. Instead we need to focus on the biggest levers of social change, like laws, corporate policies, and technology. The certifiers have a role to play in all three. Their voluntary baseline standards can form the basis for future laws, just as the voluntary HACCP food safety system later became part of US and EU regulations. They can audit companies‚Äô implementation of welfare pledges like the Better Chicken Commitment. And they can facilitate the adoption of new technology, just as Germany‚Äôs KAT certification recently helped implement the end of the killing of day-old male chicks in the country. Animal Rising and PETA also have a major role to play. Their institutional goals will differ: Animal Rising‚Äôs institutional campaigns have focused on getting UK universities to go plant-based, while PETA‚Äôs have lately focused on getting US retailers to stop selling coconut milk made with forced monkey labor. They both also use shock tactics to wake people up to the cruelties of factory farming ‚Äî just as the best radical campaigns throughout history have done. Indeed, PETA videos played a major role in educating me about factory farming 25 years ago. It‚Äôs hard to strike the right balance between idealism and pragmatism. PETA founder Ingrid Newkirk once said of Temple Grandin, who designs more humane slaughterhouses, that she ‚Äúhas done more to reduce suffering in the world than any other person who has ever lived.‚Äù Dr. Grandin in turn has told me that her work would be impossible without the pressure that advocacy groups put on food companies to reform. We need both approaches ‚Äî and more. In a world largely indifferent to factory farming, we are a small ‚Äî but growing ‚Äî group fighting it. We need all the help we can get: from vegans and omnivores, moderates and radicals, urbanites and farmers. We also need to experiment with many different tactics to maximize our shots on goals. This will cause plenty of healthy disagreement. And that‚Äôs ok. But I hope we can remember that the things we agree on ‚Äî that animals‚Äô suffering matters, that factory farming is a moral atrocity, and that it must end ‚Äî are ultimately much more important. Thanks to Animal Rising‚Äôs Ben Newman and Simple Heart‚Äôs Wayne Hsiung for reviewing a draft of this essay. Their clarifications and suggestions improved it, though they still disagree on several key points. If you‚Äôre not signed up yet, here‚Äôs your chance:

author: itstimholman
title: The Easiest Way to Eat Vegan? Go Global With Your Pantry
text: From¬†saveur.com Joe Yonan‚Äôs new cookbook reveals how to tap into a world of plant-based dishes through a few powerhouse ingredients    This interview is brought to you by the¬†SAVEUR Cookbook Club, our passionate community of food-loving readers from around the globe, celebrating our favourite authors and recipes. Join us as we cook through a new book every month, and share your food pics and vids on social media with the hashtags #SAVEURCookbookClub and #EatTheWorld.¬† Whether or not you identify as¬†vegan, there are plenty of reasons to explore plant-based cooking. Cuisines around the world have put plants at the centre of daily meals for millennia, transforming humble vegetables with flavour-packed ingredients like miso, tahini, coconut milk, and more. And, as¬†Washington Post¬†editor and author Joe Yonan argues in his new book,¬†Mastering the Art of Plant-Based Cooking: Vegan Recipes, Tips, and Techniques, vegan cooking doesn‚Äôt leave fun off the table, either. Your favourite comfort foods can be made just as good‚Äîif not better‚Äîwithout relying on animal products. Yonan‚Äôs book delivers more than 300 recipes to prove his point: that veganism isn‚Äôt just a diet but a genuine cuisine, one that puts delicious vegetables cooked with tremendous creativity at the centre of every plate. Read on for Yonan‚Äôs tips for stocking a global-inspired vegan pantry, crafting satisfying meatless mains, and letting plant-based cooking just be, well,¬†fun.    Jessica Carbone: There have been lots of reasons to go plant-based throughout history‚Äîfrom philosophical and ethical stances to health and environmental concerns. What do you think are the motivations for plant-based eating today? Joe Yonan: The trinity of motivations are primarily about health, environment, and animal welfare, and while animal welfare is very important, it‚Äôs the first two that have really grown in our current environment, especially in relation to climate change. People are finally realizing that what they eat can have an environmental effect, and that they don‚Äôt have to be all-or-nothing about it‚ÄîI call myself about 90 percent vegan now. Even making small shifts can be helpful in the collective sense. Similarly, the one piece of dietary advice that‚Äôs common across all studies is to eat a lot of vegetables and a variety of vegetables. And then there‚Äôs the marketplace response, which has given people many more plant-based options than we used to have. Maybe the number of people who say that they‚Äôre vegan or vegetarian hasn‚Äôt really changed, but the number of people who say they‚Äôre eating more vegetables and less meat keeps going up. Plant-based diets aren‚Äôt new to many cultures around the world. How is the global vegan pantry central to this book? My previous book,¬†Cool Beans, was all about legumes, which have had a huge place in¬†cucina povera,¬†as the Italians call it, for centuries. Then I also came across people like¬†Bryant Terry¬†and¬†Jocelyn Ramirez, who write so wonderfully about colonialism in diets. So when I was thinking about the recipes for this book, I wanted to remind people that this is not some fad. This is integral to the way people have eaten in most parts of the world forever. I‚Äôm not anti-progress‚ÄîI‚Äôm a modern cook and I love new things‚Äîbut when I hear about the evils of certain foods, I think, how does that square with the way that people have eaten healthfully for decades? There are methods for integrating traditional ways of eating with our modern lifestyle that can be really impactful. Do you have workhorse ingredients that you keep on hand? I always have to have coconut milk and tahini. I‚Äôm a huge tahini fan because it‚Äôs thinner than other nut butters and you can drizzle it on things, which adds richness to anything. Miso is also huge for me; it‚Äôs like a bouillon paste with that instant depth and umami. The first time I had a really good vegan mac and cheese, the person who made it put miso in it, and it‚Äôs a crucial part of the book‚Äôs cashew mac and cheese recipe; it also proves you don‚Äôt need vegan cheese to accomplish great flavour. I also can‚Äôt live without spices‚Äîthey are the fastest and best ticket to changing a flavour profile to any cuisine in the world. And I honestly don‚Äôt think that I could eat a plant-based diet without beans and mushrooms. Were there specific comfort foods that you wanted to feature in this book? I gradually moved toward veganism, so I never stopped in my tracks and said, ‚ÄúFrom this day forward, I am not going to eat any meat.‚Äù If you do that, you start to wonder how you‚Äôre going to have a hamburger or grilled cheese because these are things that are familiar and nostalgic. So, at the top of my list was a veggie burger. There‚Äôs so much deliciousness in a veggie burger that‚Äôs not trying to make you think it‚Äôs meat. The book‚Äôs burger has discernible vegetables, yet it‚Äôs put together in a way that gives you all of that satisfaction. I also leaned a little bit on Italian American foods, like baked stuffed shells. I was really excited to do an eggless pasta and a tomato ‚Äúgravy.‚Äù I often think about things people might have a visceral attachment to because a good vegan recipe can show that they don‚Äôt have to give it up.  For a lot of folks, there‚Äôs an assumption that meat should be at the centre of the plate. Are there vegan main dishes that can shake up this mindset? I have a whole chapter on mains called ‚ÄúKnife and Fork‚Äù that shows you can have vegetables at the centre of the plate and really dig into them. When you‚Äôre cooking with a plant-based strategy, it can be easy to fall back on bowls, stir-fries‚Äîstuff where everything is mixed together‚Äîand I love that. But whole roasted vegetables exemplify the centre-of-the-table idea, stuff you bring out and carve at the table. There‚Äôs a beautiful¬†cauliflower steak with a korma-inspired sauce, and it‚Äôs got little toppings and everything on it; there‚Äôs a romanesco with romesco sauce and a cider-glazed celery root. As long as everything tastes great and there‚Äôs texture and it‚Äôs got cool flavours, it can be satisfying. At the start of your dessert chapter, you state that ‚Äúplant-based cooking is not health food.‚Äù Why did you include that disclaimer? I realize that one of the pillars of switching to plant-based cooking is health, but plant-based cooking is not a cuisine of subtraction or asceticism‚Äîit can be fun and it can be delicious. There are many books that explain how to make desserts with all-natural sweeteners or whole grains, all of which are great. But in this book, you‚Äôre figuring out how to make plant-based cooking¬†delicious.¬†For example, I love the¬†sweet potato cr√®me br√ªl√©e¬†because it shows that even a classic dessert can so easily take to plant-based treatment. And my feeling is that, if you‚Äôre cooking more plant-based dishes, the healthy side of things will come anyway.  What attitude should people adopt to make the most of the book? I want them to feel excited, to say, ‚ÄúThis is going to be fun.‚Äù If this is very new to them, I want them to have a sense of, ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt wait to see where this is going to lead me.‚Äù And this is probably true of any cookbook author, but I want them to think they can jump into this and depend on the instructions and headnotes; they‚Äôre not flying without a net. When Judith Jones came up with the title for Julia Child‚Äôs¬†Mastering the Art of French Cooking,¬†she thought the most important part of the title was the ‚Äú-ing‚Äù‚ÄîI love that so much. I‚Äôm leaning really hard on the -ing because this is an active process; you never stop learning. I want to hold up plant-based cooking as something that‚Äôs as worthy of an attempt at mastery as French, Italian, or Spanish cooking, and I want people to feel engaged in the process, to feel that this is something they can do and want to do. https://www.saveur.com/culture/yonan-vegan-plant-based-cookbook/

author: safrestaurant
title: A Vegan Spot That Changes the Way You Think About Healthy Food
text:
When people think of vegan food, they often picture bland salads or tasteless tofu. But in the heart of London, SAF Restaurant is flipping that stereotype on its head. With an innovative menu that‚Äôs as healthy as it is delicious, SAF offers a refreshing take on plant-based dining that goes beyond the typical. Whether you‚Äôre vegan or just looking to try something new, SAF is a place where healthy eating feels exciting rather than restrictive. In this post, we‚Äôll explore how SAF is changing the game when it comes to what we think of as ‚Äúhealthy food.‚Äù 







1. The SAF Philosophy: Health Meets Flavor



What sets SAF apart from many other vegan restaurants is its philosophy: food should nourish your body, but it should also be a sensory experience. The team at SAF takes a creative approach to plant-based dining, using vibrant, seasonal ingredients that are full of flavor, nutrients, and texture. Here, eating healthy doesn‚Äôt mean sacrificing taste. Every dish is crafted with the goal of making you feel good both inside and out. 



Instead of the usual emphasis on bland or basic ingredients, SAF plays with bold flavors, unique textures, and unexpected combinations. This makes their food feel indulgent without the guilt. It‚Äôs the kind of place where you can enjoy a hearty meal and feel energized, rather than sluggish or overly full. 







2. Dishes That Wow: More Than Just Salad



At SAF, you‚Äôll find that the food is anything but boring. From their inventive starters to their mouthwatering mains and delectable desserts, each dish is a work of art. Let‚Äôs highlight a few menu items that are changing how we view plant-based cuisine: 




The Sweet Potato and Avocado Salad: With a tangy miso dressing, this salad combines the creamy texture of avocado with roasted sweet potato for a satisfying, savory-sweet experience. It‚Äôs far from your average salad!



Vegan Burger: SAF‚Äôs version of a vegan burger is made from a patty of grains, beans, and spices, topped with fresh vegetables and a smoky aioli. It‚Äôs the kind of burger you can sink your teeth into and feel fully satisfied.



Raw Lasagna: This raw vegan lasagna uses layers of zucchini, cashew cream, and marinara sauce to create a dish that‚Äôs fresh, rich, and full of flavor. It‚Äôs a twist on a classic, showing how plant-based versions of beloved comfort foods can still hit the spot.








3. A Sustainable Dining Experience



SAF isn‚Äôt just about serving great food; they‚Äôre also deeply committed to sustainability. The restaurant sources ingredients that are local, organic, and as eco-friendly as possible. Their commitment to sustainability extends beyond the ingredients‚Äîthey minimize waste, avoid plastic, and prioritize eco-conscious packaging. 



This eco-conscious approach not only contributes to a healthier planet but also aligns with SAF‚Äôs vision of wellness as a holistic concept, blending both personal health and environmental care. 







4. The Experience: More Than Just a Meal



Dining at SAF is an experience, not just a pit stop for food. The ambiance is warm, inviting, and relaxed, offering a space to unwind while enjoying a delicious, nutritious meal. Whether you‚Äôre coming for lunch, dinner, or just a quick coffee, the vibe encourages you to take your time, savor your meal, and appreciate the beauty of plant-based dining. 



Many diners rave about the friendly and knowledgeable staff who can recommend dishes based on dietary preferences or offer information about the ingredients. This personal touch makes the dining experience even more enjoyable, as it feels like you‚Äôre part of the SAF community. 







5. Changing Minds: Why SAF Is Perfect for Non-Vegans, Too



One of the most surprising aspects of SAF is how accessible it is to non-vegans. While many vegan restaurants may cater primarily to those already on a plant-based diet, SAF is a place where everyone‚Äîwhether you‚Äôre fully vegan or just looking to try something healthier‚Äîcan feel at home. The menu isn‚Äôt designed to convert people to veganism, but rather to showcase the versatility and excitement of plant-based cooking. 



Many visitors to SAF are pleasantly surprised by how filling, rich, and satisfying the food is. It‚Äôs proof that healthy food can be indulgent without being heavy. Whether you‚Äôre a die-hard carnivore or a vegetarian curious about vegan options, SAF offers something that will change your perception of what healthy food can be. 











Conclusion: A Healthier, Tastier Way to Eat



SAF Restaurant is more than just a place to grab a bite‚Äîit‚Äôs a reminder that healthy food doesn‚Äôt have to be bland, boring, or restrictive. With creative dishes that combine flavors, textures, and ingredients in unexpected ways, SAF proves that plant-based dining can be exciting, indulgent, and incredibly satisfying. If you‚Äôre looking to change the way you think about healthy food, SAF is the place to do it. 







Call to Action: Next time you find yourself in London, pay a visit to SAF and experience firsthand how they‚Äôre transforming healthy eating. Have you already dined at SAF? Share your favorite dishes in the comments below or tag us on social media using #HealthyWithSAF!
blog_name: SAF Restaurant | Taste the Unique Flavors of Our Culinary Delights in UK

author: amanda
title: A healthier you though plant-based living
text:
A healthier you though plant-based living
I call BS on the new year narrative that kicks off on January 1st. We‚Äôre led to believe‚Äîand often convince ourselves‚Äîthat we‚Äôll become fundamentally different overnight, as if some profound transformation takes place between 11:59 PM on December 31st and 12:01 AM on January 1st. 
‚ÄúNew year, new me‚Äù takes over, with motivation, change, and goals soaring to their peak. But while the initial spark of change may feel powerful, the real question is: can you sustain and nurture that change beyond the New Year and throughout the rest of the year? 
The New Year might mark a symbolic line in the sand, but why not create your own transition moment at any time? A work milestone, a birthday, or a significant occasion can all serve as your transition moment. The truth is you don‚Äôt need January 1st to start fresh‚Äîyou can choose any day that feels meaningful to you. 
You‚Äôre in control. Whatever date you decide on, let it be one that truly resonates with you, one that holds personal significance. That‚Äôs where lasting change and sustainability are born. 
Where to start in 2025?
As we step into the new year, many of us focus on the familiar pillars of change: eating healthier, staying fit, and living life to the fullest. These aspirations naturally align with the concept of Living a Planted Life. 
Living a Planted Life revolves around three core pillars: Mind | Body | Food. At the heart of these is a planted (or vegan) diet, known for its numerous benefits. 
If you‚Äôre feeling empowered, optimistic, and ready for change, why not explore a planted vegan diet? You don‚Äôt have to commit for the entire year‚Äîstart small. Maybe try it for the month of January, or even just a week. It‚Äôs not about the length of time but about experiencing the benefits of a diet that promotes physical health, animal welfare, and environmental sustainability. 
For me, veganism is more than a diet; it‚Äôs a lifestyle. It enhances my health and performance while embodying my compassion for all sentient beings. When I transitioned from vegetarian to vegan, my curiosity drove me. I wanted to learn, challenge the nay-sayers, and prove that a vegan diet could provide all the essential nutrients‚Äîespecially protein‚Äîfor an active, athletic lifestyle. 
Lifestyle benefits of interest

Gut health
Decreased risk of cardiovascular disease
Reduces risk of LDL cholesterol
Lowers risks of Type 2 diabetes
Reduces arthritis pain
Improved digestion
Improved skin health
Reduces inflammation

Do you enjoy vegetables?
A vegan diet can look different for everyone ‚Äì there‚Äôs no one size fits all approach, just like any other diet. With varied tastes and texture pallets, your approach to eating vegan is entirely up to you. However, the core principles of a vegan diet should guide your choices. 
A planted vegan diet is abundant in fresh fruits and vegetables including nutrient-rich dark leafy greens like kale and spinach (though many tend to shy away from these‚ÄîBrussels sprouts, anyone?).¬† Your shopping list should include fresh produce, grains, pulses, legumes, nuts, seeds and plant-based oils such as olive oil, flaxseed oil and sesame oils ‚Äì essentially, foods grown from the ground up. This diet should be low in trans fats, refined sugar and processed foods. 
Does it sound healthy? Restrictive? Don‚Äôt worry ‚Äì there‚Äôs no shortage of sweet treats or (vegan-friendly cheese to enjoy.¬† Adopting a planted vegan diet in 2025 has never been tastier, more diverse, or more accessible. Major supermarkets like Coles and Woolworths now offer dedicated vegan sections, making it easier than ever to find plant-based options (you might just have to stand next to the meat section while doing so!) 
With a well-balanced, nutrient-dense vegan diet, you won‚Äôt go hungry, nor will you lack protein, iron, or calcium. Food shouldn‚Äôt be overly complicated, and choosing a diet that supports your health, animals, and the planet can be straightforward and enjoyable. 
If you‚Äôd like personalised guidance on how to make simple yet impactful changes to your diet in the new year, feel free to reach out today. 
The post A healthier you though plant-based living appeared first on Planted Life.

Whether it‚Äôs your friends, social media influencers, or even celebrities, plant-based eating is everywhere.
